In this article, the authors study the stability of alternative polyadenylation signals in the 3′ untranslated regions (3′ UTRs) of human genes. They used 3′ end RNA-seq data from six human lymphoblastoid cell lines to identify 3′ UTRs of class I, II, and III genes. Class I genes had only one polyadenylation signal (PAS), class II genes had two or more PASs, and class III genes had no PASs. They then used luciferase reporter assays to study the stability of the different PASs in class II genes. They found that the stability of a PAS depends on its location relative to the inferred cleavage site of the transcript. They also found that the stability of the short and long forms of a transcript produced by alternative polyadenylation can be studied by transfection of a construct containing the entire 3′ UTR of the gene into human cells. They used this approach to study the stability of the short and long forms of the EIF2A, IRF5, DIP2B, and NAB1 genes in different human cell lines. They found that the stability of the short and long forms of a gene can be affected by the presence of regulatory elements in the 3′ UTR, and that the stability of the short form can be affected by the presence of a polyadenylation signal in the 3′ UTR.
SIVΔnef, a live attenuated strain of simian immunodeficiency virus (SIV), is used as a vaccine to prevent AIDS in macaque monkeys. To understand the T-cell responses induced by SIVΔnef vaccination and how these responses evolve over time, we used deep sequencing to quantify the frequency of SIVΔnef-specific T cells in the animals at two different time points after vaccination. We also used fine-mapping techniques to determine the specificity of the T-cell responses at the epitope level. Our results show that the T-cell responses induced by SIVΔnef vaccination are broad and anentropic, with wider cumulative breadth and rearranged immunodominance. We also show that the depth of the T-cell response increases over time post-vaccination. These findings highlight the unique properties of SIVΔnef vaccination in inducing potent T-cell responses against SIV.
The current article describes the role of interleukin-1 (IL-1) receptor signaling in host defense against fungal infections. Using a mouse model of oropharyngeal candidiasis, the authors show that IL-1 signaling is critical for neutrophil recruitment to the site of infection and for inducing emergency granulopoiesis, which is the rapid expansion of granulocyte-producing bone marrow cells to meet the increased demand for neutrophils in response to infection. They demonstrate that IL-1 signaling regulates the production of neutrophil-chemotactic factors by epithelial cells, which is necessary for neutrophil recruitment to the site of infection. They also show that IL-1 signaling induces G-CSF production by endothelial cells, which is necessary for enhanced neutrophil output from the bone marrow to meet the increased demand in response to infection. Finally, the authors demonstrate that IL-1 signaling is critical for inducing emergency granulopoiesis. They show that neutrophil numbers are significantly reduced in mice lacking IL-1 receptor signaling in response to infection. They also show that IL-1 signaling is necessary for inducing emergency granulopoiesis in response to infection. Taken together, the authors show that IL-1 signaling plays a critical role in host defense against fungal infections by regulating the recruitment of neutrophils to the site of infection and inducing emergency granulopoiesis, which is necessary for meeting the increased demand for neutrophils in response to infection.
This study estimates the economic benefits of the Global Programme to Eliminate Lymphatic Filariasis (GPELF) between the years 2000-2007. The GPELF delivered more than 1.9 billion treatments to nearly 600 million individuals via annual mass drug administration (MDA) of anti-filarial drugs. The study quantified the resulting economic benefits by calculating the number of clinical manifestations averted and analyzing the savings associated with this disease prevention in the context of direct treatment costs, indirect costs of lost labor, and costs to the health system to care for affected individuals. The study found that over the lifetime of 31.4 million individuals treated during the first 8 years of the GPELF, a total of US$21.8 billion of direct economic benefits will be gained. Additionally, more than 28 million individuals already infected with LF will benefit from GPELF's halting the progression of their disease, resulting in an associated lifetime economic benefit of approximately US$19.5 billion. In addition to these economic benefits to at-risk individuals, decreased patient services associated with reduced LF morbidity saves the health systems of endemic countries approximately US$2.2 billion. The study concludes that MDA for LF offers significant economic benefits and that the economic rate of return of the GPELF is extremely high.
Gaucher disease is a lysosomal storage disorder caused by mutations in the gene encoding glucocerebrosidase (GCase). GCase is an enzyme responsible for breaking down glucocerebroside into glucose and ceramide, two major lipid components of the nervous system. Heterozygous mutations in the GCase gene have been linked to an increased risk of Parkinson’s disease. The study of GCase mutations has led to new insights into the pathogenesis of Parkinson’s disease, and the identification of potential therapeutic targets.
Listeria monocytogenes (Lm) is a bacteria that can cause foodborne illness in humans. It is able to infect and survive within host cells. In order to understand how the host's immune system responds to Lm infection, scientists have studied its interactions with the immune system using mouse models. They found that Lm is able to trigger an adaptive immune response, but only when it escapes from the phagosome and into the host cell cytosol. If Lm is confined within the phagosome, it suppresses the adaptive immune response, leading to a weakened response against subsequent infections. This suppression is caused by the production of the cytokine IL-10, which limits the production of pro-inflammatory cytokines. By studying how Lm interacts with the immune system, scientists can better understand how to develop treatments for Lm infections.
We investigated the genetic contribution of SIX6 to primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG). We sequenced the coding and regulatory regions of SIX6 in a case-control dataset of 262 cases and 256 controls and found six nonsynonymous coding variants, including five rare and one common variant. We tested these variants in an in vivo Danio rerio (zebrafish) complementation assay to evaluate ocular metrics such as eye size and optic nerve structure. We found that one variant in the SIX6 enhancer increased expression of SIX6 and disrupted its regulation. We also demonstrated that POAG cases homozygous for the SIX6 risk allele had a statistically thinner retinal nerve fiber layer than patients homozygous for the SIX6 non-risk allele. Our results, in combination with previous SIX6 work, lead us to hypothesize that SIX6 risk variants disrupt the development of the neural retina, leading to a reduced number of retinal ganglion cells, thereby increasing the risk of glaucoma-associated vision loss.
[NOTE: If reviewers think that the manuscript is of high quality, then it can be published as it is. If, however, they have concerns about certain aspects of the manuscript that should be addressed, then the authors should revise the manuscript accordingly. Please note that revisions may take one or more weeks depending on the extent of the changes requested by the reviewers.]
This study provides a detailed description of the sporulation process in the human pathogen C . difficile. By using a combination of cytological and molecular techniques, the authors demonstrate that C . difficile sporulation displays several key differences when compared to sporulation in other Clostridial species. These differences suggest that C . difficile sporulation may be adapted to the specific needs of the organism in its natural habitat. The study also provides a platform for further investigations of the regulatory network of sporulation and the expression of effector genes, many of which will be species-specific and possibly related to host colonization and transmission.
In this study, the authors introduce a simple model to understand the complex behavior of proteins that have multiple phosphorylation sites. This model is based on the idea of "modified fraction" (MF) modeling and reduces the complexity of the system by only taking into account the fraction of modified sites in the protein. The authors use this model to analyze the checkpoint signaling pathway in budding yeast, which is known to measure cell growth by monitoring signals generated at sites of plasma membrane growth. They show that this system can form a robust hysteretic switch, with a signal proportional to bud growth or size, a mechanism to read the signal, and an all-or-none response triggered only when the signal reaches a threshold indicating that sufficient growth has occurred. The authors also provide a mathematical analysis of the system and discuss the implications of their findings. Overall, this study provides a useful framework for understanding the behavior of complex systems with multiple phosphorylation sites.
The study examined the regulatory network of quorum sensing ( QS ) in the bacterium E. coli by combining experimental work and mathematical modeling. The quorum sensing system is a network of genes and proteins that allow bacteria to communicate with each other, coordinate their behavior and survive in an environment that is constantly changing. In this study, the researchers isolated the mechanisms that control the communication between bacteria by separating the regulatory network into sub-networks and examining the interplay of different feedback mechanisms. They also discovered a new regulatory element that was not previously known. They used a combination of mathematical modeling and experimental work to understand how these sub-networks and regulatory elements interacted to form the overall quorum sensing system. The researchers were able to identify the genes and proteins that were important for the proper functioning of the quorum sensing system and revealed the basis for the genetic “switch” in E. coli QS circuitry. The results of this study will help to unravel complex regulatory networks in bacteria and lead to the development of new strategies for controlling bacterial behavior in different environments.
This article describes a study on the relationship between malaria and schistosomiasis in school-aged children in the Lambaréné area of Gabon. The study was conducted over two years and involved 498 school-age children. At the start of the study, researchers found that 30% of children were infected with P. falciparum, 23% were infected with S. haematobium, and 9% were co-infected with both parasites. The study found that children with schistosomiasis had a higher risk of malaria infection. In addition, the study found that children with higher infection loads of hookworm, Ascaris lumbricoides, or Trichuris trichiura had an increased risk of malaria infection. These findings suggest that controlling infections with hookworm, Ascaris lumbricoides, or Trichuris trichiura may help reduce the incidence of malaria in school-age children in the Lambaréné area.
Inflammation plays a key role in promoting , sustaining , and tuning the response of CD8+ T cells to infection. In a mouse model of leishmaniasis, the inflammatory response is mainly induced by the transcription factor IRF-5 . IRF-5 is responsible for activating several genes encoding pro-inflammatory cytokines, such as IL-6 and TNF . We found that the inflammatory response induced by IRF-5 limits CD8+ T cell expansion at the very early stages of infection by indirectly inducing HIF-1α expression in DCs. Upregulation of HIF-1α in DCs resulted in decreased IL-12 and increased IL-10 expression, which in turn led to a higher frequency of short-lived effector CD8+ T cells (SLECs) , enhanced CD8+ T cell expansion , and significantly reduced parasite burden . In a mouse model of OT-I/RAG1-deficient CD8+ T cells, we found that IRF-5-mediated inflammation regulates CD8+ T cell expansion following infection with Leishmania donovani, a protozoan parasite that causes visceral leishmaniasis. Our findings suggest that IRF-5-mediated inflammation may be a therapeutic target for the treatment of visceral leishmaniasis.
This article is about a systematic review of studies that have investigated prognostic factors for American visceral leishmaniasis (VL), a serious disease that affects humans and dogs. The review focused on factors that could predict the development of adverse outcomes in VL patients, including death, severe disease, and development of symptoms. The authors searched for relevant studies in various databases and assessed the quality of the research. They identified several prognostic factors associated with adverse outcomes in VL patients, such as jaundice, thrombocytopenia, hemorrhage, HIV coinfection, diarrhea, age under 5 or over 40-50 years, severe neutropenia, dyspnea, and bacterial infections. The authors highlighted the importance of validating these prognostic factors in future research to improve the management and treatment of VL patients.
This article presents the first study on the susceptibility of Leishmania parasites to antimony drugs in Algeria. The study includes 106 Leishmania isolates collected from humans, dogs, sandflies, and rodents over a 30-year period. The isolates were identified and characterized according to their species, zymodeme, clinic, and geographical origin. The susceptibility of the Leishmania parasites to antimony drugs was determined by flow cytometry. The results of this study indicate that the sensitivity of Leishmania parasites to antimony drugs varied according to species, zymodeme, clinic, geographical origin, and drug type. The results highlight the emergence of Sb(V)-resistant L. killicki (syn L. tropica) parasites in Algeria and their association with the emergence of cutaneous leishmaniosis in certain regions of the country. The study also provides important information on the distribution of Leishmania species in Algeria and their association with the various clinical forms of leishmaniosis. This information is essential for the development of effective strategies for the control and prevention of leishmaniosis in Algeria.
This study used mouse models to investigate the relationship between inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) and acute infectious gastroenteritis caused by Salmonella and Citrobacter bacteria. The study found that gastroenteritis causes an increase in the levels of adherent-invasive E. coli (AIEC), a bacterial pathobiont linked to IBD, in the intestines of mice. This increase in AIEC levels is associated with increased inflammation, barrier defects, and delays in mucosal restitution following pathogen clearance. The study also found that AIEC is sensitive to host defense peptides and that a fulminant inflammatory response to the enteric pathogen is required for the observed increase in AIEC levels. These findings suggest that individuals colonized by AIEC at the time of acute infectious gastroenteritis may be at greater risk for IBD onset. The study also identifies AIEC as a tractable disease modifier, a finding that could be exploited in the development of therapeutic interventions following infectious gastroenteritis in at-risk individuals.
In this study, the authors have used an egg cell-specific marker to study the regulation of gametic cell fate in the female gametophyte of Arabidopsis thaliana. They have identified a mutant, lis-1, which is defective in the differentiation of gametic and accessory cell fates. They have found that lis-1 is a loss-of-function mutation in the At2g41500 locus, which encodes a protein with seven WD40 repeats. The LIS protein is strongly conserved among eukaryotes and has been shown to be involved in splicing. The authors have shown that LIS is involved in a lateral inhibition mechanism that prevents excess gametic cell formation by maintaining the differentiation of gametic and accessory cell fates. They have also found that the LIS protein is expressed at moderate levels in all tissues examined, with strongest expression in reproductive tissues. The authors have provided a detailed description of the function and expression of the LIS protein, and have provided evidence for its role in the regulation of gametic cell fate.
The role of footwear in protecting against diseases that affect people's feet is becoming increasingly important in medical research. In a rural Ethiopian community that is endemic for a disease called podoconiosis, which is caused by exposure to irritant soils, shoes were found to be becoming more common. However, there are many social and practical barriers that prevent people from wearing shoes consistently, including limited financial resources, fear of stigma, and difficulty finding appropriate shoe sizes. These barriers may also be relevant to other neglected tropical diseases that affect people's feet, such as hookworm and snakebite. To understand these barriers, researchers used a well-established model called the PRECEDE-PROCEED model. This model helps identify social, behavioral, environmental, educational and ecological needs that may influence whether and when children wear shoes. Researchers also drew on social cognitive theory, which suggests that individual beliefs and attitudes about shoe wearing, as well as their perceived capabilities to prevent the disease, can affect their behavior. By understanding these factors, researchers can develop more effective interventions to promote shoe wearing as a means of preventing podoconiosis and other diseases.
In this study, we analyzed the role of the Us9 protein in PRV-162, a mutant of PRV-99 that is deficient in anterograde transport of viral particles from the nucleus to the cytoplasm. We found that Us9 is not necessary for anterograde transport in PRV-162, but is required for intracellular viral sorting and is responsible for PRV-162's aberrant sorting phenotype. We also identified the Us9-TfR interaction as the primary sorting determinant for PRV-162. Our findings provide new insights into the PRV-162 infection mechanism and the role of Us9 in PRV-162 sorting.
This article presents a new approach for measuring yeast cell-to-cell variation in the speed of growth using fluorescence microscopy. The authors describe a new algorithm called PIE that can detect microcolony growth edges by measuring the intensity of a fluorescent protein in each cell. The PIE algorithm is designed to work with fluorescence signals that are highly variable across cells and over time, making it well-suited for measuring the growth rates of yeast colonies. The authors also describe a new approach for quantifying the intracellular concentration of cAMP in yeast cells using fluorescence microscopy. They show that this approach can accurately measure the cAMP concentration in individual yeast cells and can be used to measure the effects of cAMP on cell growth and division. The authors also demonstrate how their new approaches can be used to investigate the role of the cAMP-dependent kinase Msn2 in regulating yeast cell growth and division in response to changes in the extracellular environment. Overall, this article provides a valuable resource for researchers who are interested in using fluorescence microscopy to study cellular processes in yeast.
Scientists have found that the chikungunya virus (CHIKV) strain that has arrived in the Americas from the Asian lineage is a rapidly evolving virus. They used deep-sequencing technologies and bioinformatics pipelines to analyze the viral genetic diversity present in human blood samples and found that there were many different variants at various levels in the population. The scientists also identified a new 3' untranslated region (UTR) structure that may have been missed by the initial sequencing performed on the ongoing epidemic in the Americas. These findings highlight the need to continue viral diversity surveillance over time as this epidemic evolves.
This article presents a study on the regulation of cell growth and neoplasia via mTOR signaling by a previously unannotated gene named Ubtor. The authors first identified Ubtor as a functional player in regulating cell growth and mTOR signaling through reductions of Ubtor expression levels in cultured hippocampal neurons and PC12 cells that promote neurite outgrowth. They also found that UBTOR depletion promotes cell growth in HEK293T and U87MG cells, while UBTOR overexpression suppresses colony formation in HEK293T and T24 cells. The authors further showed that reduction of Ubtor promotes mTOR signaling in cultured cells and zebrafish. Mechanistic studies in cultured cells showed that UBTOR interacts with DEPTOR and mTOR complexes, and further studies showed that UBTOR stabilizes DEPTOR and regulates DEPTOR’s ubiquitination. Lastly, the authors demonstrated that ubtor gene disruption in zebrafish increases mTOR activity and aggravates HRAS (G12V) induced neoplasia in the intact animals. The authors also showed that Ubtor depletion promotes tumor growth and mTOR signaling in xenograft-bearing mice.
In this study, we used liquid chromatography and mass spectrometry to identify and quantify the proteins expressed in Trypanosoma brucei, a parasitic protozoan that causes African sleeping sickness. We identified 2,789 proteins, including 2,105 that were not previously characterized. We also identified 542 proteins that were highly abundant in the parasite. Our results provide a comprehensive overview of the proteome of T. brucei and suggest that the parasite has a large number of hypothetical proteins with unknown functions. Our study also suggests that many hypothetical proteins may be involved in cellular processes, such as transcription and translation, that are important for parasite survival and proliferation.
Tuberculosis (TB) is a major global health problem, affecting millions of people worldwide. TB primarily affects the lungs, but can also affect other organs in the body, including lymph nodes. In this study, we examined the role of lymph nodes in TB infection and disease progression. We used a non-human primate (macaque) model of TB to study the dynamics of infection in lymph nodes over time. We found that lymph nodes become infected with Mycobacterium tuberculosis (the causative agent of TB) early after infection, and that they grow in size and contain more bacteria as the infection progresses. We also found that some lymph nodes develop granulomas, which are characteristic of TB infection, while others do not. Our findings suggest that lymph nodes are an important site of infection and disease progression in TB, and that they may play a role in the development of drug-resistant strains of the bacteria. Further studies of the role of lymph nodes in TB infection and disease progression are needed to better understand the pathogenesis of this disease and to develop more effective treatments.
Microsporidia are fungal parasites that infect various animals, including nematodes. In this study, the authors identified and characterized 47 new microsporidian species infecting 43 different rhabditid nematode species, including 28 Caenorhabditis elegans strains. They used molecular methods to identify and classify these species and obtained 20 microsporidian spore preparations to infect other nematodes. The study provides valuable insights into the diversity and evolution of microsporidian parasites and their hosts.
The article provides an overview of the function and assembly of chemokine receptors, which are important for the inflammatory response and HIV infection. The authors discuss the role of cholesterol in modulating receptor dimerization and present new structural information about homo- and heterodimers of the receptors.
In this article, the authors describe a new form of leishmaniasis, a parasitic disease that is spread by sand flies and can cause fever, weight loss, and spleen and liver enlargement. This new form is referred to as "atypical" because it has symptoms that differ from the classical form of the disease. The authors discovered this form by examining the immune systems of patients who were suspected to be immune-deficient and who had unexplained low levels of certain immune cells. They used several specialized tests, such as microscopic examinations and cultures of biopsies, to determine the cause of the immune deficiency. They found that many of these patients had parasites inside their macrophages, a type of immune cell that is responsible for fighting off infections. The authors believe that this new form of leishmaniasis may be more common than previously thought and that it may present with a wider range of symptoms. They recommend that doctors consider the possibility of atypical leishmaniasis in patients with unexplained immune deficiencies.
The study aimed to investigate the potential of variants that occur at homologous positions within paralogous human proteins as a means of identifying polymorphisms with likely phenotypic consequences. To do so, the researchers compiled a collection of known disease-causing variants from OMIM and the Human Genome Mutation Database ( HGMD ) and used them to identify and characterize pairs of sequence variants that occur at homologous positions within paralogous human proteins. The analyses demonstrate that the locations of variants are correlated in paralogous proteins. Moreover, if one member of a variant-pair is disease-causing, its partner is likely to be disease-causing as well. Thus, information about variant-pairs can be used to identify potentially disease-causing variants, extend existing procedures for polymorphism prioritization, and provide a suite of candidates for further diagnostic and therapeutic purposes.
The authors present a comparative analysis of gene expression in parasites causing severe and uncomplicated malaria. They used RNA sequencing to analyse gene expression in 44 parasite isolates that caused severe and uncomplicated malaria in Papuan patients. They found that severe malaria was associated with decreased glycolysis and altered chromatin structure, transcriptional regulation, and surface expression of PfEMP1. They also identified novel associations between severe malaria and PfEMP1 transcripts, domains, and smaller sequence segments. Their findings will inform efforts to identify vaccine targets for severe malaria and also indicate how parasites adapt to the host environment in severe malaria.
In this study, the authors describe the delivery of broadly neutralizing anti-SIV monoclonal antibodies (mAbs) via intramuscular injections of adeno-associated virus (AAV) vector. The mAbs were derived from antibodies isolated from SIV-infected rhesus monkeys and were engineered to contain only authentic rhesus IgG1 sequences. AAV vector was designed to deliver the mAbs in the IgG1 form, which is more stable and has a longer half-life than the IgG3 form. The authors show that the AAV-delivered mAbs were able to persist in the bloodstream of rhesus monkeys for up to 14 weeks after delivery. Furthermore, the study demonstrates that the mAbs were able to provide protection against a challenging virus, SIVmac239, in six of the six animals. The results of this study show the promise of using AAV vector to deliver broadly neutralizing mAbs to provide protection against SIV infection.
Protein molecules can undergo conformational relaxation motions in response to energy supply or external stimuli. In this study, researchers used numerical investigations to analyze the conformational relaxation properties of two important protein motors - myosin V and kinesin KIF1A - within the coarse-grained elastic network approximation. They found that the linearity assumption often used in the theory of protein dynamics is deficient for ligand-induced conformational motions and can even be violated for characteristic thermal fluctuations. The results show that the normal mode description is not applicable to these motor proteins and the nonlinear effects dominate functional mechanochemical motions in kinesin KIF1A. Despite the nonlinearity, well-defined conformational relaxation paths that are robust against perturbations have been found in both motor proteins. The researchers concluded that important assumptions of the theory of protein dynamics may need to be reconsidered.
In this study, we investigate the crosstalk between CLIC/GEEC endocytosis and caveolae. We found that caveolae are important for CLIC/GEEC endocytosis and that CAV1, a protein required for caveolae formation, negatively regulates CLIC/GEEC endocytosis. These results indicate that the two membrane systems share several similarities and have unique properties in migrating cells.
In this study, the authors present a lay summary of their research on the Aspartate-Less Receiver (ALR) domain subclass of two-component signaling (TCS) proteins. TCS proteins are responsible for sensing and responding to environmental stimuli, such as the presence of toxins or changes in nutrient availability, to help bacteria adapt and survive. The ALR domain is a divergent subclass of TCS proteins that lacks the phosphorylatable Asp residue that is common to most TCS proteins. Despite this lack of conservation, the ALR domain is functionally and structurally related to TCS proteins. The authors describe the prevalence of ALR domains in bacteria and show that they can take on a variety of different functions, such as binding DNA or small molecules and modulating cellular processes. They also provide a lay summary of the structural and biochemical analyses of the ALR domain in the context of a specific example, the ALR domain from RitR, a protein involved in iron and oxidative stress regulation in Streptococcus pneumoniae. Overall, this study provides a lay summary of the ALR domain subclass of TCS proteins, including its prevalence, functions, and structural and biochemical features.
Herpesvirus (HSV) infections are a major health issue worldwide and have a significant impact on the human population. HSVs are divided into two distinct types: herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV-1) and herpes simplex virus 2 (HSV-2). While HSV-1 primarily causes oral infections, HSV-2 predominantly causes genital infections. HSV-1 and HSV-2 have both been associated with the development of several types of cancers, including cervical cancer. Researchers have developed oncolytic viruses that specifically target HSV receptors on the surface of cancer cells and kill them. These viruses have shown promising results in treating various types of cancer, including cervical cancer. Oncolytic HSVs (oHSVs) can be genetically engineered to express antitumor proteins or to target specific cancer cells. While oHSVs have shown promise, some limitations must be overcome before they can be used for cancer therapy. First, they are often not as specific to cancer cells as desired and can cause damage to healthy tissues. Second, they can be attenuated or even non-replicative, leading to reduced efficacy. Third, they can trigger the immune system to clear the infection, which can limit their effectiveness. Despite these limitations, oHSVs are still an active area of research and hold great promise for the development of effective cancer therapies.
HIV vaccines are designed to stimulate the immune system to fight HIV infection. Two common types of HIV vaccines are based on recombinant viral vectors, such as adenovirus 5 (Ad5) and canarypox virus (ALVAC). Both vectors have been tested in clinical trials, but they have shown different levels of safety and efficacy. Researchers have found that CD4 T cells, which are central to the immune system's response to HIV infection, are highly susceptible to HIV infection when they are activated and expanded in response to Ad5-based vaccines. However, ALVAC-based vaccines induce CD4 T cells that are less susceptible to HIV infection. This finding highlights the importance of evaluating anti-vector responses in HIV vaccination.
The article explains the evolutionary processes that lead to different X inactivation strategies in mammals. X inactivation is the process in which one of the two copies of the X chromosome is turned off in female cells to balance the number of X chromosomes between males and females. The article suggests that the evolution of random X inactivation ( RXI ) in placental mammals is favored when segregating deleterious mutations have partially recessive fitness effects. It also suggests that sex-differential selection might favor the evolution of biased X inactivation patterns ( unequal expression of maternally and paternally derived X chromosomes ).
In this paper, the authors explore the antiviral activity of the CCCH-type zinc-finger protein, ZAP, against several flaviviruses, including Zika virus, Japanese encephalitis virus, and Dengue virus. They found that ZAP can inhibit the replication of these viruses in different cell lines, including human neuroblastoma cells, human astrocytes, and human neuronal progenitor cells. The authors also demonstrate that ZAP has specific antiviral activity against Zika virus and Japanese encephalitis virus, which is not observed for Dengue virus. Furthermore, they show that ZAP can inhibit the translation of viral proteins in infected cells, suggesting that ZAP may exert its antiviral activity by interfering with the viral translation machinery. Overall, the findings of this study provide important insights into the antiviral activity of ZAP against several flaviviruses and highlight the potential of ZAP as a therapeutic target for the treatment of flavivirus infections.
Rift Valley fever virus ( RVFV ) is a major human and animal pathogen that can cause severe disease including hemorrhagic fever or encephalitis. RVFV is endemic to parts of Africa and the Arabian Peninsula, but there is significant concern regarding its introduction into non-endemic regions and the potentially devastating effect to livestock populations. To date, little detailed data directly comparing the host response to infection with wild-type or vaccine strains of RVFV and correlation with viral pathogenesis has been available. Here, the authors characterized clinical and systemic immune responses to infection with wild-type strain ZH501 or IND vaccine strain MP-12 in the C57BL/6 mouse. Animals infected with live-attenuated MP-12 survived productive viral infection with little evidence of clinical disease and minimal cytokine response in evaluated tissues. In contrast, ZH501 infection was lethal, caused depletion of lymphocytes and platelets and elicited a strong systemic cytokine response which correlated with high virus titers and significant tissue pathology. Lymphopenia and platelet depletion were indicators of disease onset with indications of lymphocyte recovery correlating with increases in G-CSF production. RVFV is hepatotropic and in these studies significant clinical and histological data supported these findings, however significant evidence of a pro-inflammatory response in the liver was not apparent. Rather, viral infection resulted in a chemokine response indicating infiltration of immunoreactive cells, such as neutrophils, which was supported by histological data. In brains of ZH501 infected mice, a significant chemokine and pro-inflammatory cytokine response was evident, but with little pathology indicating meningoencephalitis. These data suggest that RVFV pathogenesis in mice is associated with a loss of liver function due to liver necrosis and hepatitis yet the long-term course of disease for those that might survive the initial hepatitis is neurologic in nature which is supported by observations of human disease and the BALB/c mouse model.
Chemotherapy for breast cancer is a vital but often ineffective treatment. We have found that CCL20 plays a key role in taxane resistance and chemotherapy failure. Our study suggests that CCL20 may be a potential biomarker for taxane resistance and a target for chemotherapy.
In this study, the authors characterize the effects of a novel protein-protein complex in Toxoplasma gondii, a parasite that causes toxoplasmosis in humans and animals. The complex, which involves two parasite-specific proteins, MYR2 and MYR3, is important for the parasite's ability to replicate inside host cells. The authors found that MYR2 and MYR3 are present in the parasite's dense granules, which are organelles that play an important role in Toxoplasma's ability to survive and replicate inside host cells. The authors also found that MYR2 and MYR3 form a stable complex that is required for the proper localization of other dense granule proteins. Additionally, the authors found that MYR3 is phosphorylated by a protein kinase that is part of the dense granule complex. The phosphorylation of MYR3 is important for the proper localization of dense granule proteins and for the parasite's ability to replicate inside host cells. Overall, the study provides important insights into the function of the dense granule complex in Toxoplasma and suggests that MYR2 and MYR3 are key components of this complex.
This article provides information on the origin recognition complex (ORC) and its role in the initiation of replication in the human papillomavirus (HPV). The ORC binds to specific DNA sequences known as origins of replication, and once bound, recruits other replication proteins to the site. The article describes how the ORC has been studied in various organisms and how it is thought to function in HPV. The article also discusses how the ORC has been targeted in cancer therapy, particularly in HPV-associated cancers.
This study investigated the presence of Brucella DNA in bovine milk in the urban and peri-urban areas of Dushanbe, Tajikistan using qPCR targeting the IS711 insertion element. The study found that 10.3% of the 570 milk samples were positive for Brucella DNA. The rpoB gene was used to sequence the DNA and determine the species of Brucella present in the samples. The results showed that one cow was infected with B. abortus and another cow was most likely infected with B. melitensis. The study highlights the need for further investigation to determine the best strategy for controlling Brucella infections in livestock in urban and peri-urban areas.
The paper describes the construction and characterization of KMT1 and KMT6 deletion mutants in the fungal plant pathogen Zymoseptoria tritici. The chromatin immunoprecipitation sequencing data obtained for KMT1 and KMT6 show a high degree of overlap with each other, suggesting that they bind to similar genomic regions. The genes that are bound by KMT1 and KMT6 are highly repressed and transcriptionally silent, and the mutants exhibit a number of phenotypes, including reduced growth, increased cell size, and altered cell wall composition. The paper also reports the construction of a KMT1/KMT6 double mutant, which exhibits a phenotype that is more severe than the single mutants. The data presented in this paper contribute to our understanding of the roles of KMT1 and KMT6 in the epigenetic regulation of Z. tritici, and provide a foundation for future studies to elucidate their functions in this important plant pathogen.
Prompt post-exposure prophylaxis ( PEP ) is an essential treatment for preventing the onset of rabies, a fatal disease that affects millions of people worldwide. However, access to life-saving rabies vaccines and biologicals is limited, particularly to the poorest sectors of society who are most at risk and bear the largest burden of rabies. Switching from intramuscular ( IM ) administration of PEP to equally effective intradermal ( ID ) regimens could mitigate vaccine shortages, significantly reduce costs, and improve the affordability and accessibility of PEP for bite victims. A universal switch to ID delivery would benefit both bite victims and healthcare providers by improving the affordability and accessibility of PEP, potentially reducing human rabies deaths, and being economical for healthcare providers.
Toxoplasma gondii is an obligate intracellular parasite that infects all mammals and birds. During infection, Toxoplasma interacts with host cells to obtain nutrients and replicate efficiently. The authors show that Toxoplasma parasites acquire host lipids, including triacylglycerol, phosphatidylcholine, and phosphatidylinositol, via a process that involves lipophagy of the host endoplasmic reticulum, and that the parasite's ability to do so is dependent on the presence of lipid droplets in the host cell. The authors also show that Toxoplasma infection results in an increase in host lipid droplets, which are associated with an increase in parasite replication. The authors suggest that the presence of host lipid droplets may be important for Toxoplasma to acquire host lipids efficiently, and that this process may be important for parasite replication. Overall, the results provide important insights into the mechanisms by which Toxoplasma gondii interacts with host cells during infection.
The article describes the screening of flavonoid chalcones as novel inhibitors of the fasciolicide enzyme FhCL1. The authors used in vitro assays to test the chalcones for inhibition and obtained promising results with the compound C34. The article also provides information on the molecular docking and molecular dynamics simulations used to predict the binding mechanism of the inhibitor.
In the retina, neurons called bipolar cells transmit visual signals to other neurons. These bipolar cells have multiple terminals that transmit the visual signal in different ways. In this study, researchers used a special imaging technique to observe the activity of multiple bipolar cell terminals in living zebrafish retinas. They found that different sized terminals behave differently, generating faster or slower calcium signals and transmitting visual signals with different adaptive properties. The study suggests that the different sizes of bipolar cell terminals may allow for the transmission of visual signals with a range of different temporal filters.
The paper describes an unsupervised probabilistic method for synapse detection and analysis that uses fluorescence microscopy (FM) images. The proposed algorithm is inspired by the biological knowledge of synapse characteristics, and it uses query-based probabilistic synapse detection. It first distinguishes signal from background noise, then determines whether the foreground pixels correspond to a 2D punctum, then evaluates the presence of adjacent presynaptic and postsynaptic puncta by correlating the corresponding IF volumes. The method provides a general framework for the evaluation of a wide variety of synapse subtypes, user-defined by setting the presynaptic and postsynaptic antibodies and puncta size. The algorithm is compared with a supervised method in a real-world dataset, and it is shown to outperform the supervised method in the cases where both methods can be used.
ZnT2 is a zinc transporter that functions in the intracellular vesicular compartment. Previously, the driving force for ZnT2-mediated zinc transport was found to be a proton gradient across the membrane. However, the stoichiometry of ZnT2 was unknown. In this study, the authors used computational modeling to predict the proton-coupled zinc transport mechanism of ZnT2 and experimentally validated it using a fluorescent zinc indicator. They found that ZnT2 transports two protons for every zinc ion, which supports a proton-coupled zinc transport mechanism. The authors also showed that BafA1, an inhibitor of the V-ATPase proton pump, abolished ZnT2-mediated zinc transport. These findings provide important insights into the mechanism of ZnT2-mediated zinc transport and its regulation.
We have shown that yeast 14-3-3 proteins regulate the activity of the replication fork-associated nuclease Exo1. We have demonstrated that 14-3-3 proteins are required to maintain Exo1 phosphorylation and activity during replication fork arrest and that a loss of 14-3-3 proteins results in replication fork collapse and DNA damage. We have also shown that 14-3-3 proteins regulate the progression of stalled replication forks during DNA replication stress. These findings provide new insights into the regulation of Exo1 and the maintenance of replication fork stability during DNA replication stress.
HIV-1 infection is a global pandemic that affects millions of people worldwide. Despite significant advances in the understanding and treatment of HIV-1 infection, it remains a major public health concern. The role of pDC in HIV-1 infection is not well defined. HIV-1 infection in the humanized mouse model leads to persistent HIV-1 infection and immunopathogenesis. We developed a monoclonal antibody that specifically depletes human pDC in all lymphoid organs in humanized mice. When pDC were depleted prior to HIV-1 infection, the induction of IFN-I and ISGs were abolished during acute HIV-1 infection. Consistent with the anti-viral role of IFN-I, HIV-1 replication was significantly up-regulated in pDC-depleted mice. Interestingly, the cell death induced by the highly pathogenic HIV-1 isolate was severely reduced in pDC-depleted mice. During chronic HIV-1 infection, depletion of pDC also severely reduced the induction of IFN-I and ISGs, associated with elevated HIV-1 replication. Surprisingly, HIV-1 induced depletion of human immune cells including T cells in lymphoid organs, but not the blood, was reduced in spite of the increased viral replication. The increased cell number in lymphoid organs was associated with a reduced level of HIV-induced cell death in human leukocytes including CD4 T cells. We conclude that pDC play opposing roles in suppressing HIV-1 replication and in promoting HIV-1 induced immunopathogenesis. These findings suggest that pDC-depletion and IFN-I blockade will provide novel strategies for treating those HIV-1 immune non-responsive patients with persistent immune activation despite effective anti-retroviral treatment.
In this study, the authors investigated the impact of sulforaphane (SFN), a compound found in cruciferous vegetables, on the infection of macrophages and T cells by HIV-1 and HIV-2, respectively. They found that SFN blocks HIV-1 infection in macrophages but not in T cells, suggesting that macrophages may be an important target for SFN-mediated protection against HIV infection. They also found that SFN blocks HIV infection after entry into the cell but before reverse transcription, and that it does not affect the levels of Nrf2, a transcription factor that has been shown to increase resistance to some viruses. These results suggest that SFN may be useful as a therapeutic agent to prevent or slow the progression of HIV infection.
This study was conducted in rural Kenya to learn more about geohelminth infections among pregnant women. Geohelminths are parasites that can cause intestinal bleeding and protein loss, especially in hookworm infections. The study found that 76.2% of pregnant women in the area had at least one geohelminth infection, with hookworm being the most common. The study also found that geohelminth infections were not associated with low body mass index or malaria parasitemia. However, hookworm infection was associated with a lower mid upper arm circumference and a lower hemoglobin level. In addition, Ascaris lumbricoides infections were associated with impaired fat digestion and reduced vitamin absorption, and Trichuris trichiura infections were associated with a lower hemoglobin level. This study found that geohelminth infections are common among pregnant women in rural Kenya, and there may be different effects of geohelminths on pregnant women depending on the type of geohelminth infection. Further research is needed to fully understand the effects of geohelminth infections on pregnant women and to determine the best ways to prevent and treat these infections.
This paper investigates the immunomodulatory and cytotoxic effects of mycolactone, a product of the bacterium Mycobacterium ulcerans, on various cells of the central and peripheral nervous systems. Mycolactone affects the Sec61-dependent translation of cytokines, leading to a reduction in the production of proinflammatory cytokines such as IL-6, TNF-α and CCL2. Mycolactone also exhibited a significant cytotoxic effect on various immune cells, including microglia, astrocytes and neurons. The authors also studied the effects of mycolactone on the neuroinflammation associated with chronic pain in rats. They found that mycolactone reduced neuroinflammation in rats by reducing the production of proinflammatory cytokines and by reducing the proliferation of microglia. The authors suggest that mycolactone could be a useful drug for the treatment of pain.
The study investigates the genetic basis of human immunity to African sleeping sickness (HAT) caused by Trypanosoma brucei gambiense in West Africa. The researchers tested for associations between candidate gene polymorphisms and HAT outcome in populations from HAT active foci in Guinea. The study found that IL6 rs1818879 allele A was associated with a lower risk of progressing from latent infection to active disease. MIF rs36086171 allele G seemed to be associated with an increased risk, but this association did not remain significant after Bonferroni correction. Similarly, MIF rs12483859 C allele seemed be associated with latent infections. APOL1 G2 allele ( DEL ) was associated with a higher risk, while APOL1 G1 polymorphism was with a lower risk of developing HAT. No associations were found with other candidate genes. The study provides valuable information on the genetic determinants of HAT outcomes and contributes to our understanding of host-parasite interactions. This knowledge may help in the development of new control tools to combat this deadly disease.
The study reports the genomic characterization of 38 healthy Indian subjects from Singapore. Whole-genome sequencing was performed on these individuals at a depth of 30X and a total of 36,735,111 single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs), 5,380,125 insertion-deletions (indels), and 20,477 structural variants (SVs) were identified. The genetic diversity of the Singapore Indians was found to be comparable to that of the Indian population in the United Kingdom. The study also provides insights into the genetic relatedness of the Singapore Indians with other South Asian populations.
The article by Barry and colleagues is a detailed analysis of the aminoglycoside resistance mechanisms in strains of Burkholderia pseudomallei. The authors used qRT-PCR, transcript analysis, mutant construction, and whole genome sequencing to examine the amrAB-oprA efflux pump. The authors found that the 2188a and 3799a strains have amrAB-oprA deletions, leading to aminoglycoside and macrolide resistance. The deletion in 2188a also removed other genes involved in malleobactin and cobalamin synthesis and anaerobic arginine deiminase metabolism. The authors demonstrate the virulence of the strain with the amrAB-oprA deletion in a murine melioidosis model. The authors also discuss the potential use of 708a for genetic manipulation experiments using Select Agent compliant antibiotics. Overall, the article provides important insights into the mechanisms of aminoglycoside resistance in B. pseudomallei and its virulence.
In this paper, the authors explored the differentiation of CD4 T helper cells into Th1 or Th2 cells by counting single transcripts and measuring immunofluorescence in individual cells. They found that transcription factors, which are usually expressed exclusively in the pertinent cell type, are actually co-expressed in individual cells in low levels that are distinct from basal levels during lineage priming. They also observed that cytokines are expressed in a small subpopulation of cells and independently of the expression of transcription factors in these single cells. The cell-to-cell variation in cytokine expression during the early phase of T helper cell differentiation is significantly larger than in the fully differentiated state. Upon inhibition of cytokine signaling, the authors observed the mutual exclusion of antagonistic transcription factors, revealing a weak intracellular network that is usually overruled by strong signals that emanate from extracellular cytokines. These findings suggest that during the early differentiation process CD4 T cells acquire a mixed Th1/Th2 state, which is instructed by extracellular cytokines. The interplay between extracellular and intracellular signaling components unveiled in Th1/Th2 differentiation may be a common strategy for mammalian cells to buffer against noisy cytokine expression.
The study by Belcher et al. 2015 aimed to identify genes that interact with the C . elegans PAQR-2 receptor, which is important for cold-adaptation. The authors used an unbiased forward genetic approach to isolate nine paqr-2 suppressors that are able to rescue the cold-adaptation defect of the paqr-2 mutant. They then characterized the genes affected by the mutations in these suppressors and found that they are involved in phosphatidylcholine synthesis and fatty acid metabolism. The authors propose a novel regulatory pathway connecting PAQR-2, phosphatidylcholine synthesis, and the regulation of fatty acid desaturation to increase membrane fluidity during cold adaptation.
This article describes the discovery of a new feature within the tegument layer of the herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1) that may play a role in genome release into the nucleus. The authors used cryo-electron tomography to reveal this feature, which is located at the portal vertex of the HSV-1 capsid. This feature is not visible in the tegument layer of the HSV-1 virion when observed in isolation, but it becomes apparent when the virus particle is viewed as part of a larger structure. The authors speculate that this new structure may be involved in the docking of the virus to the nuclear pore complex, which is required for the release of the viral genome into the nucleus of a host cell.
The study "Abstract: Parasite-induced modulation of DC and HIV-1 infection" is a research article that investigates the effects of a protein called soluble egg antigen (SEA) on human immune cells called dendritic cells (DCs) and their ability to be infected with HIV-1. The authors found that SEA can modulate the ability of DCs to be infected with HIV-1 and can also affect the phenotype and function of immune cells. This study has implications for the role of parasites in modulating the immune system and the potential for parasite-derived proteins to be used as therapeutic agents for HIV-1.
In this study, the authors provide a mathematical model to describe the process of astrocyte swelling, a phenomenon that occurs during periods of intense neuronal activity in the brain. Using this model, the authors explore the role of different ion transport mechanisms in the swelling process and investigate the impact of genetic modifications on these mechanisms. The authors conclude that the NKCC1 cotransporter plays a key role in the swelling process, and that genetic modifications that affect this transporter can have significant effects on the swelling phenotype. Overall, the study provides important insights into the mechanisms underlying astrocyte swelling and highlights the potential for genetic modifications to be used to modulate this process.
Eukaryotic genomes contain a lot of repetitive DNA that can be harmful if it is transcribed, so it is usually turned off. To do this, plants use a process called RNA interference (RNAi) that makes small pieces of RNA that can tell the plant to turn off certain genes. In this study, the researchers found out that one of the proteins involved in RNAi, called SPT5L, can bind to DNA. They also found that SPT5L and another protein called AGO4, which is also involved in RNAi, can bind to DNA at the same time, but they do it in a different way. They also showed that both of these proteins are needed for the plant to turn off certain genes that contain repeating DNA.
This article describes the importance of rpoS, a sigma factor gene, in the B. burgdorferi (Bb) bacterium that causes Lyme disease in humans and animals. The authors show that the RpoS protein is important for spirochete survival in the tick midgut, a key stage in the Bb life cycle. They also show that the rpoS gene is important for Bb to transform from a round to a spiral shape, which is necessary for spirochete motility and survival in the bloodstream of a mammalian host. The authors provide evidence that the RpoS protein is involved in the metabolism of coenzyme A (CoA), which is necessary for NADH production, and that the RpoS protein is important for the survival of Bb in the midgut of ticks. Overall, this article provides important insights into the role of the RpoS protein in the Bb life cycle and its importance for Bb survival in the tick midgut.
The article by Xu et al. describes a hierarchical relationship between the plant hormones gibberellin (GA) and jasmonate (JA) in controlling the development of stamen filaments in Arabidopsis. The authors discovered a group of three stamen-enriched genes (MYB21, MYB24 and MYB57) that are downregulated by GA in the DELLA-overexpressing mutant Q3, but not in the DELLA-deficient mutant penta. They also found that JA is upregulated by GA in Q3, but not in penta. Moreover, the authors showed that exogenous JA, but not GA, can restore the expression of MYB21, MYB24 and MYB57 in Q3, and that the expression of these genes is not restored by exogenous GA in opr3 mutant. Finally, they demonstrated that application of exogenous JA can rescue the short stamen phenotype conferred by loss of function of MYB21 and MYB24 in double mutants, but not by exogenous GA. Together, these results suggest that GA acts upstream of JA to regulate stamen development via a hierarchical relationship.
In this article, the authors explore the role of the hypoxia-inducible factor-1 (HIF-1) in the lifespan extension of Caenorhabditis elegans under dietary restriction (DR). They found that HIF-1 deficiency results in extended lifespan, which is similar to the lifespan extension observed in rsks-1/S6 kinase mutants. They also showed that the extended lifespan in HIF-1 and rsks-1/S6 kinase mutants is tissue-specific and involves the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress pathway. Overall, their findings suggest that HIF-1 and the TOR pathway play distinct roles in the lifespan extension of C. elegans under DR.
The article describes the discovery of unique enhancer regions and their role in cell differentiation and migration. It compares enhancer regions in cells that are differentiating, migrating, and not undergoing any change. It also examines the role of a transcription factor called GRHL3 in differentiation and migration and how it affects enhancer regions. The article discusses how the results of this study could help with the treatment of skin diseases. The language is scientific and uses technical terms related to genetics and biology.
This study characterizes the evolutionary history and molecular virology of endogenous retroviruses (enJSRVs) in sheep. These viruses are of the Betaretrovirus genus, which also includes the exogenous retroviruses that cause sheep respiratory tract tumors. The study reveals that two enJSRV loci entered the sheep genome before and during speciation within the genus Ovis. These loci later acquired the tryptophan-to-arginine mutation in the Gag protein, which confers a transdominant blocking phenotype. The transdominant enJSRVs became fixed in the sheep genome before or around sheep domestication. The study also provides evidence for the continuous invasion of the sheep genome by ERVs of the JSRV/enJSRVs group, as well as the emergence of proviruses that can escape the transdominant enJSRVs. These findings have important implications for understanding the coevolution of retroviruses and their hosts, and may also have implications for the development of new therapies for retrovirus-induced diseases.
The study aimed to evaluate the performance of two in-house real-time PCRs, targeting Schistosoma mansoni (Sm) and Schistosoma haematobium (Sh), in stool, urine, and biopsy samples, as well as serum, in diagnosing active schistosomiasis infections and monitoring treatment efficacy. Schistosoma PCRs were performed on 412 samples from patients with suspected schistosomiasis before anti-parasitic treatment. Results were compared to microscopic examination and serological assays (ELISA, HA, and WB). The SmPCR increased the sensitivity of diagnosing Sh in urine and Sm in stools from 4% to 10.5% and from 33.7% to 48.8%, respectively. The overall sensitivity of SmPCR on serum samples was 72.7% and reached 94.1% in patients with positive excreta (microscopy). The SmPCR specificity was 98.9%. After treatment, SmPCR positivity rates slowly declined from 93.8% at day 30 to 8.3% at day 360, whereas antibody detection remained positive after 1 year. The ShPCR also significantly increased the sensitivity of diagnosing Sh in urine from 33.7% to 48.8%, and its overall sensitivity on serum samples was 72.7%. The specificity of the ShPCR was 98.9%. After treatment, ShPCR positivity rates declined from 94.1% at day 30 to 11.1% at day 360, whereas antibody detection remained positive after 1 year. When serological assays are positive and microscopy is negative, serum PCRs provide species information to guide further clinical exploration. Biomarkers such as DNA and antibodies are of limited relevance for early treatment monitoring, but serum PCR could be useful when performed at least 1 year after treatment to help confirm a cured infection. The authors concluded that Schistosoma PCRs could be useful in diagnosing schistosomiasis infections, particularly in non-endemic countries where parasite burden can be lower, and for monitoring treatment efficacy. They also emphasized that further research is needed to develop a standardized protocol for the use of molecular methods in diagnosing schistosomiasis.
Archazolid A is a potent inhibitor of vacuolar-type ATPase that was discovered by Menche and coworkers. Its chemical structure is complex, with seven alkenes, eight methyl- and hydroxyl-bearing stereocenters, and three in-solution model conformations. We built a model using Gaussian process regression that can predict the energies of relaxed conformations at the density functional level of theory (implicit solvent, DFT/BLYP-disp3/def2-TZVP) with mean absolute errors of less than 1 kcal/mol. Our model has the potential to speed up molecular dynamics simulations of larger molecular structures, allowing for faster exploration of the chemical space.
Ebola virus (EBOV) infections have been previously described in western lowland gorillas (Gorilla gorilla gorilla) in Central Africa. The researchers report the successful non-invasive detection of antibodies against EBOV in gorilla feces. The detection of EBOV antibodies in gorilla feces allows for a better understanding of the prevalence of EBOV infections in gorillas. The researchers found that EBOV antibody prevalence reached 10% on average, demonstrating that EBOV exposure or infection is not uniformly lethal in this species. Furthermore, evidence of antibodies was identified in gorillas thought previously to be unexposed to EBOV. This new approach will contribute to a strategy to protect apes from future EBOV infections by early detection of increased incidence of exposure, by identifying immunologically naïve at-risk populations as potential targets for vaccination, and by providing a means to track vaccine efficacy if such intervention is deemed appropriate. Since human EVD is linked to contact with infected wildlife carcasses, efforts aimed at identifying great ape outbreaks could have a profound impact on public health in local communities, where EBOV causes case-fatality rates of up to 88%.
This manuscript describes the discovery of a novel ubiquitin ligase from Xanthomonas campestris pv. vesicatoria (Xcv), a bacterium that causes spot diseases on many plant species. The authors found that the Xcv outer protein L (XopL) has an E3 ubiquitin ligase domain and that it can form ubiquitin chains in vitro with Arabidopsis UBC28 and A. thaliana E2s. They also found that XopL can induce cell death in N. benthamiana and A. thaliana protoplasts. The study provides important insights into the mechanisms of bacterial E3 ubiquitin ligases.
This article presents a study on the impact of early antiretroviral treatment (ART) on T helper cell-B cell responses in acute HIV infection. The study used the RV254 cohort, which included HIV-infected individuals recruited during the earliest stages of acute infection. The study found that impaired cTfh cell function was observed in individuals treated in stage 3 when compared to stage 1/2. The cTfh/B cell cocultures showed lower B cell survival and IgG secretion at stage 3 compared to stage 1/2. This coincided with lower IL-10 and increased RANTES and TNF-α, suggesting a role for inflammation in altering cTfh and B cell responses. The data suggest that early ART for acutely HIV infected individuals could preserve T and B cell memory responses against HIV infection.
In this study, we show that the Sm . 5HTRL isoform of the schistosome 5-hydroxytriptamine receptor is a novel and effective antiparasitic target. We performed an extensive characterization of Sm . 5HTRL, including agonist and antagonist screening, to identify new compounds with activity against this receptor. Our data provide insights into the pharmacology of Sm . 5HTRL and demonstrate its potential as a therapeutic target for schistosomiasis. We also provide a detailed description of the methods used to characterize this receptor, which may be useful for future studies of other flatworm GPCRs.
The authors of this study found that the boundary between ectoderm and mesoderm cells is maintained by EphrinB/EphB signaling. They found that EphB receptors and EphrinB ligands are expressed on both sides of the boundary, and that forward signaling across the boundary is involved in maintaining the separation between these cells. They also found that EphB/EphrinB signaling regulates the motility of mesoderm cells, which are in direct contact with the ectodermal blastocoel roof.
In this study, researchers analyzed metabolites of folate-dependent one-carbon metabolism and transsulfuration pathways in 83 participants with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) and 76 age-matched neurotypical peers using Fisher Discriminant Analysis (FDA) to classify the participants as on the spectrum or neurotypical. This analysis resulted in 96.1% of all neurotypical participants being correctly identified as such while still correctly identifying 97.7% of the ASD cohort. Furthermore, kernel partial least squares (KPLS) was used to predict adaptive behavior, as measured by the Vineland Adaptive Behavior Composite score, where measurement of five metabolites of the pathways was sufficient to predict the Vineland score with an R2 of 0.45 after cross-validation. These results suggest that metabolites of these pathways are strongly correlated with an ASD diagnosis and may be used in the future to develop more accurate diagnoses and severity prediction.
The paper presents a Bayesian geostatistical model that predicts the incidence of cutaneous and visceral leishmaniasis in Brazil, based on 10-year data. The model takes into account environmental and socioeconomic factors, as well as temporal trends, to provide accurate predictions at a high spatial resolution. The results show that climate, socioeconomic variables, and spatial effects are important predictors of the disease incidence, and that the predicted number of cases in 2010 was significantly higher than the reported number. The paper highlights the importance of accurate mapping of leishmaniasis incidence for targeting interventions and reducing disease incidence.
Dengue is a viral disease that affects millions of people worldwide, and the number of cases is increasing. As the disease spreads to new regions and the force of infection changes, a broader range of clinical presentations is being recognized. Researchers at a hospital in southern Vietnam compared the clinical and laboratory features, management, and outcome of 647 adults and 881 children with confirmed dengue. They found that adults experienced more severe thrombocytopenia, a condition in which there are low levels of platelets, than children. Additionally, adults had more bleeding manifestations and organ involvement, while children had more severe signs of vascular leakage and shock. The researchers suggest that there are clear distinctions between adults and children in the pattern of complications associated with dengue infection, and these differences depend partly on intrinsic age-dependent physiological differences. They encourage the development of management guidelines appropriate to the age-groups at risk and emphasize the importance of research on disease pathogenesis.
We identified a new mutation in the CCR5 gene of sooty mangabeys (SM) that results in a lack of surface expression and function of the coreceptor, despite the fact that the SM CCR5 gene is otherwise highly conserved. This mutation, which we named CCR5Δ2, was found in 8% of SM, and together with another mutation, CCR5Δ24, results in 13% of SM lacking functional CCR5. However, these animals are still susceptible to infection with simian immunodeficiency virus (SIV) and show robust viral replication, suggesting that SIVsmm uses additional coreceptors. This is the first clear example of convergent evolution resulting in nonfunctional mutant CCR5 alleles among primate species.
This study investigates the tumorigenic potential of the transcriptional regulators MEF2 in leiomyosarcomas. The authors found that MEF2 can act as both transcriptional activators and repressors, depending on the cellular and genetic context. They also found that HDAC9, a member of the class IIa HDAC family, is required for MEF2-mediated transcriptional repression. The authors suggest that HDAC9 may be a target for therapeutic intervention in leiomyosarcomas.
The article describes the use of three different techniques, protein docking, molecular dynamics simulation and electron cryo-microscopy, to study the structure of films composed of two class II hydrophobins, HFBI and HFBII, produced by Trichoderma reesei. The study revealed a unit cell composed of six proteins, but the computational results suggest P6 symmetry while the experimental results show P3 symmetry with a unit cell size of 56 Å. The study also indicates the possibility of an alternate ordering with a three protein unit cell with P3 symmetry and a smaller unit cell size. The alternate metastable structure may play a role in increasing the rate of surface coverage by hydrophobin films and may have a mechanism of more general significance to both biology and nanotechnology.
Aminoacyltransferases are important enzymes that play a key role in protein synthesis. They catalyze the transfer of a specific amino acid to the 3'-end of the corresponding transfer RNA (tRNA). These enzymes are essential for the survival of many organisms, and have been extensively studied in bacteria, plants, and fungi. Recently, it has been discovered that these enzymes are also present in Leishmania parasites. Leishmania parasites are the causative agents of leishmaniasis, a group of diseases that affect the skin, mucous membranes, and internal organs. In this study, the aminoacyltransferase from Leishmania donovani was cloned, expressed, and purified. The enzyme was found to be specific for the transfer of l-threonine to its cognate tRNA. The purified enzyme was used to study its aminoacylation activity and its kinetic parameters. The results showed that the enzyme was capable of catalyzing the aminoacylation reaction with high efficiency and specificity. The enzyme was also found to be stable and could be purified to homogeneity. The results of this study provide valuable information on the aminoacyltransferase from Leishmania donovani, which can be used for the development of new drugs against leishmaniasis.
RIG-I is a critical component of the innate immune response to RNA viruses. In this study, the authors identify specific RNA sequences in the HCV poly-U/UC tract that are recognized by RIG-I. They find that the poly-uridine core ( U-core ) within the HCV poly-U/UC tract is essential for recognition by RIG-I, and that long poly-uridine sequences ( >U17 ) with interspersed ribocytosines induce in vitro anti-HCV responses and hepatic innate immune responses in vivo. These findings suggest that RIG-I recognition of specific RNA sequences within the HCV poly-U/UC tract triggers an innate immune response to HCV infection.
In recent years, eosinophils have been shown to play important roles in host metabolism and tissue regeneration. These functions are relevant to worm infections, where eosinophils are prominent and parasites rely on the host for nutrients to support growth or reproduction. The study aimed to investigate the mechanisms underlying the observation that eosinophils promote growth of Trichinella spiralis larvae in skeletal muscle. The results suggest that IL-4 and eosinophils are necessary for normal larval growth, and that eosinophils from IL-4-competent mice are sufficient to support growth. The eosinophil-mediated effect operates in the absence of adaptive immunity. Following invasion by newborn larvae, host gene expression in skeletal muscle is compatible with a regenerative response and a shift in the source of energy in infected tissue. Redistribution of glucose transporter 4 ( GLUT4 ) and phosphorylation of Akt are observed in nurse cells, consistent with enhancement of glucose uptake and glycogen storage by larvae that is known to occur. The data support a mechanism in which eosinophils promote larval growth by an IL-4-dependent mechanism that limits local interferon-driven responses that otherwise alter nutrient metabolism in infected muscle. The findings document a novel interaction between parasite and host in which worms have evolved a strategy to co-opt an innate host cell response in a way that facilitates their growth.
This study used a combination of methods to analyze DNA replication kinetics in different human cell lines. The authors found that the majority of cell lines replicate their genomes at an apparent speed of 200 kb/min. However, they also identified a subset of cell lines that replicate their genomes at an apparent speed of less than 200 kb/min. These cell lines include HeLa, MCF-7, and 293T cells, which have previously been used for molecular biology studies. The authors suggest that these cells may have distinct replication properties that make them useful for studies of replication.
This paper investigates how our brains can efficiently recognize objects, such as recognizing a person's face despite changes in lighting conditions, and proposes a theory that our brains use to learn this ability. The theory is based on the idea that the brain focuses on slowly changing aspects of objects, rather than rapidly changing ones, when recognizing them. The authors present an algorithm that can implement this theory and apply it to a spiking model of a neuron. They show that a modified version of Hebbian learning can be used to learn the slowest (in terms of SFA) combination of inputs in a spiking model neuron. Additionally, they show that spike-timing–dependent plasticity (STDP) can be interpreted as implementing the slowness principle. The authors conclude that their findings provide a link between SFA and trace learning, and a mathematical interpretation of STDP.
In this study, the authors used CRISPR/Cas9 to generate phenotypically unique NSCLC cell lines and found that these cells support each other to rapidly evolve a therapy-resistant phenotype via drug-induced cell state transitions, a behavior they termed "cooperative adaptation to therapy" (CAT). They developed a mathematical model that describes this phenomenon and found that it can significantly impact population growth. They also validated their findings using an ex vivo human tumor model. Their findings highlight the importance of understanding the role of phenotypic heterogeneity in acquired resistance and suggest that profiling for druggable targets alone may be insufficient to assign effective therapy.
The study aimed to estimate the seroprevalence of IgG antibodies against Spotted Fever Group (SFG) rickettsiae in the Mbeya Region of Southwestern Tanzania. SFG-seropositivity was found to be 67.9% (range among nine sites: 42.8–91.4%). Multivariable analysis revealed an association with age, warmer temperatures, male gender, and low population density. At higher elevations, higher cattle density was associated with higher seroprevalence. The study suggests that SFG rickettsial infection is common in rural populations of Mbeya Region, and its spread is further limited by temperature and higher elevation.
The article describes the role of the monounsaturated fatty acid oleate in the innate immune response of the nematode Caenorhabditis elegans. From an RNAi screen for regulators of innate immune defense genes, the authors identified the two stearoyl-coenzyme A desaturases that synthesize oleate in C . elegans. They showed that the synthesis of oleate is necessary for the pathogen-mediated induction of immune defense genes. C . elegans deficient in oleate production are hypersusceptible to infection with diverse human pathogens, which can be rescued by the addition of exogenous oleate. However, oleate is not sufficient to drive protective immune activation. The authors suggest an ancient link between nutrient stores, metabolism, and host susceptibility to bacterial infection.
The present study highlights the potential of guanine riboswitches as antibacterial targets. The research team has identified two novel compounds, PC1 and PC2, which bind to guanine riboswitches and exhibit bactericidal activity against a subgroup of bacterial species. This effect is only observed when the guanine riboswitch is under the control of a gene coding for a GMP synthetase. The bacteria that exhibit this effect include S. aureus and C. difficile, which are known nosocomial pathogens responsible for significant mortality rates in hospitals and increased healthcare costs. The researchers have also shown that PC1 targets a different metabolic pathway than the bacterial cell wall, providing a new approach to antibiotic development. The study provides promising results for the development of new antibiotics and highlights the importance of understanding the mechanisms of riboswitch function in bacteria.
We studied how monkeys' hippocampal cells encoded and used the target of gaze (what the monkey was looking at) during navigation in a virtual reality maze. We found that the cells' activity was best fit by a fine-grained state space that included current position, view, and action contexts.
