This shows that the cells encoded multidimensional, task-situated knowledge related to the target of gaze, and that this information was useful for wayfinding.
The isthmic organizer (IsO) mediates the differentiation of the midbrain and hindbrain during vertebrate development. It is characterized by a specific pattern of locally restricted gene expression around the mid-hindbrain boundary (MHB). A Boolean analysis of this pattern reveals key regulatory interactions in the IsO network. The analysis employs techniques from computational logic for the minimization of Boolean functions. Fgf8 is found to only maintain, rather than induce ectopic Wnt1 expression in mouse anterior neural plate/tube explants. Using mouse anterior neural plate/tube explant cultures, we provide experimental evidence that Fgf8 in fact only maintains, but does not induce ectopic Wnt1 expression in these explants. In combination with previously validated interactions, this finding allows for the construction of a regulatory network between key transcription and secreted factors at the MHB. Analyses of Boolean, differential equation and reaction-diffusion models of this network confirm that it is indeed able to explain the stable maintenance of the MHB as well as time-courses of expression patterns both under wild-type and various knock-out conditions. The spatial gene expression patterns around the MHB help us to understand the maintenance of this boundary on a systems level. In particular, the spatial pattern helps us to identify the maintaining, rather than inducing, effect of Fgf8 on Wnt1 expression.
Theileria annulata, a parasitic protozoan that infects bovine red blood cells, transforms and uncontrollably proliferates the cells. The transforming parasite produces many proteins that interact with cellular components and mediate the transformation process. One such protein is p104, which is produced on the surface of the transforming parasite and interacts with the host cell microtubules. In this study, the authors describe the identification and characterization of p104 as a host cell target protein of T. annulata. They show that p104 is a major schizont surface protein that functions as a bona fide EB1-binding protein, interacting with EB1 via a classic 'SxIP' motif. They also show that p104 is the first parasite-encoded EB1-binding protein described to date. The authors propose that p104 may play a role in the uncontrollable proliferation of the schizont by promoting persistent MT growth and suppressing catastrophes. Their findings provide new insights into the molecular mechanisms of T. annulata transformation and may help in the development of new strategies for controlling the parasite.
Broken replication forks can cause DNA damage that is usually repaired by homologous recombination or break-induced replication (BIR). A study showed that in budding yeast, if replicative ligase Cdc9 was mildly insufficient, the cells had persistent DNA damage, likely due to broken replication forks, constitutive activation of the DNA damage checkpoint, and longer telomeres. Telomere lengthening required functional telomerase, the Mec1-Rad9-Rad53 DNA damage signaling cascade, and the BIR repair pathway components. The Mec1-Rad53 DNA damage signaling cascade also phosphorylated Pif1, which was important for the role of Pif1 in BIR and telomere lengthening. Two other mutants with impaired DNA replication, cdc44-5 and rrm3Δ, also had long telomeres and required the Pif1 phosphorylation locus for this effect. The study proposed that the passage of BIR forks through telomeres promotes telomerase activity and leads to telomere lengthening.
Onchocerciasis is an infection caused by the filarial nematode Onchocerca volvulus . It is a major public health concern and can cause blindness, disabling dermatitis, and other symptoms. Diagnosis of onchocerciasis can be difficult and current methods rely on microfilariae found in skin snips. However, new serological tests have been developed, including a rapid immunoprecipitation system (LIPS) that uses four different Onchocerca volvulus antigens. These antigens are Ov-FAR-1 , Ov-API-1 , Ov-MSA-1 , and Ov-CPI-1 . The LIPS assay was tested on a large cohort of blinded sera from uninfected controls and patients with proven parasitic infection, including Onchocerca volvulus, Wuchereria bancrofti, Loa loa, Strongyloides stercoralis, and other potentially cross-reactive infections. The results showed that the four Ov antigens allowed for unequivocal differentiation between Ov-infected and uninfected sera with 100% sensitivity and 100% specificity. Analysis of antibody titers to each of these four antigens revealed that they were markedly different and did not correlate. Compared to Ov-infected sera, patients infected with Wb, Ll, Ss, and other conditions had markedly lower geometric mean antibody titers to each of the Ov 4 antigens. The simplified method of using a mixture of the 4 Ov antigens simultaneously in the standard format or a quick 15-minute format ( QLIPS ) showed 100% sensitivity and specificity in distinguishing the Ov-infected sera from the uninfected control sera. Finally, the QLIPS format had the best performance with 100% sensitivity and specificity values of 76%, 84%, and 93% for distinguishing Ov from Wb, Ll and Ss-infected sera. The multi-antigen LIPS assay can be used as a rapid, high throughput, and specific tool to not only to diagnose individual Ov infections but also as a sensitive and potentially point-of-care method for early detection of recrudescent infections in areas under control and for mapping new areas of transmission of Ov infection.
The study aimed to evaluate the impact of weekly iron-folic acid supplementation and regular de-worming on mean hemoglobin and the prevalence of anaemia , iron deficiency , and soil transmitted helminth infections in a rural population of women in northern Vietnam. The study found that after 54 months, mean hemoglobin rose from 122 g/L to 131 g/L, anemia prevalence fell from 38% to 18%, iron deficiency fell from 23% to 8%, while the prevalence of iron deficiency anemia was reduced to 4%. The prevalence of hookworm infection also reduced from 76% to 11%. The study also identified predictive factors for hematological outcomes.
EBV gp150 inhibits T cell activation by targeting HLA-A and HLA-B molecules. We generated EBV B cell lines expressing human HLA-A2 or HLA-A2 and CD1d and found that gp150 expression interferes with HLA-A2 presentation of both EBV and self-antigens. By contrast, gp150 does not inhibit presentation of HLA-A2 by HLA-A2+CD1d+ B cells. Moreover, gp150 inhibits activation of CD4+ T cells by interfering with the interaction of HLA-B molecules with their cognate TCRs, but does not affect activation of CD8+ T cells by HLA-A2+CD1d+ B cells. We also show that gp150 expression is required for EBV to efficiently lyse B cells in vitro. Together, these data support a role for gp150 in protecting EBV-infected B cells from destruction by CD8+ T cells.
The goal of this study was to examine the role of Tarp, a translocated effector protein of Chlamydia trachomatis, in the entry of the bacterium into host cells. Tarp has been previously shown to mediate actin polymerization, which is thought to play a role in the recruitment of actin to the site of attachment and entry. The study showed that Tarp is highly conserved among all known chlamydial species, and that all species possess at least one and up to four functional actin binding domains. The study also demonstrated that purified recombinant Tarp from all chlamydial species were capable of nucleating actin filament formation in vitro. In addition, a peptide antiserum with affinity to the actin binding domain prevented Tarp-mediated actin nucleation and significantly reduced host cell susceptibility to chlamydial infection in vitro. Overall, the study suggests that Tarp-mediated actin polymerization is a conserved feature among diverse chlamydial species and may play an important role in bacterial entry.
Schistosomiasis japonica is a zoonosis that affects many mammalian species, including water buffalo and carabao. It is a public health concern because it causes debilitating disease and adds to the economic burden of communities. The new FEA-SD technique removes much of the bulk debris and cellulose material in feces of bovines and other ruminants, allowing improved microscopic examination of S . japonicum eggs. The study was performed on 13 naturally infected Chinese water buffaloes and 25 carabao from the Philippines. The FEA-SD technique is efficient and reproducible and provides an accurate quantitative method for determining S . japonicum infection in bovines and other ruminants. It is less costly than real-time PCR and more efficient than MHT in detecting S . japonicum eggs.
This paper describes the results of a genetic study of a mouse model for progeria, a disease characterized by premature aging. The authors found that the mouse model carries a mutation in a gene that encodes an enzyme called progerin, which is responsible for the premature aging seen in the mice. The authors then used a variety of techniques to study the effects of progerin on the mice, including measurements of bone density and mechanical properties, as well as analyses of blood and tissue samples. The results of these studies suggest that progerin has a number of negative effects on the mice, including decreased bone density and mechanical properties, as well as changes in the composition of blood and tissues. The authors conclude that their findings provide important insights into the pathogenesis of progeria and may help to identify potential therapeutic targets for the treatment of this disease.
Drosophila melanogaster, commonly known as the fruit fly, has an important role in scientific research. The fruit fly genome is relatively small and simple, making it easy to study. Additionally, fruit flies have a short life cycle, making it easy to perform experiments on them. Scientists have been studying the fruit fly for over a century and have learned a lot about its biology. However, there are still many mysteries about the fruit fly and its role in nature.
Male Ae. aegypti can be marked with rhodamine B by feeding them sugar-solution containing dye. This study tested the effects of rhodamine B marking on male survival, mating success, and marking longevity. The results indicate that rhodamine B marking has no negative effects on male survival, mating success, or marking longevity. The study also found that feeding males with sugar-solution containing rhodamine B increased the rate of body and seminal fluid marking. This finding suggests that rhodamine B could be used as a quick and easy marker for male Ae. aegypti in mating competitiveness experiments.
A superantigen is a toxin that activates an immune response by binding to both T cells and antigen-presenting cells (APCs). The study shows that superantigens bind directly to CD28 on T cells to activate the immune response. The authors also show that peptides that block the binding of superantigens to CD28 can protect mice from lethal shock. These findings identify CD28 as a receptor for superantigen toxins and show a novel role for CD28 in pathogen recognition.
Understanding the mechanisms of pluripotency and cellular reprogramming is crucial for developing new approaches to regenerative medicine. Mouse embryonic stem cells (mESCs) are a model system for studying these processes, as they have the capacity to differentiate into any cell type in the body. However, mESCs have a relatively fast cell cycle, which makes them difficult to study in terms of their cellular reprogramming dynamics. In this study, the authors have used RNA interference (RNAi) to selectively inhibit the expression of a group of genes called the "cell cycle inhibitor" (CCI) genes. They found that inhibition of CCI genes slows down the cell cycle of mESCs and that this slowing down is associated with a decrease in the expression of genes that are involved in cellular reprogramming. Specifically, they found that inhibition of CCI genes leads to a decrease in the expression of genes involved in pluripotency maintenance, such as Oct4, Sox2, and Nanog, as well as genes involved in epigenetic regulation, such as Dnmt3a and Ezh2. The authors also found that inhibition of CCI genes leads to an increase in the expression of genes involved in differentiation, such as Tfap2c and Sox17. The authors conclude that the slowing down of the cell cycle of mESCs is associated with a decrease in pluripotency maintenance and an increase in differentiation. This study provides important insights into the mechanisms of pluripotency and cellular reprogramming in mESCs and has important implications for the development of new approaches to regenerative medicine.
In this report, the authors analyze the role of plasmacytoid dendritic cells (pDCs) in dengue virus (DENV) infection. They show that pDCs from dengue fever (DF) patients express high levels of the pro-apoptotic protein TRAIL, which is involved in the control of viral infection. The authors also show that pDCs can decrease DENV infection in monocytes, which are the main target cells for the virus. This effect is likely due to the production of IFN-α by pDCs. The authors suggest that pDCs play an important role in the defense against DENV infection and that they may be used as a target for therapeutic intervention in the future.
TB is the most frequent bacterial infection globally and the leading cause of death from infectious diseases. The treatment of TB is complicated and time-consuming, and the current treatment strategies are ineffective against latent TB. TNF plays a central role in the pathogenesis of TB, and its inhibition has been shown to be effective in treating TB in animal models. However, inhibition of TNF in humans is associated with increased risk of cancer, and there are concerns about the safety of anti-TNF therapy. Therefore, there is a need for safer and more effective strategies for treating TB. We developed a mathematical model of the host-pathogen system for TB and used it to simulate the dynamics of TNF production and the effects of anti-TNF antibody and receptor fusion molecules on TNF production. Our results indicate that TNF production is a complex process that is influenced by multiple factors, including the bacterial load, immune cell recruitment, and cytokine signaling. Anti-TNF antibody and receptor fusion molecules can effectively suppress TNF production, but the timing and duration of treatment are critical for success. Overall, our findings provide insights into the mechanisms of TNF production in TB and suggest that anti-TNF therapy could be an effective strategy for treating TB.
In this study, the authors used the results of Phase 1 from the 1000 Genomes Project to investigate variation in loss of ancestral retrocopies among different human populations. They also examined retrocopy expression levels using RNA-Seq data derived from the Ilumina BodyMap project, as well as data from lymphoblastoid cell lines provided by the Geuvadis Consortium. The authors developed a new approach to detect novel retrocopies absent from the reference human genome and experimentally confirmed the existence of the detected retrocopies and determined their presence or absence in the human genomes of 17 different populations. Altogether, they were able to detect 193 RDVs; the majority resulted from retrocopy deletion. Most of these RDVs had not been previously reported. The authors experimentally confirmed the expression of 11 ancestral retrogenes that underwent deletion in certain individuals. The frequency of their deletion, with the exception of one retrogene, is very low. The expression, conservation, and low rate of deletion of the remaining 10 retrocopies may suggest some functionality. Aside from the presence or absence of expressed retrocopies, the authors also searched for differences in retrocopy expression levels between populations and found 9 retrogenes that undergo statistically significant differential expression.
This study compared the inflammatory response to different types of cysticerci (different locations in the brain) in pigs that received an anthelmintic drug (praziquantel) or did not receive any treatment. The study found that cysticerci located in the brain parenchyma (tissue that makes up the brain) caused a stronger inflammatory response compared to cysticerci located in the meninges (tissue that surrounds the brain) or both the parenchyma and meninges (corticomeningeal). The study also found that disruption of the blood-brain barrier (BBB) was associated with treatment in the parenchymal tissue. The suboptimal inflammatory response to cysticidal drugs in cysticerci located in the meninges may be one reason why subarachnoid NCC is generally refractory to treatment compared to parenchymal NCC.
Yaws, a sexually transmitted disease, has been reported in Ghana in the past. It is caused by the bacterium Treponema pallidum ssp. pertenue. To determine if yaws is still present in Ghana, a survey was conducted in 30 communities. Children with skin lesions were tested for syphilis serology, and PCR for T. pallidum ssp. pertenue and H. ducreyi. The survey found that H. ducreyi was associated with a proportion of skin lesions, but the majority of lesions remain unexplained. The survey did not find evidence of ongoing transmission of yaws. The findings suggest that the previously reported cases of yaws in Ghana could be due to other infections.
HIV remains difficult to cure despite the availability of highly effective antiretroviral therapy (ART). This therapy can suppress viral replication to undetectable levels in the blood, but it does not completely eliminate the virus from the body. HIV persists in a small number of cells, known as the HIV reservoir, and this reservoir can slowly replenish itself even in the presence of ART. There is an urgent need to develop new strategies to eradicate the HIV reservoir, and new compounds that target the pathways of HIV persistence are currently under development. In this study, we evaluated the effects of two compounds that target the Jak-STAT pathway, ruxolitinib and tofacitinib, on HIV persistence in vitro. We found that ruxolitinib and tofacitinib can suppress HIV replication and reduce the size of the HIV reservoir. We also found that these compounds can prevent the expansion of CD4 memory T cells and suppress the production of inflammatory cytokines. Our findings suggest that the Jak-STAT pathway may be a promising target for HIV eradication therapies.
Baculoviruses are used to control insect pests. They specifically infect insects and are harmless to humans and the environment. However, the ability of baculoviruses to control insect pests depends on their host range. Some baculoviruses can only infect a few species of insects, while others can infect a wide range of insects. The virulence of baculoviruses also varies depending on the insect host. This study examined the host response of Spodoptera exigua to infection by two different species of baculovirus. The results showed that both viruses caused a down-regulation of immune-related genes. However, this down-regulation was more pronounced for the virus that specifically infected S. exigua. The down-regulation of immune-related genes may contribute to the virulence of baculoviruses.
This study is about apomixis, a type of asexual reproduction through seeds in which the resulting offspring are clones of the mother plant. Apomixis has the potential to be applied in agriculture by allowing for the propagation of desired genetic traits. However, apomixis is rare in crops, and attempts to introduce it through crossing have failed. In this study, researchers identified a gene called OSD1 that controls entry into the second meiotic division in the model plant Arabidopsis thaliana. They then created a mutation in this gene and combined it with two other mutations to create a genotype called MiMe in which meiosis is replaced by mitosis. This genotype produces functional diploid gametes that are genetically identical to the mother plant. This study is an important step towards understanding and engineering apomixis in crops.
The current study investigates the impact of tissue-specific information on the accuracy of disease-gene prioritization algorithms. The authors create tissue-specific protein interaction networks by combining tissue-specific gene expression data and generic protein interaction networks. They then apply these tissue-specific networks to prioritize disease-causing genes. The authors find that integrating tissue-specific information significantly improves the accuracy of disease gene prioritization. They also show that tissue-specific protein interaction networks can infer novel disease-tissue associations. The authors propose a new method for ranking disease-causing genes based on their expression in a specific tissue. They find that lowly expressed genes tend to be disease-causing in many tissues, rather than a single tissue. The authors also find that randomly assigning genes to tissues leads to similar results, suggesting that many diseases have a broad tissue distribution.
The paper describes the development of a mathematical model to study the spread of insecticide resistance in mosquitoes that transmit diseases like malaria. The model takes into account the different ways in which insecticides can be deployed and their effectiveness against mosquitoes with different levels of resistance. The model also accounts for the genetic and environmental factors that can influence the spread of resistance. The authors emphasize the importance of using mathematical models to guide decision-making on insecticide deployment strategies and to identify the best ways to minimize the spread of insecticide resistance. The paper also discusses some of the challenges and limitations of the model and suggests ways in which it could be improved in the future.
This study used cutting-edge technology to analyze the saliva of the blood-sucking insect Rhodnius neglectus, which transmits Chagas disease. The saliva was analyzed using next generation sequencing and mass spectrometry to identify the proteins present in the saliva. This is important because the proteins in the saliva help the insect to feed on blood and to evade the host's immune system. The study identified many proteins that are likely to be involved in these processes, including lipocalins, serine protease inhibitors, antigen-5, metalloproteases, disintegrins, and odorant binding proteins. The results of this study will help scientists to understand more about how blood-sucking insects feed and transmit diseases, which could lead to the development of new treatments for diseases like Chagas.
We have used the nematode C. elegans to study how bacterial environments affect the expression of genes involved in metabolism and innate immunity. We used mutants of 21 different genes to determine how each gene affects fitness and lifespan in a specific bacterial environment. We found that the response of the nematode to its environment is reflected in the genes that are differentially expressed. We also found that the extent of differential expression between bacterial environments is predictive of the effect of mutations in those genes on life history traits in those environments. Our results suggest that transcriptional profiling can be used to identify genes that may play important roles in ecosystems where native soil nematodes interact with soil bacteria.
Mammalian embryos start out as a single fertilized egg that divides multiple times to form a morula and then compacts to form a blastocyst. The blastocyst is made up of two main types of cells: the inner cell mass (ICM) and the trophectoderm (TE). These two cell types have different functions in the embryo. The ICM gives rise to the embryo proper, while the TE forms the placenta. The lineage decision between ICM and TE cells is made during the early stages of embryo development, and it is important for the formation of a normal embryo. Researchers have studied this process using live imaging and mathematical modeling. They found that stochasticity in the expression of key genes helps to promote cell plasticity, which is important for organizing the blastocyst. They also found that asymmetries in gene expression levels can provide a way to gain the benefits of stochasticity while minimizing its potentially detrimental effects. Additionally, the researchers found that by controlling the timing and pace of cell fate specification, the embryo can temporally modulate plasticity and create a time window during which each cell can continuously read its environment and adjust its fate. These findings suggest that noise has a crucial role in maintaining cellular plasticity and organizing the blastocyst.
The paper investigates the molecular basis for antibody recognition. It explores the potential for polyspecificity, or the ability of an antibody to bind multiple unrelated antigens, in germline antibodies, which are the starting structures in the germline repertoire. The paper presents a computational design process that identifies residues in the germline gene sequence that are critical for polyspecificity. The study finds that key positions in the VH gene encoding CDR1, CDR2, and the framework are important contributors for polyspecificity in germline antibodies. The study provides insights into the molecular basis for the flexibility and diversity of the antibody repertoire.
In this study, the authors developed a continuum model of phase transitions in locust populations. They focused on two behavioral phases: solitary and gregarious. By analyzing the model, the authors found that the density of locusts plays a crucial role in phase transitions. They identified the critical density beyond which gregarious locusts form traveling patches. The authors also found that the ratio of gregarious to solitary locusts depends on the conversion rates between the two phases. They concluded that their model provides a useful framework for understanding the dynamics of phase transitions in locust populations.
Here, we use tick-borne encephalitis (TBE) virus as a model to dissect the class II flavivirus membrane fusion pathway and the associated structural rearrangements of the envelope protein E. We found a monomeric conformation of E that can be postulated as a transient intermediate of the fusion pathway. TBE virus is a member of the flavivirus genus (family Flaviviridae), which encompasses a number of other important human pathogens such as yellow fever, dengue, West Nile, and Japanese encephalitis viruses. Mature flavivirus particles are characterized by an external icosahedral glycoprotein cage formed by 90 dimers of E. The structure of sE in the prefusion form shows that the three domains of sE are aligned along a rod-like molecule, with the C terminus and the fusion peptide (FP) lying at the two distal ends of the molecule. In the postfusion form, as shown in Figure 1E and 1F, DIII is displaced from its original location and thus becomes positioned at the side of DI with its C terminus pointing toward the FP. Under physiological conditions, this process is triggered by the acidic pH in endosomes during receptor-mediated endocytosis and rapidly followed by E trimerization. The monomeric conformation of E is obtained by exposing TBE virions to alkaline pH instead of the physiological acidic pH. Full fusion, however, can be induced by subsequent exposure to acidic pH, leading to hairpin formation and E trimerization, which drive the merger of the two lipid bilayers. The demonstration of a membrane-inserted prehairpin intermediate has important implications for the existing models of class II viral membrane fusion.
In this study, the authors investigate the distribution of extinction risks for two of the best-studied floras, the Cape of South Africa and the United Kingdom, for which practically complete regional Red List data have recently been published. They find that threatened plant species are over-represented within species-poor clades, which suggests a potential link between the processes of speciation and extinction. They also find that plant species' present-day vulnerabilities can be explained by their recent evolutionary past, using detailed phylogenetic data for the Cape to reveal an unusual phylogenetic signal in extinction risks for plants. This signal suggests that species with close evolutionary relationships are more likely to be vulnerable to extinction than those with more distant relationships, supporting the hypothesis that speciation and extinction are coupled. The authors also evaluate the link between speciation mode and extinction risk, finding that species with the fastest diversification rates are also the most vulnerable to extinction. They conclude that these results link speciation and extinction derive from an analysis of the unique flora found within the Cape region of South Africa and might not extrapolate across less diverse biomes with different evolutionary histories. However, they note that the trend for threatened species to fall within species-poor clades has been observed within the relatively depauperate floras of the UK and North America. They suggest that species turnover (speciation and extinction) might be rapid generally for plants, and high extinction rates may not be unusual over evolutionary timescales. Because even rapid speciation occurs over timescales too long for practical management, conservation efforts must focus urgently on reducing rates at which species are lost. They also highlight the importance of considering the key traits linked to high extinction risk when deciding upon conservation priorities, and the need for further research on the drivers of plant extinction.
Dectin-1 is a C-type lectin receptor that plays an important role in the recognition of Candida albicans by macrophages. In this study, the authors identify two novel proteins that interact with Dectin-1 in macrophages: BTK and Vav1. They show that BTK is required for the phagocytosis of C. albicans by macrophages, while Vav1 is required for the recruitment of the cytoskeletal protein actin to the phagocytic cup. They also provide evidence that Dectin-1 and BTK are involved in the recruitment of the signaling molecule PI(3,4)P2 to the phagocytic cup, which is important for the activation of Vav1 and the phagocytosis of C. albicans. These findings provide important insights into the molecular mechanisms that underlie the recognition and phagocytosis of C. albicans by macrophages.
Rift Valley fever ( RVF ) is a virus that affects cattle and humans. The virus has been found in Madagascar and researchers are trying to understand the environment and behaviors that are associated with the virus in order to prevent future outbreaks. The researchers analyzed data from a national survey of cattle and humans in Madagascar in 2008 and 2011-2013. They found that humid environments, high cattle density, and contact with raw milk were associated with the presence of the virus in humans. They also found that high cattle density was associated with the presence of the virus in cattle. Finally, the researchers used computer modeling to predict the areas where the virus is most likely to be found in cattle in Madagascar.
This manuscript describes the use of yeast to study the propagation of prion diseases, which are caused by infectious proteins that replicate themselves through the conversion of host proteins. The study focuses on RNQ1, a protein that is involved in the propagation of two prion diseases in yeast, [PSI+] and [PIN+]. The study finds that RNQ1 contains multiple prion domains that can independently propagate [PIN+] in yeast. The study also finds that the propagation of [PIN+] is not limited to the prion domains that are directly involved in the propagation of [PIN+], but is also influenced by the overall structure of RNQ1. The study provides insights into the mechanisms of prion propagation and highlights the importance of considering the overall structure of prion proteins in understanding their functions.
Deep learning is a powerful modern technique in machine learning that uses multilayer neural networks to learn a feature-based function from input (e.g., hundreds of correlated summary statistics of data) to output (e.g., population genetic parameters of interest). It has been successfully applied to population genetic inference and learning informative features of data. As an example, the authors applied deep learning to jointly infer natural selection and demography, which has not been done before. They found that soft sweeps and balancing selection occur more frequently closer to the centromere of each chromosome.
This paper explains how human papillomavirus (HPV) is linked to cervical cancer and how it is transmitted. It describes the different types of HPV, and the role of the E6 and E7 proteins in the development of cancer. The paper also explains how HPV interacts with the cell cycle and DNA repair pathways, and how it affects cell growth and division. Additionally, the paper discusses the different treatment options for HPV and cervical cancer, including vaccines and chemotherapy.
This research article presents the results of a comprehensive investigation into the elimination of the human onchocerciasis parasite, Onchocerca volvulus, in the Southern Chiapas focus in Mexico. The research team collected data on the prevalence of infective parasites in black flies, as well as the number of people with evidence of infection in their eyes or skin. They also conducted a large-scale serological survey of children to determine the prevalence of antibodies to the Ov16 antigen of O. volvulus. Based on the data collected, the authors conclude that the Southern Chiapas focus has likely achieved transmission interruption, as the prevalence of infective black flies and people with evidence of infection in their eyes or skin have declined dramatically. They also note that the prevalence of antibodies to Ov16 has decreased to near zero in the overall population sample. The authors suggest that ongoing surveillance will be necessary to ensure that transmission interruption is maintained, and that elimination of the parasite is achieved. They also note the importance of maintaining ivermectin treatment, as this is currently the only drug that is effective against O. volvulus.
Listeria monocytogenes is a pathogenic bacterium that causes foodborne illnesses in humans. The bacterium can survive and replicate in various environments, including food and the environment. When ingested by humans, the bacteria can cause illnesses such as listeriosis, which can be fatal in some cases. Understanding how the bacterium adapts to different environments and how it interacts with other organisms is crucial for developing effective strategies to control its spread and prevent illnesses.
In this paper, researchers examined the role of mutS in the survival of Vibrio cholerae in the mouse gut. They found that mutS mutants have a significant advantage in colonization of mice with a low antioxidant treatment, but not in mice with high antioxidant treatment. They also found that the advantage of mutS mutants in colonization is due to an increase in catalase production, rugose colony variants, and a mutation rate that is higher in the gut of mice with low antioxidant treatment. This study suggests that mutS mutants have a selective advantage in the mouse gut under certain conditions, and that this advantage is due to a combination of factors, including increased catalase production and rugose colony variants.
Here we report a comprehensive study of the role of the Mlh1-Mlh3 complex in recombination and crossing over in Saccharomyces cerevisiae. We have used 57 novel mlh3 alleles, including 56 point mutations and one gene deletion, to analyze the structure-function relationships of this complex in vivo. Our findings indicate that the Mlh1-Mlh3 complex plays a central role in the recombination of homologous sequences, as well as the formation of meiotic crossovers. We have also used an integrated approach, combining high-resolution structural analysis with biochemical and genetic studies, to gain a deeper understanding of the mechanisms underlying the functions of this complex. Our results provide important insights into the molecular mechanisms of meiosis and recombination, as well as a framework for further investigation of the role of these processes in human disease.
Intense use of antibiotics has led to a rapid increase in population levels of drug resistance. This has been generally necessary due to low fitness costs of resistance in the absence of treatment. Host contact structure plays a crucial role in the reversion dynamics of drug resistance. It can affect both the dynamics during treatment and the competition dynamics after treatment is stopped. Contact structure affects the distribution of infected hosts and therefore influences the residual network left for the second pathogen to spread. In the absence of treatment, heterogeneous contact structure slows down the reversion process. However, this effect is strongest in the biologically relevant case when fitness differences between sensitive and resistant strains in the absence of treatment are small.
Autism spectrum disorders (ASDs) are complex neurodevelopmental diseases that affect social interaction and communication, and result from a combination of genetic and environmental factors. While a large number of genes associated with ASD have been identified, the genetic basis of ASD is still not well understood. Using Drosophila, a simple yet versatile in vivo model, we investigated the genetic interactions that may contribute to neurological phenotypes like ASD. Specifically, we focused on the unique Drosophila orthologues of genes affected by large structural variations (such as copy number variants) that have been identified in individuals with ASD. We examined synaptic and circadian neurological phenotypes resulting from the dosage variants of unique human:fly orthologues in Drosophila. Our study identified numerous synergistic interactions between pairs of informatically-identified candidate genes whose orthologues are jointly affected by large de novo copy number variants (CNVs) in individuals with ASD. These interactions affect both synaptic and circadian neurological processes, supporting distinct molecular aetiologies. Our results demonstrate how combining information from informatic approaches with experimental validation in vivo can shed light on the underlying genetic mechanisms of complex neurodevelopmental disorders like ASD.
The article titled "Visualization of T cells in the brain during malaria infection" by Johnston et al. describes the use of two-photon microscopy to track T cells within the brain during infection with the rodent malaria parasite P. berghei ANKA. The authors used immunofluorescence and transgenic mice to identify T cells and infected parasites, respectively. They also used a novel CX3CR1-iDTR mouse model to deplete CX3CR1-expressing macrophages. The authors found that T cells accumulate within the brain during infection and that they are not required for parasite development. The authors also found that infected red blood cells are found within perivascular spaces and not the subarachnoid space, as previously thought. They also found that the arrest of T cells within the brain during malaria infection is not due to an increased interaction with infected red blood cells. The authors suggest that further studies are needed to understand the role of T cells during malaria infection.
Tungiasis is a serious skin disease caused by a type of sand flea. It occurs in areas with poor housing, low income, and lack of access to basic sanitation. This study was conducted in Vihiga County in Kenya to determine the prevalence of tungiasis and identify risk factors. A total of 437 participants aged 5 years and above were examined for the presence of tungiasis. The overall prevalence was found to be 21.5% (95% CI: 17.7–25.3%). The study found that people with low monthly income, earthen floor, lack of toilet facilities, age of participant ≤14 years, no regular use of closed footwear, and common resting place inside the house were at higher risk of getting tungiasis. This study has important implications for public health interventions to control and prevent tungiasis.
Auxin is an important hormone that regulates the growth and development of plants. It is involved in many different processes, including root development, lateral root initiation, and shoot gravitropism. The transport of auxin is controlled by a variety of transporters, including the PIN class of efflux transporters and the AUX1/LAX influx transporters. It has been shown that auxin transport is regulated by cytokinins, which are another important class of plant hormones that are involved in processes such as cell division, shoot development, and root growth. The interaction between auxin and cytokinins has been proposed to play an important role in the patterning of the vascular system in plants. In this study, the authors developed a computational model of auxin transport that takes into account the regulation of auxin transport by cytokinins. They used this model to explore the role of cytokinins in the patterning of the vascular system and found that variations in cytokinin levels are not required for correct auxin patterning. Instead, auxin-dependent modifications of cytokinin response are crucial for the necessary feedbacks. The authors also found that hormonal regulation of auxin efflux is important for the robustness of the auxin maximum. These findings provide new insights into the mechanisms underlying vascular patterning in plants.
The study identifies the TF activating NOS transcription in response to population density variation in locusts, uncovering several novel components of the NPF/NO signaling cascade underlying phase-related locomotor plasticity in locusts. The results show that a neural neuropeptide F ( NPF )/nitric oxide ( NO ) signaling pathway plays an essential role in phase-related locomotor plasticity, which results from the sequential changes in the phosphorylation and transcriptional states of nitric oxide synthase ( NOS ) as regulated by NPF1a and NPF2 systems, respectively. The study identifies CREB-B as the TF activating NOS transcription in response to population density variation and shows that NPF2-regulated NOS transcription is responsible for long-term locomotor plasticity. The findings provide insights into the neural mechanisms underlying phase-related locomotor plasticity in locusts.
In this study, the authors investigate the role of Zelda (ZLD), a zinc-finger protein that plays a key role in early development in Drosophila melanogaster, during the maternal-to-zygotic transition (MZT). To do this, they use chromatin immunoprecipitation coupled with high-throughput sequencing (ChIP-Seq) to determine the genomic landscape of ZLD binding as the embryo progresses through the MZT. The authors find that ZLD is bound to a large number of regions throughout the genome at all stages, and that many of these regions do not become active until after the MZT. They also identify a large number of enhancers bound by ZLD at cycle 14 and find that these enhancers are enriched for motifs related to early gene activation. The authors conclude that ZLD is not only required for the earliest wave of transcription but also plays a major role in activating the genome at the MZT.
The circadian clock is a biological system that regulates physiological processes in a 24-hour cycle. These processes, including sleep, hormone production, and body temperature, are controlled by a set of proteins that interact with each other in specific ways. These interactions are crucial for the proper functioning of the clock. However, little is known about the timing of these interactions and how they contribute to the regulation of circadian processes. In this study, the authors used a yeast-two-hybrid approach to identify novel interactions among circadian clock proteins in mammals. They then used molecular and genetic techniques to investigate the timing of these interactions and their effects on circadian processes. The authors found that many of the identified interactions occur at specific times of day, and that these interactions are important for the proper functioning of the circadian clock. Overall, this study provides valuable insights into the mechanisms underlying the regulation of circadian processes in mammals.
Nematode parasite allergens are rare lipid-binding proteins that are produced in large quantities. The authors of this paper have now determined the structure of one of these proteins in solution. Using this structure, they have identified two separate hydrophobic ligand-binding sites within the protein. These sites could be used to target drugs that will reduce the effectiveness of the nematode.
This is a very important paper for me. Please make sure you understand it. This study was about ciguatera, a type of fish poisoning that occurs in tropical and subtropical waters around the world. The study looked at the incidence of ciguatera in the Pacific Island Countries and Territories (PICTs) from 1973 to 2008. It found that there has been a 60% increase in the incidence of ciguatera in the last 35 years. This is a big increase and it raises the status of ciguatera to an acute and chronic illness with major public health significance. The study also looked at the social consequences of ciguatera, such as changing diet and associated medical conditions. It found that ciguatera has a significant impact on the health and well-being of people in the PICTs. This paper has important implications for public health and highlights the need for more research and resources to manage and prevent ciguatera.
Chagas disease is caused by the parasite Trypanosoma cruzi and is a serious health problem in Latin America. In this disease, the immune system does not eliminate the parasite, and it hides in tissues, leading to chronic infection. CD4+CD8+ T cells are a small subset of T cells that express both CD4 and CD8 molecules. In this study, the authors analyzed the role of these cells in the immune response against T . cruzi infection in patients with chronic Chagas disease. They found that the frequency of CD4+CD8+ T cells was higher in patients with Chagas disease than in healthy controls. Additionally, these cells expressed higher levels of inhibitory receptors, which are molecules that inhibit the function of T cells. After treatment with benznidazole, the frequency of CD4+CD8+ T cells decreased, and the expression of inhibitory receptors on these cells also decreased. This suggests that benznidazole treatment may improve the function of CD4+CD8+ T cells against T . cruzi infection. The authors conclude that this study provides important information about the role of CD4+CD8+ T cells in the immune response against T . cruzi infection in patients with chronic Chagas disease and the potential of benznidazole treatment to improve the function of these cells.
This research report describes a comprehensive study on the role of phosphoinositide-specific phospholipase C2 (PLC2) in phosphoinositide metabolism, seedling growth, and ER stress response in Arabidopsis thaliana. The study shows that PLC2 is the primary phosphoinositide-specific PLC in Arabidopsis, which is required for seedling growth. Furthermore, the study demonstrates that the plc2-1 mutant is more sensitive to ER stress than the wild type, and this is attributed to the increased levels of phosphoinositides in the plc2-1 mutant. The findings of this study provide new insights into the roles of PLC2 in phosphoinositide metabolism and ER stress response, and have potential implications for understanding the molecular mechanisms underlying plant growth and development.
The paper is about a new way to measure the causal power of systems. In this approach, the causal power of a system is evaluated by taking into account how much information about the system's past influences its present state, and how much information about the system's present state influences its future. This approach is used to study the relationship between the micro level (atoms and molecules) and the macro level (the behavior of the system as a whole) in a way that is not biased towards either level. By analyzing the information flow within a system, the authors found that macro systems can have higher causal power than micro systems. They also identified local maxima of causal power at different scales of the system, and showed that these local maxima correspond to emergent properties of the system. The authors' approach provides a new framework for understanding the relationship between micro and macro levels in complex systems.
Reactive oxygen species (ROS) are molecules with the ability to react with other molecules, which are produced in the mitochondrial respiratory chain during oxidative phosphorylation, and they play a role in signaling pathways of adaptation to environmental stimuli and in the development of destructive processes in some tissues. The main sources of ROS are complexes I, II, and III of the electron transport chain. The processes of electron transport in complexes I and III are characterized by the participation of quinone-bound proteins of different nature in the reduction of ubiquinone. The electron transport in complexes I and III is accompanied by the translocation of protons across the membrane of the mitochondrion, which leads to the formation of the transmembrane potential difference (ΔΨm). This transmembrane potential difference (ΔΨm) drives the transport of ions across the membrane of the mitochondrion and the synthesis of adenosine triphosphate (ATP). In the model of electron transport in complexes I and III, the reduction of ubiquinone is carried out in two stages. The first stage is characterized by the reduction of ubiquinone to ubiquinol outside the matrix of the mitochondrion, and the second stage is characterized by the reduction of ubiquinol inside the matrix of the mitochondrion. The model takes into account the stoichiometry of electron transport reactions, which describes the number of electrons and protons involved in the reactions. The model was validated by fitting experimental data on the effect of inhibitors of complex I on the rate of electron transport and the synthesis of ATP. The validation of the model showed the importance of the electron transport chain in the synthesis of ATP and the production of ROS. The model can be used as a basis for further study of the interaction between complexes I and III of the electron transport chain and the production of ROS.
In this article, we report the effects of mutations of motor proteins on transport properties of cargo carried by multiple wild-type and mutant motors. Our results indicate that mutants with altered stall forces might determine the average velocity and run-length even when they are outnumbered by wild type motors in the ensemble. We show that mutants gain a competitive advantage and lead to an increase in the expected run-length when the load on the cargo is in the vicinity of the mutant’s stalling force or a multiple of its stalling force. We further develop a semi-analytic method to analyze transport of cargo by multiple motors of multiple types. This technique determines transition rates between various relative configurations of motors carrying the cargo using the transition rates between various absolute configurations. This enables a computation of biologically relevant quantities like average velocity and run-length without resorting to Monte Carlo simulations. Our method is easily implementable and we provide a software package for general use.
In this study, researchers examined how a selective functional ablation of the Cacna1c gene affected the learning process in mice. Using a detailed, individual-level analysis of learning on an operant cue discrimination task, they showed that while both groups of mice (with and without the genetic modification) managed to increase reward feedback across trials, the majority of the KO mice did so by adapting an outcome-based strategy, while the majority of controls adopted the experimentally intended cue-association rule. These results highlight that much more mechanistic insight could be gained by examining response patterns in terms of a larger repertoire of potential behavioral strategies.
This study examines the effects of temperature on the reproductive success of Wolbachia-infected Aedes aegypti mosquitoes. The study found that high temperatures can negatively affect the expression of cytoplasmic incompatibility, a reproductive strategy used by Wolbachia to control arboviral diseases, and can lead to a decrease in the density of Wolbachia in the mosquito host. These findings suggest that the success of Wolbachia as a biological control agent may be influenced by environmental conditions such as temperature.
Adenoviruses are common human pathogens that have also been developed as vectors for gene therapies and genetic vaccines. Researchers wanted to learn more about the natural history of adenovirus infections in different non-human primates. They discovered that healthy populations of chimpanzees, gorillas, orangutans, and macaques shed substantial quantities of infectious adenoviruses in their stool. This shedding was much less frequent in humans. The researchers purified and fully sequenced 30 novel adenoviruses from apes and 3 novel adenoviruses from macaques. They found evidence of recombination between different adenoviruses in the natural history of B and E viruses. Their results show that zoonotic transmissions have occurred in the natural history of adenoviruses and that asymptomatic shedding of live adenoviruses should be considered in the design and interpretation of studies with adenovirus vectors. The high degree of asymptomatic shedding of live adenovirus in non-human primates and evidence for zoonotic transmissions warrants caution for primate handling and housing.
This article describes the use of molecular dynamics simulations to investigate the energetics of unwrapping nucleosomal DNA. The authors performed ABMD simulations with multiple walkers to generate conformational ensembles of the outer-turn unwrapping process and calculated the free-energy profiles. The results suggest that the unwrapping of the outer-turn of nucleosomal DNA costs about 11.5 kcal/mol and occurs asymmetrically, with one end unwrapping while the other remains wrapped. The study provides valuable insights into the dynamics of nucleosomal DNA unwrapping that can be used to improve our understanding of epigenetic regulations and the mechanisms of transcription.
In this study, the authors used a variety of techniques to investigate the role of Apolipoprotein D (ApoD) in neuronal damage caused by oxidative stress. They found that ApoD is endocytosed by astrocytes and localizes to lysosomes, where it plays a protective role by preventing lysosomal membrane permeabilization and mitigating oxidative stress-induced lysosomal alkalinization. The study provides important insights into the protective role of ApoD in neuronal damage caused by oxidative stress and highlights its potential as a therapeutic target for neurodegenerative diseases.
This paper compares the life cycle parameters and susceptibility to Leishmania donovani of two Phlebotomus orientalis colonies from Ethiopia, one from a lowland site and one from a highland site. The authors find that there are differences in life cycle parameters between the two colonies, but no genetic differences. They also find that the two colonies have different susceptibilities to Leishmania donovani, with the highland colony being more susceptible. The authors also report on cross-mating studies and the development of successful F1 hybrids between the two colonies. The paper provides important information on the biology and susceptibility of Phlebotomus orientalis to Leishmania donovani in Ethiopia.
The Chinese government has identified advanced schistosomiasis as a leading public health priority due to its serious health and economic impacts. However, it has not been included in the estimates of schistosomiasis burden in the Global Burden of Disease (GBD) study. Therefore, the quality of life and disability weight (DW) for the advanced cases of schistosomiasis japonica were estimated in a re-estimation of burden of disease due to schistosomiasis. A patient-based questionnaire evaluation was performed for advanced schistosomiasis japonica. Suspected or officially registered advanced cases in a Schistosoma japonicum-hyperendemic county of the People's Republic of China were screened using a short questionnaire and physical examination. Disability and morbidity were assessed in confirmed cases using the European quality of life questionnaire with an additional cognitive dimension (known as the “EQ-5D plus”), ultrasonography, and laboratory testing. The age-specific DW of advanced schistosomiasis japonica was estimated based on patients' self-rated health scores on the visual analogue scale of the questionnaire. The relationships between health status, morbidity and DW were explored using multivariate regression models. Of 506 candidates, 215 cases were evaluated and most of them reported impairments in at least one health dimension such as pain or discomfort, usual activities, and anxiety or depression. The overall DW was 0.447 and age-specific DWs ranged from 0.378 among individuals aged 30–44 years to 0.510 among the elderly aged ≥60 years. DWs are positively associated with loss of work capacity, psychological abnormality, ascites, and active hepatitis B virus, while splenectomy and high albumin were protective factors for quality of life. These patient-preference disability estimates could provide updated data for a revision of the GBD, as well as for evidence-based decision-making in the national schistosomiasis control program in China.
The article describes a study that used national census data to estimate the prevalence of disability in Kenya's tsetse belts. The study aimed to identify whether living in tsetse-endemic areas is associated with an increased prevalence of disability. The study found that individuals living in tsetse-endemic areas had a higher prevalence of disability than those living outside these areas. The study also found that residents of tsetse-endemic areas were more likely to have disability than migrants, and that poverty levels and household characteristics did not significantly affect the prevalence of disability. The study concluded that the tsetse fly's impact on human health occurs via two exposure pathways: directly from the bite of a pathogenic tsetse fly resulting in HAT infection or indirectly, as the potential for AAT takes land out of agricultural production and diseased livestock leads to morbidity and mortality. The study recommends that future research should focus on developing and implementing tsetse control strategies that can address the health and economic impacts of tsetse-endemic areas.
The HIV replication process is activated by various compounds, including hexamethylene bisacetamide (HMBA). In this study, the mechanism by which HMBA activates HIV transcription is explored. The authors found that HMBA activates the PI3K/Akt pathway, which leads to the disruption of the large complex (LC) and the release of the positive transcription elongation factor b (P-TEFb) to the HIV promoter. This results in the transcriptional activation of HIV and the production of new viral particles.
The paper "Detection of Leishmania virus DNA in clinical Leishmania donovani isolates and its application for the prediction of parasite virulence" describes the development of a new method for detecting Leishmania virus DNA in Leishmania donovani parasites. The method involves the use of a monoclonal antibody, J2, which specifically binds to Leishmania virus DNA. The authors demonstrate the sensitivity and specificity of the method using a variety of experimental approaches, including dot blot analysis, immunoblotting, and fluorescence microscopy. They also show that the method can be used to predict the virulence of Leishmania parasites, based on the level of Leishmania virus DNA detected. Overall, this paper provides important new insights into the biology of Leishmania parasites and the role of Leishmania virus in their pathogenesis.
The study investigates the role of pedestals in colonization and pathogenesis of EHEC and EPEC strains. The study shows that the bacterial protein EspFU promotes motility and colonization of EHEC strains on polarized epithelial cells by driving actin polymerization. The study also shows that EspFU does not affect colonization of EPEC strains on polarized cells, but does enhance motility. The study also provides insights into the role of pedestals in colonization and pathogenesis of EPEC and EHEC strains in vivo.
Extracellular vesicles (EVs) are small membrane-bound organelles secreted from cells. They play important roles in cell-to-cell communication and can carry various cargo such as proteins, lipids, and nucleic acids. One common method for isolating EVs is using differential centrifugation, where the samples are centrifuged at different speeds and the EVs are collected from the pellet at the higher speed. However, this method can be time-consuming and may result in contamination of the EVs with other cellular components. An alternative method for isolating EVs is using size exclusion chromatography (SEC), which separates the EVs based on their size. This method is faster and more efficient than differential centrifugation, but it requires a special column and solvent. In this study, we compared the two methods for isolating EVs from the helminth parasite Fasciola hepatica. We found that the SEC method produced smaller and purer EVs than the differential centrifugation method. We also found that the SEC method resulted in less contamination of the EVs with other cellular components. These findings suggest that the SEC method is a more suitable and efficient method for isolating EVs from Fasciola hepatica.
Here we present the details of a reverse engineering study of gap gene patterning in Drosophila embryos. Using experimental data, we built a model of gap gene expression that could be fitted to experimental data using parameter optimization techniques. We identify structural and practical identifiability of the parameters and demonstrate the reliability of our results by fitting the same model to independent data sets. Our results suggest that post-transcriptional regulation is not required for the correct patterning of gap genes in Drosophila embryos.
In this study, the authors investigated the role of the innate immune system in the age-dependent susceptibility to rotavirus infection. They found that the expression of the Toll-like receptor 3 ( TLR3 ), which is important for recognizing dsRNA molecules, is upregulated in the intestinal epithelium of neonatal mice compared to adults. In contrast, the expression of TLR7 was unchanged, while the expression of the retinoic acid-inducible gene 1 ( RIG1 ) and melanoma differentiation-associated gene 5 ( MDA5 ) were increased in the intestinal epithelium of neonatal mice compared to adults. The authors also found that the expression of the type I interferon-inducible genes interferon-beta ( IFN-β ) and interferon-lambda 2/3 ( IFN-λ2/3 ) was higher in neonatal mice than in adults. They further showed that Trif-deficient mice had higher viral shedding and lower epithelial expression of proinflammatory and antiviral genes compared to wild-type mice. The authors suggest that age-dependent changes in innate immune signaling contribute to the age-dependent susceptibility to rotavirus infection.
The paper "Large-Scale Analysis of Autism Spectrum Disorders Associated Rare Variants" reports the findings of a genome-wide analysis of rare variants associated with autism spectrum disorders (ASD). The analysis involved whole-exome sequencing of 1,039 individuals with ASD and 870 controls, selected to be of similar ancestry. The study aimed to investigate whether the power of rare variant analysis could be improved by combining data from multiple centers and sequencing platforms. The analysis found that mega-analysis, which involves combining all the data together for analysis, had greater power than meta-analysis, which involves combining p-values from each center separately. The study also found that principal component analysis (PCA) was effective in correcting for population structure in the analysis. Overall, the study suggests that combining data from multiple centers and sequencing platforms can improve the power of rare variant analysis for ASD.
Madurella mycetomatis is a fungus that causes a rare disease called eumycetoma in humans. This disease is characterized by the formation of grains. Many people are exposed to this fungus, but only a small number develop the disease. The fungus has chitin in its cell wall, which can trigger the immune system. Some people have genetic polymorphisms that affect their ability to fight against this fungus. In this study, researchers looked at four genetic polymorphisms that affect chitinase activity in people with eumycetoma caused by M. mycetomatis. They found that a polymorphism that results in decreased chitotriosidase activity was associated with an increased risk of eumycetoma. No association was found for the polymorphisms in the genes for AMCase. The researchers believe that their findings could help in the development of new treatments for eumycetoma caused by M. mycetomatis.
Researchers have discovered that HSV-1, a herpesvirus that causes cold sores and other infections, has a more complex life cycle than previously thought. It was found that HSV-1 can persist in the body in a dormant state, and that it can reactivate at any time. This discovery has important implications for the treatment and prevention of HSV-1 infections.
The present study aimed to compare the cellular association of PrPSc from three different mouse-adapted scrapie strains with astroglia and neurons in the thalamus during early disease progression. For this purpose, we used dual-staining immunohistochemistry to compare PrPSc from 22L, RML, and ME7 strains with astroglial and neuronal markers in the thalamus at the onset of prion disease in mice. In addition, we used quantitative real-time polymerase chain reaction (qRT-PCR) to analyze the neuroinflammatory response associated with each strain. Our results show that PrPSc accumulation in the thalamus of mice infected with different strains of scrapie was associated with different cellular types. Surprisingly, despite differences in cell-association of PrPSc among the strains, all three strains had similar patterns of upregulation of genes associated with neuroinflammation. These data suggest that cellular association of PrPSc may not be an important determinant of the neuroinflammatory response in the thalamus during early stages of prion disease in mice.
This manuscript describes a new method for building coarse-grained null models for chromosomes that takes into account both the polymer entanglement length and the volumic density. The authors demonstrate that their method allows for efficient simulations of long chromosomes during an extended time period while maintaining the correct structural and dynamical properties. They then apply their method to investigate the role of epigenomic-driven interactions in the folding and dynamics of drosophila genome. The manuscript provides a detailed description of the methods and includes a lay summary of the provided content.
We used Bayesian regression to identify genome-wide significant cis-eQTLs in 11 studies. We then used LD-based allelic heterogeneity analysis to characterize cis-regulatory elements associated with eQTLs. Finally, we used multi-task Bayesian regression to identify regulatory elements associated with multiple eQTLs in different cell types.
In order to create stable cell lines that produce bnAb, we have used the CRISPR/Cas9 technology to knockout the gene for mannose receptor A (MRA) in the CHO-S cell line. This gene is responsible for the formation of Man5-type glycans, which are the target of the bnAb. The knockout was achieved using a plasmid containing the guide RNA sequence and the Cas9 protein, which are introduced into the cells using an electroporation method. The efficiency of the knockout was confirmed by DNA sequencing and western blotting. The cells were then transfected with a plasmid containing the gene sequence for gp120, a protein that makes up the envelope glycoprotein of HIV-1. This protein was modified to express Man3-type glycans, which are also recognized by the bnAb. The resulting cell lines were tested for their ability to produce the bnAb and found to be stable and produce the bnAb at levels comparable to the parental line. The cells were also tested for their ability to produce other bnAbs and found to be stable and produce the bnAb at levels comparable to the parental line. Overall, this study demonstrates that the use of CRISPR/Cas9 technology can be used to create stable cell lines that produce bnAbs.
Tropical diseases such as filariasis and lymphatic filariasis are caused by nematodes, and are a major cause of disability and social and economic burden in developing countries. The causative nematodes, Wuchereria bancrofti and Brugia malayi, are transmitted to humans by mosquitoes. The molecular mechanisms underlying the action of anthelmintic drugs on these nematodes are poorly understood. We have identified a highly conserved mitochondrial HAD domain in the H. polymera parasite that binds to T6PP, a mitochondrial protein that plays a central role in the production of trehalose, a key component of the worm’s life cycle. We have determined the crystal structure of the complex between H. polymera T6PP and T6P, and have shown that the HAD domain binds to the phosphate group of T6P with a high affinity. We have also found that the drug albendazole targets the T6PP-T6P complex. Our results suggest that the HAD domain of T6PP may be a potential target for the development of new drugs against helminths.
We developed a computational framework that simulates vascular blood and interstitial fluid transport in whole tumours. The model is able to simulate spatially heterogeneous blood vessel architectures and, for the first time, takes into account the influence of vascular permeability on interstitial fluid transport. The model is able to accurately predict interstitial fluid flow in vivo, which is currently difficult to achieve with conventional experimental techniques.
The study highlights the importance of neutralizing antibodies (nAbs) and entry inhibitors in preventing HIV-1 infection during cell-cell transmission. The study shows that the neutralization activity of nAbs is significantly diminished during cell-cell transmission, but can be restored by including polycationic compounds in the medium, which allow cell-cell transmission to occur in the absence of free virus. The study also demonstrates the importance of inhibitors in preventing cell-cell transmission and shows that the activity of entry inhibitors is dependent on the mode of transmission. The study provides insights into the mechanism of cell-cell transmission and the role of neutralizing antibodies and entry inhibitors in preventing infection during cell-cell transmission.
This paper presents a simple mechanistic model that explains how a top-down attentional signal modulates visual responses in higher areas of the visual hierarchy. The model proposes that attentional modulation arises from feedforward connections from lower areas and feedback connections from higher areas. The model is implemented as a reciprocally connected square lattice of cells with short-range lateral inhibition. The attentional signal modifies the feedforward and feedback connections between cells, leading to shifts in RF position and size, as well as biased competition between neighboring cells. The model successfully reproduces the attentional effects on response rates and receptive field structure that have been observed in both visual areas V1 and V4.
The posterior signaling center (PSC) controls hematopoietic progenitor (hemocyte) homeostasis in the Drosophila larval hematopoietic organ, the lymph gland. The JAK/STAT signaling pathway is involved in this process, and the receptor Latran (Lat) acts as a negative regulator of this pathway.
The study is about the patterns of recombination that occur during infections of plants with two viruses from the same family and how they can be influenced by the evolutionary history of the viruses. The authors discovered that recombinant viruses sampled from natural infections have non-random patterns of recombination that are consistent with the existence of selection acting to maintain some of the existing interactions in the parental viruses. This selection could be acting to maintain the stability of the viral genomes or the encoded proteins. The study provides important insights into how recombination can influence the evolution of viruses.
In this article, the authors explore the relationship between nucleosomes and sequence evolution. Nucleosomes, which are the basic repeat units of eukaryotic chromatin, are believed to play an important role in regulating gene expression and other cellular processes. The authors suggest that nucleosomes may also influence the evolution of eukaryotic genomes, both by altering the propensity of DNA to mutate and by selection acting to maintain or exclude nucleosomes in particular locations. They find that despite some differences in the way that nucleosomes are assembled in humans and the model archaeon Haloferax volcanii, the association between nucleosome footprints and sequence evolution is remarkably conserved between the two kingdoms. The authors then examine whether selection or mutation can explain this association and find that neither model is sufficient to explain the observed patterns. Instead, they suggest that nucleosome repositioning is both necessary and largely sufficient to explain the relationship between current nucleosome positions and biased substitution patterns.
We propose a procedure to identify key positions in a protein that are dynamically important for its function. These key positions are identified by analyzing normal modes associated to the conformational change upon ligand binding. We find that key positions are mostly buried aliphatic residues localized in well-structured regions of the protein such as β-sheets and α-helices.
The article is about the role of the enzyme fructose-1 , 6-bisphosphate aldolase (FBA) in Mycobacterium tuberculosis ( Mtb ). The authors of the article used a special genetic switch to control the expression of FBA in Mtb and found that FBA is essential for the survival of Mtb in both the acute and chronic phases of infection in mice. They also found that FBA is essential for the growth of Mtb on single carbon sources, but not on mixtures of carbon sources. To study the role of FBA in Mtb, the authors used a conditional fba knockout ( Δfba ) Mtb strain that can express FBA in response to anhydrotetracycline (atc). They found that Mtb lacking FBA can only grow on mixtures of glucose and butyrate, and that this growth is dependent on the ability of Mtb to co-catabolize glucose and butyrate. The authors also studied the role of FBA in the survival of Mtb in vivo by using a fba knockout ( Δfba ) Mtb strain and a fba complemented ( Δfba +fba ) Mtb strain. They found that Mtb lacking FBA can survive in the lungs of mice, but that the survival of Mtb lacking FBA is reduced compared to Mtb expressing FBA. The authors also found that Mtb lacking FBA can survive in the spleens of mice, but that the survival of Mtb lacking FBA is reduced compared to Mtb expressing FBA. Overall, the article provides important insights into the role of FBA in the survival and growth of Mtb, and may have implications for the development of new drugs to treat tuberculosis.
Two-cysteine peroxiredoxins, also known as TRXs, are redox-active proteins that play key roles in the detoxification of reactive oxygen species (ROS) and the maintenance of redox homeostasis in living cells. In this study, the authors investigate the function of a two-cysteine peroxiredoxin, mTXNPx, which is found in the cytosol and mitochondria of Leishmania infantum promastigotes. They find that mTXNPx is essential for parasite survival and virulence in the mammalian host, but that it can be replaced by the mammalian TRX, TRX1, in the mitochondria. The authors also suggest that mTXNPx has a chaperone-like function that is required for the maintenance of kinetoplast DNA (kDNA) integrity in the promastigote stage of the parasite's life cycle.
The Histoplasma urine antigen (HUAg) test is a way to diagnose progressive disseminated histoplasmosis (PDH) in HIV patients. This test is commonly used in the United States, but not in Mexico. In 2007, a new version of the HUAg test was approved for clinical use, but it is considered less accurate than the original version. In this study, we evaluated the accuracy of the new HUAg test for diagnosing PDH in HIV patients in Mexico. We conducted a prospective study in seven hospitals, including 295 patients. The results of the study showed that the new HUAg test had a sensitivity of 67% and a specificity of 97%, which means that it is not as accurate as the original version. Despite this, it may still be useful for diagnosing PDH in HIV patients, especially in regions without access to the original version of the test.
In this study, the authors used a "micro-mass sequencing" approach to characterize the eukaryotic viral communities present in diarrhea specimens from 12 children. They detected known enteric viruses, as well as multiple sequences from putatively novel viruses with only limited sequence similarity to viruses in GenBank. The authors' findings provide evidence for the detection of known and novel viruses during episodes of diarrhea and highlight the potential of metagenomic sequencing to identify previously unrecognized etiologic agents of diarrheal disease.
The Zika virus and the dengue virus are both spread by the same type of mosquito, Aedes aegypti. Both viruses cause significant health problems, but the Zika virus causes a rare condition called microcephaly in babies. Researchers looked at how the two viruses spread in the Dominican Republic. They found that the Zika virus spread more widely among women than men. Women were also more likely to get sick than men. However, there is evidence that men are more likely to get Guillain-Barre syndrome, a rare condition that affects the nervous system. The study also looked at how the reproductive number, a measure of how many people each person with the virus infects, is different for the two viruses. The reproductive number was higher for Zika than for dengue. The researchers recommend that media campaigns and screening be done for women during Zika outbreaks to help reduce the spread of the virus.
