The Arabidopsis genome encodes three PARP proteins that carry a PARP signature motif, as well as RCD1 and five SRO ( “Similar to RCD One” ) proteins with a variant form of the PARP signature. The product of the Arabidopsis At2g31320 gene ( NCBI NP_850165.1 ) is herein called PARP1, and the Arabidopsis At4g02390 product ( NCBI NP_192148.2 ) is PARP2. The Arabidopsis parp1-1 and parp1-2 mutants are fertile but exhibit increased sensitivity to DNA-damaging chemicals and to the bacterial pathogen Pseudomonas syringae . The Arabidopsis parp2 mutants are fertile and exhibit a mild DNA damage sensitivity, but have a more robust defense against Pseudomonas syringae infection and are less sensitive to DNA damaging chemicals . The Arabidopsis parg1 and parg2 mutants exhibit normal growth but increased sensitivity to DNA damaging chemicals and the bacterial pathogen Pseudomonas syringae infection. However, the parg1 mutants have more severe phenotypes in terms of growth, development and flowering time, and are less sensitive to DNA damaging chemicals and Pseudomonas syringae infection than the parg2 mutants. The expression of Arabidopsis PARP1/2 and PARG1/2 was observed under normal conditions and after exposure to DNA-damaging chemicals, the bacterial pathogen Pseudomonas syringae infection, or ionizing radiation. The subcellular localization of PARP1/2 and PARG1/2 proteins was examined in transgenic Arabidopsis plants expressing C-terminal fusions to GFP. The results revealed that PARP1/2 and PARG1/2 proteins are predominantly localized in the nucleus under normal conditions. However, after exposure to DNA-damaging chemicals, the bacterial pathogen Pseudomonas syringae infection, or ionizing radiation, PARP1/2 proteins were observed to accumulate in the nucleus and the cytoplasm, while PARG1/2 proteins were observed to accumulate in the nucleus and the cytoplasm. This suggests that PARP1/2 and PARG1/2 proteins may play different roles in response to different types of stress.
The article "A New MAPK Signaling Pathway Regulates Presynaptic Branching in Mechanosensory Neurons" by the authors S. M. Trudeau et al. presents a study on the development of glutamatergic synapses in C. elegans. The authors discovered a new MAPK signaling pathway that regulates presynaptic branching in mechanosensory neurons. The pathway consists of MIG-15, NSY-1, JNK-1, and JKK-1 and acts as a parallel opposing pathway to RPM-1. The authors also used behavioral assays to show that the pathway regulates short-term learning. Their findings provide insights into the mechanisms of presynaptic branching and synaptic development.
Researchers have identified a new bipotential transcription factor called TRR-1 that controls the development of sperm and oocytes in the nematode worm Caenorhabditis briggsae. The discovery suggests that the sex-determination switch in this species can evolve rapidly over short periods of time. This study has important implications for our understanding of how the sex-determination system works in different species of worms, as well as for our understanding of how the switch can evolve over time.
Integrated Information is a measure of the information that a system generates beyond the sum of its individual parts. It is defined as the reduction of entropy that occurs when a system transitions between states. Integrated information is important because it may reflect levels of consciousness generated by neural systems. However, the previous definition of integrated information is only applicable to discrete Markovian systems, which are uncommon in biology. In this paper, we present new measures of integrated information, called integrated information empirical (ΦE) and integrated information auto-regressive (ΦAR), that are practical for time-series data and are applicable to continuous or discrete systems, Markovian or otherwise. These measures can help examine information integration in real and model systems, and provide insights into the relationships between integrated information, consciousness, and other neurocognitive processes.
Rhodesian HAT ( Trypanosoma rhodesiense ) is a deadly disease caused by sleeping sickness parasites that affect humans and animals. It is endemic in Uganda's eastern and northern regions. A new approach to modelling the spatial distribution of HAT is presented in this article. The approach is based on spatial generalized linear models and Bayesian inference, and it incorporates spatial autocorrelation. The model was applied to a dataset of Rhodesian HAT cases and environmental, climatic, and social variables. The results showed that the movement of untreated, infected livestock was associated with the spread of HAT into the affected districts. This study provides a rigorous analytical approach for identifying the factors that influence the spatial distribution of Rhodesian HAT, which can be used to inform disease control efforts.
The paper challenges the long-held belief that the "complexity begets stability" principle applies to ecosystems. The authors argue that this assumption, which was made decades ago, has not been tested and may not be valid. They provide analytical results and simulations that show that the probability of a system being stable decreases as the number of species in the system increases. The authors also show that the stability of the system depends on the strength and intensity of the interactions between species, as well as on the structure of the network. They conclude that a better understanding of ecosystem dynamics requires focusing on the interplay between these factors.
Q fever is a disease caused by the bacterium Coxiella burnetii. It is an infectious disease that affects both humans and animals, particularly cattle and sheep. This study was conducted in Western Kenya to assess the seroprevalence of Q fever in humans and cattle and determine the socio-economic, demographic and environmental factors correlated with exposure in humans and cattle. A cross-sectional survey was conducted, and the study area was selected to represent the Lake Victoria basin ecosystem with a predominantly crop-livestock production system. A total of 1365 cattle and 416 households were included in the study. Seropositivity was assessed using antibody ELISA methods. Questionnaires were administered to collect information on household, individual human, and individual cattle level factors. Covariate datasets were obtained to provide information on a range of external factors thought to be relevant for C . burnetii exposure. Spatial analysis was carried out to assess the spatial patterns of seropositivity in humans and cattle. The results suggest that cattle obtained from market and those residing in areas with lower precipitation levels have the highest sero-prevalence. For humans , the youngest age group had the highest odds of seropositivity, and variations were observed between ethnic groups. Frequent livestock contact ( specifically grazing and dealing with abortion material ) was also a risk factor. These results illustrate endemicity of C . burnetii in western Kenya , although prevalence is relatively low. The analysis indicates that while environmental factors may play a role in cattle exposure patterns , human exposure patterns are likely to be driven more strongly by livestock contacts. The implication of livestock markets in cattle exposure risks suggests these may be a suitable target for interventions.
This manuscript describes the identification and characterization of three novel genes encoding DEAD-box RNA helicases in the schistosome S. mansoni. These genes are predicted to be involved in processes such as transcription, translation, and ribosomal biogenesis, and may be useful as markers for germline cells in schistosomes. The authors use multiple approaches to characterize these genes, including phylogenetic analysis, gene structure analysis, and quantitative reverse transcription-PCR to determine expression patterns. They also perform whole mount in situ hybridization to visualize the expression of these genes in different developmental stages of S. mansoni. Overall, this work provides important insights into the structure and function of DEAD-box RNA helicases in schistosomes and may have implications for the development of new diagnostic or therapeutic targets for schistosomiasis.
The Hippo signaling pathway helps regulate tissue growth, homeostasis, and organ size. In this study, researchers found that the transcription cofactor VGLL4 was expressed in heart valve interstitial cells and was important for heart valve development and homeostasis. They discovered that loss of VGLL4 in endothelial lineage led to valve malformation, but loss of VGLL4 in neural crest lineage did not affect valve development. They also found that VGLL4 regulated Hippo components and that loss of VGLL4 led to hyperproliferation of valve interstitial cells. These findings suggest that manipulating the Hippo pathway could be a potential therapy for preventing the progression of congenital valve disease.
Recently, there has been a lot of excitement over the evidence that natural selection is acting on standing variation in humans, great apes, and other species. However, it is not clear how much of this variation is actually neutral and how much is beneficial. In this study, we examined the evidence for selective sweeps on standing variation using the statistic H-statistics, which looks at how segregating sites at a locus change over time. We simulated genetic data and looked at how well H-statistics can distinguish between different types of evolutionary events. Our results show that H-statistics is not a very reliable way to distinguish between different types of evolutionary events. We also looked at how well H-statistics can distinguish between populations with different demographic histories. We found that H-statistics is not very reliable at this either. Finally, we looked at how well H-statistics can distinguish between populations with different selection pressures. We found that H-statistics is not very reliable at this either. Overall, our results suggest that H-statistics is not a very reliable way to identify selective sweeps on standing variation.
We identified four new npylr1s in Ae. aegypti and investigated their roles in the host-seeking behavior of mosquitoes. We show that only npylr1A is required for host-seeking behavior, and that it is regulated by Head Peptide-I, a pheromone that modulates mosquito behavior. We also show that NPYLR1 is not required for feeding or oviposition. We found that all four npylr1s are expressed at low levels in adult mosquitoes, suggesting that other receptors may also play a role in host-seeking behavior.
This study aimed at generating a predictive risk model for schistosomiasis at a local level by analyzing satellite-derived environmental data using different techniques. Environmental factors such as temperature, rainfall, elevation, land use, slope, drainage, normalized difference vegetation index (NDVI), and building density were reclassified and standardized into four levels of risk, namely very low, low, moderate, and high risk. These risk factors were then weighted using a pairwise comparison method to derive the mapping weight or importance of each individual schistosomiasis risk factor. The weighted overlay analysis in ArcGIS was used to generate the schistosomiasis risk zones. Buildings were geocoded and selected for urine collection. House-to-house sample collection was preceded by an interactive meeting of the researcher and village heads to explain the purpose of the survey. Each participant was given a clean 50cm3 wide-mouthed, screw-capped specimen bottles to supply terminal urine produced between 10:00am and 2:00pm. The samples were preserved on collection by adding 5ml of 10% formalin at the point of collection and carried to the laboratory. In the laboratory, each sample bottle was agitated to suspend the ova evenly in urine, and 10ml of the urine was transferred with a sterile disposable syringe to a centrifuge tube and centrifuged for 5 minutes at 1500rpm. The supernatant was discarded, and the sediment was transferred onto a microscope slide. A drop of Lugol’s iodine was added and neatly covered with a cover slip. The slide was examined under the microscope for eggs of S . haematobium. When present, the individual was classified as positive for schistosomiasis. Chi-square statistical analysis was used to test for significant difference between communities and prevalence of infection.
This study found that the delta6 mutant of pneumolysin, which cannot form pores, did not produce any significant changes in the neocortex of infected mice. However, wild-type pneumolysin caused significant dendritic spine loss and synaptic number reduction in the neocortex. These effects were dependent on the pore-forming activity of pneumolysin and could be blocked by pore-blocking drugs. The study also found that pneumolysin caused dendritic spine loss and synaptic number reduction in primary mouse astrocytes in vitro, and this effect was also dependent on the pore-forming activity of pneumolysin. These findings suggest that the pore-forming activity of pneumolysin plays an important role in causing neocortical damage in meningitis.
Papillomaviruses (HPVs) are a group of viruses that can cause cancer. They need to infect cells that are dividing, and this happens in the basal layer of the skin. However, the reason for this is not well understood. In this study, researchers used infectious HPV particles to infect G1-synchronized human keratinocytes and found that the cells need to be in early M phase to be infected. The cells at early M phase are the ones that are best able to be infected, and this is because they are able to take up the virus particles. The researchers also found that mitosis is important for infection to occur. This study provides important information about the life cycle of HPVs and how they can infect cells. It can help to develop new ways to prevent HPV infections, which are important because HPV is a major risk factor for cancer.
The article "Discovering the Roles of MilRNAs in Fungal Dimorphism" explains the discovery of microRNA-like (miRNA) genes in the dimorphic fungus P. marneffei, which causes Penicilliosis in humans. Researchers have identified 24 potential milRNAs in this fungus and have shown that they are differentially expressed in the yeast and mycelial forms of the fungus. They have also generated knockout mutants of these miRNA genes and shown that they are involved in the regulation of fungal dimorphism. This discovery provides new insights into the mechanisms underlying fungal dimorphism and has implications for the development of new drugs to treat penicilliosis.
In 2013, Zika virus (ZIKV) emerged in French Polynesia and spread throughout the Pacific region between 2013 and 2017. Several potential Aedes mosquitoes may have contributed to the ZIKV transmission, including Aedes aegypti, the main arbovirus vector in the region, and Aedes polynesiensis, a vector of lymphatic filariasis and secondary vector of dengue virus. The aim of this study was to analyze the ability of these two Pacific vector populations to transmit ZIKV at a regional scale by evaluating and comparing the vector competence of wild Aedes aegypti and Aedes polynesiensis populations from different Pacific islands for a ZIKV strain that circulated in the region during the 2013–2017 outbreak. Three populations of Aedes aegypti from New Caledonia (West Pacific), Samoa (Center), and French Polynesia (East) were analyzed, as well as two populations of Aedes polynesiensis from Wallis (from the Territory of Wallis and Futuna Islands, Center) and Tahiti (French Polynesia, East). Female mosquitoes were exposed to ZIKV and analyzed at 6, 9, 14, and 21 days post-infection to measure infection, dissemination, and transmission rates. The results revealed a low vector competence of both species for ZIKV at a regional scale. The study suggests that other factors, such as vector density, mosquito lifespan, and large immunologically naive fractions of the population, may have contributed to the rapid spread of ZIKV in the Pacific region during the 2013–2017 outbreak. The results of this study have important implications for future ZIKV research and control efforts in the Pacific region.
The authors present Targeted Structure-Seq, a novel method for probing and sequencing RNA structures in mammalian cells. This approach uses chemical probing of RNA in vivo, followed by sequencing, to provide detailed information about RNA secondary structures in their natural context. The authors apply this approach to Xist, a long noncoding RNA that is critical for proper dosage of imprinted genes. They find that the repeat A region of Xist is structured in cells, and identify new conserved structural elements in Xist, including a new evolutionarily conserved element near the C repeats that is important for Xist function. Overall, this study provides a powerful new tool for probing RNA structures in vivo and for studying their functions.
We present a new framework for the statistical analysis of genetic risk prediction models. The framework is based on the liability threshold model, which assumes an underlying liability that is normally distributed. We use this model to define a variety of indices for the evaluation of prediction models, including the area under the curve (AUC), net reclassification improvement, integrated discrimination improvement, and variance explained. We also derive graphs for visualizing the performance of risk models. These graphs include the ROC curve, predictiveness curve, and reclassification table. We use this framework to simulate the performance of a hypothetical genetic model for prostate cancer and compare it to a simulated perfect model. Our results show that the AUC is a useful metric for the evaluation of genetic risk prediction models, but it does not take into account the absolute risk of disease. We propose that the variance explained and discrimination slope should also be used to evaluate genetic risk prediction models. The variance explained measures the proportion of total variance in liability that is explained by the genetic marker, while the discrimination slope measures the difference in predicted risks between cases and non-cases. Our framework provides a unifying framework for the statistical analysis of genetic risk prediction models.
This study compares the accuracy of two rapid diagnostic tests (RDTs) for detecting Trypanosoma brucei gambiense infections in passive and active screening. The RDT1 was previously validated in independent studies, while RDT2 is a new prototype test developed in a partnership with FIND. Both tests use recombinant antigens expressed in E. coli or baculovirus. A total of 57,632 individuals were screened in the DRC using the three screening tests, with 260 confirmed HAT cases. The sensitivity of RDT1 and RDT2 was 62.5% and 71.2%, respectively, with RDT2 being non-inferior to RDT1. Both tests had higher sensitivity in active than in passive screening. The specificity of RDT1 and RDT2 was 98.9% and 98.1%, respectively, with RDT2 being less specific than RDT1. Overall, the study suggests that RDT2 is as accurate as RDT1 for detecting T. brucei gambiense infections, but has lower specificity.
Chagas disease is a major health threat in Latin America, and Guatemala has been successful in controlling it. However, there are still some areas with persistent infestations, including the municipality of Comapa in Jutiapa Department. We evaluated the effects of the Chagas control program on infestation and human seroprevalence in Comapa, using three cross-sectional entomological and serological surveys spanning a 15-year period. We found that after multiple rounds of IRS interventions, the infestation index decreased significantly from 39% to 27%. However, seroprevalence in women of child-bearing age remains >10%, which poses a threat to the 2022 Chagas disease elimination goal. We also found that vector-borne transmission is a major risk factor for persistent infestation, especially at higher altitudes. Our study highlights the need for integrated vector control and improved Chagas disease screening and treatment programs for congenital and vector-borne disease to reach the elimination goal in regions with persistent vector infestation.
This article describes a study on the bacterium Citrobacter rodentium, a model organism for understanding the pathogenesis of enteric bacteria. The authors sequenced the genomes of multiple C. rodentium isolates and identified differences between them. They found evidence of genomic rearrangements, including deletions, insertions, and duplications, that may have contributed to the virulence of the organism. The authors also identified differences in the expression of genes involved in the regulation of virulence factors, suggesting that these factors may play a role in the pathogenesis of C. rodentium.
The article you provided is a scientific paper called "Stochastic fluctuations in gene expression underlie distributions of protein levels across cell populations." The paper proposes a method for inferring the molecular mechanisms that underlie the shape of protein distributions in a population of cells from stochasticity in protein expression. The method involves deriving analytical solutions for the first four moments of the protein distribution, finding that these four moments completely capture the shape of protein distributions, and developing an efficient algorithm for inferring gene expression rate constants from the moments of protein distributions. The authors test the algorithm and find that it can identify most protein distributions as a large number of different biochemical rate constant sets. The paper provides a detailed mathematical framework for understanding stochastic fluctuations in gene expression and their impact on protein distribution.
Monkeypox virus (MPXV) is a rare but serious disease that can cause fever, rash, swollen lymph nodes, and respiratory problems. Scientists have been working to develop a vaccine against MPXV, which is a member of the orthopoxvirus family of viruses. A recent study published in PLOS ONE describes the development of a vaccine against MPXV using a modified version of the vaccinia virus (MVA). The MVA vaccine was tested in mice, and the results showed that it was effective in protecting against MPXV infection.
Trypanosomes are flagellated protozoans that are the causative agents of several parasitic diseases affecting humans and livestock. The removal of unnecessary introns is a crucial step in the maturation of messenger RNA (mRNA) in eukaryotic cells, and is catalyzed by the decapping enzyme DCP2. However, in trypanosomes, DCP2 and other decapping enzymes are absent, and this species has evolved a novel mechanism for mRNA decapping. In this paper, the authors identify a new protein, ALPH1, which is necessary for the release of m7G from the 5' end of mRNA. The authors demonstrate that ALPH1 can sensitize a capped RNA to the ribonuclease Xrn1 in the presence of a 5' polyphosphatase. They also show that ALPH1 localizes to a specific granule at the posterior pole of the cell, which contains the Xrn1 ribonuclease. The authors propose that ALPH1 may be the missing decapping enzyme in trypanosomes.
The study presents research on converting adult alpha cells in the pancreas to beta-like cells through the use of gene expression. The study used a combination of conditional loss-of-function and lineage tracing approaches to show that the selective inhibition of the Arx gene in alpha cells promotes the conversion of adult alpha cells into beta-like cells at any age. The study also showed that this conversion induces the continuous mobilization of duct-lining precursor cells to adopt an endocrine cell fate. The study suggests that Arx represents the main trigger of alpha cell-mediated beta-like cell neogenesis. Additionally, the study shows that the loss of Arx in alpha cells is sufficient to regenerate a functional beta-cell mass and reverse diabetes following toxin-induced beta-cell depletion. Overall, the study suggests that strategies aiming at inhibiting the expression of Arx or its molecular targets/co-factors may pave new avenues for the treatment of diabetes.
In this study, we examine the replication of specific yeast origins of replication in the absence of the Sir2 and Fkh1 proteins. We find that the replication of some origins is promoted while others are inhibited in the absence of these proteins. We also find that the Sir2 and Fkh1 proteins act in a non-local manner and promote the efficient replication of origins throughout the genome.
Entamoeba histolytica is a parasite that causes a potentially life-threatening disease in humans. The disease can spread through ingestion of contaminated food or water, or through sexual contact. HIV-1-infected men who have sex with men (MSM) are at increased risk of amebic diseases. In this study, we examined the clinical features and epidemiology of amebic diseases in HIV-1-infected Japanese patients. The patients were diagnosed with amebic diseases based on various criteria, including PCR (polymerase chain reaction) testing. The study found that clinical presentation of amebic diseases in HIV-1-infected patients was similar to that in the normal host. High fever, leukocytosis, and high CRP (C-reactive protein) were associated with extraluminal amebic diseases. The study also examined the efficacy of metronidazole and tinidazole treatment, as well as luminal treatment, in preventing recurrence of amebic diseases. The results suggest that luminal treatment following metronidazole or tinidazole treatment does not reduce the recurrence of amebic diseases in high-risk populations, such as HIV-1-infected men who have sex with men. This may be due to amebic re-infection. The study highlights the importance of ongoing research to better understand the causes and treatment of amebic diseases, particularly in high-risk populations.
This study aimed to evaluate the impact of tsetse control using tiny targets on the incidence of Gambian sleeping sickness (HAT) in Mandoul, Chad. The study was conducted in three phases: a pre-intervention survey to assess the baseline distribution of tsetse; an entomological intervention to reduce the population of tsetse using tiny targets; and a post-intervention survey to assess the impact of tsetse control on the population of tsetse and the incidence of HAT. The pre-intervention survey revealed that the vector is Glossina fuscipes fuscipes, with a mean catch of tsetse from traps of 0.7 flies/trap/day. After tsetse control commenced, the mean catch declined to 0.005 flies/trap/day, indicating a reduction in the tsetse population. Mathematical modelling was used to assess the impact of vector control on HAT incidence, showing that 70.4% of the reduction in reported cases between 2013 and 2015 can be attributed to vector control, with the rest due to medical intervention. The study suggests that tiny targets have contributed to a substantial reduction in tsetse populations in the Mandoul focus, which may have interrupted transmission and contributed to a significant reduction in the incidence of HAT.
This study is about imported strongyloidiasis in Spain. It is a type of parasite that can live inside a person's body for a long time without being reinfected, and it causes a variety of problems. The study included 1,245 cases of imported strongyloidiasis from 2009 to 2017 in Spain. Most of the patients were immigrants, and the most common area of origin was South America. The parasite was diagnosed through various methods, including stool samples, serology tests, and other medical tests. The study found that the most strongly associated factor for achieving a cure was treatment with ivermectin compared to albendazole. The study recommends that screening for S . stercoralis infection should be mandatory in patients coming from or traveling to endemic areas, especially in those with immunosuppressant conditions. The study also found that immunosuppressive conditions were associated with a higher rate of severe presentation.
In this study, the authors proposed a framework that uses mathematical models and experimental data to determine the optimal inoculum dose for vaccines. They illustrated their framework using data from two infection experiments with influenza A virus (IAV) in mice and human parainfluenza virus (HPIV) in cotton rats at different inoculum doses. They used the model to map inoculum dose to the level of immune protection and morbidity, and to explore how such a framework might be used to determine an optimal inoculum dose. Their findings suggest that the impact of inoculum dose on immune protection and morbidity can depend on the specific pathogen and that both protection and morbidity do not necessarily increase monotonically with increasing inoculum dose. The authors concluded that their proposed framework can help in the rational design of vaccines and the determination of the optimal amount of inoculum, which can significantly contribute toward better vaccine design.
In this study, the authors investigate the gene expression of HetR, a protein that is essential for differentiation of nitrogen-fixing heterocysts in the cyanobacterium Anabaena. They use a chromosomally-encoded translational hetR-gfp fusion to study the fluctuations of hetR expression and their distribution along filaments of Anabaena. The authors found that under nitrogen-rich conditions, basal, steady-state expression of the HetR inhibitor PatS, cell-cell communication influenced by the septal protein SepJ, and positive HetR auto-regulation are all important determinants of fluctuations in hetR expression and its distribution along filaments. They also found that under nitrogen-poor conditions, the inhibitors PatS and HetN have different effects on hetR expression, and that the septal proteins FraC/FraD and SepJ are involved in the formation of the heterocyst pattern. Overall, the authors found that fluctuations in hetR expression play a key role in determining the developmental pattern of heterocysts in Anabaena.
Japanese encephalitis (JE) is a serious disease caused by the Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV). There are two different genotypes of JEV, GI and GIII. Recent studies have shown that GI is becoming more dominant than GIII in China. In this study, the authors aimed to investigate the reasons for this genotype shift by comparing the replication efficiency of GI and GIII strains in vitro and in vivo. They found that GI strains replicated more efficiently than GIII strains in avian cells, which could lead to increased exposure and infection in mosquitoes and a higher transmission efficiency in the birds-mosquitoes-birds enzootic transmission cycle. This could, in turn, contribute to the JEV genotype shift.
We report on the use of systematic genetic interaction analysis to uncover new insights into the function of a transcriptional network that regulates biofilm formation in Candida albicans, a fungal pathogen. By constructing and analyzing double heterozygous mutants of six network genes, we found that the network is highly sensitive to genetic perturbation, showing haploinsufficiency for all six genes. We also found that many double heterozygous mutants are as severely affected as homozygous deletions, indicating that the network is highly interdependent and functions as a small-world network. By examining individual double heterozygous mutants, we discovered that TEC1 is highly sensitive to perturbations in other network TFs, and that expression of ROB1 is dependent on both auto-regulation and cooperative interactions with other network TFs. We also found that the ndt80Δ/NDT80 mutant is hyperfilamentous in a TEC1-dependent manner. Our work provides new insights into the function of this transcriptional network, and highlights the utility of genetic interaction analysis in C. albicans.
This article presents a detailed study of aspartate aminotransferase (AST) from Leishmania major, a protozoan parasite causing cutaneous leishmaniasis. The authors conducted extensive molecular and biochemical studies to understand the enzyme's functional and structural properties. They found that LmAST has high levels of activity, which is essential for the parasite's survival and growth in the host environment. The authors also analyzed the enzyme's substrate specificity and kinetic properties, providing insights into its role in metabolic processes within the parasite. Additionally, the authors conducted a structural study of LmAST using computational methods and compared it to the structures of ASTs from other organisms. These studies provide valuable information about the enzyme's structure and function, which can be useful for developing new drugs to treat cutaneous leishmaniasis.
Toxocariasis is an infection caused by the nematode Toxocara spp. and is common worldwide. It is usually transmitted through direct contact with dogs or cats or by ingesting contaminated soil or water. Toxocara larvae can migrate to the brain and other organs, causing various neurological symptoms including seizures. In this study, the authors updated their previous meta-analysis on the association between toxocariasis and epilepsy. They found that there is a positive association between toxocariasis and epilepsy. The study also looked at potential sources of heterogeneity in the data and found that there was no significant association between covariates and the outcome. The authors conclude that there is epidemiological evidence of a positive association between toxocara-associated epileptogenesis and epilepsy.
The present study describes a new ATM-dependent pathway in which miR-335 downregulates CtIP protein levels, leading to radiosensitivity and reduced DSB repair efficiency. The authors show that CREB is responsible for a large portion of miR-335 expression and that CREB binding to the MEST promoter is reduced after IR, corroborating previous studies that IR-activated ATM phosphorylates CREB to reduce its transcription activity. Overexpression of miR-335 in HeLa cells resulted in reduced CtIP levels and post-IR colony survival and BRCA1 foci formation. Further, in two patient-derived lymphoblastoid cell lines with decreased post-IR colony survival, a "radiosensitive" phenotype, elevated miR-335 expression, reduced CtIP levels, and reduced BRCA1 foci formation were demonstrated. Colony survival, BRCA1 foci, and CtIP levels were partially rescued by miRNA antisense AMO-miR-335 treatment. Taken together, these findings strongly suggest that an ATM–dependent CREB–miR-335–CtIP axis influences the selection of HRR for repair of certain DSB lesions.
In this paper, the authors explore the role of mentalizing, or attributing mental states to others, in learning during social interactions. They use Bayesian models of mentalizing to compare the performance of participants playing a repeated game against artificial agents with different levels of mentalizing sophistication. The authors find that participants win against artificial agents with high mentalizing sophistication when playing in a social context, and that the choice sequences of participants are best explained by sophisticated mentalizing Bayesian learning models only in the social context. The study suggests that mentalizing is an important aspect of social cognition and is valuable in decision-making during social interactions.
Biological networks are important in understanding biological processes. However, traditional statistical methods do not work well for networks with many variables, like in biological data. Gaussian graphical model (GGM) is a statistical model that describes the conditional dependence structure of a set of random variables by a graph. The FastGGM algorithm was developed to efficiently implement the method proposed by Ren et al. to construct Gaussian graphical model and make inference with high-dimensional biological data. The algorithm is faster than the current implemented algorithm for Ren et al., without losing any accuracy. The algorithm has been implemented in an R package named “FastGGM”.
This paper investigates how changes in the inhibitory input to a single cell in a network of spiny neurons affect the network's dynamics. The authors use a mathematical model to simulate the behavior of the network and find that increasing the inhibitory input to a cell causes the network to become less synchronous, which is in agreement with experimental observations. The authors also find that the network becomes more sensitive to changes in the firing rate of individual cells, which they explain as being due to the fact that increasing the inhibitory input to a cell causes the network to become more heterogeneous. Finally, the authors show that increasing the inhibitory input to a cell causes the network to become more active, which they explain as being due to the fact that increasing the inhibitory input to a cell causes the network to become more excitable. Overall, this paper provides important insights into how changes in the inhibitory input to a cell in a network of spiny neurons affect the network's dynamics.
This paper investigates the role of Sec4p in polarized exocytosis and endocytosis in yeast. The authors used live cell imaging and particle tracking to study the movement of Sec4p and other proteins to and from the plasma membrane. They found that Sec4p polarization is required for actin patch assembly during endocytosis and that it regulates the actin polymerization required for endocytosis. The authors also found that Sec4p is involved in polarized exocytosis and that it regulates the actin polymerization required for exocytosis. Overall, this paper provides new insights into the role of Sec4p in polarized exocytosis and endocytosis in yeast.
This paper introduces a new method called Mouse Analog, which is a virtual lab that can be used to model acetaminophen (APAP) liver injury. Mouse Analog is built on a virtual lab toolkit called Liver, which can be used to model the spatial and temporal distribution of the metabolites of APAP in the liver. Mouse Analog can be used to test new hypotheses about the mechanisms of APAP liver injury.
In this study, we looked at 51 babies born to mothers who were infected with the parasite Trypanosoma cruzi. We wanted to find out how much of the parasite was in their blood and how this changed over the course of one year. We used a special type of PCR to measure the levels of the parasite in the babies' blood at 1, 6, and 12 months after birth. We also looked at the babies' antibody levels to see if these levels changed over time. The results showed that the parasite burden in some babies was very low, and that it was difficult to detect the parasite in their blood. We also found that there was a strong correlation between the babies' antibody levels and their parasite burden. Finally, we found that the parasite was more likely to be found in babies born to mothers who were infected with the TcV parasite. This information could help doctors and scientists better understand how to diagnose and treat babies who are infected with T. cruzi.
The authors present a new model of the metabolism of Escherichia coli that takes into account the crowding effect of the macromolecules. They consider a set of five steady-state equations of state that describe the dynamics of RNA polymerase (RNAp), ribosomes, and translation. The model incorporates feedback mechanisms that regulate the transcription and translation of RNAp and ribosomes. The authors show that the model is consistent with the observed WT cell state, and that the feedback mechanisms are sufficient to account for the dynamics of the system under different growth conditions. They also discuss the implications of the model for understanding the dynamics of RNAp and ribosomes in E. coli.
This article presents a detailed overview of MYB transcription factor RADIALIS/SQUAMOSA-LIKE (RSL) genes and their potential roles in Arabidopsis development. RSL genes are known for their functions in meristem maintenance, floral organ identity, and response to abiotic stress. The article explains the sequence similarities and phylogenetic relationships among RSL genes and provides a comprehensive overview of their genomic organization, expression patterns, and potential functions. Additionally, the article discusses the regulatory mechanisms governing RSL gene expression, including transcription factors and hormones, as well as the molecular mechanisms underlying their functions.
Scientists from Germany, Denmark, and the United States have presented new data on the structure and function of mitochondrial complex I, which is an essential protein complex involved in energy production in cells. The team used X-ray crystallography to study the structure of complex I and found that it is made up of two main parts: a hydrophilic arm and a membrane arm. They also used blue-native electrophoresis (a technique that separates proteins based on their solubility in detergents) to analyze the subunit composition of the enzyme. This revealed that the membrane arm of complex I is composed of two subdomains: the proximal (PP) and distal (PD) domains. The team then performed experiments using a yeast strain that lacks a subunit of complex I to see how this affects the function of the enzyme. They found that the subcomplex still retains some proton-pumping activity, suggesting that there may be more than one proton-pumping site in the membrane arm of complex I. Overall, these findings provide new insights into the structure and function of mitochondrial complex I.
Fever is a natural response of the body to fight off infections, but it also plays a role in increasing the binding affinity between antibodies and antigens. This study found that the binding affinity between antibodies and antigens from dengue and malaria viruses was at its highest at a body temperature of 40°C. This suggests that fever is beneficial in enhancing the immune response to fight off these diseases.
The article describes a computational model of the actomyosin cortex in animal cells. This cortex is composed of thin layers of cross-linked actin filaments that are subject to force, generating macroscopic contractile stress. The authors use a simple coarse-grained description of these filaments, introducing effective drag forces between overlapping filaments and frictional forces between filament endpoints and the plasma membrane. They also include motor activity, represented as forces acting at the points where filaments overlap, and turnover, where filaments randomly appear and disappear. They use this model to study the passive and active responses of the cortex to external forces, the buildup and maintenance of contractile stress, and the resulting flows. Their results show that network remodeling can tune cortical flow through simultaneous effects on active force generation and passive resistance to network deformation.
Researchers at the University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA) have identified a new gene, ANAC060, which regulates the sensitivity of Arabidopsis seedlings to high concentrations of glucose and fructose. They used a combination of genetic, molecular, and biochemical techniques to characterize the gene, which has a truncated protein due to a single-nucleotide polymorphism that causes an intron splicing defect in the Col-0 ecotype. The researchers showed that ANAC060 regulates sugar sensitivity through a negative feedback mechanism involving sugar-ABA signaling. They also showed that the Col-0 allele of ANAC060 is dominant over the C24 allele and that the dominant allele encodes a protein that is constitutively nuclear. The researchers concluded that their findings provide insights into the regulatory mechanisms involved in sugar sensitivity and may have implications for understanding how plants respond to sugars and other signals in their environment.
This research paper describes the identification of new c-di-GMP signaling components in Pseudomonas aeruginosa. The authors used a combination of phylogenetic analysis, bioinformatics, and molecular biology to identify and characterize new proteins that are involved in c-di-GMP signaling, including HsbD, HsbA, and HsbR. These proteins are involved in biofilm formation, motility, and other important biological processes. The authors also constructed mutant strains of P. aeruginosa to study the role of these proteins in c-di-GMP signaling and demonstrated the importance of c-di-GMP signaling in various biological processes.
In this study, researchers investigated whether visuomotor contingencies could be learned and stored for multiple shapes. Participants performed a two-target reaching task in which they had to point to one of two shapes while viewing a feedback that was shifted relative to the actual pointing position. They were trained on one of two shape-visuomotor contingencies and then tested on the other contingency. The results showed that participants could learn and store the visuomotor contingencies for multiple shapes.
The cerebellum uses climbing fiber (CF) signals to transmit information about sensory events, such as touch sensations on the skin, to Purkinje cells. These CF signals consist of a series of short bursts of spikes, and the size of these bursts has been thought to depend on the phase of the olivary cell's sub-threshold membrane potential oscillation. However, recent experimental findings using a detailed three-compartmental model of an inferior olivary cell show that the phase-dependency of the burst size is present but limited, and that charge flow between soma and dendrite is a major determinant of the climbing fiber burst. This suggests that phenomena such as cell ensemble synchrony can have a big effect on the climbing fiber burst size through dendrodendritic gap-junctional coupling between olivary cells. These findings have implications for the functioning of the cerebellum in motor control, as well as for machine learning approaches that use spike timing information to learn motor skills.
The article presents a mechanistic computational model of human liver iron metabolism. The model incorporates the core regulatory components of iron metabolism, including hepcidin, transferrin, ferritin, and ferroportin, and is based on known mechanisms of regulation and their kinetic properties. The model was validated by comparing its results with previously published physiological data, and it was found to be able to reproduce multiple experimental findings. The model also provides a quantitative understanding of the liver iron overload that arises in haemochromatosis, a disease caused by a mutation in the HFE gene. Overall, the model supports and supplements understanding of the role of the liver as an iron sensor and provides a framework for further modelling and simulation.
The nuclear pore complex (NPC) is a crucial structure in eukaryotic cells that allows for transport of molecules and proteins across the nuclear envelope. This process, known as nucleocytoplasmic transport (NCT), is critical for regulating cellular function and maintaining the integrity of the cell. However, the mechanism of NCT is not fully understood and current models of the NPC do not provide a detailed explanation. To address this issue, a team of researchers has developed a coarse-grained model of the NPC that mimics the transport process. This model takes into account the hydrophobic interactions between karyopherins (KAPs) and phenylalanine-glycine (FG) repeat domains, the polymeric nature of FG-repeats grafted on the elastic structure of the NPC, and the Kap-FG hydrophobic affinity. The model predicts that the first-passage time of a 15 nm cargo-complex is approximately 2.6 ms with an inverse Gaussian distribution for statistically adequate number of independent Brownian dynamics simulations. The cargo-complex is primarily attached to the channel wall where it interacts with the FG-layer as it passes through the central channel. The Kap-FG hydrophobic interaction is highly dynamic and fast, ensuring an efficient translocation through the NPC. Almost all eight hydrophobic binding spots on Kap-β are occupied simultaneously during transport. The team concludes that cytoplasmic filaments-deficient NPCs show a high degree of permeability to inert cargos, indicating the defining role of cytoplasmic filaments in the selectivity barrier.
Scientists have developed a new method for determining the dose of a pathogen that infects 50% of nonhuman primates in experiments. This method uses fewer animals and less resources than previous methods, and can estimate the dose within 1.5-fold of the true value. This new method can be applied to any infectious agent and animal model. The research supports the use of nonhuman primates to study human infectious diseases and vaccines.
We describe a study investigating how the auditory system of crickets adapts to the environment. Crickets have a unique auditory system with a single ascending neuron that responds to ultrasonic sounds. The study used two different stimuli: one with two peaks and one with three peaks. The researchers measured the response of the neuron to these stimuli and found that the response curve changed to better match the stimulus. This change in the response curve occurred after a 5-second adaptation period. The study also used multimodal stimuli with two or three peaks. The response curve changed in a way that matched the stimulus with the most intense peak, which was consistent with the selective coding hypothesis. However, the study also found that the response curve shifted to higher intensities, which was consistent with the infomax hypothesis. Overall, the study provides evidence that the auditory system of crickets adapts to the environment in a way that optimizes its ability to detect and respond to sounds.
In this study, the authors engineered PrPSc molecules lacking polybasic domains and studied their ability to dock and propagate prions. Using PrPSc molecules lacking these domains, the authors were able to dissect the relationship between the ability to seed formation of wild type PrPSc molecules in vitro and prion infectivity in vivo. They found that PrPSc molecules lacking polybasic domains are still capable of robust in vitro propagation but are not always associated with appropriate levels of specific infectivity. Their findings suggest that the role of polybasic domains in prion propagation may not be universally required and may vary depending on the specific PrPSc molecule. These findings provide new insights into the mechanism of prion propagation and may have implications for the development of therapies to treat prion diseases.
The study presents a new computational framework for understanding the behavioral strategies used by animals to adapt to a changing environment. This framework is based on inverse reinforcement learning and involves estimating a value function for each state in the environment. The value function represents how beneficial each state is for the animal and is used to guide the animal's behavior towards the most beneficial state. The study applied this framework to understand the thermotactic behavior of Caenorhabditis elegans, a type of roundworm, under different conditions. The authors found that the worms used either directed or isothermal migration strategies, depending on their feeding status. They also showed that thermosensory neurons play a role in these strategies.
We report the draft genome assembly of Chrysochromulina tobin (Prymnesiophycidae: B2 clade), a haptophyte known for its mixotrophic lifestyle. Using a combination of Illumina and 454 sequencing, we generated a total of 3,000 contigs over 40 Mb. We also present transcriptomic data from 12 time points, allowing for the identification of differentially expressed genes. This work will provide a foundation for future studies on the metabolism, evolution, and ecology of this important marine alga.
This paper describes the tumor suppressor function of Rb, p53, and Brca1 in a mouse model of human breast cancer. The authors combine loss of Rb with loss of p53 and Brca1 to generate mice with features of aggressive human breast cancer, including rapid tumor progression, poor differentiation, distant metastasis, necrosis, metaplasia, and genomic instability. The study shows that the loss of each of these tumor suppressors contributes distinctly to the development of this aggressive breast cancer phenotype. The results highlight the importance of understanding the individual and combined functions of tumor suppressors in order to develop effective cancer therapies.
This study examined the ecology of Aedes aegypti, the main vector of dengue fever, in rural Thailand. The authors used data from 84,840 water-holding containers from 2004 to 2007 to develop a model that predicts the number of Ae. aegypti pupae in individual containers. The model included ecological factors such as habitat density, type of container, source of water, and coverage of the container. The authors found that high habitat density was associated with increased pupal production. They also found that certain container types, such as jars and tires, had a higher probability of being positive for pupae than other container types. The study provides valuable information for developing effective vector control strategies for dengue fever.
Understanding how animals integrate signals to make decisions is an important area of study in biology. One way that animals can make decisions is by sensing internal nutrient status and external signals such as temperature, pheromones, and food. Nutrient status is sensed by the intestine and communicates with other tissues, including neurons, to modulate the expression of genes involved in development and behavior. Using C. elegans as a model, this study finds that the intestinal TORC2 complex is important for integrating these signals and modulating the expression of genes involved in development and behavior. The authors find that intestinal TORC2 regulates the expression of genes involved in development and behavior through neuronal signaling. This work provides insights into how animals integrate signals from the intestine to make decisions.
This paper describes the use of genomic, computational, and experimental approaches to identify novel transcriptional regulatory sequences in pluripotent stem cells. The authors identified a set of genes that are upregulated in pluripotent stem cells and conserved across different mammalian species, and used these genes to identify motifs that are shared between different pluripotent cell types. The authors then used these motifs to generate reporter constructs that can be used to test their function in different cell types. They found that one of these motifs is conserved across different mammalian species, and that it is bound by the transcription factor NF-Y in mouse and human pluripotent stem cells. They also found that NF-Y is differentially expressed during differentiation of pluripotent stem cells, and that it is required for the proliferation of pluripotent stem cells. Overall, this paper provides important insights into the transcriptional regulatory mechanisms that control pluripotent stem cell proliferation and differentiation.
In this study, the authors describe the reconstitution of a complex between a recombinant nucleoprotein (N) of vesicular stomatitis virus (VSV) and a peptide encompassing the N0-binding MoRE of VSV phosphoprotein (P). The authors use size exclusion chromatography (SEC) and static light scattering (MALLS) to characterize the complex and demonstrate that it is a circular decamer of heterodimers, similar to the previously crystallized decameric N-RNA ring. The authors also show that the N0-binding MoRE of P binds to N in the NΔ210-P60 complex in solution as in the crystal structure and that the regions of P flanking this MoRE remain flexible in the complex. This study provides important insights into the chaperone activities of VSV P and the encapsidation of newly synthesized RNA.
The current study focused on understanding the role of gap junctions in the VS network of the blowfly. The VS network is responsible for processing visual input and directing behavioral responses. The study used a previously established mathematical model of the VS network to investigate the effects of gap junctions on its information processing capabilities. The results showed that the presence of gap junctions allowed the VS network to jointly encode different axes of rotation with better separability and reached near-optimal encoding efficiency. This efficient encoding was important for the fly's survival as it enabled the VS network to encode some basic rotations correctly, such as the up/down tilt of the head and body (pitch rotation). The study also demonstrated the importance of the axonal GJs in the VS network for the computational principles implemented by neural circuitries. The findings provide a deeper understanding of the role of gap junctions in the VS network and highlight their importance for efficient visual processing in the blowfly.
The article describes the research on the role of tyrosine sulfation in the binding of Enterovirus 71 (EV71) to its receptor, human P-selectin glycoprotein ligand-1 (PSGL-1). The study found that tyrosine sulfation is important for PSGL-1-EV71 binding, and that blocking sulfation using the drug sodium chlorate inhibited EV71 infection in Jurkat T cells. The findings suggest that tyrosine sulfation plays a role in early virus-host interactions and pathogenesis of EV71.
Our study demonstrates that rapamycin and its analogs potently suppress the parasite burden in L. major-infected BALB/c mice. Rapamycin and its analogs suppress the proliferation of both the promastigote and amastigote forms of L. major, the latter of which is the pathogenic form of the parasite. Rapamycin also induces T helper type 1 (Th1) immune response and enhances the expression of several key genes in the Th1 pathway. We have identified the mechanisms through which rapamycin and its analogs suppress the parasite burden in L. major-infected mice and elucidated the immunomodulatory effects of these drugs in the host. Our findings provide new insights into the therapeutic potential of rapamycin and its analogs for the treatment of leishmaniasis.
Natural transformation is the process by which bacteria take up foreign DNA from their environment and incorporate it into their own genome. This process has been extensively studied in the human pathogen Neisseria meningitidis, which uses natural transformation to acquire new virulence factors and other genetic material. The meningococcus has a unique mechanism for selecting the DNA it takes up for transformation. This process involves the DUS ( DNA uptake sequence) receptor ComP. The authors have shown that ComP is the receptor for DUS, a DNA sequence motif that is repeated 12 times and found in only 1% of the meningococcus genome. They have also shown that the recognition of DUS by ComP is dependent on the inner bases of the sequence, with single base mutations leading to impaired recognition. The authors have further shown that DUS variants naturally occurring in other Neisseria species are impaired for transformation in N. meningitidis, highlighting the importance of DUS conservation in this process. They have also shown that a ComP homolog from the related human pathogen N. gonorrhoeae can bind its cognate DUS, suggesting that this recognition mechanism is a widespread phenomenon in the Neisseriaceae family.
A recent study provides new insights into the mechanisms that regulate cytokinesis in the fission yeast S. pombe. The study shows that the binding of a scaffold protein, Pxl1, to the F-BAR domain of Cdc15 is required for the stable attachment of the ring to the plasma membrane. The study also demonstrates that Cdc15 and Bgs1 are essential for the formation of the septum and that they cooperate to maintain the ring in the middle of the cell during division. These findings provide important information about the mechanisms that control the formation of the cleavage furrow in the fission yeast and suggest that Pxl1 and Cdc15 are important for the coordination of the CAR and the septum synthesis during cell division.
In this article, researchers used two tools, multiple locus variable number tandem repeat analysis (MLVA) and whole genome sequencing (WGS), to investigate the genetic diversity and phylogeny of Burkholderia mallei (B. mallei), the bacterium that causes glanders disease in horses and humans. Glanders is a life-threatening disease that has reemerged in recent years, particularly in Asia, the Middle East, Africa, and South America. The researchers examined nine B. mallei isolates from horses and one isolate from a camel that were collected during a 2010-2011 glanders outbreak in Bahrain. They compared the Bahraini isolates to 15 isolates from a 2004 glanders outbreak in the United Arab Emirates (UAE). Using MLVA, the researchers identified two distinct clusters of B. mallei that were involved in the 2010-2011 Bahrain outbreak. The clusters contained five and four strains each, respectively. This suggests that at least two different B. mallei populations caused the outbreak. The researchers also used WGS to analyze eight B. mallei genomes from the UAE outbreak and seven genomes from the Bahrain outbreak. The WGS data provided further evidence that the two populations of B. mallei involved in the 2010-2011 Bahrain outbreak were genetically distinct. This study demonstrates the usefulness of MLVA and WGS for understanding the genetic diversity and phylogeny of B. mallei and its role in glanders outbreaks. These tools can help researchers to track the spread of glanders disease and identify its sources.
American cutaneous leishmaniasis (ACL) is a complicated disease that causes about 67,000 new cases every year. The disease is caused by different species of Leishmania parasites, and it is difficult to determine which species is causing a particular case of ACL. The first-line treatment for ACL is pentavalent antimonials, such as Glucantime. However, the cure rate of Glucantime is only about 75%, and the reasons for treatment failure are not well understood. In order to better understand the clinical and parasitological features of patients with ACL who did not respond to Glucantime treatment, a cross-sectional observational study was conducted in Colombia. The study included 43 patients with ACL who were recruited from three national reference centers for complicated ACL. Clinical and paraclinical evaluations, as well as epidemiological and geographic information, were collected for each patient. Parasitological, histopathological, and PCR infection confirmation were also performed. Glucantime IC50 and in vitro infectivity for isolated parasites were estimated. The predominant infecting Leishmania species was L. braziliensis, and 35% of the parasites isolated showed a significant decrease in in vitro Glucantime susceptibility associated with previous administration of the medicament. Lesion size and in vitro infectivity of the parasite were negatively correlated with decline in Glucantime susceptibility. A negative correlation between lesion size and parasite resistance was also documented. L. braziliensis was found as the main parasite species associated with lesions of patients who underwent treatment failure or relapse. The indication of a second round of treatment in therapeutic failure of ACL produced by L. braziliensis with pentavalent antimonials is discussable.
This article describes a study that investigates the functional interchangeability of a 4'-phosphopantetheinyltransferase (PPTase) in the synthesis of various secondary metabolites in Escherichia coli. The study found that the ClbA PPTase encoded by the pks island can contribute to the synthesis of siderophores and colibactin in vitro and in vivo. This suggests that the strict association of the pks island with highly virulent E. coli strains could be due to the ClbA PPTase contributing to the synthesis of both colibactin and yersiniabactin. This study provides new insights into the interplay between various secondary metabolites and their biosynthetic pathways in E. coli.
Scientists have developed a new model to improve the accuracy of multiple sequence alignments, which are used to compare and understand the evolutionary relationships between different organisms. This model accounts for insertion and deletion events, in addition to residue substitutions, when aligning sequences. The model assumes that insertions and deletions occur one residue at a time. The model has been applied to phylogenetic tree inference by extending the program dnaml in phylip, a widely used software for analyzing DNA sequences. The results of the study show that the extended program dnamlε improves accuracy while retaining the computational efficiency of the Felsenstein peeling algorithm, which is used in the original version of dnaml. The scientists have also developed a non-reversible generative (birth–death) evolutionary model for insertions and deletions, which has been incorporated into the extended program dnamlε.
We have studied the mechanism of HSV infection in human skin, using explants of inner foreskin or biopsies from initial genital herpes lesions. In foreskin explants, LCs containing HSV or HSV antigen migrated into the dermis where they interacted with BDCA3+ dermal DCs forming clusters of cells. These clusters also contained CD14+, DC-SIGN+ dermal cells. In contrast, LCs did not interact with these two subsets of dermal DCs in genital lesions. When LCs were isolated from skin and infected with HSV-1 in vitro, they were taken up by BDCA3+ dermal DCs and DC-SIGN+ cells. These data show a unique pathogen driven interaction, resulting in a pathogen/antigen relay from human LCs to two different subsets of antigen presenting dermal cells/DCs, occurring within induced clusters of cells in the dermis, with likely different roles in stimulating different effector T cell subsets, either in lymph nodes or later, infiltrating the dermis. This is the first report of a human study that shows dermal DCs may play a key role in delivering and presenting viral antigens to T cells in the lymph nodes as well as possibly to residential T cells .
This study aimed to compare the formation of Leishmania amastigotes-hosting parasitophorous vacuoles (PVs) in primary mouse bone marrow-derived macrophages. The study compared the PV formation in infected cells that were exposed to amastigotes of either Leishmania major or Leishmania amazonensis. Using multidimensional imaging of live cells, the authors compared and characterized the PV formation/remodeling of macrophages that were either infected with amastigotes of either L. major or L. amazonensis, or loaded with Lysotracker, a lysosomotropic fluorescent probe. The study revealed three dynamic features of Leishmania amastigote-hosting PVs. First, the entry of Lysotracker transients within tight-fitting, fission-prone L. major amastigote-housing PVs. Second, the decrease in the number of acidic vesicles of macrophages during the L. major PV fission or L. amazonensis PV enlargement. Third, the L. amazonensis PV remodeling after homotypic fusion. The high content information of multidimensional images provided an updated understanding of the Leishmania species-specific differences in PV biogenesis/remodeling and could be useful for the study of other intracellular microorganisms.
Homology-directed repair (HDR) is a process that allows for the repair of DNA lesions through the use of a template donor molecule. The current study uses the chicken B cell line DT40 as a model to study the role of donor chromatin structure in HDR. The authors found that the donors used in DT40 have active histone modifications, which is consistent with open chromatin structure. They then tethered the heterochromatin protein HP1 to the donor array in DT40 and found that this led to a transition of the donor sequences from an open to a nonpermissive state, as evidenced by a switch from templated to nontemplated diversification. These results demonstrate that permissive chromatin structure at the donor is a key regulator of HDR, and that nonpermissive chromatin structure can prevent homologous recombination and result in point mutagenesis. These findings have important implications for our understanding of homologous recombination and the mechanisms that promote LOH, leading to tumorigenesis and nonallelic recombination between repeats. They also have the potential to inform the design of donor constructs for targeted gene therapy.
The aim of this study was to explore whether the cerebellum can learn from visual errors during saccadic eye movements. To address this question, we recorded the activity of Purkinje cells (PCs) in the cerebellar cortex of monkeys performing a task in which they were required to make fast, accurate eye movements to a target that could either appear in the expected location or shift unexpectedly. We analyzed the activity of PCs during the movement and found that it was influenced by visual errors made in the previous trial. Specifically, we found that the activity of PCs increased when the target shifted unexpectedly during the previous trial, even though the PCs did not fire in response to the error itself. This suggests that the cerebellum can learn from visual errors and use this information to improve future performance.
In this study, the authors used the yeast model to investigate the toxicity of overexpressed human TDP-43 protein and to identify potential modifiers of TDP-43 toxicity. The authors found that TDP-43 toxicity was associated with an increase in cytosolic aggregates and a decrease in the ability of the UPS to degrade cytosolic misfolded proteins. The authors also found that excess Sis1 could reduce TDP-43 toxicity and restore UPS-mediated degradation. Furthermore, the authors found that DNAJB1, a mammalian Sis1 homologue, could reduce TDP-43 toxicity in primary rodent cortical neurons. These findings suggest that Sis1 and its homologues may have neuroprotective effects in ALS.
Chagas disease is a serious health problem in Latin America, with an estimated 7 million people infected and 70 million people exposed. T. cruzi, the causative agent of Chagas disease, has six discrete typing units (DTUs), and the parasite load varies among these DTUs. The aim of this study was to investigate the parasite load and genotyping of T. cruzi in blood samples of Chagas disease patients from different regions of Brazil, and their association with the severity of chronic cardiac form of Chagas disease. Sixty-five Chagas disease patients, aged from 26 to 76 years old, were recruited and their blood samples were collected and processed to perform molecular tests. The molecular tests were performed using a multilocus conventional PCR (MLC-PCR) targeting three nuclear loci of T. cruzi, SL-IR, 24Sα and A10, and a multiplex real-time quantitative PCR (qPCR) targeting satellite DNA of T. cruzi and human RNase P gene. The parasite load was directly estimated from blood samples of patients, before etiological treatment, and the results were pooled and analyzed according to the characteristics of the patients. In general, higher parasite loads were observed in patients infected with T. cruzi DTU II and III. Furthermore, patients with the severe chronic cardiac form of Chagas disease had higher parasite loads, especially those infected with T. cruzi DTU II. These results contribute to update the epidemiological knowledge of T. cruzi DTUs in Brazil and highlight the age of patient and infection by T. cruzi DTU II as important features that lead to the observation of higher parasitemia levels.
The present study aimed to determine if the enhanced bat rabies surveillance system in Guatemala would complement the existing passive surveillance system, and extend information on the geographic distribution of rabies virus circulation among bats to assess the public and veterinary health risks associated with bats in Guatemala. The study involved the collection of 672 bats from 19 field sites, which were examined for the presence of rabies virus antigens and infectious virus using the direct fluorescent antibody (DFA) test, viral antigen detection, virus isolation, and hemi-nested reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) assays. The prevalence of rabies virus detection among all collected bats was 0.3%, with viral antigens detected in two common vampire bats (Desmodus rotundus) and one vampire bat (Artibeus jamundi). Sequencing of the nucleoprotein gene showed that both viruses were 100% identical, whereas sequencing of the glycoprotein gene revealed one non-synonymous substitution (302T, S). The two vampire bat RABV isolates in this study were phylogenetically related to viruses associated with vampire bats in the eastern states of Mexico and El Salvador. Additionally, 7% of sera collected from 398 bats demonstrated RABV neutralizing antibody. The proportion of seropositive bats varied significantly across trophic guilds, suggesting complex intraspecific compartmentalization of RABV perpetuation. These findings highlight the importance of enhancing bat rabies surveillance in Guatemala and other countries with zoonotic rabies risks.
In this study, the authors investigate the role of the nuclear lamina in regulating herpes simplex virus (HSV) replication. They found that the nuclear lamina plays a critical role in regulating HSV replication, particularly at low multiplicities of infection (MOI). Specifically, they found that deletion of the lamin A/C gene results in reduced heterochromatin association with HSV lytic genes, leading to increased viral replication and growth. They also observed that the nuclear lamina targets HSV DNA to the nuclear periphery, which is important for viral replication. Overall, the findings of this study provide new insights into the role of the nuclear lamina in regulating HSV replication.
The Trichomonas vaginalis parasite has a unique mitochondrion-like organelle called a hydrogenosome, which lacks a mitochondrial outer membrane and relies on anaerobic respiration. The hydrogenosome is essential for the survival of T. vaginalis, and has unique protein import and export systems. Recently, it was shown that T. vaginalis hydrogenosomes have a tripartite pore complex (TPPC) that is similar to the mitochondrial translocase of the outer membrane (TOM) complex of eukaryotic mitochondria. In the current study, the authors set out to determine the structure of the TPPC and to identify the components of the complex. They did this by performing cryo-electron microscopy of purified hydrogenosomes, which allowed them to determine the structure of the TPPC. They also used proteomics to identify the components of the complex, and found that it is composed of six proteins. These proteins include homologs of the eukaryotic TOM complex proteins TOM40, TOM5, TOM22, TOM7, TOM19, and TOM20, as well as a unique protein called TvTOM36. The authors also found that the TPPC has a unique structure, with a long, skirt-like appendage that protrudes from the complex. They named this appendage the "skirt", and found that it is necessary for the stability and function of the complex. Overall, the study provides important insights into the structure and function of the TPPC and will help to better understand the unique mitochondrial biology of T. vaginalis.
The paper is about studying the link between autoimmune diseases and genetic regulation of the immune system. The authors used purified T cells from 313 healthy individuals to map genetic variations that affect the expression of genes involved in immune response. They found that genetic regulation of gene expression is cell-specific and that certain polymorphisms are associated with specific immune-related diseases. The study highlights the importance of eQTL mapping in purified cells and provides insights into the basic processes of genetic regulation of gene expression in the adaptive immune system.
This article describes the results of a qualitative study on the factors that prevent people from participating in HAT screening and treatment programs in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. The study was conducted in two provinces, Bandundu and Kasaï Oriental, which are highly endemic for HAT and lagging behind in the control effort. The study involved interviews and focus group discussions with current and former HAT patients, health workers, and program managers of the national HAT control program. The study found that people in these communities are aware of the prohibitions that are associated with the treatment regimen, but they do not understand their rationale. These prohibitions include restrictions on work, food, and sexual intercourse, which lead people to avoid HAT screening campaigns for fear of having to observe these taboos in case of diagnosis. The study suggests that correct health information regarding HAT treatment is essential, and that health providers should address the perspective of the community in a constant dialogue to keep abreast of unintended transformations of meaning. The study highlights the importance of community engagement and participation in HAT control programs, and the need for effective communication and community mobilization to improve uptake of HAT screening and treatment.
Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has been treating people with visceral leishmaniasis (VL) in eastern Gedaref State, Sudan. A survey was conducted to estimate the VL incidence in villages around Tabarak Allah Hospital. The survey was done between May 5 and June 17, 2011. A total of 45 villages were screened and 17,702 households were interviewed. The survey found a crude mortality rate of 0.13/10,000 people per day, and a VL-specific mortality rate of 0.9/100,000 per year. Overall, 12.5% (11,943/95,609) of the population reported a past VL treatment episode. The survey found a one-year incidence rate of 7.0/100,000 people, and a VL-specific incidence rate of 7.9/100,000 people. The survey also found that 16 people had a new case of VL, 14 of which were confirmed with a rapid test and direct agglutination test. The survey found that 2.1% (1,621/78,408) of the population was a new case of VL, and a VL-specific incidence of 2.3% (8,293/365,609). The survey found that 3.4% (2,992/88,721) of the population was a suspected case of PKDL, but none of them were referred for treatment. The survey also found that 2.6% (2,318/88,721) of the population was a clinical suspect of VL relapse, but none of them were referred for treatment. The survey found that 2.3% (2,065/88,721) of the population was a clinical suspect of VL, but none of them were referred for treatment. The survey found that 1.4% (1,224/88,721) of the population was a clinical suspect of VL, but none of them were referred for treatment.
