This work describes the use of a new method for measuring supercoiling in bacterial DNA. The method involves the use of a "supercoil sensor" module that allows for the monitoring of both supercoiling and transcription elongation rates in real-time. The authors show that supercoiling levels vary with growth conditions and that mutations in topoisomerases can influence the average supercoil density of the chromosome. They also show that RNA polymerase can influence supercoiling levels, as it can both generate and remove negative supercoils. The authors provide a detailed description of the methods used and the results obtained, making this work accessible to a wide range of researchers.
We have investigated the role of a gene called LYST/Beige, which is known to regulate lysosome size, in the intracellular survival of a species of parasitic protozoan called Leishmania. We found that LYST/Beige expression is upregulated in response to Leishmania infection, and that the size of parasitophorous vacuoles (PVs) containing Leishmania is larger in LYST/Beige-deficient cells. We also found that inhibition of nitric oxide production can promote Leishmania survival and replication in LYST/Beige-deficient cells. Our results suggest that LYST/Beige functions as an innate defense mechanism against Leishmania infection, by regulating the size of the PVs and reducing the availability of microbicidal molecules. This study highlights the importance of lysosome function in intracellular parasite survival and provides insights into the mechanisms underlying the host response to infection.
The current study describes the generation of a zinc finger (ZF) mutant zebrafish line that lacks the Mct8 transporter gene. Mct8 is a homolog of the human MCT8 transporter, which is essential for normal brain development and function. The zebrafish mct8 mutant displays several developmental defects, including abnormalities in craniofacial and eye structures, as well as a lack of nigrostriatal dopaminergic neurons. These defects are reminiscent of those observed in patients with MCT8 deficiency. The study also shows that the Mct8 transporter is required for proper motor neuron development and function, as evidenced by defective axon arbors and synaptic connections in the mct8 mutant. Finally, the study demonstrates the use of ZF nucleases to generate a mutant zebrafish line with a specific genetic defect.
In this study, the researchers investigated the interaction between HCMV gB and gH/gL molecules. They found that HCMV gB and gH/gL proteins are already complexed in extracellular virions, suggesting that gB is activated for fusion before it undergoes fusion. The researchers also demonstrated that a significant fraction of HCMV gH/gL (devoid of gO or UL128-131) binds to gB in virions. This study provides a different model for how HCMV gB and gH/gL molecules interact and function compared with models for HSV-1 entry.
The study explores the factors that determine the segregation of mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) variants in a mouse model of heteroplasmy. The researchers discovered that the protein Gimap3 is a critical regulator of this process in leukocytes. They found that Gimap3 plays a role in the survival of T cells, which could potentially explain why mtDNA variants segregate differently in different tissues. The findings provide important insights into the mechanisms underlying mtDNA segregation and may have implications for the development of mitochondrial diseases.
Buruli ulcer (BU) is a skin infection caused by the bacteria Mycobacterium ulcerans. It is most commonly found in parts of Africa, but it has also been reported in Australia. The incubation period, or the time between exposure and symptom onset, of BU has been difficult to estimate due to the fact that most people who acquire the infection are permanent residents of endemic areas. However, in Victoria, Australia, a large proportion of BU cases are visitors to endemic areas, which makes it possible to estimate the incubation period.
This article describes a study that used reverse genetics to create a mutant strain of Toxoplasma gondii (a parasite that causes toxoplasmosis in humans and other animals) that lacks a protein called TgNCR1. The authors used a plasmid-based method to insert a knockout cassette into the TgNCR1 gene, which then underwent homologous recombination to create the mutant strain. The study used a number of different techniques to verify that the mutant strain lacked TgNCR1, including PCR, Southern blotting, and immunofluorescence microscopy. The study also used complementation to restore TgNCR1 to the mutant strain and to confirm that TgNCR1 plays a role in the parasite's growth and development. The authors suggest that TgNCR1 may be a target for the development of new anti-parasitic drugs.
Our study identifies a locus for OAS on 14q24 . 2, containing homozygous, predicted loss-of-function mutations in the SMOC1 gene in eight out of fourteen unrelated families with OAS. The phenotype associated with homozygosity for a targeted “pre-conditional” gene-trap mouse mutation of Smoc1 shows significant overlap with the human disease.
This study identifies a host cellular factor, TRIM22, that is induced by interferon treatment and blocks the late stages of HIV-1 infection. The authors used transcriptional profiling to identify TRIM22 as a factor that was strongly induced by interferon treatment. They then used shRNA knockdown to show that TRIM22 is required for the block of HIV-1 infection at the late stages. The authors also showed that the RING domain of TRIM22 is required for its antiviral activity. Finally, the authors showed that TRIM22 blocks the release of HIV-1 particles by disrupting the trafficking of Gag to the plasma membrane. Overall, this study provides important insights into the mechanisms of interferon-mediated antiviral activity and suggests a potential target for the development of new antiretroviral drugs.
Fig trees and their host-specific agaonid pollinator wasps are a classic example of an obligate mutualism. To explain the persistence of this mutualism, the current study tested whether parasitic fig wasps contribute to the overall factors that enable mutualism stability. It found that parasites preferentially exploit outer ovules, resulting in a gradient in ovule profitability to foundresses. This profitability gradient favours foundresses that preferentially oviposit inner ovules, which have increased pollinator and parasite profitability. The study also found that parasites do not appear to have evolved longer ovipositors to exploit more ovules, as a reduction in ovipositor length would not be compensated for by increased benefits. The study suggests that parasites could contribute to the stability of the mutualism, by providing an additional selection pressure that favours the selection of foundresses that preferentially oviposit inner ovules. This study thus provides evidence for the contribution of a third party in shaping the symbiotic relationship between fig trees and their pollinators. It also demonstrates that, despite the short-term costs to both partners, a mutualism can be maintained if there is a gradient in profitability between the two partners.
Plant height is an important trait that influences crop yield and productivity. A large number of genes have been identified in other crops that affect plant height. However, the molecular basis of plant height in Setaria viridis, a model grass, is largely unknown. In this study, the authors used a genetically diverse Setaria viridis population to map quantitative trait loci (QTL) associated with plant height at different stages of plant development. They used different measures of plant height, including height at the end of the growing season and daily height growth rate. They also examined the effects of different environmental conditions, such as water availability and soil nutrient content, on plant height. The authors found that many of the QTL associated with plant height are located in regions of the genome that are syntenic with regions containing genes known to affect plant height in other crops. They also identified several novel QTL that are not syntenic with known plant height genes. The authors suggest that their results provide a starting point for identifying the specific genes that are responsible for plant height variation in Setaria viridis.
In the past few years, researchers have found evidence that several flaviviruses, including yellow fever virus, dengue virus, and West Nile virus, are circulating in Brazil's Pantanal wetlands, which are home to a large number of birds and mammals. In this study, researchers collected mosquitoes from the Pantanal sub-region of Nhecolândia and tested them for evidence of flaviviruses. They found that at least one species of flavivirus, Ilheus virus, is circulating in the Nhecolândia sub-region of Pantanal. The results of this study provide further evidence that the Pantanal is a key location for the transmission of flaviviruses and highlights the need for continued surveillance of mosquito-borne diseases in this region.
Scabies is a skin disease that causes itching, and is a major public health burden worldwide. Treatments for scabies do not work well and may not kill the eggs of the parasite, leading to repeated treatments. Moxidectin (MOX) may be a better treatment option because it has a longer lifespan in the body than the current treatments, which means it could kill the eggs of the parasite. To test if MOX is a better treatment, a study was done where pigs were treated with MOX or Ivermectin (IVM) and the number of mites on their skin was counted, their skin lesions were checked, and their pruritus (itching) levels were measured. The pigs were also tested for antibodies against the parasite. The results showed that MOX was more effective than IVM at killing the mites and reducing skin lesions and itching. MOX also lasted longer in the pigs' bodies, which means it could kill the eggs of the parasite. These findings suggest that MOX could be a better treatment for scabies.
The study of cellular machines has been difficult due to functional redundancy and to the interdependency of proteins within these complexes. To identify the minimal protein composition required for cellular processes, we deleted seven genes encoding PG synthesis enzymes from S . aureus. We show that S . aureus can grow and divide with only two active PG synthesizing enzymes, PBP1 and the bi-functional PBP2 . However, these cells show loss of resistance to cell wall-targeting antibiotics and decreased virulence in a Drosophila infection model which is dependent on the presence of specific peptidoglycan receptor proteins, namely PGRP-SA . These results demonstrate that in environments where the pathogen is under selective pressure from the host or by antibiotics, the expendable PG synthesis enzymes play an important role in the pathogenicity and antibiotic resistance of S . aureus. Our results also indicate that the presence of a complex molecular machine is important for the survival of S . aureus in its natural habitat.
We have comprehensively analyzed the biology of Burkholderia pseudomallei, a saprophytic soil bacterium causing a potentially fatal infectious disease called melioidosis. Our data demonstrate that B. pseudomallei is a secretion-proficient bacterium that synthesizes a broad range of siderophores. We have also shown that the synthesis of B. pseudomallei siderophores is regulated by both iron availability and iron-dependent signals. Our data provide a foundation for understanding the molecular mechanisms of iron acquisition in B. pseudomallei and suggest that targeting of B. pseudomallei iron acquisition could be a useful therapeutic strategy for treating melioidosis.
COMMGEN is a new tool for generating consensus models of metabolic networks. It resolves inconsistencies between two or more initial models of the same organism. The tool identifies similarities and dissimilarities between models and generates a consolidated model that includes complementary information from all models. The resulting consensus model is created in a standardized namespace and retains or improves the predictive capabilities of the initial models. COMMGEN has been applied to the generation of consensus models for several organisms including yeast, human, and E. coli. These consensus models represent a more comprehensive understanding of metabolism and can be used for a range of analyses, including the prediction of metabolic phenotypes.
In this study, we identified two genes, fam20b and xylt1, that affect the development of the skeletal tissues in zebrafish. The mutations in these genes lead to decreased cartilage matrix and increased chondral bone formation. We used different techniques to analyze the effects of these mutations on the development of the skeletal tissues in zebrafish, including morphological studies, gene expression analysis, and RNA in situ hybridization. We also performed an analysis of the expression of the Runx2b gene, which is known to be involved in the development of the skeletal tissues in zebrafish. Our study provides important insights into the genetic mechanisms that regulate the development of the skeletal tissues in zebrafish.
This study investigates the role of the Top2 transcription factor in the process of chromosome separation during meiosis in Drosophila melanogaster. The authors used a combination of genetic and molecular techniques to examine the effects of Top2 depletion on chromosome dynamics and separation. They found that depletion of Top2 led to a specific defect in the ability of heterochromatic regions to separate during prometaphase I, as well as a failure of the achiasmate 4th chromosomes to move precociously towards the spindle poles. These defects ultimately resulted in the inability of oocytes to successfully complete meiosis I. The authors concluded that the separation of heterochromatic regions is essential for the proper completion of meiosis, and that Top2 plays a critical role in this process.
This study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of mass use of 4% deltamethrin-impregnated collars in preventing canine visceral leishmaniasis (CVL) in dogs living in a highly endemic area for VL. The dogs in the intervention area were collared and continued to be collared throughout the study, while the dogs in the control area received the standard of care for VL control, which did not include collar use. The study found that the mass use of deltamethrin-impregnated collars was effective in reducing the incidence of CVL in dogs living in a highly endemic area for VL. We have found that genes with high expression breadth, or genes that are expressed in many tissues, are more likely to be located on the X chromosome and that this is a conserved feature across therian mammals. This is consistent with previous observations that expression in the germ line is reduced on the X chromosome, as this leads to a reduction in the breadth of expression of genes that have paralogs on the autosomes. We have also found that the reduction in breadth of expression on the X is not due to selection against male-biased expression, as there is no difference in expression breadth between genes with male-biased expression and those without, both on the X and autosomes. We have, therefore, proposed a new theory that the reduction in breadth of expression on the X is due to the increased level of expression on the X leading to a traffic jam effect, where there is competition for transcriptional output, resulting in a reduction in breadth of expression. This theory is supported by evidence from other species, including plants and yeast, where expression in the germ line is reduced and the breadth of expression of genes with paralogs on autosomes is lower on the X chromosome.
We looked at the prevalence and structure of Helicobacter pylori infections among Cameroonians. We found that the prevalence of infection was lower in the Baka Pygmies than in neighboring agriculturalists. We did not find a new population of H. pylori among the Baka, suggesting that they acquired their infections from non-Baka neighbors. We also found that the frequency of infection among the Baka was probably limited by their small population size and other demographic factors.
Dengue viruses are a major cause of viral infections worldwide, and can lead to severe complications such as hemorrhagic fever and death. The viral protein NS5 is a key protein for the replication of the dengue virus, and contains a nuclear localization signal (NLS) that allows it to be transported to the nucleus of the host cell. In this study, we have identified a monomeric NLS in the C-terminus of DENV NS5 that mediates nuclear localization of the protein. We have also identified a novel role for this NLS, which is that it mediates the interaction between NS5 and importin-α, a protein that is necessary for nuclear transport. We have used a combination of molecular biology and biophysical techniques, including X-ray crystallography, to identify this NLS. Our results suggest that the NLS in the C-terminus of NS5 plays a key role in the replication of the dengue virus, and that it is a potential target for the development of therapeutic agents.
Neglected tropical diseases ( NTDs ) are common in developing countries and have negative impacts on health and well-being. The World Health Organization ( WHO ) recommends that public health interventions be implemented in areas where disease prevalence exceeds certain thresholds. However, many NTD-endemic countries have not been able to launch or scale-up programs because they lack the necessary baseline data. In this study, a new methodology called the integrated threshold mapping ( ITM ) methodology was developed and field-tested for lymphatic filariasis ( LF ), trachoma, schistosomiasis, and soil-transmitted helminths ( STH ). The methodology is designed to be resource-efficient and to determine whether a threshold for public health intervention has been attained. The protocol is specific to the disease-specific age groups. The methodology was compared to the current WHO mapping methodologies for each disease in one district each in Mali and Senegal. The results of both methodologies were compared in terms of public health intervention, and feasibility, including cost. The study found that the ITM methodology reached the same conclusions as the WHO methodologies regarding the initiation of public health interventions for trachoma, LF and STH, but resulted in more targeted intervention recommendations for schistosomiasis. The ITM was practical, feasible, and demonstrated an overall cost saving compared with the standard non-integrated WHO methodologies. The integrated mapping tool could facilitate the implementation of much-needed programs in endemic countries.
The present study is a comprehensive examination of the role of histone H4 ubiquitination in chromatin dynamics and transcriptional regulation during the cell cycle. The authors show that H4 ubiquitination is regulated by the E3 ligase ZNF326A, and that this modification is essential for the proper segregation of chromosomes at mitosis. Furthermore, they demonstrate that H4 ubiquitination is required for the activation of specific genes during S phase. Overall, this work provides a detailed picture of the role of H4 ubiquitination in regulating chromatin dynamics and transcription during the cell cycle.
The paper describes the development and application of a new statistical method, GeneProgram, for analyzing large genome-wide expression datasets. The method is designed to automatically discover coherent sets of genes that are differentially expressed in a tissue-specific manner, and to represent these sets as expression programs. The method is based on a probabilistic model that can accommodate different types of data and experimental conditions, and can be used to summarize expression data over multiple time-points or tissues. The authors evaluate the performance of the method on synthetic and real-world data, and use it to discover new insights into the response of human tissues to infection. The method provides a new approach to understanding complex expression patterns in large datasets, and has the potential to be useful in a wide range of applications.
NK cells are an important part of the innate immune system and are known to play a role in protecting against viral infections. NK cells are characterized by their expression of the interferon-gamma (IFN-γ) gene, which is involved in the antiviral response. In this study, the authors investigated the epigenetic regulation of IFN-γ in NK cells from healthy individuals and those with viral infections. They found that NK cells from individuals with viral infections had a different epigenetic pattern in the IFN-γ locus, which could be responsible for the high IFN-γ production observed in these cells. The authors also identified a subset of NK cells with memory-like properties that displayed a specific epigenetic pattern, which could contribute to their enhanced ability to produce IFN-γ in response to viral infections. Overall, this study provides important insights into the epigenetic regulation of IFN-γ in NK cells and its potential role in viral infections.
Legionella pneumophila is a gram-negative bacterium that is found in freshwater environments. When it is phagocytosed by eukaryotic cells, it remodels the Legionella-containing phagosome to form a compartment that allows its intracellular replication. L. pneumophila is able to replicate in a wide variety of phagocytic cells, from amoebae to macrophages. The Dot/Icm type IV secretion system is an essential virulence determinant that translocates L. pneumophila effector proteins into host cells during infection. These effector proteins control host cell functions to initiate trafficking of the L. pneumophila vacuole, promote host cell survival, modulate innate immune responses, and promote bacterial egress. There are over 100 known L. pneumophila effector proteins, but the biochemical and cellular functions of most effector proteins remain unknown. In this study, the authors identify a new class of bacterial effectors called "metaeffector" that targets and regulates a cognate effector within the host cells. The metaeffector LubX, which carries two U-box domains, functions as a negative temporal regulator of SidH within host cells. The authors also identify the gene encoding SidH as a target of LubX. They propose the designation "metaeffector" for this class of bacterial effectors and identify a novel mechanism by which L. pneumophila effectors are regulated.
HIV-1 virus rapidly diversifies following transmission, and this diversification is thought to be driven by escape from the host's immune response. In this study, we analyze patterns of diversification in HIV-1 env gene in 81 homogeneous infections. We found that rapid diversification of the virus typically occurs at CTL epitope sites in early infection, indicating that escape from CTL responses is a common and early event. In some cases, rapid diversification occurred at sites with high mutation rates, suggesting that APOBEC-mediated mutation may drive the pathway of immune escape. Frameshifting insertions and deletions are evenly spread throughout env, but are preferentially fixed in the variable regions. These results provide the most detailed view yet of the process of diversification of the homogeneous viral population following transmission.
The paper proposes a minimal mathematical model for the epigenetic silencing of yeast genes. The model incorporates known interactions between histone proteins and various enzymes that add or remove chemical groups from histone proteins, which in turn affects the interaction of Sir proteins with chromatin. The model suggests that multiple different histone modifications can be present simultaneously in a single region of chromatin, creating a 'bivalent' state that is stable in the presence of certain perturbations. The paper also highlights the importance of non-linear interactions between histone modifications in the formation of bivalent states and the stability of epigenetic silencing. Overall, the model provides a framework for understanding the complex interactions between histone modifications and their role in the establishment and maintenance of epigenetic silencing.
In this study, we investigated whether gut microbiota (GM) composition differs between children with oedematous or non-oedematous malnutrition. We used stool samples from 87 children aged 6–24 months who were admitted to the hospital for treatment of severe acute malnutrition (SAM) in Uganda. We extracted total genomic DNA from the samples and performed PCR amplification followed by Denaturing Gradient Gel Electrophoresis (DGGE) and tag-encoded 16S rRNA gene-targeted high throughput amplicon sequencing. We then analyzed GM composition by comparing alpha and beta diversity measures, and ANOVA mean relative abundance and G-test of independence between the two groups. We found that GM composition differs between children with oedematous and non-oedematous malnutrition, with non-oedematous children having lower GM diversity. However, we did not find any clear compositional differences between the two groups. These findings suggest that non-oedematous malnutrition is associated with lower GM diversity compared to oedematous malnutrition.
The study aimed to investigate the variation in telomere length among yeast isolates and identify the genetic factors that influence it. The researchers screened 112 wild-type Saccharomyces sensu stricto isolates and found extensive telomere length variation in S. paradoxus isolates. This variation was associated with the geographic origin of the isolates, with European strains having very short telomeres and American strains having telomeres three times as long. Insertions of a URA3 gene near telomeres allowed accurate analysis of individual telomere lengths and telomere position effect (TPE). Crossing the American and European strains resulted in F1 spores with a continuum of telomere lengths, suggesting that many quantitative trait loci (QTLs) are involved in length maintenance. Variation in TPE was also quantitative but only weakly correlated with telomere length. Genotyping F1 segregants identified several QTLs associated with telomere length and silencing variation. These QTLs include likely candidate genes but also map to regions where there are no known genes involved in telomeric properties. The researchers validated by reciprocal hemizygosity that YKU80 and TLC1 are telomere-length QTLs in the two S. paradoxus subpopulations. Furthermore, they propose that sequence divergence within the Ku heterodimer generates negative epistasis within one of the allelic combinations, resulting in very short telomeres.
We applied computational modeling to the data from a recent electroencephalography ( EEG ) study investigating value-based decision making in the human brain. Our model includes an explicit decision not to decide process, which results in a delay of the final decision. We also found that the decision not to decide is accompanied by an increase in oscillatory power in the beta band ( 14–30 Hz ), a well-established neural marker of inhibition of motor responses. Finally, we tested our model experimentally in the context of an adapted version of our task. Our results support the conclusion that the decision not to decide process is a fundamental component of the decision-making process and can have a profound effect on the final decision.
We have identified a monogenic autosomal recessive mutation in the SUV39H2 gene that causes the HNPK phenotype in Labrador Retrievers. This mutation causes an amino acid change in a highly conserved region of the SUV39H2 protein that is essential for its function. The mutation affects a residue that is critical for catalysis and it is predicted to cause a defect in the methylation of histones. This defect results in the failure of the epidermis to undergo the final differentiation step, leading to the accumulation of proteinaceous fluid in the stratum corneum. This defect causes the characteristic clinical signs of HNPK, including crusts and fissures on the nasal planum.
The study aimed to investigate the genotypes and phenotypes of reassortants generated in swine co-infected with avian and swine influenza A viruses. The study used 57 influenza A viruses recovered from 43 feral swine that were experimentally inoculated with a mixture of avian and swine influenza A viruses. The study found that many different reassortants were generated in the swine, but the majority of these had PB2 and PB1 genes from swine and H3N2 genes from avian viruses. The study also found that some of the reassortants were transmitted to contact swine and caused infection, but the study did not determine which tissue tropisms were associated with transmissibility. Overall, the study demonstrated the importance of studying the genotypes and phenotypes of reassortants generated in swine co-infected with avian and swine influenza A viruses.
We conducted a follow-up study of children born to pregnant women with schistosomiasis in Uganda. We examined whether maternal schistosomiasis affects the children's schistosome infections, immune responses, and regulatory T cell frequencies at age five years. We found that maternal schistosomiasis did not influence the children's schistosome infections or immune responses, but maternal treatment with praziquantel during pregnancy was associated with lower expression of FoxP3 on regulatory T cells in the children. This may indicate that maternal treatment during pregnancy affects the children's immunoregulatory responses to schistosomiasis, although more research is needed to confirm this.
In order to eliminate the need for macrophages to undergo reprogramming from phagocytosis to macropinocytosis during infection, a protein kinase C (PKC) signaling pathway was discovered to be responsible for this change. This pathway is activated by different stimuli, including IFN-γ, which triggers the phosphorylation of serine residues in the coronin 1 protein. These phosphorylated residues interact with Eps8, a protein that links to the F-actin cytoskeleton and enhances its polymerization. This enhances the formation of macropinosomes and thus the internalization of bacteria. By inhibiting the PKC signaling pathway, it was possible to block the reprogramming of macrophages and thus prevent the internalization of bacteria.
The paper is about a study conducted in Arua District, Uganda to assess the knowledge, perceptions, and acceptance of tsetse baits (traps and targets) in villages where they had or had not been used previously. The study aimed to understand community acceptance of traps, which is a crucial element for successful tsetse control. The study involved 16 focus group discussions with male and female participants in eight villages across Arua District. Discussions were audio recorded, translated, and transcribed. The results showed that while communities in villages where tsetse baits had been used previously had positive attitudes towards them, communities in villages where baits had never been used had negative perceptions of them. The negative perceptions were related to the duration of experience with tsetse control programs, which were seen as harmful to livestock. The study recommends that early engagements with communities and carefully designed sensitization campaigns are needed to build acceptance of tsetse baits. This is important for successful tsetse control, which can help to reduce the risk of HAT in West Nile, Uganda.
Recombination is a fundamental biological process that allows for genetic diversity and evolution. It is especially important in the context of sex chromosomes, where recombination has been shown to be reduced or absent. Despite the importance of recombination, our understanding of the rates and distribution of recombination across the genome remains limited due to the difficulty of accurately detecting recombination events and the heterogeneity of recombination rates across the genome. In this study, we used high-throughput sequencing and a custom-designed mapping protocol to accurately detect and map recombination events in Drosophila melanogaster. We sequenced eight crosses involving RAL strains, which are a widely used strain set in Drosophila genetics. We mapped each cross to a reference genome and calculated recombination rates for each chromosome arm. We found that recombination rates vary significantly across the genome, with some regions having higher recombination rates and others having lower recombination rates. We also found that the distribution of recombination events is significantly overdispersed, suggesting that there may be some underlying biological mechanisms influencing the distribution of recombination events. Additionally, we found that there is a bias towards GC/G heterozygotes being preferentially repaired towards G and C nucleotides, which is consistent with a previous study on the same strain set. Overall, our study provides a comprehensive analysis of recombination rates and their distribution across the genome of Drosophila melanogaster.
In the present study, we have identified two IDN2 paralogs, IDP1 and IDP2, in Arabidopsis. IDN2 is a key component of the RdDM pathway that is required for DNA methylation and siRNA accumulation. The IDN2-IDP1/IDP2 complex facilitates the recruitment of effector complexes to specific chromatin regions at a downstream step of the RdDM pathway. Unlike IDN2, IDP1 and IDP2 are incapable of binding double-stranded RNA, suggesting that they have distinct roles in the IDN2-IDP1/IDP2 complex. The IDN2-IDP1/IDP2 complex plays a crucial role in the RdDM pathway, which is responsible for maintaining genome stability and regulating gene expression.
Neutrophils are an important part of the first line of defense against invading pathogens. During Leishmania infection, neutrophils play distinct roles depending on the combination of mouse strain and parasite species. In this study, we focused on understanding how neutrophils interact with Leishmania braziliensis, a parasite that causes cutaneous leishmaniasis. We found that exposure of neutrophils to L. braziliensis induces changes in the expression of surface molecules such as CD18 and CD62L, and leads to the oxidative burst. Using mCherry-expressing L. braziliensis, we determined that these effects were mainly observed in infected cells and not in bystander cells. We also found that neutrophils exposed to L. braziliensis release TNF-α and neutrophil elastase. Lastly, we found that neutrophils infected with L. braziliensis display markers of early apoptosis. We show that L. braziliensis induces neutrophil recruitment in vivo and that neutrophils exposed to L. braziliensis respond through activation and release of inflammatory mediators. This outcome may impact on parasite elimination, particularly at the early stages of infection.
This article describes the development of a within-herd transmission model of bovine tuberculosis (bTB) to evaluate the potential impact of new diagnostic tests on the control of bTB in Great Britain. The model was developed using an individual-based approach with stochastic processes to simulate the spread of infection between cattle within herds. The model includes the impact of various factors such as herd size, herd structure, and demographics on the transmission of bTB. It also incorporates the effects of vaccination on the transmission of bTB and the impact of different diagnostic tests on the detection of infected animals. The model was used to evaluate the effectiveness of different diagnostic tests and the potential impact of new diagnostic tests on the control of bTB in Great Britain. The article concludes by emphasizing the importance of considering the potential impact of new diagnostic tests on the control of bTB and the need for further research to better understand the effectiveness of new diagnostic tests in controlling the disease.
Trichuriasis is a neglected tropical disease caused by the whipworm Trichuris trichiura. It is estimated that 500 million people worldwide are infected and it is a leading cause of disability in children. Current treatments are not very effective and there is a need for new anthelmintic compounds. In this study, researchers screened 480 small molecules from a drug-like library against Trichuris muris using an automated motility assay. They identified a new class of molecules, the dihydrobenzoxazepinones, which are active against both the adult and egg stages of Trichuris. These compounds have low cytotoxicity against murine gut epithelial cells and one of the compounds, OX02983, was found to reduce the ability of embryonated T. muris eggs to establish infection in the mouse host in vivo. These results demonstrate the potential of the dihydrobenzoxazepinones as a new class of anthelmintic compounds active against both the egg and adult stages of Trichuris. They also highlight the potential for targeting the egg stage of the parasite in infection control strategies.
The original hypothesis that date hubs are global connectors is contested in the revised paper, as the effect of deleting date hubs on network connectivity is attributed to a small subset of them. The paper also explores the validity of the date/party dichotomy and suggests that the functional roles of hubs might be better described by link-centric measures rather than node-centric ones.
This paper describes the development of a new method to measure the information content of genetic data in different pathogen outbreaks. The authors introduce the concept of "transmission divergence," defined as the number of mutations separating whole genome sequences sampled from transmission pairs. They use parameter values obtained by literature review, and simulate outbreak scenarios alongside sequence evolution using two models described in the literature. The authors find that, while mean values vary significantly between the pathogens considered, their transmission divergence is generally very low. They also describe the impact of transmission divergence on our ability to reconstruct outbreaks using two outbreak reconstruction tools, the R packages outbreaker and phybreak. They illustrate the importance of transmission divergence for outbreak reconstruction and the need to expand the toolkit of outbreak reconstruction tools to integrate other types of epidemiological data.
This study aimed to identify escape genes in vivo in mouse tissues using RNA-seq and allele-specific expression analysis. A mouse model was used with complete skewing of the XCI of the spretus X due to an Xist mutation on the BL6 X. This model allowed for the identification of common and tissue-specific escape genes. The results showed that the percentage of escape genes varies between tissues, ranging from 3-7% in any tissue examined. The study also identified potential regulatory mechanisms for escape genes, such as CTCF occupancy. The findings of this study have significant implications for understanding the regulation of XCI and the maintenance of dosage compensation in mammals.
The manuscript entitled "Characterization of a novel cysteine protease from Plasmodium vivax" describes the molecular and biochemical characterization of a novel cysteine protease named VX-4 from Plasmodium vivax. The authors first identified VX-4 from a phylogenetic tree and then expressed and purified it from E. coli. They then determined the optimal conditions for refolding and characterized its enzymatic activity. The authors also performed a kinetic analysis of VX-4 and determined its substrate specificity. Finally, they performed immunoblotting experiments and found that VX-4 is expressed in the erythrocytic stages of P. vivax.
This is a scientific paper that describes the reconstruction of a metabolic and gene expression (ME) model for the acetogen Clostridium ljungdahlii. The model was reconstructed using existing literature and data, and includes all major central metabolic, amino acid, nucleotide, lipid, major cofactors, and vitamin synthesis pathways as well as pathways to synthesis RNA and protein molecules necessary to catalyze these reactions. The model accurately predicted secretion of acetate, ethanol, and glycerol during changing carbon and metal availability and revealed how protein allocation and media composition influence metabolic pathways and energy conservation in this model acetogen. The paper provides a valuable resource for researchers interested in understanding acetogen metabolism and its potential for biotechnological applications.
In this study, the authors used genome-wide association analysis to identify differentially expressed genes in a panel of primary osteoblasts from patients with osteoporosis and healthy controls. The analysis revealed a list of 274,097 probesets, including 17,749 meta-probesets, that were differentially expressed between osteoporotic and control bone samples. The authors then focused on probesets that were associated with flanking single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) within 250 Kb of the flanking genes. This analysis revealed 101 probesets that were differentially expressed in response to specific SNPs, and the authors then validated these associations using real-time PCR. Finally, the authors identified a set of 28 candidate genes, including FAM118A, that were differentially expressed in response to specific SNPs and that were also associated with osteoporosis in previous studies. These findings provide a valuable resource for further research into the genetic and molecular mechanisms underlying osteoporosis.
Scientists have discovered a new way to make a type of beer called lager. They found a way to make it using a yeast called Saccharomyces eubayanus, which is not commonly used in brewing. This yeast does not use a certain type of sugar called maltotriose, which is found in the wort used to make beer. To fix this problem, the scientists used a technique called laboratory evolution to make the yeast use maltotriose. They did this by exposing the yeast to chemicals and then growing it in a special type of food called wort. After several rounds of this process, the yeast was able to use maltotriose. The scientists also found that this process happened because of a change in the yeast's genes, which is a common way for living things to adapt to their environment. This change allowed the yeast to use a new type of food that it could not use before.
Influenza is a serious health concern and its strains with distinct antigenicity are a significant threat to public health. Researchers have developed a novel model called "EADpred" to assess the mortality burden of influenza A ( H1N1 ) virus by accurately predicting its antigenic distance to its previous strains for each season. The model uses the antigenic distance to predict the total excess all-cause mortality caused by influenza A ( H1N1 ) virus in a given season. The model was tested using data from 1977 to 2009 and was found to have a high predictive accuracy. This study demonstrates that the antigenic distance of influenza virus can be used to predict the mortality burden of influenza, which can help in formulating cost-effective control and intervention strategies for influenza.
This study examines the virulence factors of the Asian Soybean Rust pathogen, Phakopsora pachyrhizi. The authors identify a small cysteine-rich protein, PpEC23, that suppresses the plant's defense system, allowing the rust fungus to grow and spread. The authors also show that PpEC23 interacts with a soybean transcription factor, GmSPL12l, which is involved in the plant's defense response. This study provides important insights into how pathogens manipulate the host plant's immune system to establish infection and cause disease.
We have identified the EphA2 receptor as a host-derived protein that Chlamydia trachomatis adheres to and invades through during infection. We have shown that Chlamydia-induced activation of the PI3K-Akt signaling pathway is mediated through EphA2 and that the loss of EphA2 leads to increased sensitivity of the host cells to apoptosis induction. Our findings suggest that EphA2 functions as a signaling receptor that Chlamydia utilizes to modulate the host cell response during infection.
In this study, we propose a model that explains the role of active dendritic conductances in dendritic excitability. We show that, owing to the non-linear properties of active dendritic conductances, the average output of a model of an active dendritic tree is a highly non-linear function of its afferent rate. This allows dendrites to enlarge their dynamic range, reaching an average output of over 50 dB. Our model also yields double-sigmoid response functions, as observed in retinal ganglion cells, and we claim that the enhancement of dynamic range is the primary functional role of active dendritic conductances.
Bacteria use regulatory networks to adapt to different environments. The study of these networks is important for understanding bacterial behavior and for applications in fields such as biotechnology, drug discovery, and medicine. However, the study of these networks is challenging because it requires the inference of regulatory interactions from noisy time-series data. In this work, we use fluorescent reporter proteins to monitor gene expression in real time. We then develop a method to correct for the difference between mRNA and protein concentrations and to incorporate global physiological effects in the inference of regulatory interactions. We apply our method to the study of the FliA-FlgM module in the E. coli motility network, using both wild-type and mutant strains, and in different growth conditions. We find that the inclusion of protein concentrations and global physiological effects is necessary to obtain a reliable inference of the regulatory interactions. We then use the derived regulatory model to predict the dynamics of the network, both structurally and quantitatively, and find that our inference method allows the model to fit the observed data much better than a previously used approach.
This paper describes a study of the distribution and dynamics of Oligoryzomys fulvescens, a rodent species in Panama, using non-spatial and spatial statistical analyses. The authors found that there were heterogeneous patterns in the population densities and dispersal of O. fulvescens, which varied across seasons and among years. The species typically was locally absent during the late transitional months of the season, and re-established locally in subsequent years. These populations re-occurred in the same area during the first three years but subsequently re-established further south in the final year of the study. The spatial autocorrelation analyses indicated that local populations encompassed approximately 300–600 m. The borders between suitable and unsuitable habitats were sharply demarcated over short distances. O. fulvescens showed a well-defined spatial pattern that evolved over time, and led to a pattern of changing aggregation. Thus, hot spots of abundance showed a general shifting pattern that helps explain the intermittent risk from pathogens transmitted by this species. This variation was associated with seasonality, as well as anthropogenic pressures that occurred with agricultural activities. These factors help define the characteristics of the occurrence, timing, intensity, and duration of synanthropic populations affected by human populations and, consequently, the potential exposure that local human populations experience. The authors conclude that the results of their study provide insight into the spatial and temporal dynamics of rodent hosts, which may help explain the risk of pathogens that are transmitted from wildlife to humans.
The article describes a new method for predicting the impact of amino acid changes on the antigenic phenotype of influenza A viruses. The method, called antigenic tree inference, is based on a least-squares optimization procedure that fits pairwise antigenic distances onto an evolutionary tree for the major antigenic determinant of influenza A viruses. The authors applied this method to infer antigenic trees for human influenza A viruses from 1968 to 2003. They found that the method accurately predicted the antigenic distances between isolates based on antigenic cartography data. Additionally, the authors identified known and novel antigenic types, as well as the amino acid changes associated with the transition between antigenic types. The method could also be used to predict the antigenic impact of individual amino acid exchanges in the evolution of influenza A viruses. The authors suggest that this method could be useful for understanding the evolution of influenza A viruses and predicting the antigenic properties of novel viral isolates.
Using a high-throughput RNAi screen, we identified host cell factors and processes that are required for the entry of human papillomavirus 16 (HPV16) into cells. HPV16 entry requires the permeabilization of the nuclear envelope and association of the virus with host cell chromatin. Mitosis is important for HPV16 nuclear entry since it allows the association of the virus with host cell chromatin aligned on the metaphase plate. Our findings provide a mechanistic insight into the process of HPV16 entry into host cells.
This article presents a detailed description of the genome sequence of the banana fungus Phytophthora fijiensis, a major cause of banana plantations disease. The authors used a combination of genetic mapping and sequencing techniques to assemble the genome, and identified over 10,000 predicted protein-coding genes. The article also includes a description of the resistance mechanisms and virulence factors present in the fungus, as well as a comparison of the P. fijiensis genome to the genomes of other plant pathogens.
The study presents a new approach for analyzing the evolution of regulatory elements in different species. Traditional approaches focus on the conservation of sequences to identify regulatory elements. However, this new approach uses a birth-death model to trace the evolution of lineage-specific binding sites without relying on detailed base-by-base cross-species alignments. The model was applied to analyze the evolution of binding sites based on the ChIP-seq data for six transcription factors (GATA1, SOX2, CTCF, MYC, MAX, ETS1) along the lineage toward human after human-mouse common ancestor. The results indicate that a substantial fraction of binding sites in humans have origins since the divergence with mouse. The study also found that over 15% of all binding sites are unique to hominids. These elements are often enriched near genes associated with specific pathways and harbor more common SNPs than older binding sites in the human genome. The results support the ability of the method to identify lineage-specific regulatory elements and help understand their roles in shaping variation in gene regulation across species.
In this study, the authors identify a region of the zebrafish per2 promoter that is required for light-driven per2 expression in both vivo and vitro conditions. They use a combination of transient expression assays, transgenic fish lines, and knock-down experiments to characterize this regulatory region. The authors find that a 43-base-pair region of the per2 promoter is sufficient to drive light-dependent per2 expression and that this region contains two transcription factor binding sites, one for the circadian clock protein BMAL1 and one for the light-inducible transcription factor TEFI. The authors also show that TEFI is required for light-driven per2 expression and that it acts through the E-box binding site in the per2 promoter. These findings provide important insights into the mechanisms of light entrainment in the zebrafish circadian clock.
This article describes a study that investigated the role of coronin in Plasmodium berghei sporozoites, the human malaria parasite's stage that infects mosquitoes. The authors found that coronin is required for efficient transmission of the parasite from mosquitoes to mice. They also demonstrated that coronin plays a role in sporozoite motility through actin filament-binding. Lastly, they suggest a switch in signaling pathways linking calcium- and cAMP- mediated signaling during migration and invasion.
This study describes the characterization of Leishmania mexicana strains with altered sterol composition and function. The study used whole-genome sequencing and RNA sequencing to identify genetic changes in these strains, and qRT-PCR and western blotting to validate the results. The study also showed that these strains are more resistant to amphotericin B and have altered intracellular growth patterns in macrophages. The findings of this study provide a better understanding of the mechanisms behind drug resistance in Leishmania parasites, and may inform the development of new drugs to combat these infections.
How does the brain process information from visual stimuli? Using EEG data from a visual grating task, we analyzed how attention and prediction affect the neural representation of visual features. We found that attention modulates the neural response to the predicted stimulus but not to the unpredicted stimulus, and that the neural representation of the predicted stimulus is more robust across trials. These results suggest that attention enhances the neural representation of information that is expected to be most relevant, while also reducing the neural response to unexpected information.
The sub-Saharan African parasite Trypanosoma brucei causes the deadly disease human African sleeping sickness (HASS). There are three main sub-species of T. brucei that differ in their virulence towards humans and animals. One sub-species, T. b. rhodesiense, is highly virulent to both humans and animals, while the other two sub-species, T. b. gambiense and T. b. brucei, are less virulent to humans, but can still cause serious disease in animals. Previous research has shown that the serum resistance mechanism of T. b. rhodesiense is dependent on the expression of a serum resistance associated (SRA) gene. However, the serum resistance mechanism of T. b. gambiense is not yet understood. In this study, the authors investigate the serum resistance mechanism of T. b. gambiense by comparing the properties of the human serum resistance phenotypes of two different T. b. gambiense sub-groups. They found that one sub-group had a variable human serum resistance phenotype, similar to T. b. rhodesiense, while the other sub-group had a stable human serum resistance phenotype. The authors then used recombinant APOL1, a human serum factor that is part of the trypanolytic factor (TLF) complex, to investigate whether this complex is involved in the serum resistance of T. b. gambiense. They found that the variable sub-group of T. b. gambiense was resistant to APOL1, while the stable sub-group was sensitive. This suggests that the serum resistance mechanism of T. b. gambiense may be different from that of T. b. rhodesiense, and may involve a different trypanolytic factor.
The current paper is about investigating whether DNA methylation of the HIV-1 long terminal repeat (LTR) plays a role in regulating HIV-1 latency. The authors use a model of HIV-1 latency and a patient study to investigate the role of methylation in controlling the reactivation of HIV-1 from latency. They find that DNA methylation of the HIV-1 LTR plays a role in controlling the reactivation of HIV-1, but not in the initial suppression of HIV-1 transcription. The authors also show that DNA methylation of the HIV-1 LTR differs between patients with different levels of HIV-1 viremia.
A study has been conducted to identify genetic variants in 39 lines of the Drosophila melanogaster Genetic Reference Panel (DGRP) using an integrative and local assembly-based approach for variant discovery. The study identifies more than 3 . 6 million distinct variants, among which are over 800,000 unique insertions, deletions (indels), and complex variants (1 to 6,000 bp). The SNP density is higher near other variants, but variants themselves are not mutagenic, nor are regions with high variant density particularly mutation-prone. Rather, the elevated SNP density around variants is mainly due to population-level processes. The study also provides insights into the regulatory architecture of gene expression variation in adult flies by mapping cis-expression quantitative trait loci (cis-eQTLs) for more than 2,000 genes. Indels comprise around 10% of all cis-eQTLs and show larger effects than SNP cis-eQTLs. The study identifies two-fold more gene associations in males as compared to females and finds that most cis-eQTLs are sex-specific, revealing a partial decoupling of the genomic architecture between the sexes as well as the importance of genetic factors in mediating sex-biased gene expression. Finally, the study performs RNA-seq-based allelic expression imbalance analyses in the offspring of crosses between sequenced lines, which reveals that the majority of strong cis-eQTLs can be validated in heterozygous individuals. The full catalog of variants can be obtained from dgrp.epfl.ch/downloads and the RNA-seq data are available in the ArrayExpress Database using accession number E-MTAB-1266.
The relationship between the rectified surface electromyographic (EMG) signal and the neural drive to muscles can be influenced by amplitude cancellation. Amplitude cancellation refers to the reduction of the total amplitude of the sum of individual motor unit action potentials compared to the rectified EMG signal. This reduction can be modeled as a signal-dependent noise term, which in turn alters the power spectrum of the rectified EMG signal. The extent of this distortion is greatest for low frequencies, which reduces the ability to accurately infer individual frequency components of the neural drive from the rectified EMG signal.
The YUC family of enzymes is involved in the regulation of auxin production, which is important for root growth and development. The authors investigated the role of YUC enzymes in the regulation of auxin production during root growth inhibition in response to aluminum (Al) stress. The results show that YUC enzymes are involved in regulating the local production of auxin, which is important for the regulation of root growth and development. The authors also identified transcription factors, such as EIN3, PIF4, and ARF1, that are involved in the regulation of YUC enzymes during root growth inhibition in response to Al stress.
In this study, researchers investigated the function of natural killer (NK) cells in controlling simian immunodeficiency virus (SIV) infection in rhesus macaques. They found that certain SIV peptides, which bind to specific receptors on NK cells called killer-cell immunoglobulin-like receptors (KIRs), can suppress the activity of NK cells. These findings suggest that SIV may have evolved mechanisms to evade detection by NK cells, which could contribute to the ability of SIV to establish and maintain long-term infections in macaques. The researchers also discovered that changes in certain residues of SIV peptides can affect their ability to inhibit NK cells, providing a possible basis for the emergence of SIV variants with altered virulence. These findings provide important insights into the complex interactions between viruses and host immune cells, and highlight the potential for viruses to evade the immune response and cause disease.
In this study, we describe the in vitro evolution of a strain of Haemophilus influenzae (H. influenzae) that has undergone microevolution in response to nutrient limitation. We identified a single-nucleotide mutation in the icc gene, which encodes a 3′, 5′-cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) phosphodiesterase, that contributes to the adaptation of this strain to an intracellular niche. The mutation results in an amino acid change in the enzyme that alters its cAMP phosphodiesterase activity. This mutation is likely to be responsible for the increased intracellular survival of the mutant strain in the presence of a heme-iron restriction. Additionally, the mutant strain exhibits increased virulence in a chinchilla model of H. influenzae infection, leading to increased inflammation and a higher number of bacterial cells in the middle ear. Overall, our findings suggest that microevolution in response to nutrient limitation can lead to increased virulence and adaptation to the intracellular environment in H. influenzae.
The immune response of mammals to bacterial infections is mediated by many different mechanisms, one of which is the control of iron availability for the pathogen. Iron is essential for bacterial growth and virulence, and limiting its availability to the pathogen has been shown to be an effective strategy to restrict its growth. The bacterium Burkholderia pseudomallei is a gram-negative, non-spore forming bacterium that causes the disease melioidosis in humans and animals. It has been shown that B. pseudomallei is able to grow under iron-limiting conditions, and that its ability to acquire iron from its environment is crucial for its growth and virulence. In this study, the authors investigated the mechanisms by which B. pseudomallei is able to acquire iron from its environment, and how these mechanisms are affected by the host immune response. They found that B. pseudomallei is able to acquire iron through a variety of mechanisms, including the use of siderophores, heme, and transferrin. They also found that the host immune response is able to limit the availability of iron to B. pseudomallei, through the upregulation of iron-binding proteins and the downregulation of iron export systems. The authors conclude that the ability of B. pseudomallei to acquire iron is crucial for its growth and virulence, and that the host immune response plays an important role in limiting its ability to do so.
The paper presents a new method called "functional mode analysis" (FMA) that allows for identifying the collective motion of a protein that is directly related to a particular protein function. This method is applied to four biomolecules to illustrate its use: a polyalanine helix, T4 lysozyme, Trp-cage, and leucine-binding protein. In FMA, a functional quantity that quantifies the functional state of the protein is used. The technique seeks the collective motion that is maximally correlated to the functional quantity and optimizes it iteratively. The method is useful to understand the relation between the protein function and its motions.
This study provides an in-depth analysis of the order of intron removal in the nuclear genes of Euglena gracilis, a unicellular eukaryotic organism. The researchers used a combination of sequencing technologies and bioinformatics to analyze the splicing of introns in two genes of Euglena gracilis. They found that the order of intron removal is not always consistent with the arrangement of introns in the gene, and that this process can take place much later than expected. The researchers also identified a set of introns that are removed much later than the others, and suggest that this may be due to their unusual structure or the presence of alternative splicing. Overall, this study provides a valuable resource for researchers studying eukaryotic splicing and the formation of introns.
In this study, the authors developed a mouse model of juvenile infection with a subclinical dose of coxsackievirus B3 (CVB3) that caused no evident symptoms either immediately following infection or in adult mice. However, following physiological or pharmacologically-induced cardiac stress, juvenile-infected adult mice underwent cardiac hypertrophy and dilation indicative of progression to heart failure. The authors also observed a compensatory increase in CD31+ blood vessel formation in the hearts of adult mice subjected to cardiac stress, but this effect was suppressed in juvenile-infected mice. Additionally, CVB3 efficiently infected juvenile c-kit+ cells, and cardiac progenitor cell numbers were reduced in the hearts of juvenile-infected adult mice. These results suggest that the exhausted cardiac progenitor cell pool following juvenile CVB3 infection may impair the heart's ability to increase capillary density to adapt to increased load. This study provides evidence that a mild CVB3 infection may predispose the heart to pathologic remodeling later in adult life.
The current paper investigates the role of caspase-1 in the pathogenesis of Burkholderia pseudomallei, a bacterium that causes melioidosis. Melioidosis is a rare but often fatal infection that is endemic in certain regions of Southeast Asia and Northern Australia. The study shows that caspase-1 is activated in infected macrophages and plays a key role in the induction of pyroptosis, an inflammatory form of cell death. The paper also shows that caspase-1 activation is required for the production of reactive oxygen species (ROS) and the release of pro-inflammatory cytokines. In addition, the study shows that caspase-1 is activated in response to flagellin, a protein found in the flagella of B. pseudomallei. Flagellin is known to be a potent activator of caspase-1 in other bacterial infections, including Salmonella enterica and Listeria monocytogenes. Taken together, the study suggests that caspase-1 plays an important role in the host response to B. pseudomallei infection and may be a potential target for therapeutic intervention.
In this study, we isolated kinβγ knockout mutants and found that kinβγ plays an important role in pollen germination on the stigma surface. The kinβγ knockout mutants exhibited defective pollen germination in vivo and in vitro, which was attributed to the reduced ROS level in the pollen. The results suggest that the kinβγ knockout mutants have a defect in the pollen–stigma interface, which is a critical step for pollen germination.
The study shows that RNase III is essential for Bacillus subtilis to survive. It degrades two type I toxin-encoding mRNAs, txpA and yonT, which are from two prophages (Skin and SPβ) in the bacterial genome. The researchers used multiple techniques to investigate the role of RNase III in the degradation of these mRNAs, including RNA sequencing, Northern blot analysis, and in vitro RNA cleavage assays. The study suggests that the essential role of RNase III in Bacillus subtilis is to protect the cell from the expression of harmful toxin genes in prophages.
We have shown that EV release is not restricted to infective stage parasites but is conserved across the life cycle of B. malayi. The Excretory/Secretory system represents one mechanism for EV release, which are uniformly internalized by murine macrophages via phagocytosis. EVs from different life stages of Brugia spp. contain known and putative host immunomodulatory molecules but the asymmetric distribution of these molecules between male and female worms suggests Brugia’s ability to modulate the host immune response may have a sexual dimorphic element.
The article describes a study conducted to determine the prevalence of scabies and impetigo in the rural villages of the Western Province in the Solomon Islands. The study found that scabies is a very common skin condition that affects people of all ages, with infants and young children being particularly vulnerable. The article also highlights the importance of proper diagnosis and treatment of scabies and impetigo to prevent the spread of these skin conditions.
We found a correlation between the proportion of CD8+ and CD4+ T cells in the brain of adult mice and the rate of adult neurogenesis in the hippocampus. This correlation is likely due to shared genetic loci, with the exception of the H-2Ea locus which had a dominant influence on T cell subsets but no impact on neurogenesis. We also found that CD4+ T cells or subpopulations thereof mediate the effect. Our results suggest that the natural genetic variation that controls T cell development and homeostasis has a broader impact on hippocampal function than previously thought. Specifically, our findings suggest that adult neurogenesis may be involved in the known functions of the hippocampus, such as learning and memory, and may have additional roles that are as yet unknown.
Chagas disease is caused by Trypanosoma cruzi and is a major health problem in Latin America. We previously screened the T. cruzi sequence database and identified 71 potential vaccine candidates. We now report the development of a DNA-prime/protein-boost vaccine (TcVac2) consisting of three antigen candidates (TcG1-TcG3) that were phylogenetically conserved in clinically important strains of T. cruzi, expressed in the infective and intracellular stages of the parasite, and elicited lytic antibody responses in immunized mice. We further tested the protective efficacy of TcVac2 in mice challenged with T. cruzi. The results suggest that TcVac2 induced robust antibody and cell-mediated immune responses against T. cruzi and provided protection from acute parasitemia and chronic parasite persistence and immunopathology in chagasic mice.
Type 1 diabetes (T1D) is a complex disease with multiple genetic factors contributing to its pathogenesis. In this study, we aimed to compare different machine learning approaches for predicting T1D risk. We used the largest T1D dataset available, which includes ∼1, 500 samples from the 1958 British Birth Cohort, ∼1, 500 samples from the UK Blood Service Control Group, as well as ∼2, 000 samples each from the disease collections: type 1 diabetes ( T1D ) , type 2 diabetes ( T2D ) , rheumatoid arthritis ( RA ) , inflammatory bowel disease ( IBD ) , bipolar disorder ( BD ) , hypertension ( HT ) , coronary artery disease ( CAD ) , as previously described . We applied a support vector machine ( SVM ) algorithm, a widely used method in machine learning, for predicting T1D risk in three different case-control datasets. We also compared the performance of SVM with that of logistic regression ( LR ), a commonly used approach in genetic studies. We found that SVM performed better than LR in terms of both sensitivity and specificity. Our results suggest that SVM may be a useful tool for predicting T1D risk and for personalized medicine in T1D.
In this study, we examined the role of circulating memory CD8+ T cells in the response to skin viral infection. We found that memory CD8+ T cells from the circulation rapidly enter the skin following infection, regardless of their ability to survey peripheral lymph nodes. We also found that memory CD8+ T cells that enter the skin do not express CD103 and become functional CD69+/CD103- TRM following the resolution of viral infection. Furthermore, we found that the differentiation of memory CD8+ T cells to the TRM phenotype is dependent on the expression of genes that regulate tissue retention, including CD62L and KLRG1. Our findings highlight the importance of the tissue microenvironment in determining the fate of circulating memory CD8+ T cells following skin viral infection.
In this article, the authors describe how a specific protein is localized to either the axon or the dendrites of neurons. The axon is the long, slender part of a neuron that sends out signals to other neurons, while the dendrites are the branching parts that receive signals from other neurons. The authors show that a protein called Myosin VI is specifically localized to the dendrites of neurons, and they explain how they know this. They also show that another protein, Nav1.2, is specifically localized to the axon of neurons, and they explain how they know this as well. This information is important because it helps us understand how different parts of a neuron can have different properties, which is essential for how neurons work together to form networks in the brain.
In the animal kingdom, there are two main types of sex determination: genetic and environmental. In genetic sex determination, the sex of an individual is determined by genetic factors. In environmental sex determination, the sex of an individual is determined by environmental cues. Daphnia magna is a freshwater branchiopod crustacean that undergoes environmental sex determination. Recent studies have identified two Dsx genes in D. magna that play a role in the development of male and female traits. One of these genes, DapmaDsx1, is responsible for the male trait when expressed during environmental sex determination. The domain organization of DapmaDsx1 is similar to that of Dsx genes from insects, which are thought to be the sister group of branchiopod crustaceans. However, the molecular basis for sexually dimorphic expression of DapmaDsx1 is different from that of insects. During embryogenesis, expression of DapmaDsx1 is increased only in males and its transcripts are primarily detected in male-specific structures. Knock-down of DapmaDsx1 in male embryos results in the production of female traits including ovarian maturation, whereas ectopic expression of DapmaDsx1 in female embryos results in the development of male-like phenotypes. These results establish DapmaDsx1 as a key regulator of the male phenotype in D. magna. Our findings reveal how environmental sex determination is implemented by selective expression of a fundamental genetic component that is functionally conserved in animals using genetic sex determination. We infer that there is an ancient, previously unidentified link between genetic and environmental sex determination.
In this study, we evaluated the efficacy of a trivalent HSV-2 vaccine containing gC2, gD2 and gE2 subunit proteins in protecting rhesus macaques from vaginal challenge with HSV-2. The vaccine was designed to provide improved protection against HSV-2 by targeting multiple HSV-2 proteins that are important for virus entry and replication. The vaccine was formulated with CpG oligonucleotide and alum adjuvants to enhance immune responses. The results showed that the trivalent vaccine induced high levels of neutralizing antibodies against HSV-2, which were associated with a lower rate of vaginal shedding of HSV-2 DNA and lower levels of replication competent virus after challenge. The trivalent vaccine also provided better protection against genital lesions than the gD2 vaccine alone, which suggests that targeting multiple HSV-2 proteins can improve vaccine efficacy. Overall, these results demonstrate the potential of a trivalent HSV-2 vaccine containing gC2, gD2 and gE2 subunit proteins to provide improved protection against HSV-2 infection in humans.
Segmental duplications and other highly repetitive regions of the genome make it difficult to map protein-DNA interactions with ChIP-seq. Our research has developed a new analytical method, called Perm-seq, that can accurately allocate multi-mapping reads in these regions. We found that our prior-enhanced approach significantly improves multi-read allocation accuracy over methods that do not use additional data types. We applied Perm-seq to ENCODE ChIP-seq datasets from 64 different factors and found many novel protein-DNA interactions in segmental duplication regions. We also analyzed the sequence characteristics of these novel interactions and found that they shared overall sequence characteristics with protein-DNA interactions in non-repetitive regions. Our research has important implications for the study of transcriptional regulation in repetitive regions of the genome.
This study explored the link between schistosomiasis, a parasitic worm infection, and HIV-1 transmission in Tanzania. The authors analyzed data from a population of adults living in seven villages in the Magu District, who were tested for HIV in 2007, 2010, and 2013. The study found that women with schistosome infection had a higher odds of becoming HIV-1-infected than those without. In addition, the study found that the odds of becoming HIV-1-infected were higher in women with S. haematobium infection than in those with S. mansoni infection. The study also found that individuals with active schistosome infection at the time of HIV-1 acquisition may have impaired immune control of HIV-1, resulting in higher HIV-1 viral loads at the time of HIV-1 seroconversion.
We discovered that rDNA copy number is altered in cancer genomes. Copy number changes can be both global and regional. We found that rDNA copy number is reduced in cancer genomes with mTOR activation. We also discovered co-occurring increased copy number of additional genes. These data suggest that rDNA copy number can be altered in a natural system. Additionally, we discovered that copy loss does not compromise proliferation, rRNA production, or protein synthesis in mouse HSCs. These findings provide evidence that rDNA copy number can be altered in a natural system and does not necessarily affect ribosome biogenesis.
We have reported an integrated approach to investigate bacterial growth dynamics in Salmonella Typhimurium infection. We followed the fate of eight wild-type isogenic tagged strains ( WITS ) in the spleen and liver of infected mice and their blood over the course of a systemic infection. By comparing the dynamics of each subpopulation at different body sites, we were able to dissect the determinants of net growth at different infection stages. Our results show that during the early phase of infection, bacteria replicate and grow in the organs via a homogeneous process, and spread between organs via a stochastic process, but after 24 h p.i., bacterial growth becomes heterogeneous, and spread between organs becomes more deterministic. We also found that components of the immune response affect spatiotemporal bacterial population dynamics. The methods developed in this study will facilitate our understanding of bacterial growth dynamics in other animal models of infection and will provide a paradigm shift in our understanding of the whole animal infection process.
In this paper, the authors propose a new approach to solving the inverse problem of binocular 3D motion perception. They suggest that local velocity constraints in combination with binocular disparity and other depth cues provide a more flexible framework for the solution of the inverse problem. In the context of the aperture problem, they derive predictions from two plausible default strategies and predict perceived motion directions for ambiguous line motion. Their theoretical results suggest that velocity constraints and disparity from feature tracking are needed to solve the inverse problem of 3D motion perception. It seems plausible that motion and disparity input is processed in parallel and integrated late in the visual processing hierarchy.
The O-acetylation of alginate, a polysaccharide produced by cystic fibrosis patients, by P. aeruginosa enzymes is important for bacterial survival and persistence in the cystic fibrosis lung. The O-acetylation of alginate by P. aeruginosa enzymes is mediated by three enzymes: AlgX, AlgA, and AlgJ. AlgX and AlgA are O-acetyltransferases that transfer an acetyl group to the C6 carboxylic acid of alginate, while AlgJ is a ligase that seals the O-acetylated alginate chain. In this study, the crystal structure of P. aeruginosa AlgJ, AlgJ79–379, was determined.
