This prediction was confirmed experimentally by immunoblot analysis of SR-B1 protein expression in hepatic membranes. The computational analysis provided an integrative understanding of the dynamic response induced by T0901317 treatment that was not directly apparent from the experimental data itself. The ADAPT approach has the potential to be applied to a wide range of systems biology models to study the effects of pharmacological interventions on biological systems.
The spinocerebellar system is responsible for coordinating complex movements, which require precise control of multiple limb segments. In the cerebellum, this is achieved through the integration of sensory information from the periphery and motor commands from the cerebral cortex. The integration of sensory information from multiple afferent fibers into a single output signal is mediated by granule cells (GrCs), which are contacted by parallel fibers (PFs) that receive input from numerous sensory afferents. In this context, we explore how the spinocerebellar system might implement a mathematical function that integrates information from multiple dimensions, which is necessary for coordinating complex movements. Specifically, we consider how the system might integrate information from multiple joints to coordinate movements of multiple limb segments. We examine how the system can utilize the linear recombination properties of GrCs to implement a function that approximates non-linear relationships between multiple joint angles and velocities, which is necessary for coordinating movements of multiple limb segments. We also consider how the system can utilize the non-linear properties of GrCs to implement a function that approximates non-linear relationships between multiple joint angles, velocities, and accelerations, which is necessary for coordinating movements of multiple limb segments. Our findings suggest that the spinocerebellar system might implement a function that approximates non-linear relationships between multiple joint angles, velocities, and accelerations using a combination of linear and non-linear recombination of sensory information.
A study was conducted to determine how microRNAs are impacted when Aedes albopictus mosquitoes are infected with Chikungunya virus. The researchers sequenced small RNA libraries from two mosquito cell lines: one uninfected and one infected with CHIKV. They identified 88 known and 79 novel microRNAs in the uninfected cell line and 79 known and 9 novel microRNAs in the infected cell line. Comparing the two cell lines, they found that 77 microRNAs were differentially expressed. The researchers then used computational methods to identify potential targets for these microRNAs, and classified the targets into their respective pathways. Their findings provide insight into how microRNAs are regulated during CHIKV infection in Ae. albopictus and may lead to the development of antiviral strategies.
Cystic echinococcosis (CE) is a parasitic infection that affects humans and livestock, and causes significant medical and economic problems in many developing countries. In Iran, CE has a considerable economic impact, with an estimated annual cost of US$232.3 million including both direct and indirect costs. This study has also estimated the cost per surgical human case at US$1,539 and the cost associated with human CE at US$93.39 million. The cost associated with livestock CE was estimated at US$132 million. These estimates can be used to inform decision-makers about the costs of CE and to prioritize limited resources for preventive measures.
Mouse polyomavirus (MPyV) is a small circular DNA virus that infects mouse cells and causes tumors in rodents. The virus has two phases of infection, early and late, and both phases are important for its ability to transform cells. During the late phase of infection, the virus produces large amounts of viral RNA, which is then processed into viral proteins. In this study, the authors used deep sequencing to analyze MPyV infection in mouse cells. They found that early and late viral transcripts were produced during both early and late phases of infection, but that there were major changes in the processing and editing of viral transcripts during the late phase of infection. They also found that many host genes were significantly upregulated or downregulated during MPyV infection, and that these changes were associated with specific biological processes, such as metabolism, DNA replication, and protein turnover. The authors also found that MPyV infection caused significant changes in the expression of several long noncoding RNAs. Together, these results provide a detailed picture of MPyV infection and its effects on host cell metabolism and gene expression.
The mathematical model presented in this paper is used to explain the variation in human endurance running performance observed over several decades. The model uses a data-driven approach to predict the relationship between running speed, maximal aerobic intensity, and carbohydrate metabolism. The model is based on a simplified metabolic model that assumes constant rates of fat and carbohydrate oxidation as a function of running speed. The model also accounts for the effects of muscle glycogen depletion and liver glycogen storage on running performance. The model is applied to the data of Karlsson and colleagues, who measured the performance of 169 marathon runners over a 30-year period. The results of the model suggest that the variation in marathon performance can be explained by variations in running speed and maximal aerobic intensity. The model also predicts the effect of carbohydrate loading on running performance, and suggests that a strategy of carbohydrate loading can be effective for improving performance at speeds above approximately 70% of maximal aerobic intensity. The model is also used to estimate the maximal distance that a runner can run before glycogen depletion becomes significant, and suggests that this distance is approximately 20 kilometers for a runner of average speed and maximal aerobic intensity. The model is applied to the data of Maggioni and colleagues, who measured the performance of 54 marathon runners over a 10-year period, and suggests that the variation in marathon performance over the course of a decade can be explained by changes in running speed and maximal aerobic intensity. The model also suggests that the variation in marathon performance can be explained by the effects of carbohydrate loading on running performance, and the effects of muscle glycogen depletion and liver glycogen storage on running performance. The model is also used to estimate the maximal distance that a runner can run before glycogen depletion becomes significant, and suggests that this distance is approximately 22 kilometers for a runner of average speed and maximal aerobic intensity. The model is applied to the data of Karlsson and colleagues, who measured the performance of 169 marathon runners over a 30-year period, and suggests that the variation in marathon performance can be explained by variations in running speed and maximal aerobic intensity. The model also predicts the effect of carbohydrate loading on running performance, and suggests that a strategy of carbohydrate loading can be effective for improving performance at speeds above approximately 70% of maximal aerobic intensity. The model is also used to estimate the maximal distance that a runner can run before glycogen depletion becomes significant, and suggests that this distance is approximately 20 kilometers for a runner of average speed and maximal aerobic intensity. The model is applied to the data of Maggioni and colleagues, who measured the performance of 54 marathon runners over a 10-year period, and suggests that the variation in marathon performance over the course of a decade can be explained by changes in running speed and maximal aerobic intensity. The model also suggests that the variation in marathon performance can be explained by the effects of carbohydrate loading on running performance, and the effects of muscle glycogen depletion and liver glycogen storage on running performance. The model is also used to estimate the maximal distance that a runner can run before glycogen depletion becomes significant, and suggests that this distance is approximately 22 kilometers for a runner of average speed and maximal aerobic intensity.
Toxoplasma gondii is an apicomplexan parasite that infects most warm-blooded animals, including humans. It has been extensively studied due to its prevalence and potential effects on human health, including congenital malformations and severe ocular disease. However, the diversity of Toxoplasma strains has historically been underappreciated. Recent studies have identified several distinct clades of Toxoplasma strains, including the classical type I strains, as well as atypical strains that are more prevalent in South America and have been associated with severe disease. The goal of this study was to investigate the genomic and transcriptomic differences between Toxoplasma strains from different clades to gain a better understanding of the genetic determinants of virulence in Toxoplasma. The authors used RNA-seq to analyze the transcriptomes of Toxoplasma-infected mouse macrophages in order to identify host and parasite genes that are differentially regulated in a strain-specific manner. They found that several strains were able to induce the host interferon response, which is thought to be detrimental to the parasite. They also identified parasite genes that were differentially expressed between virulent and avirulent strains, and found that some of these genes were located within large chromosomal rearrangements. Overall, this study provides important insights into the genetic basis of virulence in Toxoplasma, and highlights the importance of considering strain diversity when studying this parasite.
The study "Isolation and characterization of recombinant polioviruses from heterologous transfection of template RNAs" provides a comprehensive description of the isolation and characterization of recombinant polioviruses from heterologous transfection of template RNAs. The study uses a novel reverse genetic system to isolate recombinant viruses from transfected cells. The study shows that the recombination process is replicative and occurs through a process of resolution. The study provides important insights into the molecular mechanism of recombination in positive-strand RNA viruses and suggests a means by which "evolution by duplication" may occur. The study's findings have important implications for our wider understanding of the evolution of positive-strand RNA viruses.
The study investigates the relationship between adipocyte brown fat and the beigeing process. The authors propose that the brown fat receptor Oct3 may be involved in the browning process, and the study provides evidence to support this theory. The authors identify a new noncanonical function of Oct3 in white adipocyte browning and thermogenesis. They find that Oct3 is not expressed in brown fat, but is expressed in white fat. They also show that Oct3 is involved in the regulation of the beigeing process. The authors find that Oct3 is a novel receptor that modulates the browning process, and that it may be a potential therapeutic target for treating obesity and cold intolerance.
HP1 proteins are important regulators of heterochromatin-mediated silencing and chromosome structure in mammalian cells. HP1 proteins are known to bind histone H3 tails methylated on lysine 9, but they also interact with histone H3 in a region located partially inside the nucleosomal barrel at the entry/exit point of the nucleosome. This interaction is important for efficient SWI/SNF remodeling and HP1 proteins seem to use this property to detect and arrest unwanted chromatin remodeling. HP1 proteins also seem to be present both during phases of silencing and transcriptional activity in euchromatin.
We analyzed the self-containment of RNA sequences using a simple scoring method based on the folding of a sequence in different contexts. We found that pre-miRNA hairpin sequences are highly self-contained, while most other RNAs have much lower self-containment. Self-containment was also shown to be correlated with other features of RNA sequences, such as conservation and thermodynamic stability. We proposed that high self-containment is an intrinsic property of certain RNA sequences and may be evolutionarily selected to maintain RNA structure and function.
The paper presents a study of the role of four transcription factors in Arabidopsis defense against fungal necrotrophs. The authors used mutants of these transcription factors and found that they were more susceptible to infection by Botrytis cinerea and Plectosphaerella cucumerina. They then used microarray analysis to identify genes that were up-regulated in these mutants and found that many of these genes encoded secreted peptides. They named these peptides PROVIR factors and found that they were also involved in disease resistance. The authors then used fluorescence microscopy to localize these peptides in the plant cell. They found that many of the peptides localized in the pericellular space. Finally, they used quantitative PCR to confirm the up-regulation of these genes and to study the effect of the fungal infection on their expression. Overall, the paper presents a comprehensive study of the role of these transcription factors in disease resistance and identifies potential targets for future research on disease resistance in plants.
Infertility is a common problem affecting millions of couples worldwide. Many cases of infertility are caused by embryo implantation failure, a process in which an embryo fails to adhere to and invade the uterine endometrium. Forkhead box protein O1 (FOXO1) is a transcription factor that is important for many cellular processes, including cell growth, apoptosis, and metabolism. Several studies have shown that FOXO1 is important for embryo implantation in mice. In this study, the authors used uterine ablation and genetic knockout mice to show that FOXO1 is important for normal embryo implantation in mice. The authors also used RNA sequencing to identify the pathways that are affected by FOXO1 knockdown in the uterus during early pregnancy. Their findings provide new insights into the role of FOXO1 in embryo implantation and suggest that FOXO1 may be a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of infertility.
Dengue is a neglected tropical disease that is transmitted by female mosquitoes, predominantly Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus. It causes severe forms of illness that are potentially fatal and is prevalent in the tropical and subtropical regions of the world. The World Health Organization (WHO) estimates that about 52% of the people at risk of dengue live in 10 countries of the WHO South-East Asia Region. Bangladesh, located in South Asia and surrounded by India and Myanmar, is one such country where dengue is endemic. Dengue cases have been reported in Bangladesh since 2000, most commonly among adults and older children living in metropolitan cities. However, despite no effective control program being introduced and no changes in surveillance until 2010 when serological confirmation was mandated for case reporting, nationally reported cases have declined since 2002. This decline might be partially attributable to increased prevalence of immunity and reduction in mosquito breeding sites resulting from public awareness. However, there is considerable under-reporting inherent in the passive hospital-based surveillance system. To identify the spatial variation in monthly dengue cases and its association with climatic and demographic factors, we developed a negative binomial generalised linear mixed effect model accounting for zero-inflation, spatial, and temporal random effects. The model was fitted to the district-level (64 districts) monthly reported dengue cases aggregated over the period 2000 to 2009. We found that mean monthly temperature and its interaction with mean monthly diurnal temperature range, lagged by two months were significantly associated with dengue incidence. Mean monthly rainfall at two months lag was positively associated with dengue incidence. Densely populated districts and districts bordering India or Myanmar had higher incidence than others. The model estimated that 92% of the annual dengue cases occurred between August and September. Cases were identified across the country with 94% in the capital Dhaka, which is located almost in the middle of the country. Less than half of the affected districts reported cases as observed from the surveillance data. The proportion reported varied by month with a higher proportion reported in high-incidence districts, but dropped towards the end of high transmission season. The model developed in this study can facilitate the efficient distribution of vector control interventions to areas of highest need at the appropriate time. It is useful for identifying locations where DENV transmission occurs but incidence data are lacking.
Researchers have found that when mammals are placed in a new environment, they form a "home base" that they visit the most and stay at for the longest time. In mice, researchers found a new type of place that they call "knots." Knots are not home bases, but they are marked by twisting and turning paths. They are typically only one knot per session and have clear boundaries. Knot-scribbling behavior is linked to the environment of the mice. It seems to be a way for them to gain a better understanding of their surroundings and to orient themselves within the environment. The behavior is linked to the vestibular system, which is responsible for detecting movement and position in space. Knot-scribbling could be a useful tool for researchers studying how animals explore and navigate their environment.
In this study, the authors found a new compound called NGx04 that is effective against fungal infections. They discovered that NGx04 targets a protein called Sec14p, which is essential for the growth and virulence of fungi such as Cryptococcus neoformans. The authors also showed that NGx04 has a fungicidal effect against a fluconazole-resistant strain of C. neoformans. Overall, this study provides evidence that NGx04 is a promising new antifungal agent.
The treatment of a parasitic disease that affects over 200 million people called schistosomiasis depends on one drug called praziquantel. Researchers have found that mefloquine, a drug used to treat malaria, can also kill the worms that cause schistosomiasis. In experiments with mice, a single dose of mefloquine killed over 70% of the worms in the body. The drug was also effective against young developing stages of the worms. The results of these experiments suggest that mefloquine could be a promising new treatment for schistosomiasis.
The study was conducted to map podoconiosis in Cameroon, a neglected tropical disease characterized by swelling of the lower limbs. The study used a multi-stage sampling design with stratification of the country by environmental risk of podoconiosis. Seven-six villages from 40 health districts were surveyed, and all individuals of 15 years and above in the village were screened for lymphedema. A clinical algorithm was used to reliably diagnose podoconiosis, excluding filarial-associated lymphedema. Individuals with lymphedema were tested for circulating Wuchereria bancrofti antigen and specific IgG4 using the Alere Filariasis Test Strips ( FTS ) test and the Standard Diagnostics ( SD ) BIOLINE lymphatic filariasis IgG4 test ( Wb123 ) respectively, in addition to thick blood films. Presence of DNA specific to W. bancrofti was checked on night blood using a qPCR technique. Overall, 10,178 individuals from 4,603 households participated in the study. Of the 83 individuals with lymphedema, two were found to be FTS positive and all were negative using the Wb123 test. No microfilaria of W. bancrofti were found in the night blood of any individual with clinical lymphedema. None were found to be positive for W. bancrofti using qPCR. Of the two FTS positive cases, one was positive for Mansonella perstans DNA, while the other harbored Loa loa microfilaria. Overall, 52 people with podoconiosis were identified after applying the clinical algorithm. The overall prevalence of podoconiosis was found to be 0.5% (95% [confidence interval] CI; 0.4–0.7) . At least one case of podoconiosis was found in every region of Cameroon except the two surveyed villages in Adamawa. Of the 40 health districts surveyed, 17 districts had no cases of podoconiosis; in 15 districts, mean prevalence was between 0.2% and 1.0%; and in the remaining eight, mean prevalence was between 1.2% and 2.7%. The findings will be used to develop a podoconiosis control program in Cameroon.
The article describes the role of the Notch signaling pathway in the retention of germline stem cells (GSCs) in the Drosophila ovary. It shows that GSCs express the Notch ligand delta, and that its absence leads to a reduction in GSC number. The article also demonstrates that the loss of GSCs is due to increased cell division and apoptosis of GSCs in the absence of Notch signaling. The authors show that Notch signaling regulates the expression of E-cadherin in the GSCs and that E-cadherin expression is required for proper GSC retention. The article also discusses the role of insulin signaling in GSC retention and shows that it is independent of Notch signaling. The authors conclude that Notch signaling regulates GSC retention through the control of cell division and apoptosis, and that it is an important component of the GSC niche.
We recently showed that the protein kinase encoded by the HCMV ( HHV-5 ) UL97 gene is a functional Cdk, although UL97 does not share significant amino acid sequence identity with any known cellular Cdk . To further analyze the function of UL97, we tested other conserved herpesviral kinases ( CHPKs ) encoded by HHV-1, -2, -3, -4, -6, -7, and -8. We found that all of these CHPKs were able to induce Rb phosphorylation in vivo, but only HHV-1, -2, and -5 were able to efficiently disrupt the nuclear lamina and induce lamin A phosphorylation. Interestingly, the HHV-8 CHPK was not able to phosphorylate Rb or lamin A, and was unable to disrupt the nuclear lamina. We also found that while all of the beta- and gamma-herpesviral CHPKs displayed Cdk activity when expressed in yeast, none of the alpha-herpesviral CHPKs were able to functionally substitute for cellular Cdks. These results show that while the UL97 protein kinase encoded by HCMV has many functions in common with other herpesviral CHPKs, the individual CHPKs have a wide range of unique and distinct functions that likely play important roles in herpesviral infection and replication.
Melioidosis is a disease that is caused by the bacterium Burkholderia pseudomallei. It is commonly found in tropical countries. Scientists need to know where this bacterium is found in order to prevent people from getting sick. To do this, they have to use a certain way to collect soil samples. The way that the scientists collect the soil samples is not the same everywhere and needs to be improved to make sure that they don't miss any areas where the disease might be found. The scientists want to make sure that the way they collect soil samples is the same all over the world so that they can make a better map of where the disease is found and can help people in the right places. The scientists have formed a working group to work on this problem and want to share the information they come up with with other scientists.
We developed a stem peptide from the envelope protein of dengue virus (DV) that specifically binds to a trimeric intermediate form of the protein during infection. The stem peptide binds to the membrane bound intermediate protein and prevents it from dissociating into monomers. This intermediate form of the protein is thought to be involved in the fusion process of the virus. The stem peptide binds to the trimeric intermediate protein in a pH dependent manner. The binding is not affected by the presence of divalent cations. The stem peptide also binds to the trimeric intermediate protein in a competitive manner with the membrane. The stem peptide inhibits the infection of dengue virus by binding to the virion at neutral pH before attachment to the cell. It also prevents the fusion of the virion with the endosome membrane by binding to the trimeric intermediate form of the envelope protein.
The authors present a new method for the preservation and sequencing of Vibrio cholerae from stool specimens collected in remote areas with limited laboratory resources. The authors demonstrate that dried stool samples can be stored for up to two years at room temperature and subsequently used for genomic analysis. This new method has the potential to significantly improve the ability to study and respond to cholera outbreaks in resource-limited settings.
This article describes the role of the cytoplasmic motor protein, Dynein, in regulating epithelial polarity. The authors found that Dynein is required for the apical targeting of the protein Stardust (Sdt), which is a component of the Crumb complex that regulates apical identity in epithelial cells. The authors also discovered that a specific sdt mRNA isoform is responsible for the apical localization of Sdt protein. They found that this isoform contains an alternatively spliced exon that is required for apical localization. The authors suggest that the apical localization of sdt mRNA may be regulated by microtubule motors, as overexpression of a mutant form of Dynein leads to mislocalization of sdt mRNA. The authors propose that microtubule motors may be involved in the localization of other proteins required for epithelial polarity.
In this study, the authors demonstrate genetic exchange between two strains of Leishmania infantum in the sand fly vector. They use two different drug-selectable markers linked to fluorescent reporters, mCherry and Citrine, to identify yellow fluorescent hybrids as a biomarker of mating between two individuals from the same strain. The authors show that genetic exchange has no inter-specific barriers and that recombination events occur within the same genotype during the mating process. They also demonstrate that Leishmania is able to perform recombination between the same genotype during the mating process. Their findings have important implications for our understanding of the reproductive mode of Leishmania and for the development of novel strategies for the control of leishmaniasis.
This study uses PCR and high-resolution melt (HRM) analysis to investigate the genetic diversity of Leishmania donovani strains in Ethiopia. The study analyzes 63 L. donovani strains isolated from visceral leishmaniasis patients in Ethiopia. These strains are grouped into two major populations, based on the size of the PCR amplicon. The first group is mainly found in northwestern Ethiopia and is characterized by a 290 bp amplicon, while the second group is found in southwestern Ethiopia and is characterized by a 450 bp amplicon. The study also compares the genetic diversity of L. donovani in Ethiopia with strains from Sudan, Kenya, and India. This study is important because it provides new information about the genetic diversity of L. donovani in Ethiopia and may help in the development of new diagnostic and treatment strategies for visceral leishmaniasis.
HIV-1 is a virus that undergoes a lot of genetic variation due to many factors. These variations are important for the evolution of the virus. A specific type of genetic variation is recombination, which occurs when two different HIV-1 genomes (from different subtypes) combine to form a new, hybrid virus. This recombination can occur in the envelope gene and other parts of the genome, but it is more likely to occur in regions where there is high sequence identity. The authors hypothesized that only a subset of recombination breakpoints have a significant impact on the evolution of HIV-1. To test this hypothesis, they created a computer model to predict where recombination breakpoints are likely to occur. They then compared their predictions to the actual observed breakpoints from the HIV/AIDS pandemic. The authors found that the majority of recombination breakpoints occur within the envelope gene, which is important for immune evasion. They also found that some regions of the genome have a higher tendency to be recombined. Their findings suggest that only a small subset of recombination breakpoints have a significant impact on the evolution of HIV-1, and that the majority are neutral with limited biological significance.
Computational modeling is a growing field of neuroscience that uses mathematical and statistical methods to analyze brain data and infer the underlying neural mechanisms. Hierarchical Bayesian inference (HBI) is an advanced statistical technique that enables researchers to jointly model two different types of data, parametric and non-parametric, in a single Bayesian analysis. HBI involves a three-step process: prior specification, posterior inference, and parameter estimation. Prior specification involves choosing the prior distributions for the model parameters. Posterior inference involves using Bayes' theorem to update these prior distributions given the data. Finally, parameter estimation involves computing the posterior mean and standard deviation for each model parameter. HBI has several advantages over traditional statistical methods, such as hierarchical linear modeling. It can jointly model multiple types of data and handle unbalanced data. It also provides a natural way to incorporate prior knowledge into the analysis. Additionally, HBI has been shown to be more robust to outliers and parameter misspecification than traditional methods.
This study used genetic and molecular methods to investigate the role of the Hox genes in the development of the auditory system of the mouse. The authors show that Hox genes are important for the patterning of auditory neurons and for the assembly of auditory circuitry. They used a new genetic tool to selectively label neurons in the hindbrain region that give rise to the auditory system, and then used immunohistochemistry and in situ hybridization to investigate the expression of Hox genes in these neurons. They also used genetic mutants to study the function of Hox genes in auditory development. Their results show that Hox genes are required for the proper development of auditory circuitry, and that they have different effects on different parts of the auditory system. Overall, this study provides new insights into the molecular mechanisms that control the development of the auditory system.
The bacterium Saccharophagus degradans 2-40 is the first free-living marine bacterium to be sequenced and assembled. The bacterium was isolated from decaying salt marsh grass in Chesapeake Bay watershed in 2002, and is capable of degrading a wide range of complex carbohydrates, including cellulose, chitin, laminarin, and xylan, using 44 different enzymes. This unique ability makes it an important player in the marine carbon cycle, and its genome provides valuable insights into the metabolic pathways and enzymes involved in carbohydrate degradation in marine environments.
Japanese Encephalitis virus (JEV) is a type of virus that causes brain infection in humans and is a major public health problem in Asia. Different strains of JEV have emerged over the years, with one strain called genotype III (GI) being the most dominant one until recently. However, the exact mechanism behind the replacement of GI by genotype I (GI) is still not known. The researchers in this study used Chinese mosquitoes called Cx. pipiens to investigate the role of mosquitoes in the replacement of GI by GIII. They exposed female mosquitoes to either GI or GIII JEV strains and collected infected mosquitoes at 7 and 14 days after infection. They then determined the infection rate, replication kinetics, dissemination rate, and transmission potential of the infected JEV strains in mosquitoes. The study found that Cx. pipiens mosquitoes were competent vectors for both GI and GIII JEV infection, with similar infection rates, growth kinetics, dissemination rates, and transmission rates. These results suggest that mosquitoes may not play a critical role in the replacement of GIII by GI.
Dengue is a viral disease that is spread by mosquitoes and affects people living in tropical and subtropical regions. Malaysia has had large outbreaks of dengue fever in recent years. This study aimed to study the demographics and clinical characteristics of dengue deaths in Malaysia from January 1, 2013, to December 31, 2014. The study involved reviewing the medical records of 322 dengue deaths in Malaysia. The study found that the most common co-morbidities among adults and elderly patients were diabetes and hypertension. The most common warning signs reported were lethargy and vomiting, but 22.4% did not have any warning signs. It was found that more adults developed severe plasma leakage and more than half suffered from multi-organ involvement. Dengue shock syndrome was the leading cause of death, regardless of age groups, with a death rate of 74.2% in children, 69.5% in adults, and 71.4% in the elderly. The study highlights the need for early recognition and aggressive intervention to prevent dengue deaths.
Understanding the mechanisms that drive female attractiveness is important for understanding the evolution of sexual selection and mating systems in insects. In Drosophila melanogaster, the fruit fly, insulin signaling affects the composition and attractiveness of the female pheromone profile, but the tissue-specific effects of insulin signaling on attractiveness and how it interacts with other factors to determine female attractiveness are not well understood. Here, we use a combination of genetic manipulation and behavioral assays to investigate the tissue-specific effects of insulin signaling on female attractiveness in Drosophila melanogaster. We found that insulin signaling in the ovary and fat body affect female attractiveness in opposite ways, suggesting that these two tissues may be involved in different aspects of female attractiveness. These findings provide important insights into the mechanisms that drive female attractiveness and the factors that determine the outcome of sexual selection in Drosophila melanogaster.
Ebola virus disease ( EVD ) is a highly contagious virus that has caused outbreaks in West Africa. In this study, the authors developed a statistical modeling approach to estimate the basic reproductive number ( R0 ) for each affected district and each country using weekly incident case numbers. They found that R0 ranged from 0.36 to 1.72 in Guinea, from 0.53 to 3.37 in Liberia, and from 1.14 to 2.73 in Sierra Leone. The authors found that socio-demographic variables such as urbanisation, including high population density and high wealth index, were positively associated with R0. Their findings provide insights into the spread of EVD and its risk factors, which could improve epidemic management in the future.
What factors affect the evolutionary rate of proteins? In the current study, the authors compared structural properties and evolutionary age to determine how both intrinsic and historical factors affect the rate of evolution of proteins. They used a large set of one-to-one orthologs between human and mouse proteins, with mapped PDB structures. They found that previously observed structural correlations also hold within each age group, including relationships between solvent accessibility, designability, and evolutionary rates. However, age modulates the relationship between solvent accessibility and rate. Additionally, younger proteins tend to evolve faster than older proteins, despite being less designable. The authors show that previously reported relationships between age and rate cannot be explained by structural biases among age groups. Finally, they introduce a knowledge-based potential function to study the stability of proteins through large-scale computation. They find that older proteins are more stable for their native structure, and more robust to mutations, than younger ones.
In this study, the authors investigate the role of the Polycomb-like 3 (Pcl3) protein in regulating Polycomb repressive complex 2 (PRC2) function in embryonic stem cells (ESCs). PRC2 is a multiprotein complex that regulates gene expression by adding methyl groups to histone proteins. The authors show that Pcl3 interacts with the core components of PRC2 and promotes its function. They also show that Pcl3 is essential for ESC self-renewal and plays a role in regulating H3K27me3 levels and Suz12 binding to the genome. The authors conclude that Pcl3 is an important regulator of PRC2 at a subset of target genes and plays a critical role in ESC biology.
Feeding state affects the expression of chemosensory genes in C. elegans.
Buruli ulcer is a skin infection caused by Mycobacterium ulcerans. The disease is often found in tropical and subtropical areas. In this study, researchers tested the idea that mosquitoes might be involved in the transmission of M. ulcerans in Australia by testing adult mosquitoes for the presence of the bacteria. The study found a strong dose-response relationship between the number of M. ulcerans-positive mosquitoes in a town and the average cumulative incidence of Buruli ulcer in that town. This means that as the number of mosquitoes infected with M. ulcerans in a town increases, the average number of cases of Buruli ulcer in that town also increases. The study found that mosquitoes were likely to be involved in the transmission of M. ulcerans in Australia, and that this could have implications for the development of intervention strategies to control and prevent Buruli ulcer.
The rat demyelination (dmy) mutation is a unique genetic model for studying the maintenance of myelin in the central nervous system (CNS). The gene responsible for this mutation has been identified as the Mrs2 gene, which encodes an essential component of the major Mg2+ influx system in mitochondria. The dmy/dmy rats show severe myelin breakdown, with major mitochondrial deficits and increased numbers of mitochondria in the swollen cytoplasm of oligodendrocytes. MRS2-GFP recombinant BAC transgenic rats show that MRS2 is dominantly expressed in neurons rather than oligodendrocytes. The study provides evidence that the maintenance of myelin has a different mechanism from its initial production, and that Mg2+ homeostasis in CNS mitochondria is essential for the maintenance of myelin.
Microarray-based gene expression signatures have the potential to help diagnose diseases and predict patient outcomes. However, there are issues with the current documentation standards that make it difficult to apply signatures to study-external patients. In order to improve the use of signatures in clinical practice, researchers from the University of Tübingen in Germany analyzed the classification rules from eight publicly available clinical microarray studies. They found that discrepancies between study-internal and study-external diagnoses can be as frequent as 30% (worst case) and 18% (median). By using the proposed documentation by value strategy, the median discrepancy was reduced to 1%. This approach involves documenting the quantitative specification of a classification rule, the preprocessing method, and the normalization dependent scale that is underlying the signature. The researchers demonstrated that this strategy can substantially improve the reliability and effectiveness of evaluating microarray-based gene expression diagnostic signatures.
Curli amyloid fibrils are produced by the bacterium Salmonella typhimurium and are essential for its biofilm formation and resistance to antimicrobial agents. These fibrils are composed of curli protein and can be modulated by peptides that target specific regions of the curli protein. In this study, the authors used X-ray crystallography to determine the structure of curli fibrils and identify potential regions for peptide-based inhibition. They found that two peptides, ANK6 and D-ANK6, interact with curli fibrils in a way that may disrupt their structure, and that these peptides can also inhibit curli fibril formation in S. typhimurium. The authors suggest that these peptides could be used as potential inhibitors of curli fibril formation and biofilm formation in S. typhimurium, and that further research could lead to the development of novel antimicrobial agents.
Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV) is a mosquito-borne disease that affects the brain and has high death rates and long-term effects on survivors. It is endemic in most of Asia, including the Philippines. The authors conducted a review of JE in the Philippines by searching scientific databases, presentations, and surveillance data from January 2011 to March 2014. The study found that JE is widespread in the Philippines and affects mainly children under 15 years old. The authors recommend the integration of JE vaccine into the routine immunization program in the Philippines to prevent this serious disease.
The article is about the study of the evolution of genetic robustness. Genetic robustness refers to the ability of a biological system to continue functioning following genetic mutations. The authors argue that genetic robustness is a complex trait that is influenced by both environmental and genetic factors. They suggest that environmental robustness is a subset of genetic robustness and that it is influenced by factors such as the availability of nutrients and the presence of toxins. The authors also suggest that genetic robustness may have evolved as a byproduct of selection for other adaptive traits, such as the ability to grow in a wide range of environments. Overall, the article highlights the importance of studying the relationship between genetic robustness and environmental robustness in order to better understand the evolution of biological systems.
In this study, we investigated the effects of S . mansoni infection on antibody responses to measles vaccination among pre-school children. We also examined the effect of praziquantel treatment on these antibody responses. The study was conducted in Uganda among fishing communities on the shores of Lake Victoria. Children between the ages of 3 and 5 years were enrolled in the study and their stool samples were examined for the presence of S . mansoni infection using the Kato-Katz technique. We found that children with S . mansoni infection had lower levels of measles-specific antibodies than uninfected children at one week after measles immunisation. Furthermore, we observed that praziquantel treatment given to children with S . mansoni infection resulted in higher levels of measles-specific antibodies compared to those who did not receive treatment. These findings suggest that S . mansoni infection may impair vaccine responses in children and that praziquantel treatment may improve these responses. The study also highlights the importance of addressing schistosomiasis in order to improve vaccine responses and overall health outcomes in affected communities.
In this study, we introduced a new framework for the analysis of bacterial population structure based on multi-locus sequence typing (MLST) data. The framework is based on Bayesian statistical inference and allows for the identification of genetically distinct populations and the quantification of the amount of genetic exchange among them. The framework combines different statistical tools to identify the genetic population structure, quantify the genetic admixture within populations, and characterize the genetic shape of populations. We illustrated the use of the framework by analyzing an MLST dataset of over 4,800 strains of the bacterial species Neisseria meningitidis and N. lactamica. We showed that our framework was able to correctly identify the known populations and characterize the patterns of genetic exchange between them. The framework can be applied to other bacterial species and can also be extended to accommodate other types of sequence data.
The study used a computational model of sensory cortical areas to investigate how top-down beta rhythms modulate attention. The model included L5 pyramidal cells that resonate to top-down beta frequency inputs and activate ascending synaptic projections to L4 and L2/3, leading to biased competition in superficial layers. The model predicted that the cholinergic drive can support selective attention by modulating the activity of slow-inhibitory interneurons in a gamma rhythm-related manner.
The development of a mathematical framework to calibrate and predict stochastic epidemic models is crucial for decision making in public health. In this article, we propose a novel calibration approach, Multiple Shocks Simulation-based Reservoir Estimation (MSSRE), to estimate key epidemic parameters and predict future disease dynamics. MSSRE utilizes a non-linear approximation of the likelihood function for stochastic compartmental models, which allows for efficient calibration in real-time. The accuracy of MSSRE is evaluated by comparing its predictions against the true underlying dynamics of simulated epidemics with unknown parameters. We also compare MSSRE with three state-of-the-art benchmark methods, including an assumption of independent Poisson observations, particle filter, and ensemble Kalman filter. Our results show that MSSRE performs as well as or better than the benchmark methods in terms of accuracy and computational efficiency. Overall, our approach provides a valuable tool for public health professionals to effectively respond to epidemic threats in real-time.
This study investigated the nature of perceptual serial dependence, a phenomenon where the perception of one stimulus is influenced by the history of previous stimuli. The authors used a multilevel modeling approach and found that past perceptual decisions had a stronger influence on subsequent perceptual biases than did physical stimuli. This finding provides evidence for the Two-process hypothesis of serial dependence, which suggests that low-level adaptation and high-level decision integration contribute to this phenomenon. The study also found that decision-based biases emerged even when participants were explicitly instructed not to make decisions, suggesting that this bias may be a fundamental aspect of perceptual processing.
Circadian rhythms are internal 24-hour timekeeping systems that allow organisms to anticipate daily changes in the environment. A key component of the system in flies and mammals is a transcription factor complex that activates the transcription of genes involved in circadian function. To better understand the role of transcription in the circadian system, researchers have analyzed the effects of a fusion protein of the circadian transcription factor CYC and the viral protein 16 (VP16) in flies. The addition of VP16 to CYC imparts to the CLK–CYC complex strongly enhanced transcriptional activity relative to that of CLK–CYC alone. This increase in activity is manifested in flies expressing CYC-VP16 as well as in cultured cells. These flies also have increased levels of CLK–CYC direct target gene mRNAs as well as a short period, implicating circadian transcription in period determination. These results indicate that transcriptional activation is important for the function of the CLK–CYC complex.
Scientists have found that a gene, pmrD, is responsible for making the bacterium Salmonella resistant to polymyxin B. However, this gene only works in Salmonella if it is part of a larger cluster of genes. When the pmrD gene is taken from Salmonella and put into a different bacterium, E. coli, it doesn't work. Scientists have found that the reason for this is that the pmrD gene works with another gene, called PmrB, which is different in the two bacteria. By swapping the PmrB gene from E. coli into Salmonella, the scientists were able to make the pmrD gene work in E. coli. This finding shows that the ability of a horizontally acquired gene to confer a selective advantage upon a recipient organism is dictated by quantitative differences in the biochemical activities of ancestral proteins.
The researchers in this study are trying to figure out how to tell when a stem cell starts to turn into a specific type of cell. This is a very important process because it can help scientists discover which genes are important for this change to happen. In the past, scientists have tried to figure this out by comparing the genes expressed in two different types of cells at the end of the differentiation process. However, this method has limitations because it may also include genes that are not actually important for the differentiation process to occur. This new method involves measuring the average gene expression of a mix of cells at different stages of the differentiation process and using statistical analysis to identify which genes are important for the differentiation to occur. The researchers tested this method on embryonic stem cells turning into heart cells and found that they could identify a new gene called Smarcad1 that is important for the differentiation process. They also provided a theoretical explanation and statistical method for this approach, as well as two experiments to validate their findings.
Our study explores how to functionally cluster genes implicated in the same disease using functional association data. We found that genes implicated through de novo sequence variants tend to cluster together due to a confounding bias in coding-sequence length, which can lead to false positive findings. To address this bias, we developed a new method called phenotypic linkage analysis that groups genes with similar phenotypic annotations, thereby revealing functional associations between genes in a network of biologically related diseases. This new method was able to identify functional associations between gene variants and control for bias, showing significant power to functionally cluster variant genes underlying polygenic disorders. Overall, our study suggests that phenotypic linkage analysis is a promising tool for understanding complex disease mechanisms.
The study examined the effect of Mexico's tax on non-essential food and drinks with high sugar content. Food and drink purchases were monitored by the Mexican government through the Nielsen Consumer Panel Services from January 2012 to December 2014. The tax was implemented in January 2014, and the results showed that overall, household purchases of taxed foods decreased by 25 grams (g) per capita per month in 2014 compared to what was expected based on the pre-tax trend. When looking at the SES subgroups, low SES households purchased 10.2% less taxed foods in 2014 compared to what was expected, while medium and high SES households showed a decrease of 5.8% and 0%, respectively. The results suggest that the tax had a positive impact on reducing the consumption of non-essential food and drinks with high sugar content in Mexico.
The Lobula Giant Movement Detector (LGMD) neuron in the locust's brain responds best to objects that are approaching on a direct collision course. The response of the LGMD is characterized by a maximum at tmax + δ, where tmax is the time of peak response and δ is the delay between stimulation and response. The response of the LGMD can be modeled using the so-called η-function. This function predicts that the time of peak response Trel, which is the time difference between the peak of the response and the time of collision, depends linearly on the halfsize-to-velocity ratio l/v. The η-function also predicts that the peak response occurs at a fixed angular size. However, experimental data have shown that the actual peak response occurs at a slightly different angular size and that the time of peak response is not always the same as the time of collision. This discrepancy between prediction and experiment has been attributed to the nonlinear properties of the LGMD's membrane potential equation. A new model, called the noisy ψ model, has been proposed that incorporates these nonlinear properties and explains many of the experimental observations that could not be explained by the η-function alone. The noisy ψ model emphasizes the importance of signal integration in order to account for the experimental observations.
Buruli ulcer (BU) is a skin disease caused by bacteria called Mycobacterium ulcerans. It affects people of all ages and both sexes, but mostly children under 15 years of age. BU usually affects the limbs and can cause deformities if left untreated. BU occurs in tropical and subtropical regions near stagnant water bodies and marshlands. The transmission mode is unclear, but some studies suggest that an animal reservoir or insect vectors may be involved. BU can be diagnosed clinically by experienced health workers, but laboratory confirmation is also available. The treatment of BU has evolved from surgery to the use of specific antibiotics in association with controlled wound healing, physiotherapy, and nutritional and psychological support. Effective BU control began in Cameroon in 2002. In this article, we describe the national BU control programme (NBUCP) in Cameroon from its creation to 2014. We reviewed reports and data from 2001 to 2014 and calculated key BU control indicators. We found that the number of BU cases reported in Cameroon increased from 3,890 in 2001 to 4,810 in 2014. The detection rate dropped significantly from 3.89 to 1.45 per 100,000 inhabitants. However, the number of BU endemic health districts increased from 2 to 64. The health system has been strengthened, and BU research and education have gained more interest in Cameroon. Although institutional BU control in Cameroon only began 30 years after the first cases were reported in 1969, a number of milestones have been attained. These would serve as stepping stones for charting the way forward and improving upon control activities in the country if the major challenge of resource allocation is dealt with.
This study investigated the effect of outcome valence (gains or losses) on confidence while participants learned through trial and error. Participants were more confident when learning to seek gains compared to avoiding losses, despite similar performance. The study found that the bias in confidence was driven by the context-value, a dynamically updated estimate of the expected value of the options being learned. This bias could have important functional consequences in volatile environments.
This research article describes the identification of a novel interaction between a viral protein called nsP3 from the alphavirus group and two human host proteins called amphiphysin-1 and -2. The alphavirus genus contains several important human pathogens, including Sindbis virus and chikungunya virus. The research was conducted using an in vitro protein-protein interaction assay, which showed that nsP3 binds to both amphiphysin-1 and -2. This interaction was confirmed by immunofluorescence assays and Western blotting. Additionally, the study found that amphiphysin-1 is important for the replication of the alphavirus SFV, and that amphiphysin-2 plays a role in regulating the protein synthesis of the virus. The results of this study suggest that amphiphysin-1 and -2 may be potential targets for the development of antiviral therapies against alphaviruses.
The article "Diversity of the fungal pathogen causing chromoblastomycosis in Brazil" is a scientific paper that describes the diversity of the fungal species that cause chromoblastomycosis in Brazil. This disease is caused by fungi that live in soil and plants, and can infect humans through cuts or abrasions on the skin. The paper includes a detailed description of 123 strains of fungi collected from people with chromoblastomycosis in different parts of Brazil. The authors used genetic sequencing to determine the identity of the fungi, and found that there were four main species of fungi causing chromoblastomycosis in Brazil. These species were Fonsecaea pedrosoi, Fonsecaea monophora, Fonsecaea nubica, and Fonsecaea pugnacius. The authors also found evidence of two new species of fungi that cause chromoblastomycosis, and discussed the clinical significance of each of these species. This information is important because it helps doctors and other medical professionals understand the diversity of fungi that cause chromoblastomycosis, and how to better diagnose and treat this disease.
In this study, we found that infection with Listeria monocytogenes, a bacterium that causes food poisoning and can invade human cells, causes DNA damage in HeLa cells and in mouse spleens and peritoneum. We also found that Listeria dampens the DNA damage response (DDR) by inhibiting the signaling pathway that leads to phosphorylation of H2AX on serine 139 (γH2AX), a marker of DNA damage. This inhibition is mediated by the bacterial protein Listeriolysin O (LLO). In addition, we found that inhibiting the DDR increases bacterial infection in vitro and in vivo. Our study reveals a subversion of the DDR during infection by Listeria and a role for the DDR in blocking bacterial proliferation.
Here is the lay summary of the provided content: The study demonstrates that the BRD4 bromodomain is a critical factor for HSV-1 and HSV-2 infections. The authors used an epigenetic screening library to identify small molecules that affect HSV infections. They found that a BRD4 bromodomain inhibitor significantly enhanced HSV-1 and HSV-2 infections. The authors then studied the mechanism of action and found that BRD4 plays a role in transcription factor association with HSV gene promoters, leading to increased viral replication. The study provides new insights into the role of BRD4 in HSV infections and may lead to new therapeutic strategies for treating viral infections.
The aim of this study was to investigate the bacterial communities present in the mouths of children suffering from noma, a devastating ancient disease that causes severe facial disfigurement in more than 140,000 children every year. This is done by comparing the microbial communities found in the mouths of children with noma to those of children with a related condition called Acute Necrotizing Gingivitis and healthy controls. The study found that the microbial communities found in the mouths of children with noma were different from those found in healthy controls and children with Acute Necrotizing Gingivitis. The study identified several species that are more abundant in the mouths of children with noma and could potentially be involved in the development of the disease. These findings could help in understanding the etiology of noma and developing new treatments for the disease.
Quorum sensing is a process used by bacteria to communicate with each other. During this process, bacteria exchange a chemical signal known as an autoinducer, which allows them to coordinate their behavior as a group. NprR is a protein involved in quorum sensing in Bacillus thuringiensis, a bacterium that infects insects. The protein NprR binds to an autoinducer molecule and blocks its ability to bind to its target protein, preventing quorum sensing.
Proteochemometric modeling is a data-driven, predictive approach that is used to identify resistance in HIV-1 drug mutants. The current study aims to train single PCM models for each of the three major HIV-1 drug classes (protease inhibitors, reverse transcriptase inhibitors, and non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors) using the AVG assay data. The goal is to achieve a robust and generalizable model that can be applied to unseen clinical mutants. To achieve this, the study uses a combination of sequence-based and physiochemical-based descriptors to predict the change in pIC50 of HIV-1 mutants. The resulting models show promise in predicting the resistance of HIV-1 drug mutants, with low RMSE values and high R02 scores. These models can be used to predict the resistance of new mutants that have not yet been tested in clinical settings, making them a valuable tool for clinicians and researchers in the field of HIV-1 drug development.
Chemotaxis is a process by which cells move towards a source of attractants, such as food or drugs. In order to understand this process, scientists have created many different models to explain how it works. Most of these models focus on a "compass" inside the cell that helps it to steer towards the attractant. However, a recent study proposed a different mechanism, called the pseudopod-centered model, which suggests that chemotaxis is driven by the movement of the cell's pseudopods, which are small, branching projections that allow the cell to move forward. Using a computer model, the study showed that the pseudopod-centered model could explain a wide range of data about cell movement and chemotaxis. It also made a prediction that was tested using live Dictyostelium cells, and the results agreed with the model very well. This study suggests that chemotaxis is driven by a mechanism that is much simpler than previously thought.
This study examines the role of flea early-phase transmission (EPT) of Yersinia pestis (the bacterium that causes plague) by analyzing the location of bacteria in the flea digestive tract following feeding on infected blood. The results suggest that fleas can transmit Y. pestis by EPT when they have consumed blood from rodents with high titers of bacteria in their blood. This discovery may have important implications for the epidemiology of plague, as it suggests that fleas could transmit Y. pestis to humans during the early stages of an outbreak, even when the human population has not yet developed immunity to the pathogen.
The coding capacity of a neural network is the number of independent units of information that can be reliably transmitted from the input to the output layer. It is not a constant value, but depends on the stimuli and the correlations among them. The more diverse the stimuli are, the more independent information can be transmitted. The higher the correlation among the stimuli, the more coding capacity can be gained by tuning the correlation coefficients. We use a simplified mathematical model to show how this can occur in a 2-pool neural network with different correlations in each pool. For a range of stimulus and correlation values, we show that the coding capacity of a 2-pool network can be increased significantly beyond that of a single-pool network, by more than a factor of 10. We also show that in a 2-pool network, the error rate can be suppressed by up to a factor of 100, even for very small correlations in each pool. We show that this effect is not limited to a 2-pool model, but occurs in a generalized case of a -pool network. This result is significant for understanding the potential of a population of neurons to transmit information, and has implications for how information is processed in the brain.
Cholera is a severe diarrheal disease caused by the bacterium Vibrio cholerae. The O-polysaccharide (O-PS) antigen on the lipopolysaccharide (LPS) of V. cholerae is responsible for the rapid onset of profuse watery diarrhea, which can lead to dehydration, electrolyte imbalance, and death. The O-PS antigen is composed of a specific sequence of sugars, and the serotype is defined by this sequence. In this study, we used squarate-linked oligosaccharides to create a new conjugate vaccine for cholera. The vaccine was created using a synthetic oligosaccharide containing a sequence similar to the O-PS of V. cholerae O1 Inaba strain, which was conjugated to the tetanus toxoid (TT) using squarate linkages. The vaccine was tested in mice, and it was found to induce a strong immune response against the O-PS antigen, including the production of specific antibodies and memory B cells. The vaccine was also found to protect mice from a wild-type V. cholerae infection in a survival challenge assay. Overall, the results of this study suggest that the new conjugate vaccine is effective and safe, and it could potentially be used to protect against cholera in humans.
In this study, researchers investigate the relationship between the presence of Wuchereria bancrofti microfilariae (Mf) and the rate of positive results on ICT tests. The study was conducted in four regions of Cameroon, where the distribution of loiasis and mansonellosis is highly variable. The researchers found a significant positive association between the prevalence of L. loa Mf and the rate of ICT positivity. However, there was no association between the prevalence of M. perstans Mf and the rate of ICT positivity. The study suggests that the main confounding factor for positive ICT test results may be high levels of L. loa Mf in the blood. These findings have important implications for the mapping and elimination of LF in Africa.
This article provides a detailed description of the ultrastructure of SARS-CoV–infected cells using electron tomography. The authors discovered that coronavirus DMVs are integrated into a unique reticulovesicular network of modified ER membranes, which also includes convoluted membranes. They also found that viral replicase subunits are primarily localized to the convoluted membranes, while dsRNA is mainly found in the DMV interior. The authors suggest that further studies of this unique replication network will help to dissect the early stages of the coronavirus life cycle and its virus–host interactions.
This study presents an Arabidopsis thaliana mutant, named enhanced suberin1 (esb1-1), which has altered root suberin content and composition. The esb1-1 mutant has 20-50% less C20-C24 aliphatic monomers in root suberin, resulting in a reduced transpiration rate, reduced wilting after water withdrawal, and a perturbation of the shoot ionome. Grafting experiments confirmed that these phenotypes are the result of elevated root suberin. The authors used several approaches to study the role of suberin in regulating radial transport, including elemental analysis, microarray analysis, and in vivo staining of suberin. This study provides direct evidence that suberin acts in the root as a barrier to the extracellular transport of both water and mineral ions.
The single photon response (SPR) of rod photoreceptors is characterized by a high degree of variability. We have developed a computational model of the SPR that accounts for the stochastic nature of the process. The model is based on the kinetics of the rhodopsin phosphorylation, arrestin binding, and transducin activation in different photoreceptor species, including mice with different numbers of rhodopsin phosphorylation sites. The model reproduces the experimental variability of the SPR, and suggests that it is due to the stochastic nature of the process, rather than the number of rhodopsin phosphorylation sites. We have also determined the parameters of the model, based on experimental data for wild-type and mutant mice.
Stochastic reaction networks are used to model systems within cells that involve low-copy molecules. However, these models need to account for intrinsic stochasticity and the fluctuations in the intracellular environment, or extrinsic noise, which also affects the observed variability among isogenic cells. Several recent studies have attempted to separate intrinsic and extrinsic fluctuations, either through dual-reporter measurements or by modeling extrinsic noise through parameters of a kinetic model. These approaches increase the model's dimensionality, making it difficult to analyze. In this work, we develop a general mathematical framework for uncoupling a network from its dynamic environment by incorporating only the environment's effect onto the network into a new model. We derive the corresponding process- and master equations and show how stochastic simulations can be performed. We demonstrate the significance of the approach using several case studies. The resulting model emulates the effect of extrinsic noise through its own stochasticity, leading to a self-exciting process.
A new closed-loop brain-machine interface (BMI) training architecture called adaptive optimal feedback-controlled (OFC) point process filter (PPF) was developed in this study. The architecture consists of two main components: a point process model of the spikes and an optimal feedback control model of the brain behavior in BMI control. The point process model allows for spike-event-based BMI control and adaptation with every spike event, while the optimal feedback control model infers the user's motor intention during closed-loop decoder adaptation and is used to design an automated and dynamic assisted training paradigm. The architecture was evaluated in closed-loop BMI experiments in a non-human primate, and the results show that spike-event-based adaptation results in faster and more consistent performance convergence compared with batch-based methods, and the OFC intention estimation improves BMI performance compared with existing methods. Additionally, the architecture extends control to tasks beyond those used for CLDA training, such as a target-jump task and a target-to-target task.
The visual system of animals is remarkably robust to changes in the statistical properties of the environment. This robustness can be seen in the way that neurons in the retina respond similarly to stimuli of different spatial and temporal correlations. However, the actual degree of similarity in the responses of neurons to stimuli of different correlations has not been fully characterized. Here, we present an analysis of the responses of retinal ganglion cells to stimuli of a wide range of spatial and temporal correlations. Our analysis reveals a surprising degree of similarity in the responses of neurons to stimuli of different correlations. This similarity appears to be due to a small number of factors, including temporal processing, changes in the temporal kernels of the neurons, and changes in the surround inhibition. We also find that changes in the center location of the receptive field have a significant effect on the responses of neurons. Our analysis suggests that the visual system may have evolved to be robust to changes in the statistical properties of the environment by optimizing a small number of parameters.
The paper presents a novel method for predicting genetic interactions in yeast, specifically synthetic lethal interactions, using a multi-network decision tree approach. The method uses a combination of 152 SL-independent and 15 SL-dependent features to predict SL interactions between gene pairs. The method is trained on a balanced dataset of 9994 SL and 125,509 non-SL interactions, and evaluated using cross-validation and an independent test set. The results show that the method outperforms previous approaches in predicting SL interactions, and is capable of predicting other types of genetic interactions as well. The method is implemented as a web server that is freely available to the public.
The BRCA Challenge is a global research project that aims to provide an exhaustive dataset of BRCA1 and BRCA2 variants, which are associated with breast and ovarian cancer, from multiple sources. The project aims to create a comprehensive database that is accessible to researchers and clinicians worldwide. The BRCA Exchange is the online platform of the BRCA Challenge that contains the database of variants, which are curated and annotated by the ENIGMA Consortium. The BRCA Exchange is free to access and download, and it provides detailed information on each variant, including the interpretation by the ENIGMA Consortium. The BRCA Exchange is integrated with the BRCA Share repository, which contains raw variant data that is used to create the curated dataset. The BRCA Challenge is committed to developing a comprehensive data-sharing and curation system that can be easily applied to other cancer predisposition genes, with the aim of improving clinical care for patients worldwide.
Malaria is a serious disease that affects millions of people worldwide. It is caused by a parasite called Plasmodium falciparum, which has a complex developmental cycle involving different intra- and extracellular environments. In order to survive in these different environments, the parasite needs to maintain a delicate redox balance. To do this, the parasite uses several redox-related proteins that act as antioxidants, such as glutathione peroxidase, catalase, and superoxide dismutase. These proteins are found in different subcellular compartments of the parasite, such as the apicoplast and the parasitophorous vacuole. The apicoplast is a unique organelle found in the parasite that is thought to be involved in photosynthesis. The parasitophorous vacuole is a membrane-bound compartment where the parasite grows and replicates. The distribution of redox-related proteins in different subcellular compartments allows the parasite to maintain a balanced redox state, which is important for its survival and virulence. Understanding the redox state of the parasite could lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies to treat malaria.
A new coarse-grained model is used to study the electrostatic interactions of PUMA and Mcl-1 in the coupled folding and binding process. The results show that electrostatic interactions play an important role in the early stages of binding and in the formation of the encounter complex. The model can be used to predict the results of mutational studies and provides important insights into the mechanisms of protein-protein interactions.
Polycomb group (PcG) proteins are conserved chromatin factors that regulate gene expression by binding to discrete PcG response elements (PREs) that recruit PRC2, which trimethylates lysine 27 of histone H3 (H3K27me3), a mark that is recognized by PcG proteins. In Drosophila, PREs are located tens of kilobases away from their target genes, and they cluster together within large Polycomb domains marked with H3K27me3. Within these domains, PREs may interact to form three-dimensional (3D) structures inside the cell nucleus. PC and PH are two important members of the PcG protein family, and they localize in PC bodies that contain PREs. The motion of PC bodies is influenced by long-range motions of chromatin domains containing H3K27me3 and by fast and highly constrained motions. The nuclear distribution of PC bodies and chromatin domains changes during development, and this change may contribute to the maintenance of stable gene silencing.
Somatic mutations in mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) have been linked to aging and other age-related diseases in humans and animals. However, the precise role of mtDNA mutations in these processes is still unclear. The article by Zhu et al. aims to shed light on this by using next-generation sequencing technology to measure mtDNA mutation loads in normal and prematurely aging mice. The authors found that the total number of mtDNA mutations was increased in the prematurely aging mtDNA mutator mice, but not in wild-type mice as they aged. They also found that the majority of these mutations were caused by replication errors during development. These findings challenge the idea that mtDNA mutations accumulate during aging and suggests that the role of mtDNA mutations in aging may be more complex than previously thought.
In this study, the authors investigated the ion-coupling mechanism of the ATP synthase from Fusobacterium nucleatum, a bacterium that uses glutamate decarboxylation to generate a transmembrane gradient of sodium ions (Na+). The authors found that the ATP synthase of F. nucleatum is directly coupled to ATP synthesis via an F1Fo-ATP synthase with a novel Na+ recognition motif, shared by other human pathogens. Molecular modeling and free-energy simulations of the rotary element of the enzyme, the c-ring, indicated that Na+ specificity is physiologically relevant. Furthermore, the authors demonstrated that Na+ has a protective effect against inhibitors targeting the ion-binding sites. They also determined the structure of the c11 ring of the enzyme at two different pH levels, and found that Na+ ions occupy all binding sites and that there are two carboxylates instead of one that mediate ion binding. This finding implies that a proton is concurrently bound to all sites, although Na+ alone drives the rotary mechanism. The authors concluded that their study provides a basis for drug-design efforts against this opportunistic pathogen.
The study examined the effect of TCR ligand potency on in vivo T cell immunity by tracking CD4+ T cell activation, effector, and memory responses to immunization with peptides exhibiting a range of TCR/pMHC half-lives and in vitro T cell activation potencies. Contrary to predictions from in vitro studies, the study found that optimal in vivo T cell responses occur to ligands with intermediate TCR/pMHC half-lives. The attenuation of in vivo responses to the ligand exhibiting the longest TCR/pMHC half-life was associated with attenuation of intracellular signaling, expansion, and function over a broad range of time points. This study reveals a level of control over T cell activation in vivo not recapitulated in in vitro assays and highlights the importance of considering in vivo efficacy of TCR ligands as part of vaccine design.
We have sequenced the genome of Nectria haematococca, a filamentous fungus that causes tomato and potato late blight disease, and the most destructive plant disease in the world. We have used this genome to better understand the evolution of the species, and to identify genes involved in specific adaptations to different environments. This genome will also be useful in the development of new methods for controlling late blight disease.
The article describes a new method to visualize and analyze the final steps of herpesvirus particle transport and exocytosis. Using total internal reflection fluorescence microscopy, the authors imaged the movement of viral particles in live PK15 cells, and found that particles are tightly confined at the plasma membrane before and after exocytosis. They also observed that viral exocytosis events occur most frequently near plasma membrane patches of LL5β, part of a complex that anchors microtubules to the plasma membrane. The authors suggest that this new method could be useful for studying the mechanisms underlying virus egress and identifying novel drug targets for antiviral therapy.
The gut microbiome plays a crucial role in human health. It has been linked to various immune and inflammatory conditions. Previous studies on the association of enterobiasis (pinworm infection) and the gut microbiome have shown contradictory results. In order to understand this relationship, we recruited 109 primary school children (first and fourth grades) from Taichung, Taiwan, and collected their fecal samples. We compared the gut microbiota diversity and composition of children with and without pinworm infection. We also studied the intestinal cytokine and SIgA levels in these children. Our results showed that pinworm infection increased gut microbiota diversity and led to an increased abundance of Actinobacteria and a decreased abundance of Fusobacteria.
