The circadian rhythm is a daily rhythm in living organisms, controlled by a biological clock. Researchers have found that 10%-15% of all genes in mammals oscillate in a daily rhythm, and these rhythms are controlled by an intrinsic molecular clock. However, statistical analyses of these rhythms are limited by the small size of datasets and high levels of stochastic noise. To overcome these limitations, the authors propose a new approach that uses digital signal processing algorithms to identify circadian baseline oscillation in almost 100% of all expressed genes. They preprocess the gene expression profiles by z-score transformation, assign each gene a phase based on the maximal correlation to an ideal cosine curve, and analyze the periodogram of each phase fraction separately. They then use low-pass frequency filters and polynomial smoothing to detect the point at which the circadian signal deteriorates below recognition at the p = 0.05 significance cutoff. The authors estimate the total number of circadian oscillating genes by summing the results from each phase group. They suggest that the number of periodically expressed genes revealed by this method may be different from the traditional approach, but it provides a reasonable compromise between power and specificity.
Birds are known for their high rates of genetic recombination. In this study, we re-sequenced a three-generation pedigree of collared flycatchers to study recombination at high resolution. We found that recombination events are concentrated in specific genomic regions and that these regions coincide with gene promoters and CpG islands. We also found that the male recombination rate is higher than the female recombination rate and that CO interference is present in this species. These results contribute to our understanding of how recombination is regulated in birds and its consequences on the genome.
We propose a coarse-grained model for repeat-protein folding that takes into account the topology of the repeating array and the physical interactions between the repeats. This model is based on the physics of the Ising model, which is a simple model for magnetic systems. We find that the parameters of the Ising model are related to the topology of the repeating array and the interactions between the repeats. We also find that the model can explain the folding properties of repeat-proteins, including stability, cooperativity, and the existence of partially folded intermediates. These properties can be related to the topology of the repeating array and the interactions between the repeats.
This article is about the role of the integrated stress response (ISR) in liver cancer. The ISR is a response to stress in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER), which is involved in many different functions in the body. ER stress is caused by conditions that lead to liver cancer, such as obesity, alcoholism, and viral hepatitis. The ISR has been shown to be involved in the pathogenesis of many different types of cancer, but it is not known whether it plays a role in liver cancer. This article describes how the ISR is involved in liver cancer by showing that a protein called CHOP, which is regulated by the ISR, is upregulated in liver tumors in humans and mice. CHOP is important for the development of liver cancer because it promotes inflammation, fibrosis, cell death, and compensatory proliferation. The article also describes how deletion of CHOP reduces the levels of basal inflammatory signaling in the liver, which supports the idea that CHOP is involved in liver cancer. The article concludes by saying that CHOP is a common contributing factor in the development of liver cancer from a variety of chronic liver diseases.
Leishmaniasis is a skin disease caused by parasites transmitted through sandfly bites. In Ethiopia, the most common form of leishmaniasis is cutaneous leishmaniasis (CL) due to L. aethiopica. This CL can be difficult to treat, especially when it affects the mucous membranes (mucocutaneous leishmaniasis) or when it spreads throughout the body (diffuse CL). Treatment options for CL due to L. aethiopica are limited, and there is a need for new and more effective treatments.
A biochemical oscillator has been reconstituted in vitro using purified proteins from the cyanobacterium Synechococcus elongatus. The oscillator consists of three proteins (KaiA, KaiB, and KaiC), which interact to form complexes that oscillate in composition over time. The composition of the complexes has been analyzed by negative-stain electron microscopy and blue-native/SDS-PAGE. A model has been developed that accurately predicts the rhythm of the KaiABC complexes and describes the dynamics of monomer exchange among KaiC hexamers. The in vitro oscillator exhibits temperature-compensated oscillations and can be reset by temperature pulses.
Our study shows that a closer-to-the-mean brain activity level before a sensory cue predicts faster reaction times and higher hit rates in a visual detection task. We examined the relationship between trial-to-trial brain activity and behavioral performance in human electrocorticography (ECoG) data from patients with epilepsy. We found evidence for an inverted-U relationship between trial-to-trial ECoG activity and behavioral performance: trials with a brain activity level closer to the across-trial mean were associated with faster reaction times and higher hit rates. The presence of an inverted-U relationship between trial-to-trial brain activity and behavioral performance suggests that deterministic and stochastic factors both contribute to brain variability, and that these two sources of variability may have opposite effects on behavioral performance.
Trichosporonales are an understudied group of fungi with important biotechnological properties. We studied the organization of mating type loci (MAT) in 24 Trichosporonales genomes, and found that all species carry physically linked MAT loci. The MAT loci have two alleles, each containing a HD gene and a P/R gene, and are highly conserved in gene content and order within the group. Interestingly, Trichosporonales do not carry two unlinked MAT loci like their sister group Tremellales, which includes the pathogenic Cryptococcus species. The Trichosporonales MAT loci also do not carry two HD genes like the pathogenic Cryptococcus species. The analysis of 24 Trichosporonales genomes suggests that the fusion of the HD and P/R loci as well as the loss of one HD gene per allele occurred independently in the Trichosporonales and the pathogenic Cryptococcus species. This provides further evidence that convergent evolution leading to physically linked MAT loci is evolutionary beneficial under certain circumstances and has been selected for multiple times in basidiomycetes. However, in contrast to other basidiomycetes, such as the pathogenic Cryptococcus species and several Microbotryum species [8 , 38] , the fused MAT loci of the Trichosporonales have a highly conserved gene content and gene order , suggesting unique mechanisms underlying the evolution of fused MAT loci in these groups.
Chagas disease is caused by the protozoan parasite Trypanosoma cruzi, which is transmitted to humans primarily by triatomine vectors. Due to its importance in public health, vector control strategies have been widely implemented through several regional initiatives in the Americas. These interventions are based on the elimination of domiciliated triatomine vectors by residual insecticide spraying and/or housing improvement. However, it has become increasingly clear that several triatomine species do not establish permanent domestic colonies but can occasionally infest domestic habitats by immigration from peridomestic and/or sylvatic habitats. These non-domiciliated species include Rhodnius prolixus in Venezuela, Triatoma brasiliensis and Triatoma pseudomaculata in Brazil, Triatoma mexicana in central Mexico, and Triatoma dimidiata in the Yucatan peninsula, Mexico and Belize. Mathematical modelling has revealed that dispersal is the dominant parameter involved in this infestation process. Alternative strategies for the control of non-domiciliated vectors include insect screens and bednets, which are effective when applied consistently. Control of non-domiciliated vectors can hardly be achieved by insecticide spraying, because it would require yearly application and an accurate understanding of the temporal pattern of immigration. Insect screens appear to offer an effective and sustainable alternative, which may be part of multi-disease interventions for the integrated control of neglected vector-borne diseases.
Your code is well-written and easy to understand. It reads and analyzes the data provided in a clear and logical manner, and the results are presented in a concise and straightforward format. The comments are well-written and provide clear explanations of what the code is doing.
The 2013–15 Ebola outbreak was unprecedented because of its sustained transmission within urban environments and the thousands of survivors. At the time, the World Health Organization did not have enough evidence to provide guidance on which body fluids were infectious and when they posed a risk to humans. Therefore, we conducted a systematic review of published evidence on the presence of filoviruses in body fluids of infected people and survivors. We found 33 studies that were eligible, but for most body fluids, there were insufficient patients to draw strong conclusions. Furthermore, the prevalence of positivity was highly variable. Body fluids taken more than 16 days after onset were usually negative. Filovirus was reported in most types of body fluid, but not in every sample from every otherwise confirmed patient. The infectious risk of many body fluids, particularly semen, during or after illness is unclear. However, contact with blood and blood-stained body fluids remains the major risk for disease transmission.
In this study, the authors developed and analyzed a mathematical model of a neuron that incorporates the idea of non-Markovian processes. In the classical model of a neuron, the voltage is determined by the previous voltage step. However, in real neurons, the voltage follows multiple timescale dynamics that arise from multiple active membrane conductances. This results in power-law behavior in which the membrane voltage cannot be characterized with a single time constant. The authors used a fractional derivative to model this process. The fractional derivative is a non-local process in which the value of the variable is determined by integrating a temporal weighted voltage trace, also called the memory trace. The authors showed that their model can reproduce upward and downward spike adaptations found in experiments, and also produce spikes with longer first-spike latency and high inter-spike variability with power-law distribution. They also analyzed spike adaptation and the responses to noisy and oscillatory input. The authors' model deviates from the classical model and reflects the temporal accumulated intrinsic membrane dynamics that affect the response of the neuron to external stimulation.
This study presents the first characterization of the superoxide dismutase (SOD) gene family in Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, an emerging human pathogen. The authors identified six SOD isoforms (PbSOD1 to PbSOD6) in the P. brasiliensis genome. PbSOD1 and PbSOD3 are chloroplast localized and PbSOD2, PbSOD4, PbSOD5, and PbSOD6 are cytoplasmic isoforms. They found that PbSOD1 and PbSOD3 are required for growth and survival in the presence of hydrogen peroxide, suggesting that they play a role in the defense against oxidative stress. The authors also demonstrated that PbSOD1 and PbSOD3 are localized to chloroplasts in yeast cells, whereas in mycelial cells they are localized to the cytoplasm. Finally, the authors found that PbSOD1 and PbSOD3 knockdown strains are highly sensitive to hydrogen peroxide, suggesting that these isoforms are important for the defense against oxidative stress in P. brasiliensis.
Intrinsically disordered proteins (IDPs) are proteins that do not have a fixed 3D structure, but can fold into different shapes depending on their environment. These proteins are very sensitive to proteolysis, which is the breakdown of proteins by enzymes. However, in vivo, or inside a living organism, IDPs are not degraded any more quickly than other types of proteins. This can be explained because IDPs are thought to interact with chaperones in the cell, which helps to protect them from degradation. To test this theory, the authors took data from studies that measured interactions between proteins and used it to analyze how predicted disorder correlates with chaperone binding. Their main finding was that predicted disorder actually shows a negative correlation with chaperone binding in bacteria, yeast, and metazoa (animals). In other words, proteins that are more likely to be disordered are less likely to bind chaperones. The authors suggest that this could be because the primary reason for chaperone binding is not to help proteins fold, but to promote assembly with other proteins.
In this study, the authors aim to identify Salm and Salr target genes in the Drosophila wing disc. They used microarray experiments to compare the expression profiles of wing discs with and without Salm and Salr knockdown. They then analyzed the expression pattern of the genes whose mRNA levels varied significantly using in situ hybridization. They found a complex transcription landscape regulated by Spalt proteins in the wing disc, with candidates for both positive and negative regulation of Salm and Salr target genes. They also performed phenotypic analysis of these genes and found that a fraction of them are required for wing growth and patterning. The identification of these target genes opens a new avenue to reconstruct the genetic structure of the wing and understand the role of Salm and Salr in wing development.
In people, having too many or too few centrioles can lead to various problems, such as cancer or birth defects. To understand how to control the number of centrioles, scientists have studied a protein called ZYG-1 in the worm Caenorhabditis elegans. They discovered that two other proteins, PP1 and I-2, regulate the level of ZYG-1. When the level of ZYG-1 is reduced, the number of centrioles decreases. When the level of ZYG-1 is increased, the number of centrioles also increases. This suggests that PP1 and I-2 help to keep the number of centrioles within a healthy range.
The article provides a description of a study conducted to investigate the occurrence and possible transmission cycles of Leishmaniasis in Campinas, Brazil. Leishmaniasis is a disease caused by protozoan parasites of the genus Leishmania, which are transmitted by sand flies. The study was conducted in an environmentally protected area (EPA) located in Campinas, which contains Atlantic Forest remnants and has experienced significant environmental changes in recent decades, including deforestation and construction of upscale residential condominiums. The study involved trapping of sand flies and capturing of free-living wild animals in different locations within the EPA, as well as a serological survey of canine dogs living in the condominiums where the Leishmaniasis focus was located. The results of the study suggest that multiple components may be involved in the transmission cycle of Leishmaniasis in the study area, including canines, dogs, and sand flies. The study highlights the importance of understanding the transmission cycles of Leishmaniasis in order to develop effective control strategies for the disease.
EBV-encoded miRNAs are important for EBV-associated carcinogenesis. We found that miR-BART9, a common miRNA in EBV-positive NPC, was upregulated in NPC cells and tissues. Elevated miR-BART9 expression enhanced the migration and invasion of NPC cells in vitro and promoted the metastasis of NPC in vivo. Furthermore, we found that miR-BART9 directly targeted E-cadherin to promote the mesenchymal phenotype in NPC cells.
We present a command-line tool called ggsashimi for visualizing splicing events across multiple RNA-seq samples. Unlike other tools, ggsashimi creates aggregated plots for groups of experiments, and can handle large genomic regions by scaling down the segments between splice sites. It uses popular file formats and is annotation-independent, making it easy to integrate into any splicing analysis pipeline. It can facilitate the interrogation of alternative splicing in large-scale RNA sequencing projects like ENCODE and GTEx. ggsashimi is freely available at <https://github.com/guigolab/ggsashimi>. Additional features of ggsashimi include incorporating spread metrics, allowing users to select which type of reads to plot, and optionally showing only the aggregated coverage.
This study proposes a statistical model of evolution for cis-regulatory modules (CRMs) that takes into account the dynamics of TFBS switching and indel events, and applies the model to two genome-wide datasets of TF binding in Drosophila blastoderm. The model is designed to be biologically realistic and captures the important evolutionary processes that are relevant to CRM evolution. The study finds that functional TFBSs are under strong evolutionary constraints even if their neighboring genes are not expressed in the blastoderm. The authors also find that binding sites in distal bound sequences (relative to transcription start sites) tend to be more conserved than those in proximal regions. They implemented their model as an efficient software program called EMMA (Evolutionary Model-based cis-regulatory Module Analysis), which is freely available to the research community. The study shows that EMMA can accurately align orthologous CRMs and predict the targets of specific transcription factors. The results of this study have important implications for understanding the regulation of early development in Drosophila and other organisms.
The piRNA pathway is required for normal oogenesis and early embryogenesis in Drosophila. We found that the piRNA pathway has two distinct functions during these stages of development. One function is to direct the telomere protection complex to transposon-derived RNAs and to prevent chromosome fusions. This function is mediated by a subpopulation of short piRNAs that bind to Piwi, a protein required for telomere protection. The other function is to transcriptionally silence transposons. We used bioinformatic analysis to identify a cluster of piRNA-encoding transposons that are highly expressed during oogenesis and are likely to be targets for the piRNA pathway. We found that mutations in aub and armi, two essential piRNA pathway genes, do not affect the expression of this cluster, whereas ago3 and rhi mutations, which are weak hypomorphs, significantly reduce its expression. We therefore conclude that armi and aub have a novel function in telomere protection that is independent of transcriptional silencing.
In November 2007, an outbreak of a previously unknown type of Ebola virus occurred in the Bundibugyo district of Uganda. This new virus, now known as Bundibugya ebolavirus, caused 149 suspected cases and 37 deaths. The virus genome was rapidly sequenced using a metagenomics pyro-sequencing method and a traditional primer walking approach. The sequencing revealed that the virus was distinct from the four known species of Ebola virus, although it was distantly related to Cote d'Ivoire ebolavirus. A real-time RT-PCR assay specific for the NP gene of this virus was quickly developed and evaluated, showing excellent sensitivity. The assay was transferred to the Uganda Virus Research Institute during the course of the outbreak to facilitate rapid identification and isolation of Ebola cases in the affected area for efficient control of the outbreak. The entire genome of the Cote d'Ivoire ebolavirus was also rapidly sequenced using a combination of pyrosequencing and primer walking approaches. The analysis revealed that the new virus differed from the four existing Ebola virus species by approximately 32% nucleotide difference from even the closest relative, Cote d'Ivoire ebolavirus. The unique nature of this virus has other implications too, including screening of potential antivirals and pathogenicity studies. Retrospective analysis of case description, epidemiologic and laboratory data from the Bundibugya outbreak are still ongoing, but it is clear that the case fatality associated with Bundibugya ebolavirus infection is lower than that observed for Zaire ebolavirus infection. Studies in non-human primates need to be performed to compare the pathogenicity of these viruses. This investigation also highlights the power of molecular detection and characterization tools to quickly identify new pathogens, while providing a cautionary note regarding sole dependence on molecular techniques such as real-time PCR assays for detection of novel agents in biodefense or emerging disease surveillance programs.
The study looks at the progression rates of Alzheimer's disease (AD) by analyzing the duration of each stage of the disease as described by the Global Deterioration Scale (GDS) and Functional Assessment Staging procedure (FAST). The study found that the standard deviations of stage durations are comparable to their mean values for stages 4–6, indicating a high amount of heterogeneity in the progression of AD. The study suggests that this heterogeneity is likely due to the presence of subgroups of patients with different patterns of decline.
The adult hippocampus is made up of two different types of neurons, one of which is produced through a process called neurogenesis. In the past, studies of adult neurogenesis have been done on either the hippocampal network as a whole or in isolation from other regions of the brain. However, the hippocampus receives input from other regions of the brain, and in the new study, the researchers have introduced a spatial dimension to the network model. They have used grid cells, which are neurons found in the entorhinal cortex that fire in response to specific locations in space, to create a more realistic input pattern for the network. The researchers have then used three different adaptation strategies to test the performance of the network with this new type of input pattern. They found that the strategy that incorporated both additive neurogenesis and neuronal death outperformed the other two strategies, and that the performance of the network was most dependent on the timing of neuronal death. Overall, the study provides evidence for the importance of neurogenesis in the hippocampus and the ways in which it interacts with other regions of the brain.
This paper reports the discovery of a previously unknown role for peroxidases in the maintenance of lysosomal function in trypanosomes. The authors demonstrate that in the absence of peroxidase activity, trypanosomes undergo lysosomal disintegration, followed by damage of the mitochondria and other cellular membranes, and total cell lysis. The process is linked to the endocytosis of iron ions, which are required for DNA synthesis, antioxidant defense, mitochondrial FeS cluster biosynthesis, and, depending on the developmental stage, for mitochondrial respiration and alternative oxidase. The discovery of this unprecedented biological role of peroxidases is expected to have strong impact on respective studies in other human pathogens as well as the mammalian host.
Pmel is an albino mouse that carries a single-nucleotide mutation in the Pmel gene, leading to the production of a truncated Pmel protein. The Pmel−/− mice have a normal coat color and do not exhibit albinism. They are viable and fertile, and the absence of albinism suggests that the mutation is not a loss-of-function mutation. The Pmel−/− mice have a hair coat color that is intermediate between black and red, which is likely due to the production of pheomelanin. The Pmel−/− mice have normal ear pigmentation and normal hearing, suggesting that the Pmel gene does not play a significant role in these tissues. The Pmel−/− mice also do not exhibit a hair follicle cycling defect or increased susceptibility to skin cancer. The Pmel−/− mice are useful for studying the function of Pmel in other tissues, such as the eyes, without the confounding effects of albinism.
The study aims to determine the effectiveness of environmental interventions for dengue vector control. Environmental interventions are sustainable and safe methods that do not pose risks of environmental contamination or toxicity. The study conducted a systematic review and meta-analysis of 19 studies, which involved 16 studies contributing data to the meta-analysis. Three environmental methods were evaluated: container covers with and without insecticides, waste management, and elimination of breeding sites. The study found that each of the investigated environmental methods had some effectiveness in reducing larval and pupal densities of Aedes sp. mosquitoes. However, the overall role in the reduction of dengue transmission of vector control remains unclear due to issues with study design.
This study describes the identification of stalled translation sites in response to the small molecule PF8503 in human cells. The authors used high-throughput ribosome profiling to identify ribosome stalled translation sites in cells treated with PF8503. They found that PF8503 stalls translation at sites that were also stalled by a protein translation inhibitor called HHT. The authors also show that these stalled translation sites are enriched for mutations in genes involved in ribosome biogenesis and ribosome function. The study provides insights into the mechanism of action of PF8503 and could lead to the development of new treatments for ribosomal diseases.
Our research team has recently discovered that the viral protein SOX, produced by the Kaposi's sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSHV), plays a key role in the destruction of cellular RNA. This protein stimulates the polyadenylation of certain cellular transcripts, leading to their degradation. We have found that this process occurs in a manner dependent on SOX's ability to bind to RNA. Our work is important because it uncovers a novel mechanism by which KSHV, a human cancer-associated virus, may contribute to the pathogenesis of Kaposi's sarcoma. It also reveals a new role for the polyadenylation pathway in RNA turnover, a process that is important for maintaining cellular gene expression.
The type III interferon receptor ( IL-28R ) is important for host defense against some viral pathogens, but its role in the innate immune response to bacterial pathogens is unknown. In this study, the researchers infected mice with S . aureus or P . aeruginosa and found that IFNλ was induced. This resulted in downregulation of the microRNA miR-21 , sustained expression of PDCD4 , and increased production of proinflammatory cytokines. They also found that mice lacking the IFNλ receptor or PDCD4 had significantly improved clearance of the bacteria and less pulmonary pathology.
This study assesses the factors that contribute to death in patients with late-stage sleeping sickness (HAT). The study included 781 patients with confirmed HAT cases and complete medical records. The main outcome measure was death, which occurred in 17.2% of the standard melarsoprol schedule, 12.1% of the short melarsoprol schedule, 5.4% of the first-line eflornithine regimen, 9.1% of the NECT regimen, and 36% of the selective eflornithine regimen. After adjusting for treatment, the most significant predictors of death were clinical dysfunction on admission (odds ratio: 10.40, 95% CI: 6.55–16.51), high protidorachy (odds ratio: 2.14, 95% CI: 1.35–3.39), presence of parasites in the cerebrospinal fluid (odds ratio: 1.70, 95% CI: 1.03–2.81), and high cytorachy (odds ratio: 1.99, 95% CI: 1.18–3.37). A multivariable analysis within treatment groups retained clinical dysfunction on admission (in ARS 9, ARS 10, and DFMO B groups) and high protidorachy (in ARS 10 and DFMO B groups) as significant predictors of death. The study recommends that clinical dysfunction on admission and high protidorachy should be included in the present case definition and used as a basis for standardized clinical records.
The paper presents a method to track and analyze the social behavior of flies in a large group. The method uses a graph-based approach to identify individual flies in a crowded scene and tracks their movements over time. It also includes a machine learning algorithm to detect touch interactions between flies. The method is validated using expert annotations and applied to analyze the effects of isolation on social behavior and metabolism in flies.
This is a pilot study that aimed to improve clinical care for patients with diarrheal diseases in Bangladesh by using a smartphone-based tool. The tool was adapted from WHO diarrheal disease management guidelines and included a function to estimate a patient's weight, which is important for treating these diseases. The tool was evaluated at two remote hospitals in Bangladesh, and the study found that the tool improved the adherence to guidelines for the treatment of patients with diarrheal diseases. The study also found that the tool improved the accuracy of weight estimates, especially for younger children. The study suggests that smartphone-based decision-support tools can improve the quality of care for patients with diarrheal diseases, and it could be expanded to include more diseases and hospitals in the future.
This study examines the effects of temperature changes on the survival and reproduction of a host species ( Daphnia magna) and its parasite ( Ordospora colligata). The study used experimental data to build a mathematical model of the within-host parasite population dynamics and host survival. The model incorporated parameters such as host and parasite reproduction, host and parasite mortality, and parasite growth, which were assumed to have temperature dependencies. The study found that parasite growth, host reproduction, and host mortality were all negatively affected by high temperatures. The model also showed that the cost of infection (i.e. the percent reduction in mean lifespan due to infection) increased with temperature, suggesting that climate change could have significant negative effects on host–parasite interactions.
In this study, we propose a microcircuit of four types of interneurons (parvalbumin-positive, somatostatin-positive, and vasoactive intestinal peptide-positive) and excitatory pyramidal cells that provide a biophysical mechanism for the modulation of somatic and dendritic inhibition of pyramidal cells. We show that the mutual inhibition between somatostatin-positive and vasoactive intestinal peptide-positive neurons can lead to an amplification of weak signals arriving at somatostatin-positive neurons. This amplification can transform weak signals into strong responses and can switch the microcircuit between two distinct processing modes.
Microbiota plays an important role in various aspects of human health, including disease. To link specific microbes to specific phenotypes, researchers use a statistical technique called microbiome-wide association studies (MWAS) that compare microbial abundances between two groups of samples. However, these studies can produce spurious associations that do not provide any mechanistic insight due to microbial interactions. In this study, the authors developed a method called Direct Association Analysis (DAA) that removes indirect associations and applied it to the largest dataset on pediatric inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). DAA showed that only a small subset of associations is directly linked to IBD and pointed to immunomodulation, butyrate production, and the brain-gut axis as important factors in the inflammatory bowel disease.
In this study, the authors compared the effect of Wolbachia on the replication and transmission of two flaviviruses, DENV and WNV, using two different infection models: transient infection and stable transinfection. The transient infection model involved injecting Wolbachia bacteria into the mosquitoes, while the stable transinfection model involved transinfecting mosquitoes with Wolbachia bacteria. The results showed that both infection models had a similar effect on DENV and WNV replication and transmission. Specifically, the Wolbachia bacteria had a blocking effect on both viruses, which means that they reduced the ability of the viruses to replicate and spread within the mosquito population. This study provides important evidence for the potential use of Wolbachia as a natural control method for mosquito-borne diseases such as dengue fever and West Nile virus.
This study examines the relationship between cilia, organelles that project from cells and serve a variety of functions, and the InvC, a specialized region of the cilium that is associated with signal transduction. The authors use C . elegans as a model organism to study the InvC and its relationship to other parts of the cilium. They use genetic and imaging techniques to show that the InvC is distinct from the rest of the cilium and that it is established early in development. They also show that the InvC is required for the proper placement and function of cilia. The authors use a combination of genetic and imaging techniques to investigate the relationship between the InvC and other parts of the cilium. They find that the InvC is distinct from the rest of the cilium and that it is required for the proper placement and function of cilia. The authors also use genetic and imaging techniques to investigate the relationship between the InvC and other parts of the cilium. They find that the InvC is distinct from the rest of the cilium and that it is required for the proper placement and function of cilia. Overall, this study provides important insights into the structure and function of cilia.
The myelin sheath is a multilayer of lipid-rich membrane that wraps around axons in the central and peripheral nervous systems. This layer is essential for the efficient saltatory conduction of nerve impulses along axons. Myelination is a highly regulated process that involves the coordinated differentiation and maturation of oligodendrocytes, the myelin-forming cells of the CNS. In this study, the authors have used Scribble, a highly conserved regulator of intracellular polarity, as a model to understand the molecular mechanisms that control myelination and remyelination in the CNS. They have demonstrated that Scribble is essential for myelination and that it is expressed in oligodendrocytes throughout different stages of development and differentiation. The authors have also shown that loss of Scribble function results in impaired myelination, suggesting that Scribble is required for the establishment of intracellular polarity. Their work has important implications for the understanding of the molecular mechanisms that control myelination and remyelination, and for the development of therapeutic interventions to treat demyelinating diseases of the CNS.
The bacterium Listeria monocytogenes produces a virulence factor called Sls, which is a cytotoxic and hemolytic protein that has been linked to systemic infection. To better understand the role of Sls in the virulence of L. monocytogenes, a comprehensive investigation of the Sls-related genes in this pathogen was conducted. The study revealed that the Sls-related genes form a cluster that encodes three inducible cytotoxic and hemolytic proteins, LslA, LslB, and LslC. The results of the study suggest that the Sls-related genes are part of a larger set of virulence genes that contribute to the survival of L. monocytogenes in macrophages. The study also demonstrated the utility of a luciferase-based reporter system to investigate the regulation of the Sls-related genes in L. monocytogenes.
Mycetoma is a rare disease that affects the skin and underlying tissues. It is caused by fungi or bacteria that form large structures called grains within the tissue. Researchers wanted to know more about how these grains are surrounded by immune cells and whether a specific type of immune cell, called Th17 cells, are involved in mycetoma. They studied the immune cells in the tissue surrounding grains from three different types of mycetoma: Madurella mycetomatis, Actinomyces pelletieri, and Streptomyces somaliensis. They found that in all three types of mycetoma, the cells surrounding the grains were made up of three different types of immune cells: neutrophils, macrophages, and T cells. They also found that a specific type of T cell, called Th17 cells, were more common in tissue surrounding grains from Actinomyces pelletieri and Streptomyces somaliensis than Madurella mycetomatis. They also found that the levels of Th17 cells were correlated with the severity of the disease. This study provides new information about the immune cells involved in mycetoma and could lead to new ways to treat the disease.
Intrinsically disordered proteins ( IDPs ) are a type of protein that do not fold into a specific structure but instead exist as a random coil. These proteins play important roles in the body, including transcription, translation, and cell cycle regulation. Many proteins that cause cancer are IDPs. The transcriptional activation domain of the Ewing's Sarcoma oncoprotein family ( EAD ) is a type of IDP that is involved in protein-protein interactions without a coupled folding and binding process, a phenomenon known as "fuzziness." Researchers have studied the EAD to better understand this process and have found that it is driven by a balance between EAD conformational entropy and favorable EAD-target cation-π contacts. This finding offers a general conceptual framework for promiscuous target recognition by polyvalent IDPs.
Borrelia burgdorferi, the causative agent of Lyme disease, encodes a protein called lon that is homologous to the Escherichia coli lon protein. We have purified and characterized recombinant B. burgdorferi lon (rLon-1) and a mutant form of the protein, rLon-1S714A, in which a catalytically important serine residue has been mutated to alanine. Using these proteins, we have determined the optimal pH for rLon-1 proteolytic activity and the ability of rLon-1 to hydrolyze casein. We have also characterized the activity of rLon-1 in an insulin-chaperone-like assay. Our results demonstrate that rLon-1 has chaperone-like activity, suggesting that this protein may have a role in regulating protein folding within B. burgdorferi.
This article describes a type of immune response called antibody-dependent phagocytosis (ADP) and its relevance in controlling viral infections. The article explains how ADP is different from other types of antibody-mediated immune responses, such as ADCC and neutralization. The article also highlights the importance of studying ADP in the context of HIV infection. The article concludes by providing an overview of the methods used to measure ADP and discusses future directions for research in this area.
In this study, we used a computational simulation model to estimate the global economic and health burden of hookworm infection. We found that in 2016, hookworm infection caused 2,126,280 disability-adjusted life years (DALYs) worldwide, with 4,087,800 DALYs when cognitive impairment outcomes are included. The economic burden of hookworm infection also varies by country, with Brazil facing the largest burden and China facing a moderate burden. However, the model suggests that hookworm infection is associated with a significant economic burden worldwide, even when cognitive impairment is not included. The study highlights the need for more resources to be allocated to controlling hookworm infections and reducing their global burden.
The article describes the effects of hypoxia on axon pathfinding in the developing zebrafish brain. Hypoxia was induced using a specialized chamber that allows precise control of oxygen levels. The study used genetic and chemical modifiers of the hypoxic response to investigate the mechanisms of hypoxia-induced axon pathfinding errors. The results show that hypoxia disrupts axon pathfinding in zebrafish through an evolutionarily conserved mechanism, by activation of the hif1α pathway and increased expression of ephrinB2. The study also shows that magnesium sulfate helps reduce hypoxia-induced upregulation of ephrinB2 and decreases the frequency of pathfinding errors. The findings suggest that hypoxia-induced axon pathfinding errors may contribute to the adverse neurocognitive outcomes seen in preterm infants. The article provides important insights into the effects of hypoxia on axon pathfinding in the developing brain and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies to protect against the adverse effects of hypoxia.
This study evaluated the changes in lung structure and density in an experimental model of pulmonary paracoccidioidomycosis (PCM) in mice. PCM is a fungal disease that affects the lungs, and the study aimed to understand the progression of the disease by using high-resolution computed tomography (HRCT) and histopathology. In this study, male BALB/c mice were infected with Paracoccidioides brasiliensis (Pb) conidia, and the progression of the disease was monitored by HRCT and histopathology. The results showed that the lesions were mainly located around the hilus and affected more frequently the left lung. HRCT showed that consolidation, peri-bronchial nodules, and confluent granulomatous reaction were the most common lesions. Histopathology revealed that consolidation was equivalent histologically to a confluent granulomatous reaction, while nodules corresponded to individual compact granulomas. Discrete focal fibrosis was visible gradually around granulomas, but this finding was only evident by histopathology. HRCT provided valuable information about the distribution and topography of the lesions and helped in understanding the progression of the disease. This study provides a useful tool for evaluating and quantifying pulmonary damage in experimental PCM models, which can help in the development of more effective treatments.
Visceral leishmaniasis (VL) is a potentially fatal disease caused by a parasite called Leishmania donovani. A modified IFN-γRA test has been developed to detect the cell-mediated immune response in VL. This test can potentially be used to measure the cell-mediated immune response in L. donovani infection. The positive IFN-γ response to stimulation with leishmania antigens in patients with active VL was contradictory to the conventional finding of a non-proliferative antigen-specific response of peripheral blood mononuclear cells. Further research is needed to better understand this contradictory finding.
This study demonstrates the development of a mouse model of persistent Yersinia pseudotuberculosis infection. The mouse model recapitulates key aspects of human chronic yersiniosis, such as persistent bacterial colonization, commensalism with the host, and recurrent episodes of acute infection. The study also provides insights into the bacterial factors that contribute to chronic infection and the host immune responses that control Yersinia. These findings may have implications for the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of chronic yersiniosis.
The article describes a mutant of the fungus Magnaporthe oryzae (the causative agent of rice blast disease) with a defect in the hyphal penetration process. The mutant was isolated from a screen for T-DNA insertion mutants that were defective in the penetration process, but had no other visible defects. The authors then went on to characterize this mutant and found that it was defective in the formation of appressoria, the fungal structures that are required for infection of host plants. The authors also found that the mutant was defective in the oxidative stress response and that it was able to form oxidative radicals during the hyphal penetration process. The authors suggest that the mutant could be useful for understanding the mechanisms of hyphal penetration and the roles of oxidative stress and the formation of appressoria in this process.
In this study, researchers used geographic information systems to map the distribution of Schistosoma haematobium in Ghana. They compared the predictions from this mapping tool with the actual prevalence of infection in schools from a survey conducted in 2010. The authors found that the predictions from the map were not always accurate and that there were instances where the map underestimated or overestimated the prevalence of infection in schools. They also found that the practical implications of using the map to make decisions about which schools to treat were not always clear. Overall, the authors suggest that mapping tools should be used as a tool to help inform decision-making, but not as a standalone tool, and that it is important to validate predictions from these tools with actual data.
In this study, we investigated the role of prostaglandins, which are derived from polyunsaturated fatty acids, in the regulation of sperm behavior and fertilization. Using mutations in the fatty acid biosynthesis pathway in Caenorhabditis elegans, we showed that specific loss of prostaglandins affects sperm motility and fertilization efficiency. Furthermore, we demonstrated that the C. elegans oocytes secrete prostaglandins to promote sperm guidance and fertilization. Our study highlights the importance of prostaglandins in sperm behavior and fertilization.
Protein engineering is a powerful approach to deimmunizing biotherapeutic candidates, but deimmunization via the popular strategy of point mutations can be challenging and often fails to eliminate immunogenic potential while preserving function. To address this challenge, we present a novel design-based approach to deimmunization that leverages advanced protein engineering tools and in silico prediction of epitope content. Here, we describe the design and production of 18 Pareto optimal variants of Enterobacter cloacae P99 Beta-lactamase, a biotherapeutic target that has been previously deimmunized using conventional empirical methods. These variants were generated by using the protein engineering tool Pepfr, which finds the entire set of Pareto optimal designs by combining an immunogenicity-focused objective function with a function-focused objective function. We analyzed the immunogenicity and function of each variant using in silico and in vitro assays. Our results demonstrate that the immunogenicity and function of P99βL can be simultaneously optimized, and that this strategy results in deimmunized variants with improved function. Our findings illustrate the potential of advanced protein engineering tools and in silico prediction for the development of highly immunogenic biotherapeutic targets.
We show that elevated temperature can lead to increased recombination in Arabidopsis thaliana and that the extra COs are formed by the major Type I interference sensitive pathway. We also show that heat-induced COs are not the result of an increase in DNA double-strand breaks and that the hyper-recombinant phenotype is likely specific to thermal stress rather than a more generalized stress response. Our findings provide initial mechanistic insight into how environmental cues modulate plant meiotic recombination and may also offer practical applications.
This article describes a knowledge-based approach to integrating computational predictions and experimental data in a network to support biological hypothesis generation. The approach uses a network representation of the knowledge and the data, with nodes representing genes and edges representing relationships between them. The knowledge network is generated from literature curation, while the data network is generated from experimental data. The integration process involves combining the knowledge and data networks, allowing the exploration of the data in light of what is already known. Different methods for combining the networks are presented, including naive Bayes and likelihood ratio-based approaches. The article demonstrates the application of this approach using gene expression data and protein-protein interaction data.
This article presents a comprehensive analysis of the proteome of the extracellular vesicles (EVs) produced by the parasitic liver fluke Fasciola hepatica. EVs are small membrane-bound vesicles that are released by many types of cells and can play important roles in intercellular communication. The authors identified 752 proteins in the F. hepatica EVs using mass spectrometry and found that many of these proteins were surface-exposed and were modified with glycan structures. They also found that the proteome of the EVs was different from the proteome of the tegumental surface of the fluke. The authors suggest that F. hepatica EVs could be used as a diagnostic tool for fasciolosis, the disease caused by infection with the fluke.
The cycling dof (CDF) transcription factor 2 (CDF2) interacts with DCL1, a key component of miRNA processing, to affect the transcription of a subset of pri-miRNAs in Arabidopsis. This finding reveals a novel link between transcription factor-mediated transcriptional control of miRNA genes and the processing of miRNAs. Additionally, the authors provide evidence that CDF2 functions as a transcriptional activator of pri-miRNA genes, and that it may play a role in the control of flowering time in Arabidopsis. This work has important implications for our understanding of the mechanisms underlying miRNA-mediated gene regulation.
The study investigated the role of protein geranylgeranylation in the oocyte during early folliculogenesis. It found that the levels of geranylgeranyl diphosphate (GGPP) and geranylgeranyl diphosphate synthase (Ggpps) increase in oocytes during early folliculogenesis, and this process is required for the proliferation of granulosa cells and the primary-secondary follicle transition. The study also found that the loss of Ggpps in oocytes blocks the oocyte-granulosa cell contact and the secretion of oocyte materials such as growth differentiation factor-9 (Gdf9). This study provides evidence that GGPP-mediated protein geranylgeranylation is essential for the establishment of oocyte-granulosa cell communication and the primary-secondary follicle transition, which is a key phase of folliculogenesis.
In this study, the authors have developed a model for the complete transcription bubble of RNA polymerase II, and have performed MD simulations to investigate the channels for NTP entry. They have constructed the model using existing X-ray and cryo-EM data, and have validated the model by comparing the simulation results with experimental data. The study provides new insights into the dynamics of NTP entry into the active site of RNA polymerase II, and has implications for understanding transcription regulation.
In this study, the authors used laboratory-confirmed cases of dengue illness to estimate the magnitude of underrecognition of dengue cases in Thailand and Cambodia. They collected data from two prospective cohort studies in Thailand and one in Cambodia, which included a total of over 21,000 children aged 3 to 19 years. The authors found that in Thailand, the estimated number of undiagnosed dengue cases was between 31,000 and 165,000 per year, while in Cambodia the number of undiagnosed cases was between 18,000 and 95,000 per year. These findings highlight the importance of improving the accuracy of national surveillance data in order to better understand the true burden of dengue illness in these countries.
The study described above investigates the effects of natural killer (NK) cell activation on antiviral immune responses in vivo. The authors use a mouse model where NK cells can be efficiently activated by the natural killer complex. They show that efficient NK cell activation leads to an acceleration of CD8 T cell responses against a viral infection, as well as to a reduction in the production of interferon-alpha (IFN-α) by plasmacytoid dendritic cells (pDCs). These results suggest that NK cell activation can have a positive impact on antiviral immune responses in vivo.
This study investigates the role of AtNUC-L1, a nucleolin-like protein, in the regulation of rRNA gene expression in Arabidopsis thaliana plants. The study found that AtNUC-L1 plays a major role in controlling active and repressed rRNA gene variants in Arabidopsis. The authors used a variety of techniques, including molecular cloning, immunohistochemistry, and quantitative PCR, to examine the effects of disruptions in the AtNUC-L1 gene on rRNA gene expression. They found that AtNUC-L1 plays a central role in a mechanism responsible for switching expression of rRNA genes that involves IGS transcription and symmetric DNA methylation. The authors suggest that AtNUC-L1 might be a key regulator of rRNA gene expression in plants.
We have successfully identified human cytosolic proteins that interact with HCMV UL38. These include components of the NuA4 acetyltransferase complex, the HDAC1 deacetylase complex and the TSC2/mSin3A transcriptional co-repressor complex. Interestingly, we found that CHD4 and RBBP4 proteins from the NuA4 complex were upregulated in HCMV-infected cells. Our study provides insight into the mechanism of HCMV gene regulation and highlights the importance of protein interaction analysis for understanding viral infection.
The researchers used phage display libraries to map the antibody repertoire of RSV in young children prior to and following RSV infection. They found that the number of antibodies bound to RSV-G increased significantly after RSV infection, while the number of antibodies bound to RSV-F did not change significantly. They identified several novel epitopes in RSV-F and RSV-G, including an immunodominant epitope in the F-p27. They also found that antibody binding to pre-fusion F was 2-3 times higher than to post-fusion form. For RSV-G, antibody responses were high following early RSV infection in children, but declined significantly in adults. They used Surface Plasmon Resonance (SPR) based kinetic analysis with panels of serum from different age groups (<2 yr; 10–14 yr; 30–45 yr) to delineate the evolution of the antibody responses. Their findings could help in the development of effective countermeasures including vaccines for RSV.
In this study, we examined the mode of action of emodepside, a macrofilaricide that targets ion channels. We found that emodepside targets SLO-1 potassium channels, which are expressed in different isoforms in male and female worms. We also found that an alternative splice variant of the SLO-1 gene, which is expressed in male muscle, is more sensitive to emodepside than the variant expressed in female muscle. Our findings suggest that the sex of the filarial worm may influence its sensitivity to emodepside and that this could be taken into consideration when designing macrofilaricide treatment regimens in humans.
The Global Programme to Eliminate Lymphatic Filariasis (GPELF) is a public health initiative led by the World Health Organization (WHO) and the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation. The goal of the program is to eliminate lymphatic filariasis (LF), a parasitic disease that affects 1.3 billion people worldwide and causes debilitating symptoms such as swollen limbs and genitals. The GPELF recommends that countries conduct rapid diagnostic tests (RDTs) to detect circulating filarial antigens in order to determine the prevalence of LF and guide treatment programs. The RDTs currently in use are based on antibodies that recognize the W. bancrofti-specific carbohydrate epitope of the AD12 monoclonal antibody. However, these tests do not work well in areas co-endemic with Loa loa, a parasite that shares similar antigens with W. bancrofti. In this study, we used immunoblotting and immunoprecipitation to identify and purify L. loa antigens that are specific to that parasite and can be distinguished from W. bancrofti antigens. We also used proteomics to analyze and identify the proteins that make up the L. loa antigens. Our results suggest that the L. loa antigens are a complex mixture of proteins that can be purified and characterized using immunoblotting and proteomics. This information can be used to develop new diagnostic tests that are specific for L. loa and can be used in areas where co-endemicity with W. bancrofti is a problem.
In this article, the authors present a new analysis method for identifying ciliary genes in C. elegans, based on a combination of transcriptomics and network analysis. The authors use RNA-seq data from seven developmental stages of C. elegans to identify genes with similar expression patterns to known ciliary genes. They then use network analysis to group these genes into clusters based on their expression patterns. The authors validate their method by identifying known ciliary genes within the clusters and by analyzing the localization of known ciliary genes. They also use their method to identify new ciliary genes and analyze their localization. Overall, this study provides a novel approach for identifying ciliary genes in C. elegans and may help advance our understanding of the function and regulation of cilia in this model organism.
Brain cells called place cells fire at different rates in different parts of their environment. Scientists have known that place cells can be used to infer the animal's position. But they don't know how the brain does it. They think that the brain does not have access to independent stimulus measurements and has no prior knowledge of the stimulus space. They used hippocampal place cells as a model system. They found that knowing which groups of cells fire together reveals a surprising amount of structure in the underlying stimulus space, allowing the brain to construct its own internal representations. They also found that they could use these representations to accurately track the animal's position.
The paper describes a study that investigated the role of a specific inflammatory protein called interleukin-1 (IL-1) in viral fulminant hepatitis (FH). The study used a mouse model of FH, which was created by infecting mice with a virus called murine hepatitis virus strain-3 (MHV-3). In the study, the researchers found that the virus infected mice that lacked a specific protein called interleukin-1 receptor 1 (IL-1R1) showed reduced levels of IL-1 in their blood and livers, as well as less severe liver damage. They also found that blocking the production of IL-1 in the virus infected mice prevented them from producing a specific type of reactive oxygen species (ROS) called superoxide, which is produced by a type of white blood cell called macrophages. The researchers also found that blocking the production of IL-1 in the virus infected mice reduced the production of another type of ROS called hydrogen peroxide, which is produced by a protein called NADPH oxidase. The study provides new insights into the role of inflammation in viral FH and suggests that targeting IL-1 and its production pathway could be a useful therapeutic approach for this disease.
Hookworm infections can cause severe anemia and iron deficiency in children in tropical areas, especially in pre-school children. Multiplex real-time PCR was used to determine hookworm species, prevalence, and infection load in pre-school children in Malawi. The results showed that Necator americanus and Ancylostoma duodenale are prevalent in Malawi. Moderate and high infection loads of A . duodenale were significantly associated with severe anemia. Iron deficiency was positively associated with A . duodenale infection load. The results demonstrate the need for quantitative and species-specific screening of hookworm infections to combat severe anemia and iron deficiency in children living in resource poor settings.
This study investigated the role of COM-1, a protein that is homologous to the yeast protein CtIP/Sae2/Ctp1, in the process of meiosis during gametogenesis in Caenorhabditis elegans. COM-1 was found to play a crucial role in the repair of DNA double-strand breaks (DSBs), which are induced in germ cells during meiosis. The authors showed that COM-1-deficient germ cells repair DSBs through the error-prone pathway of non-homologous end joining (NHEJ), leading to a lack of crossovers (COs), extensive chromosomal aggregation, and near-complete embryonic lethality. In contrast, germ cells defective for both COM-1 and Ku, another protein involved in NHEJ, were viable and proficient in CO formation. The authors also showed that COM-1 acts parallel to the nuclease EXO-1 to promote interhomolog HR at early pachytene stage of meiotic prophase, thereby safeguarding timely CO formation. Together, their results uncovered the potentially lethal properties of NHEJ during meiosis and identified a critical role for COM-1 in NHEJ inhibition and CO assurance in germ cells.
This article describes the results of a study using a capuchin monkey model for aerosolized B . pseudomallei infection. The study aimed to identify and characterize the immunogenic proteins and polysaccharides produced by this bacterium, which cause melioidosis in humans and animals. The study used a 2-DE Western blot and mass spectrometry analysis to identify immunogenic proteins, and ELISA assays to quantify antibody concentrations to the whole cell lysate and individual proteins and cell wall antigens. The study identified several immunogenic proteins, including enolase, thiol peroxidase, alkyl hydroperoxide reductase, and heat shock protein 60. Additionally, two polysaccharides, capsular polysaccharide and type A O-polysaccharide, were identified as immunogenic. These results provide insight into the humoral response to B . pseudomallei infection and may inform the development of new diagnostic or therapeutic strategies for melioidosis.
The cell cycle is a series of events that are controlled by cyclins and cyclin-dependent kinases (CDKs) . Cdk1, also known as Cdc2, is an important kinase that is responsible for the transition from G2 to M phase of the cell cycle. In this study, researchers used biochemical and microscopy techniques to study the activity of Cdk1 during the transition from G2 to M phase in human cells. They found that Cdk1 activity is initially low in G2 and increases during the transition to M phase. This increase in activity is due to the dephosphorylation of Cdk1 and the activation of the Cdc25 phosphatase. The researchers also found that the translocation of Cdk1 from the cytoplasm to the nucleus during mitosis does not reduce its activity. These findings provide important insights into the regulation of Cdk1 activity during the cell cycle and its role in the transition from G2 to M phase.
HIV-1 is a diverse virus with over 7,000 subtypes, and current vaccines do not target all of the subtypes. The authors studied superinfected women and found that their neutralizing antibody responses were broad and did not target specific subtypes or epitopes. This suggests that vaccines that use diverse antigens, such as viral particles or plasma, may be effective against diverse HIV-1 strains.
HCMV is a common human herpesvirus that causes various diseases, including congenital abnormalities, dementia, and blindness. In this article, we will discuss the pathogenesis of HCMV in the nervous system. First, we will provide an overview of HCMV and its interactions with the host immune system. Then, we will describe how HCMV enters the nervous system and establishes a lifelong infection. After that, we will discuss the mechanisms by which HCMV causes various neurological diseases. Finally, we will provide suggestions for future research on the prevention and treatment of HCMV-related neurological diseases.
This study investigates the evolution of transcription factor (TF) binding in Drosophila embryos across four species of the melanogaster group. The authors analyze ChIP-seq data for four AP TFs (bcd, gt, hb, and kr) in each of the four species and compare the binding patterns. They find that although the TFs are bound in similar regions of the genome, their binding patterns are not conserved. The authors also show that the conservation of TF binding is influenced by the divergence of DNA motifs, the distance to the nearest gene, and the number of TFs bound to a locus. They also analyze mRNA levels for the same set of genes and find that they are correlated with the TF binding patterns.
In the year 2008, a study was conducted in two primary health centres in Thanjavur district, Tamil Nadu, India, endemic for bancroftian filariasis that had undergone eight rounds of mass drug administration. The study was carried out to determine age-specific infection patterns, distribution of infections by households and sites, and to identify 'hotspots'. The findings of the study indicate that antigenaemic persons were clustered both at household and site levels. The study also found that the prevalence of microfilaraemia and antigenaemia in children were not uniform across sites and age groups. Based on the prevalence of microfilaraemia and antigenaemia in children, 7 'residual' and 17 'transmission' hotspots were identified. The study concludes that spatial clustering of infections in the study area indicates the need for developing good surveillance strategies for detecting 'hotspots', adopting evidence-based sampling strategies and evaluation unit size for transmission assessment surveys.
This study is a systematic review of the community-effectiveness of temephos, a type of chemical larvicide that is used to kill mosquito larvae, in controlling dengue vectors and disease transmission. The study included 27 studies from 6 different databases and found that when used as a single intervention, temephos effectively reduced entomological indices, which are measures of mosquito infestation. However, when combined with other interventions, temephos did not have the same effect, and studies found that it was not sustained over time or reduced the immature stages of mosquito development. The authors suggest that further research is needed to determine the most effective way to use temephos in dengue vector control programs.
This research is about the role of cohesin in chromosome segregation during meiosis and mitosis. Cohesin is a complex that holds sister chromatids together during DNA replication and cell division. It is present along the length of chromosomes, but most abundant at the centromere and surrounding regions, called the pericentromere. This study shows that the budding yeast Ctf19 kinetochore subcomplex and the replication fork-associated factor, Csm3, are important mediators of pericentromeric cohesion, but they act through different mechanisms. Components of the Ctf19 complex direct the increased association of cohesin with the pericentromere, while Csm3 is dispensable for cohesin enrichment in the pericentromere but essential in ensuring its functionality in holding sister centromeres together. The authors also found that Csm3 is not required for cohesin association with the pericentromere, but plays a role in cohesion establishment at the pericentromere that is non-overlapping with Iml3 and Chl4. Their results indicate that Iml3 and Chl4 ensure the association of cohesin with the pericentromeric region, to facilitate its subsequent incorporation into functional linkages through a replication-coupled step, which requires Csm3.
Dengue fever (DF) is a viral infection transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes and causes a spectrum of clinical symptoms ranging from mild fever to severe hemorrhagic fever. The immune response to dengue virus involves the activation of various cell types such as T lymphocytes, natural killer cells and dendritic cells. In this study, we conducted a metabolomics and lipidomics analysis of serum samples from DF patients to gain insights into the host response to dengue virus. We identified a number of metabolites and lipids that were differentially regulated in DF patients compared to healthy controls. These include amino acids, phospholipids and sphingolipids. The metabolic pathways involved in the regulation of these metabolites and lipids include the tricarboxylic acid cycle, phospholipid metabolism, sphingolipid metabolism and the citric acid cycle. The results of this study provide a unique insight into the host response to dengue virus and may contribute to the development of new therapeutic strategies for dengue virus infections.
This article describes a study that mapped and analyzed networks of research institutions and researchers working on neglected tropical diseases (NTDs) in Germany and their collaborations with institutions and researchers from other countries. The study used bibliometric data from the SCOPUS database to identify publications with German affiliations that addressed 11 kinetoplastid and helminthic diseases and five NTD groups receiving the highest German government research funding. Co-authorship networks were created for each disease and their collaborating co-authors and collaborating research institutions. The study used OpenRefine software to clean the bibliometric data, OpenStreetMaps API to geocode research institutions, and Table2Net tool to create the networks. The networks were visualized using Gephi software, and researchers and research institutions were ranked by their occurrence count, h-index, and betweenness centrality. The study found that the share of NTD publications with German affiliations is approximately half of its share in other fields of medical research. The study also identified strong performers on an individual level and knowledge hubs within individual researcher networks. The study concludes that the mapping and analysis of research networks could help identify opportunities for collaboration and inform evidence-driven policy making.
Lymphatic Filariasis (LF) and Soil-Transmitted Helminths (STH) have been targeted by Haiti since 2000, with a strong mass drug administration (MDA) program. By 2012, the country had reached full national scale and was able to stop treatment for LF throughout almost all of it. This was achieved through several key programmatic elements, including community awareness and education, trust of drug distributors, direct observation, easy access to treatment, and quality data collection. The evidence of success lies in both the high treatment coverage obtained and the significant reduction in burden of infection. These efforts have helped establish best practices for NTD control, poised to address two future challenges: maintaining control of STH infections after the community-based LF treatment platform ceases and ensuring appropriate morbidity management for patients currently suffering from lymphatic filarial disease.
This study provides insights into the cell cycle regulatory mechanisms in S. meliloti, a plant pathogen that forms a mutualistic association with legume plants. The authors investigated the effects of depleting the CtrA protein, a master regulator of the cell cycle in bacteria, on the cell cycle progression and morphology of S. meliloti. They found that CtrA depletion led to a significant decrease in cell division rate, and that the cells became elongated and lost their typical rod shape. The authors further explored the transcriptional regulatory mechanisms underlying these phenotypes and identified a number of genes that may be involved in the control of the cell cycle in S. meliloti. Overall, this study provides a foundation for understanding how the cell cycle is regulated in S. meliloti and how this regulatory network may be influenced by the bacterium's symbiotic relationship with plants.
Francisella tularensis is a highly infectious bacterium that can cause a severe and often fatal disease called tularemia. It is a facultative intracellular bacterium, meaning it can survive and replicate both inside and outside host cells. The ability of F. tularensis to survive and replicate inside host cells is important for its virulence. One way F. tularensis does this is by using a special protein called gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase (GGT). GGT allows F. tularensis to use glutathione (GSH) as a source of cysteine when inside host cells. GSH is a molecule that is abundant in the host cell and is important for many cellular functions, including defense against oxidative stress. Without GGT, the ability of F. tularensis to use GSH as a source of cysteine is severely reduced, and the bacteria are strongly attenuated for virulence. This shows that GGT is important for F. tularensis to survive and replicate inside host cells, and for its ability to cause disease.
In this study, the authors examined whether different Leishmania species can fuse with each other's parasitophorous vacuoles (PVs) in infected mammalian cells. Leishmania is a parasite that causes a variety of diseases in humans and other animals, including cutaneous, mucocutaneous, and visceral leishmaniasis. It has two main forms: promastigotes, which live in the gut of insect vectors, and amastigotes, which live in the host cell's cytoplasm. Promastigotes are flagellated and larger, while amastigotes are non-flagellated and smaller. In the study, macrophages were infected with L. amazonensis amastigotes and then superinfected with L. major promastigotes or amastigotes. The authors examined whether the two species could fuse their PVs using time-lapse image acquisition and determined whether the fusion would affect the survival, multiplication, and differentiation of the parasites. The authors found that L. major promastigotes were able to fuse with L. amazonensis PVs but L. major amastigotes were not. The authors also found that L. major promastigotes were able to multiply within L. amazonensis PVs but did not differentiate into amastigotes. In contrast, within their own, unfused PVs, L. major amastigotes differentiated into proliferating amastigotes. These findings suggest that the ability of Leishmania species to fuse their PVs may vary depending on the species and the form of the parasite.
In this study, we examined the neutralization capacity of monomeric and trimeric HIV-1 Env glycoproteins that were expressed on VLPs. We found that rabbit sera and guinea pig sera raised against native trimeric VLPs exhibited unique neutralization capacities compared to sera raised against monomeric gp120 or gp41 expressed on VLPs. We identified a potent neutralizing antibody (10E8) that was specific to a quaternary epitope of gp41 and that was able to neutralize a diverse panel of HIV-1 isolates, including Tier 2 isolates. The 10E8 antibody could neutralize HIV-1 isolates that were resistant to other antibodies and small-molecule drugs. Furthermore, we found that the 10E8 antibody bound to the native trimeric Env expressed on VLPs with high specificity and affinity. Our study provides insight into the development of broadly neutralizing antibodies against HIV-1.
Buruli ulcer (BU) is a skin disease caused by a bacterium called M. ulcerans. It is most common in rural areas of Africa and can be very serious if not treated. BU can be cured with antibiotics, but it can take a long time for the wounds to heal after treatment. Researchers have looked at different markers that could help them understand the process of wound healing after treatment for BU. They found that myofibroblasts, which are cells that make up scar tissue, were not present in untreated BU lesions. However, these cells emerged during the healing process and were found in areas with fibronectin, a protein that helps cells stick together. After antibiotic treatment, many cells, including myofibroblasts, showed an "activated" phenotype, which means that they were ready to perform their functions. The researchers also found that apoptosis, or programmed cell death, occurred in healing wounds and that cytokeratin 16 expression increased in the epidermis. They concluded that the markers they identified could be used to monitor wound healing in antibiotic-treated BU lesions.
The study presented in this paper investigates the role of axonal mitochondria in supporting impulse activity in vivo. Using a novel technique that combines confocal time-lapse imaging with electrophysiological stimulation of mammalian axons, the authors show that mitochondrial transport is modulated by neuronal activity in adult mammalian axons. Specifically, the study demonstrates that low frequency electrical stimulation reduces the velocity of axonal mitochondria, while high frequency stimulation increases the velocity of axonal mitochondria. These findings suggest that the regulation of mitochondrial transport may play a critical role in maintaining bioenergetic homeostasis in response to changing demands on axonal metabolism.
This article describes the characterization of a spinal disc degeneration phenotype in a mouse model with mutations in the Filb-n gene. The authors used a combination of histological, immunohistochemical, and biochemical techniques to analyze the discs of Flnb+/+ and Flnb–/–mice. They found that the Flnb–/–mice had a more ectopic differentiation of the annulus fibrosus cells, leading to abnormal endochondral ossification and disc degeneration. This phenotype resembled the degenerative disc disease seen in aging humans. The authors also demonstrated that the Flnb–/–mice had increased TGF-β activity in the discs, leading to the speculation that the mutation may alter the signaling pathways involved in disc degeneration. Overall, this article provides valuable insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying spinal disc degeneration in Flnb–/–mice.
In a series of new studies, we reveal that the THOV protein, a member of the highly conserved THO/TIP export machinery, undergoes a novel immune evasion mechanism. We show that the THOV protein selectively recruits host translational factor IIB (TFIIB) into the nucleus, leading to depletion of TFIIB in the cytoplasm. This depletion of TFIIB impairs mRNA translation in the cytoplasm, leading to reduced induction of the interferon response. Our studies provide insights into how the THOV protein may evade host immune responses through a novel mechanism, and have implications for the development of new antiviral therapies.
We have summarized the information about B19V NS1-induced cell cycle arrest and the role of NS1 TAD2 domain in the dysregulation of the cell cycle. We have provided a detailed explanation of B19V NS1-induced cell cycle arrest and the role of NS1 TAD2 domain in the dysregulation of the cell cycle. We have also discussed the possible pathways that are involved in B19V NS1-induced cell cycle arrest and the role of NS1 TAD2 domain in the dysregulation of the cell cycle. We have provided a schematic representation of the pathways involved in B19V NS1-induced cell cycle arrest and the role of NS1 TAD2 domain in the dysregulation of the cell cycle. Finally, we have provided a lay summary of the information provided in the article.
This article describes the role of the endothelial glycocalyx (EGL), a layer of carbohydrate-rich molecules that covers the surface of blood vessels, in Dengue virus (DENV) infection. The authors review the literature on the relationship between DENV and the EGL and describe their own experimental studies, which suggest that DENV infection can cause EGL disruption and that this disruption may contribute to the development of severe DENV disease.
