The article also discusses the potential mechanisms by which DENV might disrupt the EGL and the implications of this disruption for the pathogenesis of DENV infection. Overall, the article provides an important overview of the current understanding of the relationship between DENV and the EGL and highlights areas where further research is needed.
In this study, the authors report the discovery of two yeast ubiquitin ligases, Dma1 and Dma2, that are required for proper septin dynamics and spindle positioning during mitosis. They found that the loss of these ligases impairs the function of the spindle position checkpoint (SPC) and leads to aneuploidy. The authors also identified Elm1 as a target of Dma1/2-mediated ubiquitination and showed that its recruitment to the bud neck is crucial for the correct SPC response. Their findings suggest that the integrity of the bud neck is important for proper SPC signaling.
The human genome is highly adapted to the diverse environments that humans have occupied throughout our history. In this study, we used data from 61 worldwide human populations to identify genetic loci that underlie adaptations to continuous climate variables. We focused on the summer and winter seasons, including precipitation rate, relative humidity, solar radiation, maximum temperature, and minimum temperature. We also included latitude in our analyses. By using a Bayesian linear model method that controls for population history and accounts for differences in sample size among populations, we identified genome-wide significant SNPs with strong signals for adaptation to environmental variables. We found strong evidence for adaptation to pigmentation and immune response phenotypes. Our results also identify several novel candidate gene regions associated with climate and provide insights into the evolutionary history of human adaptation to climate.
SQT1 is a genetic disorder characterized by prolonged cardiac repolarization. Using a Markov chain model of IKr (the rapid delayed rectifier potassium current), we have compared the kinetic properties of WT and N588K-hERG/IKr. The Markov chain model reproduces the experimental data, including rapid activation and inactivation of IKr, and a shift in the voltage dependence of inactivation. The model has been incorporated into the TNNP human ventricular cell model, and was validated by comparison with data from the original TNNP model and the Luo-Rudy model. The model has been used to simulate the action potential in a single cell, and in 1D, 2D and 3D tissue models. We have simulated the initiation and conduction of an excitation wave, and have shown that in 3D, the presence of SQT1 mutation leads to transmural heterogeneity in the action potential and the re-entry excitation wave, which are not observed in the WT model.
In this study, the authors propose a new method for understanding the collective motion of animals using deep attention networks. They have found that by using attention modules, they can build a model that is both predictive and insightful. The model is able to recover the ground-truth interaction rule used to generate the data and also to identify the number of interacting neighbours. They have tested the model using simulated trajectories and experimental trajectories of 60-100 zebrafish. They have found that at high velocities, interactions correspond to alignment or alignment mixed with repulsion at close distances. They have also found that each zebrafish decides where to move by aggregating information from the group as a weighted average over neighbours. They have found that the weights are higher for neighbours that are close, in a collision path or moving faster in frontal and lateral locations. The network also extracts that the number of interacting individuals is dynamical and typically in the range of 8-22, with 1-10 more important ones.
In this study, the authors used a phylodynamic approach to estimate the fitness cost of major drug resistance mutations in the Swiss HIV cohort study (SHCS). They used a birth–death model to estimate the resistance evolution and reversion rates of major drug resistance mutations in the SHCS. The authors compared the transmission rates of hosts infected with drug-resistant and sensitive strains. They found that only the 90M mutation in the protease gene had significantly higher fitness than the drug-sensitive strains. The following mutations associated with resistance to reverse transcriptase inhibitors were found to be less fit than the drug-sensitive strains: 67N, 70R, 184V, 219Q. The highest posterior density intervals of the transmission ratios for the remaining resistance mutations included in this study all included 1, suggesting that these mutations do not have a significant effect on viral transmissibility within the Swiss HIV cohort. These patterns are consistent with alternative measures of the fitness cost of resistance mutations. Overall, the authors demonstrated that their phylodynamic approach can shed light on the dynamics of HIV resistance evolution.
The research in this paper focused on the role of the Elongator complex, which is involved in the modification of tRNAs, in the oxidative stress response of fission yeast. The authors found that the Elongator complex is not necessary for the transcriptional regulation of oxidative stress genes, but rather for the modification of tRNAs that affects translation efficiency. They also found that the absence of the Elongator complex affects the production of two oxidative stress proteins, Atf1 and Pcr1. The authors propose a model where the Elongator complex is required for efficient translation of oxidative stress proteins, which is critical for the survival of the cell under oxidative stress conditions.
Primate lentiviruses such as HIV-1 encode a protein called Nef that is important for viral replication and disease progression. In this study, the authors examined how Nef affects the sensitivity of HIV-1 to neutralizing antibodies. They found that Nef conferred up to 50-fold resistance to neutralizing antibodies that target a specific region of the viral envelope protein. This resistance was observed with different strains of HIV-1 and SIV, and was independent of the ability of Nef to enhance viral infectivity. The authors suggest that Nef may alter the recognition of this region of the viral envelope protein by neutralizing antibodies. They also found that Nef conferred resistance to neutralizing antibodies that target other regions of the viral envelope protein, but this effect was less pronounced. Overall, the findings of this study suggest that Nef plays an important role in protecting HIV-1 from neutralizing antibodies.
In this study, the authors used high-throughput sequencing and advanced bioinformatics analyses to characterize the transcriptomes of uninfected and Opisthorchis viverrini-infected Bithynia siamensis goniomphalos. They identified 7,655 differentially expressed genes (DEGs) associated with 43 distinct biological pathways, including pathways associated with immune defense mechanisms against parasites. Among the DEGs with immune functions, transcripts encoding distinct proteases displayed the highest down-regulation in Bithynia specimens infected by O. viverrini, whereas transcription of genes encoding heat-shock proteins and actins was significantly up-regulated in parasite-infected snails when compared to the uninfected counterparts. This study lays the foundation for functional studies of genes and gene products potentially involved in immune-molecular mechanisms implicated in the ability of the parasite to successfully colonize its snail intermediate host. The annotated dataset provided herein represents a ready-to-use molecular resource for the discovery of molecular pathways underlying susceptibility and resistance mechanisms of B. siamensis goniomphalos to O. viverrini and for comparative analyses with pulmonate snail intermediate hosts of other platyhelminths, including schistosomes.
This study aimed to investigate the association of genetic variants of the complement receptor 1 (CR1) gene with leprosy susceptibility in a Brazilian population. We genotyped nine single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in CR1 using PCR-SSP and measured CR1 mRNA and soluble CR1 (sCR1) levels using real-time TaqMan PCR and ELISA, respectively. We found that the most frequent haplotype (CR1-HapA) was associated with increased risk of leprosy, especially in paucibacillary cases. We also observed that the allele CR1-rs3849266T was associated with increased risk of paucibacillary leprosy. In addition, we found that CR1-rs11118131C and CR1-rs11118167T were associated with increased risk of multibacillary leprosy. We also observed that higher levels of CR1 mRNA were associated with increased risk of multibacillary leprosy. Our findings suggest that CR1 genetic variants and mRNA levels may influence the susceptibility to leprosy, especially to the paucibacillary and multibacillary forms of the disease.
Researchers recently completed a study that involved more than 3,300 participants from the KORA F3 and F4 cohorts to investigate sex-specific differences in serum metabolite concentrations and their underlying genetic determination. They found that there were significant differences between males and females for 102 out of 131 metabolites, indicating that the metabolite profiles of males and females are different. The study also showed that specific genetic variants in metabolism-related genes depict sexual dimorphism. The researchers concluded that their study provides new important insights into sex-specific differences of cell regulatory processes and underscores the importance of studying sex-specific effects in research.
The authors propose a new formulation for the objective function in metabolic modeling, which they call Minimization of Metabolic Adjustment (MiMBl). MiMBl is designed to minimize the metabolic adjustment caused by a perturbation to a metabolic network. It takes into account the stoichiometry of the network and the fluxes of the metabolites involved in the perturbation. The authors demonstrate that MiMBl outperforms other objective functions commonly used in metabolic modeling, such as minimization of overall flux and maximization of yield, in terms of predicting the correct metabolic adjustment for a given perturbation. They also show that MiMBl is robust to changes in the stoichiometric representation of the network and the scaling of the objective function coefficients. Finally, the authors apply MiMBl to a case study of genetic interactions in the yeast metabolic network and show that it can successfully predict interactions that are not captured by other objective functions.
This article presents a study of the genetic structure of the black rat, Rattus rattus, in Madagascar. The black rat is a major host for the plague bacterium Yersinia pestis. The genetic structure of a population may influence its ability to transmit the plague, and it is important to understand the genetic structure of rat populations in order to control plague epidemics. In this study, the genetic structure of rat populations was investigated in four different areas of Madagascar that are affected by plague epidemics. Genetic markers were used to compare the genetic structure of rat populations within each area, and to compare the genetic structure of rat populations from different areas. It was found that the genetic structure of rat populations was different in each area, and that there was a strong correlation between genetic structure and geographic distance. This suggests that the dispersal of rats may be an important factor in the transmission of the plague.
This report describes the identification and characterization of 11 novel SmLy6 family members in the schistosome S . mansoni. This family is implicated in surface adherence and immunogenicity of the schistosome tegument. The authors found that SmLy6 proteins are glycoproteins with a predicted GPI anchor and therefore surface-localized. The authors identified putative orthologues of SmLy6 in S . haematobium and S . japonicum. They further confirmed the expression of SmLy6A-K in 14 life cycle stages of S . mansoni. The authors used structure prediction algorithms to generate 3D models of SmLy6 family members, which revealed a conserved structure. Finally, the authors used mice as a model organism to show the humoral immune response to recombinant SmLy6A and SmLy6B in endemic S . mansoni infection in humans, providing evidence that these proteins are immunogenic and surface-localized. This information may be useful for the development of novel vaccine candidates.
The study presents a computer simulation of the epithelial tissue in the Drosophila retina. The simulation minimizes global interfacial energy between cells, which is based on the timing of N-cadherin expression in cells and its temporal relationship to the remodeling of cell-cell contacts. The simulations reproduce the geometries of wild-type and mutant cells, distinguish features of cadherin dynamics, and emphasize the importance of adhesion protein biogenesis and its timing with respect to cell remodeling. The study also indicates that N-cadherin protein is recycled from inactive interfaces to active interfaces, thereby modulating adhesion strengths between cells.
We used fluorescence recovery after photobleaching (FRAP) experiments to determine the turnover rate of MT1-MMP at single invadopodia. We found that the fluorescence recovery was well-fitted by a double-exponential plot with time constants of 26 s and 259 s. The recovery was primarily dependent on vesicle transport, but negligibly on lateral diffusion. We then used the observed kinetics of the FRAP experiments to construct a computational model that successfully reproduced our FRAP experiments. We inhibited vesicle transport both experimentally and in simulation, and found that this blocked ECM degradation, indicating a crucial role of the rapid turnover of MT1-MMP in ECM degradation. We also showed that the extent of the reduction in ECM degradation depended on the degree of reduction in the MT1-MMP turnover. Finally, we showed a synergistic effect of the rapid turnover of MT1-MMP and proteolytic activity in ECM degradation. We conclude that our computational model provides a new in silico tool to design and evaluate intervention strategies in cancer cell invasion.
This paper describes a study that directly measures the dynamics of HIV-1 drug resistance evolution in macaques. The study compares viral populations in different body compartments and finds evidence of compartmentalization of drug-resistant viral variants in the macaque model of HIV-1 infection. The study provides evidence that drug-resistant variants may be emerging in vivo before detectable changes in plasma viremia are observed, and that changes in viral populations may be occurring in vivo in a manner that is distinct from what has previously been observed in vitro. The study has important implications for the understanding of HIV-1 drug resistance evolution and for the development of new strategies for the prevention and treatment of HIV-1.
A mathematical model shows how interactions between positive and negative diffusible signals can drive the development of morphological forms in tissues. This process can lead to bistability, self-sustaining elongation, branching and spatial self-organization. Such phenomena are not Turing patterns.
Myopia is a common eye disorder characterized by nearsightedness. The causes of myopia are multifactorial and include both environmental and genetic factors. In this study, we used genome-wide association studies to identify genetic associations with myopia in European individuals. Our results indicate that there are 22 genetic loci associated with myopia, including some that have not been previously identified. These loci are involved in various biological processes including neuronal development, eye growth, and scleral remodeling. Our findings provide insight into the complex genetic factors underlying myopia and highlight potential targets for future research and treatment.
In this paper, we will present a modified model for the swimming of a lamprey that incorporates body curvature feedback from mechanoreceptors in the skin. The model uses a chain of coupled oscillators to simulate the CPG, and an immersed boundary method to model the body and fluid dynamics. The feedback from the mechanoreceptors is implemented in two different ways, either as a directional feedback that depends on the direction of curvature, or as a magnitude feedback that depends on the magnitude of curvature. The model is tested by simulating the swimming of a lamprey in steady state and in a pulsing mode, and the effects of the different feedback mechanisms are compared. The results show that the directional feedback leads to more efficient swimming in the steady state, while the magnitude feedback leads to more efficient swimming in the pulsing mode.
HIV is a virus that spreads quickly and efficiently among humans. It is divided into different subtypes, each with its own characteristics. Some subtypes are better at spreading than others. One explanation for this is the first-come advantage. This means that the first subtype that arrives in a new population has a better chance of becoming dominant. It does this by out-competing the other subtypes that arrive later, and taking longer to be displaced by even more fit subtypes. This effect can be seen in the way that HIV is spreading around the world. It is also possible that the way that HIV is spreading is being affected by other factors such as interference, which refers to the ways that certain subtypes of HIV interact with each other. These factors can make it harder for a subtype to become dominant, by either reducing its ability to spread or by reducing the way that it interacts with other subtypes.
The content describes the organization of muscle cells during development. The authors suggest that extracellular cues are important for the organization of intracellular space in a way that supports the organization of myofibrils and their parallel alignment to form bundles. They used mathematical modeling and computer simulation to understand the mechanisms of muscle cell patterning. They also used traction force microscopy and immunofluorescence to visualize the structures and movements of muscle cells. The authors hope that their findings will be useful for understanding the development of heart muscle and the formation of heart disease.
The Wolbachia bacteria are being tested as a biocontrol agent in five Brazilian suburbs to reduce dengue transmission. The Wolbachia bacteria can invade and spread to infect all individuals within wild mosquito populations, but requires a high rate of maternal transmission, strong cytoplasmic incompatibility, and low fitness costs in the host. Extensive differences in climate, field-release protocols, urbanization level, and human density among the sites where this bacteria has been deployed have limited comparison and analysis of its invasive potential. In laboratory experiments, the wMel Wolbachia strain causes strong cytoplasmic incompatibility, a high rate of maternal transmission, and has no evident detrimental effect on host fecundity or fertility. Mark-release-recapture experiments using Wolbachia-uninfected mosquitoes in two areas of Rio de Janeiro showed that the conditions by which the infection frequency reached 100% varied greatly between sites, and were strongly influenced by the size of the local mosquito population. Through analysis of laboratory, field, and mathematical data, the researchers show that the wMel strain of Wolbachia possesses the characteristics required to spread effectively in different urban socio-demographic environments, including those where mosquito releases from the Eliminate Dengue Program will take place.
This article provides a detailed characterization of the JMJ703 protein, a histone lysine demethylase, from rice. The authors demonstrate that JMJ703 is necessary for plant cell division and stem elongation, and that it specifically demethylates mono-, di- and trimethylated H3K4 in vitro and in vivo. They also show that a catalytic core of JMJ703 is sufficient for demethylation activity, and that key residues involved in the enzymatic activity are conserved in plant-specific JMJD2-like proteins.
HIV-1 capsid recruitment of host cell factors required for infection. The authors show that the HIV-1 capsid recruits host cell factors to promote infection through a multimeric interface involving NUP153, CPSF6, PF74 and BI-2.
This article describes the construction of a genetic linkage map for Ae. aegypti, a mosquito species that is a major vector of dengue fever. The map was constructed using genomic DNA from a backcross of mosquitoes, which allowed the identification of regions of the genome that were inherited from a specific parent. The map was constructed using restriction fragment length polymorphisms (RFLP) and single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNP) to identify the position of genetic markers on the map. The map was then used to identify regions of the genome that were associated with a resistance phenotype to the bacterial parasite Brugia malayi. The authors suggest that this map could be used to identify the genetic basis of resistance in Ae. aegypti and potentially lead to the development of strategies to enhance the resistance of mosquitoes to dengue fever.
This study was conducted in five mid-sized cities in Brazil, representing four distinct climate regions, to compare the efficiency of four different traps against Aedes aegypti with the traditional larval survey. The study lasted 24 months, and traps were installed in 15 different areas. The positivity and density indices were calculated for each trap, and they were found to be different between traps and cities. The density indices were consistently correlated with the entomological inference provided by the larval survey, suggesting that these trap indices can be used as complements or alternatives to the larval survey. The study also demonstrated that the choice of trap depends on its cost and ease of use, as well as the desired surveillance goals.
This study provides insights into the structure-function relationship of the antiviral protein A3G, which is a member of the APOBEC family of cytidine deaminases. The authors used homology modeling, mutational analysis, and crosslinking to identify key residues involved in the oligomerization, packaging, and antiviral function of A3G. They found that a mutation in a hydrophobic residue that is conserved across APOBEC proteins disrupted oligomerization and RNA binding, and reduced the antiviral activity of A3G. The authors also identified an arginine residue that is involved in oligomerization and that may contribute to the RNA editing activity of A3G. These findings provide important information for understanding the mechanisms of APOBEC-mediated antiviral activity and may have implications for the development of new antiviral therapies.
We sequenced the entire bab locus of 96 inbred lines of Drosophila melanogaster, identified 6,756 polymorphisms, and found 1412 and 73 potential binding sites for the transcription factors Abd-B and Dsx, respectively. We found 51 SNPs associated with female abdominal pigmentation. Using allele specific expression, we found 11 SNPs associated with variation in bab2 transcript levels. Overall, our results demonstrate that large-effect QTL alleles can reflect the cumulative effects of many sequence polymorphisms, and suggest that functional elements of the genome are larger than previously thought.
This study investigates the effects of pneumococcal bacteriocins on the adaptability and pathogenesis of Streptococcus pneumoniae (S. pneumoniae) in a biofilm model. The authors demonstrate that S. pneumoniae can use pneumococcal bacteriocins as a source of nitrogen and phosphorus, and that these bacteriocins are involved in the regulation of blpA, a gene that encodes a regulatory protein involved in the production of S. pneumoniae bacteriocins. The authors also show that pneumococcal bacteriocins can be used as a tool to kill competing bacteria in a biofilm, providing a potential mechanism for S. pneumoniae to outcompete other microorganisms in the nasopharynx. Overall, this study provides important insights into the role of bacteriocins in the adaptability and pathogenesis of S. pneumoniae in the human host.
In this study, the authors investigated the role of the protein SRp20 in the IRES-mediated translation of poliovirus RNA. They found that SRp20 is a key component of the translation initiation machinery and interacts with the host protein PCBP2 in the translation of poliovirus RNA. The authors also showed that the interaction of SRp20 with PCBP2 is critical for the translation of poliovirus RNA, and that the deletion of SRp20 results in a significant decrease in virus yield.
The study by Banks et al. aimed to identify the genetic causes of various congenital abnormalities affecting the nervous system and endocrine glands. They used an N-ethyl-N-nitrosourea (ENU) mutagenesis screen with engineered mice carrying a LacZ cassette in place of the Sox10 gene, a transcription factor important for the development of melanocytes and other neural crest cells. The study identified four heritable mutations that altered the embryonic expression of Sox10LacZ, including one mutation caused by a single nucleotide substitution in the extracellular domain of the epidermal growth factor receptor 3 (Erbb3) gene. The Erbb3 mutation resulted in impaired epidermal growth factor signaling and embryonic lethality, demonstrating the importance of this receptor in neural crest cell development. The study provides insights into the genetic causes of various developmental abnormalities and highlights the role of epidermal growth factor signaling in neural crest cell development.
The study aimed to identify the factors that influence the reinfection rate of Schistosoma mansoni in the fishing community of Booma in northwestern Uganda. The study focused on the ethnic groups, Alur and Bagungu, who are known to have different levels of reinfection. The study used data from a previous study where individuals were treated with praziquantel twice and were followed for 22 months. Reinfection was assessed using faecal egg counts. The study found that the factors that influenced the reinfection rate of S. mansoni in Booma were age, ethnicity, sex, duration of water contact, and cercarial exposure. The study also found that there was a balance of IgE and IgG4 antibodies that were important in determining the reinfection rate. The findings of the study are important because they can help in identifying the individuals who are at high risk of reinfection and in developing strategies for reducing reinfection rates in the community.
Clonorchiasis is a disease caused by a type of parasitic worm called Clonorchis sinensis. To estimate the severity of infection in people with clonorchiasis, scientists use a method called stool examination. They count the number of eggs from the feces of infected people to determine how many eggs are being shed each day (called Eggs Per Gram or EPGs). In a new study, scientists collected adult worms from people with clonorchiasis and compared the number of worms to their EPGs. They found that there was a positive correlation between the two, meaning that the more eggs a person had, the more worms they were likely to have. The study also found that egg count per worm per day could be estimated at around 3,770 in an individual with EPGs of 2,664 and 106 worms collected. These findings help scientists estimate the severity of infection in people with clonorchiasis.
This study aimed to identify potential targets for novel therapeutics or combinations of drugs in the treatment of antimicrobial drug resistance. The researchers used a genome-wide screen in yeast to identify novel genetic components within interaction networks as potential targets in combination therapies. They focused on antifungal drug resistance and identified 18 synthetically lethal S. cerevisiae genetic mutants in cells expressing C. glabrata PDR1+ gain-of-function alleles. One mutant, lacking the histone acetyltransferase Gcn5, was investigated further. Deletion or drug-mediated inhibition of Gcn5 caused a lethal phenotype in C. glabrata cells expressing PDR1+ alleles, and also inhibited the emergence of fluconazole-resistant C. glabrata isolates in evolution experiments. The researchers concluded that their data provided proof of concept that synthetically lethal genetic screens can identify novel candidate proteins that, when therapeutically targeted, could allow effective treatment of drug-resistant infections.
Poliovirus (PV) replication is a complex process that requires the cooperation of many host and viral factors. Understanding the molecular mechanisms of PV replication is critical for developing antiviral therapies to treat or prevent PV infections. This study aimed to identify molecular markers of PV replication that could be used to develop antiviral therapies. To this end, the authors used a combined approach of in vitro studies, molecular cloning, and electron microscopy to identify membrane structures in PV-infected cells that are associated with PV replication.
The article describes a study that aimed to develop a new strategy for finding small molecules that could be used to treat Chagas disease, a parasitic infection that affects millions of people worldwide. The strategy involved using computer modeling to screen a large database of molecules and identify those that might be effective against the parasite. The researchers then tested the most promising molecules in experiments to see if they were safe and effective in killing the parasite. The article concludes that the strategy was successful in identifying several promising new molecules that could be used to treat Chagas disease.
The study describes the design and development of two DNA vaccines that encode the envelope protein of the yellow fever virus. The vaccines were constructed by amplifying the DNA sequence of the envelope protein from the YF 17DD virus strain and inserting it into a plasmid vector. The plasmid was then transfected into 293 cells and analyzed by Western blotting and fluorescence microscopy to verify that the envelope protein was expressed. The vaccines were also tested in mice, and the results showed that they were able to induce T-cell and neutralizing antibody responses that were comparable to those induced by the YF 17DD vaccine. Furthermore, both DNA vaccines were able to protect mice against lethal YF infection. Overall, the study provides a proof-of-concept for the development of DNA vaccines against YF, which may be useful for future vaccine development efforts.
The pathogenic bacterium Vibrio cholerae uses the chitin from crustacean shells in its environment to survive and evolve by sharing genes. The genes needed to use chitin are controlled by the orphan sensor kinase ChiS. We used transposon mutants to discover that the SlmA protein is a new regulator of the chitin-using genes. SlmA has not been linked to gene regulation before. We found that SlmA binds directly to the chitin-using gene promoter and is required for their expression. We also found that SlmA's ability to regulate gene expression is linked to its ability to bind DNA, not to its role in controlling cell division.
This is a technical paper on a new computational method for solving dynamic systems with a large number of parameters. The method is based on algebraic formulations of the problem and uses Taylor approximations to discretize the differential equations and to obtain computationally efficient solutions. The authors introduce a new randomized maximum a posteriori (MAP) approach to solve the parameter estimation problem that uses random perturbations of the observed data to circumvent nonlinearities and constraint issues. They also propose an efficient algorithm for solving the MAP problem using interior point methods and a rigorous convergence analysis. The authors demonstrate the effectiveness of their approach by applying it to several biological examples.
In this study, the authors utilized the nCounter molecular detection and quantitation system to analyze gene expression profiles in response to infection with West Nile virus (WNV) in various tissues of Swiss Webster mice. They identified differentially expressed genes (DEGs) in the brain, spleen, liver, lung, and kidney tissues, as well as a panel of 179 inflammatory-related genes that were differentially expressed across all tissues. Additionally, they compared the gene expression profiles of WNV-infected mice to those of mice that were injected with saline, and identified genes that were differentially expressed between the two groups. Finally, they used the DAVID and STRING databases to perform functional enrichment and protein-protein interaction analysis, respectively, on the DEGs from each tissue. Overall, this study provides a comprehensive analysis of the gene expression profiles in response to WNV infection in various tissues of Swiss Webster mice, which can be useful for understanding the pathogenesis of WNV infection and developing new therapeutic strategies.
Rabies is a serious illness that affects both humans and animals. It can cause death and is caused by a virus. In Mozambique, the majority of rabies cases are not reported and there is limited information available on the incidence of human rabies and animal bites. A rabies outbreak occurred in Maputo and Matola cities in 2014, which prompted the investigation of the incidence of human rabies and animal bites. Fourteen cases of human rabies were detected in Maputo and Matola cities and neighbouring Boane district during this time period. All cases had been bitten by a dog. Only one of the 14 rabid dogs had been immunized. The investigation included a case control study and community investigation. Factors significantly associated with human rabies were age under 15 years, bite by a stray or unimmunized dog, deep wound, bite on the head, and lack of post-exposure prophylaxis. The control measures for rabies are poor in Maputo and Matola cities. The introduction of the rabies vaccine, education campaigns for communities, and the removal of stray dogs are some of the ways to prevent the spread of rabies. The study highlights the need for improved prevention and control measures for rabies in Mozambique.
The study reported the identification of a new febrile seizure (FS) gene, SCN9A, which encodes Nav1 . 7, a type of sodium channel in the brain. The authors analyzed 21 affected individuals in a large Utah family with FS and found a potential mutation in a highly conserved amino acid called p . N641Y in the large cytoplasmic loop between transmembrane domains I and II. To confirm the role of SCN9A in FS, the authors analyzed a collection of 92 unrelated FS patients and found 5% had missense variants in highly conserved amino acids in the gene. After one of these children with FS later developed Dravet syndrome (severe myoclonic epilepsy of infancy), the authors sequenced the SCN1A gene, which is known to be associated with Dravet syndrome, and found a heterozygous frameshift mutation. Subsequent analysis of 109 Dravet syndrome patients yielded nine Nav1 . 7 missense variants (8% of the patients), all in highly conserved amino acids. Six of these Dravet syndrome patients with SCN9A missense variants also harbored either missense or splice site SCN1A mutations and three had no SCN1A mutations. This study provides evidence for a role of SCN9A in human epilepsies, both as a cause of FS and as a partner with SCN1A mutations in Dravet syndrome.
In this section, we will provide a brief lay summary of the provided content. We have explained the basics of morphogenesis, including the concept of growth, polarity, and pattern formation. We have introduced the two main approaches to modeling pattern formation in tissues, namely the mechanical and regulatory approaches. We have then provided an overview of the GPT-framework, which is a computational tool for modeling morphogenesis based on the mechanical approach. We have highlighted the key features of the GPT-framework and how it differs from other mechanical approaches. Finally, we have discussed the limitations of the GPT-framework and some of the current research in this field.
The study investigates the patterns of HIV escape rates and their effects on CD8+ T cell killing efficacies. The study finds that the observed pattern of escape rate decrease (ERD) is likely caused by interference between mutations that occur at multiple sites in the HIV genome simultaneously, rather than independent mutations occurring sequentially. The study suggests that the underexponential decline of escape rates over time is a contributing factor to this phenomenon. The study highlights the importance of considering interference effects in the estimation of escape rates and mutation-associated selective coefficients, as current estimation techniques are inadequate for interference regimes. The study emphasizes the need for novel estimation methodologies based on the analysis of HIV strains, rather than mutation frequencies.
Our research group has developed a mathematical model that simulates the tumor volume changes in response to cisplatin-based chemotherapy regimens. The model is based on a discrete time and space stochastic cellular automaton and has been validated using a data set of 41 patients with non-small cell lung cancer who received cisplatin-based chemotherapy. The model allows for the prediction of tumor volume changes based on the applied chemotherapy regimen and provides an estimate of the cell kill rate for each proliferative cell type considered in the model. The model can be used to predict the efficacy of different chemotherapy regimens and to optimize the dosing schedule and duration of treatment in individual patients. The model can also be used to investigate the mechanisms of resistance to chemotherapy and to identify potential targets for the development of novel therapies.
Biofilm-associated antibiotic tolerance is a major health threat due to bacteria's high levels of tolerance to multiple antibiotics. Biofilm-associated antibiotic tolerance can be attributed to two distinct processes: persistence and drug indifference. Persistence refers to subpopulations of slow or non-growing bacteria, while drug indifference refers to the entire population. Although molecular bases of persistence are under active investigation, drug indifference is far less well understood and hypothesized to be multifactorial and to result from reduced antibiotic diffusion to slow growth rate of many cells within biofilms. Alternatively, local gradients of nutrients, oxygen, pH, signalling molecules and waste products, as well as genetic heterogeneity, which can arise through mutations, recombination, and stochastic gene expression, could lead to physiologically specialized subpopulations exhibiting high tolerance to extracellular stresses such as antibiotics. The SOS stress response induced in heterogeneous and nutrient-deprived biofilm microenvironments is a molecular mechanism leading to biofilm-specific high tolerance to the fluoroquinolone ofloxacin.
Malaria is a major global health problem, causing over 400,000 deaths annually, most of which occur in sub-Saharan Africa. The parasite that causes malaria, Plasmodium falciparum, requires a human host to reproduce and can cause severe illness and even death in humans. The cytoskeleton of P. falciparum merozoites is crucial for invasion of human erythrocytes, which is a vital step in the life cycle of the parasite. Understanding how the cytoskeleton of merozoites is controlled is important for developing new strategies to prevent and treat malaria. A new study published in PLOS Biology provides important insights into the role of cAMP in controlling the cytoskeleton of P. falciparum merozoites during invasion.
Strongyloides stercoralis is a type of roundworm that lives in the soil and can infect humans. This parasite is often neglected, and there is not much information about how many people are infected. A group of researchers looked at studies from around the world that were published in the last 20 years to get a better understanding of how many people are infected. They also looked at different groups of people, such as those with HIV/AIDS, to see if they were at higher risk for infection. They used a special computer program to analyze the data and found out that S. stercoralis infection is quite common in some areas of the world, especially in Africa, Asia, and South America. They also found that people with HIV/AIDS and alcoholism might be at higher risk for infection. Overall, the researchers say that S. stercoralis infection should not be overlooked and more research is needed to understand it better.
Circadian rhythms are daily changes in gene expression and physiology that persist even in the absence of external environmental cues. In mammals, such rhythms are organized in a hierarchical fashion, with cell-to-cell coupling keeping individual cells in tight synchrony in cultured cells. The damping rate of population-level bioluminescence recordings can serve as an accurate measure of overall stochastic noise and can be used to measure the effect of clock perturbations on stochastic noise. This study shows that higher noise at the single-cell level results in faster damping at the population level and that stochastic noise can be changed in a dose-dependent fashion by small molecule modulators. The study also shows that stochastic noise is altered independently of period, amplitude, and phase. Finally, the study hypothesizes that the unperturbed clock is highly optimized for robust rhythms, as very few gene perturbations are capable of simultaneously increasing amplitude and lowering stochastic noise. This study demonstrates the importance of considering the effect of circadian perturbations on stochastic noise, particularly with regard to the development of small-molecule circadian therapeutics.
This study is about the drug target FtsZ, a protein that is essential for the division of bacteria cells. The study presents an analysis of the binding site of FtsZ for the drug PC190723. This analysis is done using a method called PocketFEATURE, which measures the similarity between the binding site of PC190723 and other binding sites from different proteins. The results of this analysis show that the binding site of PC190723 is dependent on the species and nucleotide-binding state of FtsZ. The study also includes a comparison of the binding site of PC190723 in different bacterial species, as well as the effect of different mutations on the binding site. The results of this study provide important information for the further development of FtsZ inhibitors.
In this study, we present the first crystal structure of the LEDGF-IN complex. The structure reveals that the N-terminal domain of LEDGF interacts with the NTD of IN, while the C-terminal domain of LEDGF binds the CCD of IN. Our results provide insights into the mechanisms of concerted integration of HIV-1 and other lentiviruses into host chromatin, and suggest the use of LEDGF mutants for targeted lentiviral integration in gene therapy applications.
Cells in our body have their own set of kinetics that determine their behavior. When cells become cancerous, they inherit these kinetics, which determine how the cancer progresses. The kinetics can change due to genetic mutations and epigenetic alterations. Some of these changes can be favorable and increase the fitness of cancer cells, causing them to grow faster and form tumors. In this study, we developed a mathematical model to track how the kinetics of cancer cells change over time. We focused on several traits that are important for cancer progression, including cell migration, cell division, cell death, and telomere length. We found that proliferation potential is the strongest modulator of tumor growth. When proliferation potential is increased, it leads to larger populations of non-stem cancer cells, which can inhibit the division of cancer stem cells. When proliferation potential is decreased, it loosens this inhibition and allows for frequent division of cancer stem cells. We also found that cancer stem cells become more heterogeneous over time, which can result in different populations of cancer cells with varying kinetics. This study can help us better understand how cancer progresses and how it may be treated.
The paper describes a mathematical model of how a pathogen can adapt to humans and spread from animals to humans. The paper focuses on the case of the influenza A (H5N1) virus, but the model is general enough to be applied to other zoonotic diseases as well. The paper shows that the probability of a zoonotic infection becoming established as a human-to-human infection is highly dependent on the rate of evolutionary adaptation, which determines how well the virus can adapt to humans. The paper also shows that the probability of emergence depends on the spatial structure of the human host population, such as the number of villages and cities and the amount of contact between them. The paper uses a branching process model to show that emergence can be predicted with a high degree of certainty in large populations. However, in small populations, emergence is inherently unpredictable. The paper shows that the spatial structure of the human host population has a negligible effect on the probability of emergence in large populations, suggesting that evolutionary factors are more important.
This study aimed to investigate the genetic diversity and patterns of reassortment of influenza A viruses isolated from wild birds in Canada and the United States. We analyzed 287 full genomes of influenza A viruses collected over a 25-year period from two distinct populations of migratory waterfowl. Our analysis reveals that the genetic diversity of influenza A viruses in these two populations is relatively low, indicating that the viral populations are structured and not randomly mixed. This suggests that the evolution of influenza A viruses in these two populations may be influenced by geographic barriers to migration, such as the Rocky Mountains. We also found evidence of genetic reassortment between these two populations, which may have important implications for the evolution of influenza A viruses in North America.
The present study describes the generation of a novel cross-neutralizing monoclonal antibody (MAb) designated MAb S139/1, which is specific to influenza A virus hemagglutinin (HA). MAb S139/1 binds to a common antigenic site shared among a variety of HA subtypes and neutralizes viral infectivity in vitro and in vivo. The findings of this study demonstrate the potential of cross-reactive antibodies in heterosubtypic immunity against influenza A virus infection.
The study aimed to assess the effect of ivermectin treatment on the prevalence of S . stercoralis infection in an Aboriginal community in northern Australia over a three-year period and to assess the validity of using a lower ELISA cut-off in diagnosis. A three-year cohort study of 259 adult Aboriginal adults living in a remote community in northern Australia was conducted. S . stercoralis infection was diagnosed using commercial ELISA testing and a lower threshold for treatment was used than that recommended. Follow up was conducted at 6 months and 3 years following ivermectin treatment. Treatment with ivermectin was highly effective and resulted in a sustained fall in the prevalence of infection in the study group. Results of treatment suggested the use of a lower ELISA threshold for treatment was valid in this setting. Follow-up identified a small group of subjects with persistently positive ELISA serology despite repeated treatment. The study highlights the importance of following up with patients after treatment to ensure that the infection has been eliminated.
In this study, the authors investigate the ability of relatively low prion conversion efficiency strains to interfere with each other in vivo and in vitro and the contribution of PrPC in this process. They found that long incubation period strains, when present in the same host, can interfere with each other and this is likely dependent on the relative onset of conversion of the blocking and superinfecting strain. They also found that a mixture of long incubation period strains does not completely block one strain from causing disease, suggesting that strain interference may be limited to specific strains. These findings have important implications for interspecies transmission and emergence of prion strains from a mixture.
Intrinsically disordered proteins (IDPs) and regions (IDRs) have been shown to play a role in allosteric regulation, despite their lack of ordered structures. The comprehensive ensemble model proposed here compares the roles of ordered and disordered proteins in allostery. It is shown that the order-order transition (MWC mechanism) and the disorder-order transition (EAM mechanism) have comparable contributions to allostery in the comprehensive model. The results suggest that IDPs/IDRs may be advantageous for allosteric regulation due to their high probability of being in the disordered state, which facilitates the order-disorder transition. This is in contrast to the previous EAM model, which considered only the order-disorder transition and found IDPs/IDRs to be less advantageous for allostery. The results of the study have implications for the design of allosteric drugs.
The article titled "β-Catenin promotes the formation of squamous epithelium during prostate development" discusses the role of a protein called β-Catenin in the development and function of the prostate gland. The prostate gland is a small gland located in the male reproductive system that produces a fluid that helps to liquefy and transport sperm during ejaculation. The article describes how β-Catenin is important for the growth and branching of the ducts that make up the prostate gland during development. The article also discusses how β-Catenin is important for the proper differentiation of prostate cells into the different types of cells that make up the prostate gland. Finally, the article describes how β-Catenin is important for the function of the prostate gland in adult males. Overall, the article provides important insights into the role of β-Catenin in the development and function of the prostate gland.
Researchers need to understand the local culture and beliefs of the community where they are conducting a study. This is especially important when conducting research in developing countries. Informed consent is a crucial part of ethical research. It is important to ensure that participants understand the information provided and are able to make an informed decision about whether to participate in the study. Informed consent is often not an easy process, especially in places where the majority of people are not literate. In these situations, it is important to use appropriate language, provide appropriate information, and take into account any cultural differences that may affect the process of informed consent. In a genetic study of podoconiosis in southern Ethiopia, the researchers conducted a rapid assessment to understand the local culture and beliefs about informed consent. They used a combination of focus groups and in-depth interviews to gather information. They found that it is important to provide information in a way that is appropriate for the local population and to take into account any cultural differences that may affect the process of informed consent. By doing so, the researchers were able to develop an informed consent process that was appropriate for the local population and ensured that participants were able to make informed decisions about whether to participate in the study.
This study investigates the dynamics of T cell proliferation in vivo during an EdU labelling experiment, in the thymus and spleen of FVB and C57BL/6 mice at 2 and 18 months of age. The proliferation rate of T cells was calculated according to the rate of EdU labelling of S phase cells during pulse and chase phases. The results show that T cell proliferation is highly heterogeneous, but with a specific "signature" that depends upon genetic origins, is specific to cell differentiation stages in thymus and spleen, and is altered with age.
Mitochondrial tRNA mutations can cause severe human diseases with variable penetrance. We found a new pathological mutation in a mouse mitochondrial tRNA that is similar to a human mt-Ti mutation. This mutation causes an abnormal folding of the mt-tRNAIle and is responsible for mitochondrial dysfunction in the mutant cells. We also found that this mutation can be partially suppressed by mitochondrial biogenesis, a process that is normally enhanced by increased ROS production. We conclude that this mutation and others like it may facilitate the evolution of pathological mtDNA mutations in humans.
In this study, the authors compared the expression of X-linked genes to that of autosomal genes in human triploid cells. Triploid cells have three sets of chromosomes: one set of sex chromosomes (X or Y) and two sets of autosomal chromosomes. The authors used expression arrays to analyze the expression of X-linked and autosomal genes in triploid cells with one or two active X chromosomes (Xa). They found that the average expression ratio of X-linked to autosomal genes was approximately 1 in normal diploid cells but was lower in triploid cells with one active X chromosome and higher in triploid cells with two active X chromosomes. This suggests that the X chromosome expression is not strictly adjusted to achieve a perfect balance in triploid cells. The authors also found that there was a range of individual X-linked gene expression levels in relation to ploidy, and that a small subset (∼7%) of genes had expression levels apparently proportional to the number of autosomal sets. This suggests that there may be an epigenetic mechanism that senses the ratio between the number of active X chromosomes and autosomal sets. The authors conclude that their findings support the idea of epigenetic regulation of X chromosome expression in triploid cells.
The dN/dS ratio is a commonly used measure to quantify selection pressures on protein-coding regions. It is calculated by comparing the rates of substitutions at non-silent and silent sites, and is expected to exceed unity if selection promotes changes in the protein sequence. However, the relationship between dN/dS and selection is not always straightforward, and the expected value of dN/dS is dependent on the population size and the selection pressure. In this study, the authors analyze the relationship between selection pressures and dN/dS in samples drawn from a single population, and find that it is relatively insensitive to selection pressure. They also show that the signature of positive selection across divergent lineages, dN/dS>1, does not hold within population: strong positive selection is expected to produce dN/dS<1 among population samples. These results have important implications for the interpretation of dN/dS measurements among population-genetic samples, and suggest that the standard interpretation of dN/dS is unjustified when applied to intra-specific samples.
The idea that natural selection has no effect on linked genetic variation has been an important assumption in population genetics. However, a number of recent studies have suggested that natural selection may have a stronger effect on linked genetic variation than previously thought. In this study, the authors explored whether natural selection could affect linked genetic variation between species with different divergence times. They examined the relationship between genetic diversity, functional elements, and recombination rate across several species pairs. The authors found that for species with short split times, genetic diversity near functional elements was reduced. This reduction in genetic diversity was consistent with the idea that natural selection could be affecting linked neutral sites. The authors also performed simulations to explore whether selection in the ancestral population could generate the empirical patterns. They found that selection in the ancestral population could reduce the level of genetic diversity in the descendant populations. These findings suggest that natural selection may have a stronger effect on genetic variation than previously thought.
The circadian clock controls the daily rhythms of biological processes, and its disruption leads to various diseases including cancer. The mammalian circadian clock consists of two main transcriptional-translational feedback loops, which are regulated by the negative regulators PERIOD (PER) and CRYPTOCHROME (CRY) proteins and the positive regulators CLOCK (CLK) and BMAL1 proteins. The loops regulate each other and the target genes involved in various physiological processes such as sleep, metabolism, and stress response. Previous studies have shown that the circadian clock is controlled by post-transcriptional modifications such as phosphorylation and ubiquitination. In this study, the authors identified the CK2α kinase as a novel post-transcriptional regulator of the circadian clock. They showed that CK2α phosphorylates PER and TIM proteins, leading to their degradation. They also showed that the knockdown of CK2α in mouse brain leads to an increase in PER and TIM protein levels, resulting in an extension of the period of the circadian rhythm. Overall, the authors identified a novel post-transcriptional regulator of the circadian clock and showed that it controls the daily rhythms of biological processes.
Cruzipain, a cysteine peptidase from Trypanosoma cruzi, is involved in the adhesion of the parasite to the posterior midgut of Rhodnius prolixus.
The study identified twenty genes that suppress a cytoplasmic dynein heavy chain mutation in the Caenorhabditis elegans roundworm. The study used a genetic screen of a conditional cytoplasmic dynein heavy chain mutant at a semipermissive temperature with a genome-wide RNA interference library to reduce gene functions. The identified genes were found to suppress the dynein mutant but not other conditionally mutant loci, and twelve of the 20 specific suppressors did not exhibit sterile or lethal phenotypes when their function was reduced in wild-type worms. The study also found 29 additional genes that when reduced in function, suppress conditional mutations not only in dynein but also in loci required for unrelated essential processes. The study concludes that conserved but nonessential genes contribute to dynein function during the essential process of mitosis.
In this study, researchers investigated the role of Ku in programmed DNA double-strand breaks (DSBs) in Paramecium tetraurelia, a unicellular eukaryote. Ku is a complex of two proteins, Ku70 and Ku80, that is essential for the repair of DSBs through non-homologous end joining (NHEJ) in somatic cells. Paramecium undergoes a unique form of meiosis called sexual transformation, during which the germline nucleus is transmitted to the progeny while the somatic nucleus is destroyed and a new one is formed. In this process, massive genome rearrangements occur, including the precise excision of internal eliminated sequences (IESs), which are repeated sequences that are not needed in the new MAC. Ku70a and Ku80c are specifically expressed in the new MAC and are essential for the recovery of a functional somatic nucleus. The researchers used RNA interference to knock down Ku80c and found that DSB repair was impaired, leading to the accumulation of DNA breaks in the new MAC. Furthermore, Ku70a/Ku80c was found to interact functionally and physically with the domesticated transposase PiggyMac, which is responsible for DNA cleavage at IES boundaries. Overall, the study shows that Ku plays a crucial role in programmed DSB repair during sexual transformation in Paramecium.
In this study, we used laser capture microdissection to isolate neurons from the hippocampus of mice infected with scrapie, a prion disease. We then used a combination of microarray analysis and real-time PCR to determine gene expression changes in these neurons. We found that there were significant changes in gene expression over time, with many genes involved in synaptic and neuronal function showing alterations. We also identified miRNAs that were differentially expressed over time, with many of these miRNAs having predicted targets that were enriched in synaptic and neuronal function. These data provide insight into the molecular mechanisms underlying prion disease progression and may inform therapeutic approaches.
The article aims to provide a new mathematical model that simulates the granuloma formation in the liver of mice infected with the parasite L. donovani. The model is based on stochastic Petri nets, which are a type of mathematical modeling that allows for the simulation of complex systems of interacting entities. The authors conducted a series of experiments to test the accuracy of the model and found that it was able to reproduce many of the key characteristics of the disease observed in mice, including the presence of granulomas in the liver, the recruitment of immune cells to the site of infection, and the production of cytokines by these cells. The authors also tested the model's ability to predict the effects of different treatments on the course of the disease and found that it was able to accurately simulate the effects of several different treatments. Overall, the article demonstrates the potential of stochastic Petri nets as a tool for simulating complex immune responses and for predicting the effects of different treatments on these responses.
Researchers have found that a simple chemical kinetic model of transcriptional regulation can perform arithmetic operations such as addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division. They have also found that by changing the parameterization of the model, it can approximate equality and inequality operations. Additionally, they have found that multiple transcription factor binding sites on the promoter can be used to approximate any analytic function. These findings are important for interpreting naturally occurring networks and suggest new possibilities for designing synthetic networks.
The study analyzed CHIKV genomes from a recent outbreak in the Northeast region of Brazil. The results show that both Asian/Caribbean and ECSA genotypes expanded their ranges and are cocirculating in the Northeast region of Brazil. In addition, the study provides evidence of coinfection of ECSA and Asian/Caribbean CHIKV genotypes in naturally infected human individuals, and molecular clock analysis estimates that the ECSA genotypes spread northwards around mid 2015.
This research shows that the H-NS protein in bacteria can differentially regulate core genome DNA and DNA acquired through horizontal gene transfer (HGT). The H-NS protein from a plasmid in Salmonella enterica serovar Typhimurium, called R27, has evolved to selectively silence HGT genes, while not interfering with the regulation of the core genome. This study also shows that the Hha protein is required for differential regulation of HGT genes by H-NS, while H-NS homoligomers regulate core genes. These findings provide new insights into how bacteria can adapt to new environments by regulating their DNA.
This study is a comprehensive transcriptomic analysis of the Leishmania parasites during their life cycle. The authors compared the expression profiles of three different Leishmania species (L. major, L. braziliensis, and L. infantum) using high-throughput RNA sequencing. They identified differentially expressed genes between the three species and during the life cycle stages of the parasite. The study provides a valuable resource for researchers and clinicians working on Leishmaniasis.
The article describes the development and evaluation of a molecular method based on the loop-mediated isothermal amplification (LAMP) technique for the detection of Amphimerus sp. liver fluke DNA in human stool samples. Amphimerus sp. is a fish-borne parasite that causes amphimeriasis and has recently been reported as endemic in the tropical Pacific side of Ecuador with a high prevalence in humans and domestic animals . The diagnosis of amphimeriasis is currently based on the stool examination to identify parasite eggs, but it lacks sensitivity and may be confounded with other liver and intestinal flukes. The molecular method developed in this study is highly sensitive and specific for the detection of Amphimerus sp. DNA in clinical samples and has the potential to be adapted for field diagnosis and disease surveillance in amphimeriasis-endemic areas.
The provided content includes a lay summary of a research article titled "Ykt6, a novel autophagy-associated protein, regulates autophagic SNARE complexes in Drosophila". The lay summary explains that the study is about the protein Ykt6, which is involved in the process of autophagy in fruit flies. The authors found that Ykt6 interacts with the proteins Vamp7 and Snap29 to form a tetrameric complex that facilitates autophagosome-lysosome fusion. They also found that loss of function of Ykt6 leads to an accumulation of undigested autophagosomes in the cytoplasm, and that the mutant flies exhibit defective lysosome function. The authors conclude that Ykt6 plays an important role in regulating autophagic SNARE complexes in Drosophila.
Antimicrobial peptides (AMPs) are important for innate immunity, and they have been shown to have antimicrobial activity against Nontypeable Haemophilus influenzae (NTHi), a common colonizer of the human upper respiratory tract. The SapBC permease is an outer membrane protein complex that has been shown to be important for the antimicrobial activity of NTHi against chimeric antimicrobial peptides (CAPs) and LL-37. In this study, the authors show that the SapBC permease is required for the antimicrobial activity of NTHi against CAPs. They also show that the SapBC permease is important for the sensitivity of NTHi to the antimicrobial activity of LL-37. The authors conclude that the SapBC permease is important for the antimicrobial activity of NTHi against CAPs and LL-37, and that it may be a potential target for therapeutic intervention.
The study aims to investigate the role of active degradation in shaping how the master transcription factor MarA coordinates its downstream targets in Escherichia coli. MarA controls a variety of stress response genes and active degradation of MarA has a short half-life compared to other cellular proteins. The authors modify MarA's half-life by knocking down the protease that targets it via CRISPRi or by engineering MarA to protect it from degradation. The study found that active degradation can impact both the rate of coordination and the maximum coordination that downstream genes can achieve. The authors also found that perfect information fidelity and instantaneous coordination show that trade-offs between these properties are impossible. The study has implications for the regulation of stress response genes in bacteria and suggests that active degradation plays an important role in shaping the kinetics of gene expression.
Leishmania parasites are transmitted by sandflies and can cause a range of skin lesions depending on the species. MKP-2 is a protein that helps control the immune response to these parasites, but we didn't know much about how it worked. In this study, we looked at how MKP-2 affects the immune response to L. major, a species that can cause lesions that eventually heal on their own. We found that MKP-2 deficient mice had a more severe infection than wild-type mice, with more parasites and bigger lesions. We also found that these mice had a lower type-1 immune response, which is important for fighting off parasites. However, the type-2 immune response, which is usually associated with allergic reactions, was also lower in the MKP-2 deficient mice. This suggests that MKP-2 is important for both type-1 and type-2 immune responses, but in different ways. We also looked at how MKP-2 affects macrophages, which are important cells in the immune system. We found that MKP-2 deficient macrophages were more susceptible to infection with L. major, but that if they were activated by LPS and IFN-γ, they were just as effective at killing the parasites as wild-type macrophages. This means that MKP-2 doesn't affect the ability of macrophages to kill parasites, but it does affect their ability to resist infection in the first place. Overall, our results suggest that MKP-2 plays an important role in the immune response to L. major, but that it affects both type-1 and type-2 responses in different ways.
The pancreas is a simple, stereotypical organ with a ductal tree that follows a predictable pattern of growth and remodeling. Using a combination of live imaging, fluorescence-activated cell sorting, and computational modeling, the authors describe the process of pancreatic ductal remodeling in detail. They find that the ductal system in the developing pancreas is stereotypical at each stage and that the remodeling of the ductal network can be described using a simple set of rules. The authors' work has important implications for our understanding of the development of other organs with branching tubes.
In this study, we used computational methods to analyze the kinesin motor domain and understand the mechanism of its large-scale conformational changes. We performed dynamic network analysis, cross-correlation analysis, and principal component analysis on crystal structures and molecular dynamics simulations. We found that the α4–α5 subdomain undergoes a conformational change from a protruding to a retracted state. We also identified a cluster of residues in the loop8-β5 region that are dynamically connected to the α4–α5 subdomain. These findings provide insight into the mechanism of conformational changes in the kinesin motor domain and its function.
The bacterial Lux system is a gene expression reporter that is used to measure gene transcription in bacteria and eukaryotes. It is fast, sensitive, and non-destructive, making it useful for high-frequency measurements. However, the Lux system is complex, and the bioluminescence it produces is affected by a variety of factors that can make it difficult to interpret. In this study, the authors developed a computational model of the Lux system that includes a new mechanism for LuxAB and Fre reactions and new experimental data for the LuxAB reaction from Photorhabdus luminescens—the source of modern Lux reporters. They also improved the mechanisms for all reactions and synthesis and turn-over of Lux proteins. Using this model, the authors were able to reverse engineer promoter activity from the bioluminescence, which allows them to better interpret Lux assays.
The article discusses the discovery of three drugs that are effective in treating hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) caused by enterovirus 71 (EV71) and coxsackievirus A16 (CVA16). The authors used a crystal structure of CVA16 to identify key residues involved in interactions with the inhibitor GPP3. They then used in silico docking to investigate the interactions of GPP3 with two next-generation capsid binders NLD and ALD. The authors conducted a meta-analysis using the available structural information to gain a deeper insight into the structural features required for capsid binders to interact effectively and those that confer broad-spectrum anti-enterovirus activity. Overall, their findings have important implications for the development of new drugs to treat HFMD.
In this study, the authors explore the role of low-density lipoprotein receptors in the Toll-mediated immune response of Drosophila. They find that the serpin Necrotic is taken up in the garland and pericardial athrocytes by LpR1 and LpR2, and that these cells are responsible for degrading Necrotic through multi-vesicular bodies and delivering it to lysosomes. The authors also show that Necrotic uptake is visibly increased after 30 minutes and peaks at 6-8 hours following infection. The study sheds light on the mechanisms of serpin turnover and the role of endocytosis in the immune response of Drosophila.
This study reveals that the BMP signal is activated in the left coelomic pouch, specifically in the veg2 lineage, but not in the small micromeres, of sea urchin embryos. This study also showed that BMP signaling is required for activating the expression of the left-sided genes and the formation of the left-sided structures. In addition, Nodal signals on the right side inhibit BMP signaling and control LR asymmetric separation and apoptosis of the small micromeres. These findings suggest that the opposing roles of Nodal and BMP signals in establishing LR asymmetry are conserved in deuterostomes.
This study investigates the mechanisms underlying the block to viral immediate early (IE) gene expression during S and G2 phases of the cell cycle. The authors found that CDK inhibition, either by checkpoint activation or the chemical inhibitor roscovitine, was sufficient to fully restore virus permissiveness in S/G2 cells. They also found that CDK inhibition was also successful in antagonizing the silencing of lytic gene expression during quiescent, latent-like infection of undifferentiated NTera2 (NT2) cells. These results suggest a mechanistical link between cell cycle and latency-associated repression of IE gene transcription and highlight the importance of CDK activity in the outcome of infection.
HIV-1 elite controllers can maintain undetectable levels of HIV-1 replication in the absence of antiretroviral therapy (ART), and this is mediated by the generation of highly-efficient HIV-1-specific T cell responses. However, the mechanisms that support the development of these protective T cell responses are incompletely understood. We found that dendritic cells (DCs) from elite controllers have the ability to effectively mount cell-intrinsic type I interferon (IFN-I) secretion in response to HIV-1 infection, which supports effective HIV-1-specific CD8 T cell responses. These data suggest that cell-intrinsic IFN-I secretion plays an important role in dendritic cell-mediated immune control of HIV-1.
Scientists have found 66 genes that cause fat cells to get bigger and store more fat in flies. One of these genes is a type of protein called Sir2, which helps regulate energy storage and utilization in cells. The Sir2 gene was discovered using a simple and quick screening method that measures how well flies float in a sugar solution. The team also discovered that Sir2 mutant flies live longer than normal flies when fed sugars but not amino acids, suggesting that Sir2 helps flies use food efficiently and balance their energy needs.
The aim of this study was to analyze the process of asymmetric cell division in 42 species of nematodes, all closely related to the well-studied Caenorhabditis elegans. By recording the first embryonic division of each species, the researchers obtained a collection of subcellular phenotypes that they could use to study the evolution of various cellular processes. Specifically, they analyzed the positioning of the mitotic spindle during cell division and found that, while all species underwent an asymmetric first cell division, there was large variation in the degree of cell asymmetry and in several parameters controlling spindle movement. These parameters included spindle oscillation, elongation, and displacement. Importantly, these parameters changed frequently during evolution with no apparent directionality in the species phylogeny, except for spindle transverse oscillations, which were an evolutionary innovation at the base of the Caenorhabditis genus. These changes were also unrelated to evolutionary variations in embryo size. The findings of this study suggest that, while the essential process of asymmetric cell division has been conserved over the course of nematode evolution, the underlying spindle movement parameters can combine in various ways.
The DNA binding protein OmpR plays a key role in the regulation of virulence factors in Salmonella Typhimurium. In this study, the authors have investigated the differences in OmpR regulation between S. Typhimurium and Escherichia coli. They found that while both species have identical amino acid sequences in OmpR, there are differences in how it is regulated. In E. coli, OmpR is regulated primarily by the phosphorylation of its histidine residue by the EnvZ sensor kinase. On the other hand, in S. Typhimurium, OmpR is regulated by both phosphorylation and DNA topology. The authors also found that while there is a relatively high degree of specificity for DNA binding by OmpR in both species, there is also a significant degree of flexibility in the DNA binding motifs recognized by OmpR. These findings suggest that OmpR has evolved to be a versatile transcriptional regulator that can bind to a wide range of DNA sequences to regulate different virulence factors in different environments.
The study reports the characterization of a novel bacterial protein secreted through the type III secretion system of Chlamydia trachomatis, a human pathogen. The protein, named NUE (nuclear effector), is a histone methyltransferase that targets mammalian histones in the nucleus. It has enzymatic activity and is found in the soluble nuclear fraction and in chromatin-associated proteins. It is the first nuclear effector identified in chlamydiae. Its potential role in pathogenesis is discussed.
This paper investigates the association between genome-wide homozygosity and adult height. The authors found a highly significant inverse association between height and genome-wide homozygosity, equivalent to a height reduction of up to 3 cm in the offspring of first cousins compared with the offspring of unrelated individuals, an effect which remained after controlling for the effects of socio-economic status. This suggests that height is influenced by the combined effects of many recessive genetic variants.
This study examined the immune response of blood monocytes in patients with malaria. The authors found that certain subgroups of monocytes had different functions and were associated with different levels of parasitic activity. The authors also found that the level of antibody-dependent cellular inhibition (ADCI) activity was correlated with the percentages and absolute numbers of certain subsets of monocytes, and that the highest levels of ADCI activity were associated with the highest percentages and absolute numbers of CD14hiCCR2+CX3CR1+ monocytes. These findings suggest that certain subsets of monocytes may play a role in the control of malaria parasites and highlight the importance of understanding the complex relationships between the phenotype and function of monocytes in malaria infections.
Our study provides the first evidence that Schistosoma mansoni infection is associated with increased numbers of HIV-target cells, both in the blood and foreskin, of men at high risk for HIV acquisition in Uganda.
