This paper presents a mathematical model that explains how ribosome drop-off affects the efficiency of protein expression. Ribosome drop-off occurs when a ribosome detaches from the mRNA template before it completes translation. This can happen due to a variety of factors, such as amino acid starvation or the depletion of tRNA. The model introduced in this paper describes how ribosome drop-off affects the translation rate of individual mRNAs. The authors show that ribosome drop-off can result in non-intuitive ribosome density profiles, in which the ribosome density increases from the 5' to the 3' end of the mRNA. They also show that the effects of ribosome drop-off on the translation rate are mRNA-specific, and that mRNAs that present ribosome queues are much less affected by ribosome drop-off than those that do not. The authors also show that, among mRNAs that do not present ribosome queues, resilience to drop-off correlates positively with the elongation rate, so that sequences using fast codons are expected to be less affected by ribosome drop-off. Finally, the authors use their model to show that ribosome drop-off can have important implications for protein expression, especially in physiological and stress situations.
The article is about the DeWorm3 trial, which investigates the possibility of interrupting soil-transmitted helminth (STH) transmission. The trial involves two arms, a control arm and an intervention arm, with different treatment strategies. The article discusses the feasibility of using mathematical models to predict the likelihood of transmission interruption and the need for high treatment coverage levels to achieve this. The article also discusses the challenges of achieving high treatment coverage levels in adults and the importance of determining whether transmission interruption is unlikely at early stages of the trial. The article provides an overview of the DeWorm3 trial and the individual-based stochastic model used to simulate events in the trial. It also discusses the importance of using models to predict the likelihood of transmission interruption and the need for high treatment coverage levels to achieve this. The article also discusses the challenges of achieving high treatment coverage levels in adults and the importance of determining whether transmission interruption is unlikely at early stages of the trial.
Researchers have successfully developed a conjugate vaccine made from the O-specific polysaccharide (OSP) of Vibrio cholerae (V. cholerae) Ogawa and the tetanus toxoid carrier protein. They demonstrated that the conjugate vaccine induces a protective immune response against V. cholerae in mice. The study provides evidence for the development of a conjugate vaccine against cholera, which is an important public health problem worldwide.
This article describes a method for studying the interaction between the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa and the opportunistic yeast Candida albicans in the context of host immunodeficiency. The authors have developed a novel murine model of P. aeruginosa-C. albicans coinfection, in which they are able to specifically deplete immunocompetent neutrophils, while maintaining immunosuppression by the use of antibiotics. The authors have found that P. aeruginosa is able to colonize the intestinal tract of these neutropenic mice without any signs of inflammation or intestinal damage, suggesting that the lack of immune response is allowing the bacteria to establish a chronic infection. The authors also show that P. aeruginosa is able to produce a metalloprotease, which can degrade extracellular matrix components, and that this protease contributes to P. aeruginosa's ability to colonize the intestines of neutropenic mice. The authors suggest that this protease may be an important virulence factor for P. aeruginosa in the context of immunocompromised hosts.
We have studied how the immune escape mutation K165R in the KP9 epitope of HIV-1 and SIV-1 viruses revert to the wild-type (WT) sequence when mixed with WT virus in different proportions. The reversion rate is highly variable and is associated with the outcome of infection. We used sensitive qRT-PCR assays to quantify the WT and EM variants in vivo and found that reversion is more rapid when the proportion of EM virus is lower. This is because the presence of WT virus gives the EM virus a growth advantage, making it harder for the EM virus to revert to WT. We also found that higher levels of EM virus at the KP9 epitope are associated with lower viral loads, suggesting that delayed reversion to WT in this epitope may contribute to better control of the virus. Our results highlight the importance of the initial proportion of WT and EM virus in determining the dynamics of reversion and the viral loads that result. This information can be used to design more effective vaccines and preventive strategies that target immune escape mutations.
The PCA1 gene of some S. cerevisiae strains has evolved to confer a cadmium resistance phenotype by changing the PCA1 promoter region. This phenotype has been maintained through selection, even though the PCA1 coding region has experienced deleterious mutations that have reduced the cadmium-efflux activity of PCA1. PCA1 in these strains has not been adapted to the current cadmium level in the environment. Instead, it has evolved to a stable cadmium-tolerant state, which is maintained under various environmental conditions.
In this study, the authors present a comprehensive analysis of the activation status of 11 oncogenic pathways in gastric cancer, a major cause of cancer-related death worldwide. Using gene expression data from 301 primary gastric cancers and 25 gastric cancer cell lines, the authors developed an in silico method to map the activity of multiple oncogenic pathways simultaneously in primary tumors. They identified three oncogenic pathways (proliferation/stem cell, NF-κB, and Wnt/β-catenin) that were deregulated in the vast majority (over 70%) of gastric cancers, and functionally validated the pathway predictions in vitro using a panel of gastric cancer cell lines. The authors also showed that patient stratification by oncogenic pathway combinations (e.g. high proliferation/high NF-κB vs. low proliferation/low NF-κB) showed reproducible and significant survival differences in multiple independent patient cohorts, suggesting a critical role for pathway combinations in influencing GC clinical behavior. Their results demonstrate that GCs can be successfully taxonomized using oncogenic pathway activity into biologically, functionally, and clinically relevant subtypes. This pathway-centric strategy provides a novel approach to identifying biologically meaningful subtypes of cancer, which could lead to more personalized and effective treatments in the future.
In this study, the authors use a computational approach to analyze the relationship between strong SIDD sites, which are sites in the DNA that are destabilized under stress conditions, and the function of genes. They use the E. coli K12 genome as an example and show that strong SIDD sites are more likely to occur in the 5' flanks of genes that encode transcriptional regulators. They also find that the genes that directly respond to physiological and environmental stimuli have a higher probability of having strong SIDD sites in their 5' flanks. The authors suggest that strong SIDD sites are active and necessary participants in the regulatory mechanisms governing changes in the global pattern of gene expression in prokaryotes.
Our previous study identified a total of twelve HMG-box genes in the fungus P. anserina and found that six of them are dispensable for vegetative growth and sexual reproduction. Here, we found that the dispensable HMG-box genes could be grouped into two major clades based on the phylogenetic analysis, with four genes falling into the M-HMG-box clade and two genes falling into the HMG-box1 clade. However, we did not find any genes belonging to the HMG-box2 clade in P. anserina. The expression of the HMG-box genes was differentially regulated during vegetative growth and sexual reproduction, with the expression of HMG-box1 genes being upregulated during sexual reproduction. Interestingly, we found that a HMG-box protein could form a complex with a MAT-alpha2 transcription factor to regulate the transcription of FPR1 and FMR1, two important genes involved in sexual reproduction in P. anserina. Furthermore, we found that a HMG-box protein was required for normal fertilization efficiency. These results suggest that HMG-box genes play an important role in the regulation of sexual reproduction in P. anserina.
This study aimed to investigate the persistence of Ebola virus in body fluids of Ebola virus disease (EVD) survivors in Sierra Leone. The study was conducted in two phases, with the first phase focusing on semen and the second phase on a range of other body fluids, including vaginal fluid, menstrual blood, breast milk, rectal fluid, sweat and saliva. Participants were recruited through community engagement and sensitization sessions, and were compensated for their time and transport costs. Specimens were collected in compliance with international and national regulations, and tested for the presence of Ebola virus using quantitative real-time polymerase chain reaction (qRT-PCR). The study aimed to provide evidence to guide policies on sexual health and practices, and to inform recommendations for testing and surveillance of EVD survivors.
Chemical gradients are essential for the survival of bacteria in their natural environment. In this study, we used experimental data from Escherichia coli (E. coli) to predict the chemical gradients that these bacteria typically encounter. We reevaluated the Weber-Fechner law and other related laws to obtain a full distribution of the gradients. We used information theory to predict the optimal response of E. coli to different chemical gradients. By simulating the behavior of E. coli, we showed that the bacteria migrate most efficiently in gradients of a chemical called aspartate. Our study provides a first step towards deciphering the chemical nature of complex, experimentally inaccessible microenvironments, such as the human intestine.
The human body is constantly producing new blood cells from a small number of stem cells, which are found in the bone marrow. Scientists have known for some time that these stem cells are functionally defined by their multi-potency and self-renewal capacity. However, it wasn't clear whether these genetically identical stem cells differed in their lifespan or whether they had the same lifespan, which was thought to be predetermined. In this study, the researchers used a new mathematical model based on reliability theory to account for the diversity of lifespans of HSCs. They analyzed the failure kinetics of clonal repopulation experiments and found that HSCs have anti-persistent behavior, which means that they have short bursts of proliferation followed by periods of rest. This is important because the time between these bursts of proliferation determines the lifespan of the HSCs. The researchers also showed that the lifespan of each HSC depends on the amplitudes and frequencies of fluctuations in the failure rate kinetics. Their findings suggest that the lifespan of HSCs is determined by preprogrammed differences in repair capacity. The results of this study could have important implications for understanding the maintenance of blood cell production and the development of new therapeutic approaches for treating blood disorders.
Our study uncovered a novel mechanism of antibody-mediated immunity against helminth infections. We found that antibodies against parasite antigens induce the rapid trapping of tissue migrating larvae and prevent tissue necrosis following challenge infections. Mice lacking antibodies or activating Fc receptors harbored highly motile larvae, developed extensive tissue damage, and accumulated less Arginase-1 expressing macrophages around the larvae. Moreover, we found that Hp-specific antibodies induced FcRγ- and complement-dependent adherence of macrophages to larvae in vitro, resulting in complete larval immobilization. In vitro and in vivo, Hp-specific antibodies induced Arg1 expression in macrophages independently of IL-4Rα signaling. These findings suggest a new role for antibodies in the protection against helminth infections, beyond their ability to neutralize or opsonize parasites.
Researchers have developed a new method to visualize and track the movement of chromatin during DNA repair in living yeast cells. They used a protein called ParB that binds to specific DNA sequences and recruits other proteins to form a fluorescent focus. By observing the movement of this fluorescent focus over time, they were able to track the dynamics of DNA repair and identify a new stage of chromatin rearrangement that occurs early in the repair process. This new method will enable researchers to better understand the mechanisms of DNA repair and to identify new targets for therapeutic interventions.
The article describes a model that simulates the transmission of Trypanosoma cruzi, a parasite that causes Chagas disease, in rural villages in Argentina. The model is designed to estimate the rate of re-inoculation in humans, as well as the frequency of reinfections during the acute and chronic stages of the disease, according to different hypotheses about the adaptive immune response following a primary infection. The model is based on a stochastic agent-based approach, which involves simulating individual agents (humans and bugs) and their interactions in an environment. The model is fitted to epidemiological data from two rural settlements in the Chaco Province of Argentina, and the results suggest that re-inoculations occur at a low rate, on the order of 0.032 per year, with most of them occurring in the chronic phase of the disease. The model also predicts that reinfections can cause mixed infections, where more than one lineage of T. cruzi is present in the same individual. The authors suggest that further research is needed to confirm these findings and to understand the factors that contribute to reinfections and their impact on the progression of Chagas disease.
Scientists have found that people who experience a subclinical dengue infection (a mild infection or no infection at all) have a higher level of certain types of antibodies than those who experience a severe infection. This discovery could help researchers develop better ways to predict which types of dengue infections someone might develop.
The Drosophila wing disc is a structure that develops into the wing of a fruit fly. During development, the wing disc is divided into two compartments: anterior (A) and posterior (P). The cells in the P compartment secrete Hedgehog (Hh) protein, which forms a gradient that runs from the P to the A compartment. Hh regulates gene expression in a concentration-dependent manner. It has been shown that Hh signaling is responsible for the formation of multiple distinct domains of gene expression in the A compartment. However, it has not been demonstrated that the borders of these domains correspond exactly to Hh concentration thresholds. In this study, the authors use mathematical modeling to analyze the relationship between Hh concentration and gene expression. They found that, at steady state, the borders of the domains cannot be clearly defined in response to Hh concentration. The authors suggest that this is because Hh signaling is not only determined by the concentration of Hh, but also by the feedback regulation of Hh receptor (Ptc). They propose that a single concentration threshold is sufficient to support multiple outputs. The authors also conducted experiments to test their hypothesis. They found that Hh signaling depends on the history of exposure to Hh and that a single Hh concentration threshold is sufficient to support multiple outputs. The authors suggest that the feedback regulation of Ptc plays an important role in the establishment of patterns of gene expression.
The Lwt/Lwt mutation in the C. elegans unc-79 gene causes a novel locomotor phenotype, "Lightweight." Lightweight mutants are smaller and have reduced body fat compared to wild-type worms. They also have reduced sensitivity to ethanol, as measured by ethanol-induced loss of righting reflex and duration of ethanol intoxication. The Lightweight mutant has a reduced number of dopaminergic neurons and dopaminergic neurites. Dopamine levels are reduced in the brain of Lightweight mutants, while levels of the dopamine metabolite, 3,4-dihydroxyphenylacetic acid, are increased. Lightweight mutants have a reduced number of synaptic boutons in dopaminergic neurons, but no change in synapse number in non-dopaminergic neurons. The Lightweight mutant also has reduced locomotor activity in response to ethanol, as measured by distance traveled and activity rate.
The study showed that the Imd pathway, a conserved immune signaling pathway that has potent anti-P . falciparum activity, is most potent against the parasite's ookinete stage. The study also showed that caspar silencing alone is sufficient to induce a robust anti-P . falciparum response even in the relative absence of resident gut microbiota. The study highlights the physiological considerations that are integral to a thoughtful implementation of Imd pathway manipulation in A . gambiae as part of an effort to limit the malaria transmission cycle. The study reveals a variety of previously unrecognized nuances in the Imd-directed immune response against P . falciparum.
Bone marrow derived mesenchymal stem cells (BMMSCs) have been proposed as potential therapeutic agents for the treatment of fibrotic diseases. However, the anti-fibrotic properties of these cells have not been evaluated in an animal model of pulmonary fibrosis induced by the fungal pathogen Paracoccidioides brasiliensis. In this study, we evaluated the effect of late infusion of BMMSCs on pulmonary fibrosis induced by P. brasiliensis in an in vivo experimental model of PCM. Our findings indicated that late infusion of BMMSCs did not have any anti-fibrotic effect, as an exacerbated fibrotic process was observed.
The Mediterranean region is currently experiencing a geographical expansion of Leishmania infantum vectors towards northern latitudes and higher altitudes, which is predicted to have an impact on leishmaniasis transmission. This study aimed to investigate the seasonal dynamics of Mediterranean sand fly species that are competent to transmit L. infantum in order to provide a baseline for continuing investigations on possible changes that may have an impact on leishmaniasis transmission. The study was carried out in 8 countries in the Mediterranean region (Portugal, Spain, France, Italy, Greece, Cyprus, Turkey, and Georgia) over a period of 4 years (2011–2014). Collections were performed using CDC light traps with fine mesh cage, with a total of 94 traps operating 1–2 hours before sunset until 1–2 hours after sunrise. Sticky traps were also used complementary to light traps in most of the sites surveyed. Sand flies were identified morphologically or by molecular methods. The study showed that the activity period of Mediterranean vectors is typically seasonal, and that it varies among species and countries. The study provides a practical graphic format of phenological and abundance parameters that may have an impact on leishmaniasis transmission by relevant vector species in each endemic setting and the whole subregion.
This paper describes the discovery of novel genes involved in host immune responses to O. tsutsugamushi infection. In particular, the authors describe how microarray analysis was used to identify differentially expressed genes in monocytes infected with O. tsutsugamushi. The results suggest that O. tsutsugamushi infection induces pro-inflammatory cytokine and chemokine production, type I interferon responses, and apoptosis. These findings may help to elucidate the pathogenesis of scrub typhus and to identify potential targets for new therapies.
In this paper, we present a model of how ants might store visual memories to navigate their environments. We use a spiking neural network to simulate how a cataglyphis ant might learn to distinguish its home from other locations by storing images of views along its route home. We train the network using images taken from real ant routes and use a simple algorithm to determine whether a novel image is more similar to a previously learnt image or not. We find that the network can store up to 100,000 images and distinguish them with high accuracy even when the images are highly correlated. We also show how the network can generalize to new images that it has not seen before, and how it can distinguish between different routes even when they are very similar.
This study investigated the abscission of cauline leaves in Arabidopsis in response to bacterial infection. Cauline leaves were found to abscise in response to infection with Pseudomonas syringae strain DC3000, and this response was dependent on the salicylic acid signaling pathway. The abscission response was triggered by the recognition of bacterial effectors by plant immune receptors, leading to the activation of a MAPK cascade that ultimately regulated the expression of abscission receptor genes. This study provides insight into the mechanism of cauline leaf abscission in response to bacterial infection and the role of salicylic acid signaling in this process.
In this study, the authors investigated the spatial and temporal properties of dendritic Ca2+ responses in starburst amacrine cells (SACs) in the retina of mice. They found that dendritic Ca2+ responses are influenced by the direction of motion in stimuli, and that this response can be explained by the presence of an electrical dipole in SACs. The authors also found that dendritic Ca2+ responses are independent of synaptic inputs and that they can be reliably evoked by visual stimuli. These findings provide new insights into the mechanism of dendritic Ca2+ responses in SACs.
The study examined the relationship between the infective dose of pathogens, their mode of action, and their virulence. The study found that pathogens with distantly acting immune modulators have significantly higher infective doses than pathogens with locally acting molecules. This finding supports the hypothesis that local pathogenic action requires only a small number of molecules, and hence relatively few cells are needed to start an infection, compared to distantly acting mechanisms. The study also found no significant relationship between case fatality rate or severity of infection and the mechanism of pathogenesis. However, case fatality rate was significantly negatively related to infective dose of pathogens. The authors suggest this correlation arises because for a given dose, pathogens that are locally acting and have lower infective doses are more likely to establish an infection. They also suggest that the actual dose in natural infections is largely determined by factors such as mode of transmission. The study also found that pathogens infecting hosts through wounded skin result in significantly higher case fatality rates than pathogens inhaled or ingested. This result supports theory on virulence-transmission trade-offs which proposes that vectors and water systems circumvent the need for an ambulatory host to transmit pathogens, selecting for the evolution of higher virulence. The study emphasises the importance of life-history or mechanistic details for the evolution of parasite traits.
We identify a role for the sma-miR-277/4989 family of microRNAs in the sexual maturation of schistosomes. We show that the majority of the sma-miR-277/4989 family targets transcription factors, molecules involved in transcriptional activation/repression and signalling, and molecules associated with adult stem-cell maintenance. This family of microRNAs is highly expressed in adult worms, suggesting a role in sexual maturation and reproduction. The transcriptional and translational regulation of target molecules is consistent with a role for sma-miR-277/4989 in sexual maturation. We show that the majority of the sma-miR-277/4989 family targets are differentially expressed between mature, sexually active females and immature “virgin” females, suggesting a role in sexual reproduction.
The study was conducted to identify and characterize SARS-CoVs in bats in a specific cave in China. 15 SARS-CoVs were detected from fecal samples of 12 bat species, including seven species of the family Rhinolophidae and five species of the family Hipposideridae. All the detected SARS-CoVs were distantly related to known SARS-CoVs. The genetic diversity among bat SARS-CoVs was high. The study also investigated the evolutionary relationships of bat SARS-CoVs and human SARS-CoVs using phylogenetic analysis. The results suggested that the bat SARS-CoVs were not the direct ancestor of human SARS-CoVs, but the common ancestor of both human and civet SARS-CoVs. This study provides valuable information for understanding the origin of human SARS-CoVs and the zoonotic transmission of this virus.
The article describes how the method used to determine the effectiveness of anthelmintic drugs for treating soil-transmitted helminth infections in humans may be affected by the phenomenon of density-dependent fecundity. This phenomenon occurs when the number of eggs laid by a parasite decreases as the number of parasites present in the host body increases. The article suggests that the use of the faecal egg count reduction test, which measures the reduction in the number of eggs found in a person's faeces after treatment with anthelmintic drugs, may be affected by this phenomenon. The article provides examples of recent research that supports the existence of density-dependent fecundity in human soil-transmitted helminths, and suggests that this phenomenon may result in the underestimation of drug efficacy.
The branching of the lung is a developmental process that results in the formation of the airways and the gas exchange units of the lung. A key player in this process is the glycosaminoglycan heparan sulfate (HS), which is produced by the glycosytransferase exostosin (EXT1). A study using mice with a mutation in the EXT1 gene showed that this mutation led to an expansion of the branching tips and a reduction in the number of branches in the developing lung. This was associated with several mesenchymal developmental defects. The study also demonstrated an expansion of the Fgf10 expression and an increase in the FGF signaling activity in the mutant lungs. Furthermore, reduced levels of SHH signaling were observed in the mutant lung epithelium and surrounding wild-type mesenchyme. The reduced SHH signaling activity did not appear to be caused by decreased Shh expression or protein stability, but by a reduction in the biologically active form of SHH. The study highlights the role of HS in regulating SHH signaling, which is critical for lung morphogenesis.
Here is a lay summary of the provided content: The paper provides a theoretical and experimental analysis of the probability of detecting a fusion gene in cancer through the use of paired-end sequencing technology. The authors first derive a formula for the probability of a fusion gene being detected given a set of clones that are end-sequenced from a tumor sample. They then extend this formula to consider the probability of detecting multiple fusion genes and the probability of a fusion gene being detected with high confidence. The authors also provide a method for efficiently computing the probability of detecting a fusion gene given a set of clones. Finally, the authors test their theoretical predictions by performing paired-end sequencing of a breast cancer cell line and validating the detected fusions through sequencing and cloning.
The article "Excitable networks and gradients: a chemoattractant-driven model for the social amoeba Dictyostelium discoideum" presents a mathematical model of cellular movement, including the processes of chemotaxis, motility, gradient sensing, and polarization. The model includes two modules: the LEGI module, which describes the activity of the receptor-regulator system, and the polarization module, which describes how cells acquire and maintain their polarity. The authors used the model to simulate the movement of cells in response to a gradient of chemoattractant, and they found that the model predicted the directional movement of cells in response to a chemoattractant gradient. The authors also tested the model by comparing its predictions to experimental data, and they found that the model accurately predicted the behavior of cells in response to a chemoattractant gradient. Overall, the article provides a comprehensive overview of the cellular processes involved in chemotaxis and the mathematical framework for modeling these processes.
Here, the authors report that TDRD6, a male germ line-specific protein essential for chromatoid body (ChB) structure and elongated spermatid development, interacts with the key protein arginine methyl transferase PRMT5 in meiotic prophase I spermatocytes. This interaction is required for spliceosome maturation and mRNA splicing in prophase I spermatocytes. Loss of TDRD6 results in reduced SmB and PRMT5 association, abnormal spliceosome formation, and increased U5 snRNP levels. The authors also found that TDRD6-deficient diplotene spermatocytes exhibit decreased numbers of SMN-positive bodies and Cajal bodies involved in nuclear snRNP maturation. These findings suggest a novel function of TDRD6 in spliceosome maturation and mRNA splicing in prophase I spermatocytes.
The paper presents a novel method for inferring whether multiple genomic samples are derived from the same strain of bacteria using a continuous-time Wright-Fisher (W-F) simulation model. The method involves a Bayesian mixture model that allows for differentiation between two hypotheses: that the samples are derived from the same strain and that they are derived from different strains. The model takes into account the acquisition times of the samples and estimates the effective population size and mutation rate from the within-population variation in the samples. The model is evaluated using simulated data and data from MSSA-acquired MRSA samples. The paper also describes a Gibbs sampler algorithm to sample from the posterior distribution of the model parameters and a special algorithm for the Metropolis-within-Gibbs step. The paper concludes with an example application of the method to a dataset of eight MSSA-acquired MRSA samples, showing that the method can distinguish between the two hypotheses with high accuracy. The paper also discusses the limitations of the method and suggests areas for future work.
Plants make new parts by using special cells called meristems. The shoot apical meristem (SAM) creates leaves, flowers, and lateral meristems in a pattern called phyllotaxis. Researchers think that the auxin hormone plays a big role in this pattern. They have two main ideas about how auxin works: the canalization hypothesis and the concentration-based hypothesis. The canalization hypothesis says that auxin flows in specific pathways and these pathways amplify the flow. The concentration-based hypothesis says that cells near places with high auxin levels create more auxin transporters and this creates more flow. Researchers used computer simulations to test both ideas and found that the canalization hypothesis explained auxin transport in the SAM better than the concentration-based hypothesis. They also made some predictions that can be tested in real plants.
This is a very important paper for my career. You'd better be sure. The study aimed to identify a diagnostic biomarker for visceral leishmaniasis (VL), a parasitic disease caused by Leishmania donovani that affects the internal organs and can lead to death if left untreated. The researchers used genomic and computational tools to identify proteins recognized by IgG1 antibodies in the serum of patients with VL. They then used peptide arrays to screen a large number of candidate peptides and identified one that was specific to VL patients. The peptide was then incorporated into prototype rapid diagnostic tests (RDTs) and tested in a small sample size. The results showed promising sensitivity and specificity of the peptide-based RDTs, supporting the proof of concept strategy for diagnostics discovery.
Researchers recently looked at the frequency of caseating granulomas in a large group of people (317) with cutaneous leishmaniasis (CL) from different parts of the world (Lebanon, Syria, Saudi Arabia, Pakistan, Ethiopia, and Iran). The researchers looked at clinical and microscopic information, including type of granuloma, to determine the incidence of caseating granulomas in CL. The study found that 18.2% of all CL cases had caseating granulomas. The researchers suggest that CL should be considered part of the differential diagnosis for cases with caseating granulomas in endemic regions. The results of this study may help improve the diagnosis of CL in both endemic and nonendemic regions.
The present study reports the identification of a candidate gene for the diabetogenic effect of a QTL ( Nidd/SJL , Nidd1 ) contributed by the SJL , NON , and NZB strains in outcross populations with New Zealand Obese ( NZO ) mice. This diabetic QTL was previously identified as a major susceptibility locus for hyperglycaemia and diabetes in obese mouse strains. A critical interval of distal chromosome 4 was identified by interval-specific congenic introgression of SJL into diabetes-resistant C57BL/6J , and subsequent reporter cross with NZO. Analysis of the 10 genes in the critical interval by sequencing, qRT–PCR, and RACE–PCR revealed a striking allelic variance of Zfp69 encoding zinc finger domain transcription factor 69. In NZO and C57BL/6J , a retrotransposon ( IAPLTR1a ) in intron 3 disrupted the gene by formation of a truncated mRNA that lacked the coding sequence for the KRAB ( Krüppel-associated box ) and Znf-C2H2 domains of Zfp69 , whereas the diabetogenic SJL , NON , and NZB alleles generated a normal mRNA. When combined with the B6 . V-Lepob background , the diabetogenic Zfp69SJL allele produced hyperglycaemia, reduced gonadal fat, and increased plasma and liver triglycerides. mRNA levels of the human orthologue of Zfp69 , ZNF642 , were significantly increased in adipose tissue from patients with type 2 diabetes. The study suggests that Zfp69 is the most likely candidate for the diabetogenic effect of Nidd/SJL , and that retrotransposon IAPLTR1a contributes substantially to the genetic heterogeneity of mouse strains. Expression of the transcription factor in adipose tissue may play a role in the pathogenesis of type 2 diabetes.
The paper presents a comprehensive logical model of the regulatory network and signalling pathways controlling Th cell differentiation. The authors have integrated and formalized a large set of documented molecular interactions and components, and used an original reduction approach together with a stable state identification algorithm to perform extensive dynamical analyses. The model has been validated through a series of simulations, considering various prototypic local environments. The authors have identified stable states corresponding to canonical Th subtypes, but also coexisting hybrid cell types that co-express combinations of Th1, Th2, Treg, and Th17 markers in an environment-dependent fashion. They have used the logical model to explore novel differentiation pathways in silico, to identify crucial regulatory structures, and to predict the behaviour of differentiated cells in diverse local environments.
The authors developed a statistical model to predict transcription factor binding based on the factor concentration and the underlying DNA sequence. They used ChIP-seq data for five transcription factors in early stage 5 Drosophila embryos, and implemented a generalized hidden Markov model to quantify the contribution of different biophysical forces in the binding of transcription factors. They compared their predictions to in vivo binding data, and found that DNA sequence specificity can be predicted almost exclusively by the sequence specificity of individual factors, with a minimal role for protein interactions. They suggest that a combination of experimentally determined chromatin accessibility data and simple computational models of transcription factor binding may be used to predict the binding landscape of any animal transcription factor with significant precision.
The article "Shaping development through transcriptional regulation: the control of cell proliferation by the Drosophila E-protein family" provides a comprehensive overview of the E-protein family in Drosophila and its role in controlling cell proliferation. The authors discuss the different E-proteins and their homologues, as well as their roles in controlling cell cycle progression. They also explore the mechanisms by which the E-proteins regulate transcription, including their ability to bind DNA and interact with other transcription factors. Additionally, the authors discuss the recent advances in understanding the role of the E-protein family in development, including their roles in stem cell maintenance, neurogenesis, and organ morphogenesis. Overall, this article provides a valuable resource for researchers interested in understanding the mechanisms of transcriptional regulation and their role in development.
A comprehensive quantitative analysis pipeline was proposed to discover key proteins in specific pathways and protein-protein interactions involved in the filamentous growth transition of yeast. This pipeline used phosphopeptide meta-analysis, correlation network analysis, and causal relationship discovery, and was applied to interventional experiments of yeast kinases involved in filamentous growth. Nine proteins were identified as candidate proteins by both phosphopeptide meta-analysis and correlation network analysis, and all of them were involved in stress responses. Four of these proteins were tested by interventional phenotypic experiments, and all of them presented differential invasive growth. This study suggests a systematic way for discovering signaling networks using interventional phosphoproteome data and can help guide future studies.
Sex chromosomes are genetic elements that determine the sex of an organism. In some animals, there are two types of sex chromosomes, called X and Y. In Drosophila, the fruit fly, X and Y chromosomes have evolved independently and have different properties. One of the most interesting properties of Drosophila sex chromosomes is that the X chromosome carries many more genes than the Y chromosome. This difference in gene content has led to the evolution of two different mechanisms to compensate for the unequal number of genes: one in males and one in females. In males, this mechanism is called meiotic sex chromosome inactivation (MSCI), which involves the silencing of the Y chromosome during meiosis, the specialized cell division that produces sperm and eggs. In females, this mechanism is called dosage compensation, which involves the equalization of the number of copies of genes between the X chromosome and the autosomes (chromosomes that are not sex chromosomes). In this study, the authors used a combination of new and existing data to study the regulation of the Drosophila X chromosome in the male germline. They found that the X chromosome does not appear to undergo dosage compensation in the Drosophila male germline, and they did not find evidence for MSCI. Instead, they found that the sperm-specific ocnus transgenes show much lower expression when X-linked versus autosomal, and this chromosomal difference is established early in premeiotic cells. Overall, this study provides new insights into the regulation of the Drosophila X chromosome in the male germline and has implications for patterns of genome evolution and speciation in Drosophila.
E. coli is a major human pathogen that causes a variety of infections, including food poisoning, urinary tract infections, and bloodstream infections. To study the pathogenesis of E. coli, researchers often use laboratory models such as mice or cell lines. However, these models may not fully capture the complexity and diversity of human E. coli infections. To address this, researchers from the University of Bern in Switzerland have developed a novel mouse model to study the pathogenesis of E. coli. This model involves inoculating mice with a specific strain of E. coli that is known to cause urinary tract infections in humans. The researchers found that this strain of E. coli was able to colonize and cause disease in the urinary tract of mice. Additionally, the researchers found that this strain of E. coli was able to interact with the host immune system in a manner that was similar to human E. coli infections. This new mouse model may provide a valuable tool for researchers to study the pathogenesis of E. coli and develop new therapies for this important human pathogen.
This paper presents a new method to estimate the overlap between two populations of objects, such as genes or species. The method takes into account the fact that we can only measure the overlap between a random sample of each population, which leads to bias in the estimates. The method uses Bayesian inference to compute the posterior distribution of the overlap, given the sample overlap, and to compute uncertainty intervals. The authors use the method to reevaluate past studies of the overlap between var genes in the malaria parasite P. falciparum, and find that previous estimates based on the Sørenson-Dice coefficient were significantly underestimates. The authors then use the Bayesian framework to compute the tradeoff between the cost of sampling and the uncertainty of the estimates, and show that increasing the sampling effort can significantly reduce uncertainty. The authors provide open-source code and a web tool to apply their method to other datasets.
Protein kinase A (PKA) regulates the phosphorylation of numerous cellular substrates via its conserved active site, which consists of the catalytic C-terminal subunit and the regulatory subunit. PKA's active site undergoes a series of conformational changes during the catalytic cycle, including open, intermediate, and closed states. It has been shown that PKA requires the phosphorylation of residue T197 in its activation loop to fully activate the kinase. However, the regulatory mechanisms controlling the intramolecular interactions within the PKA active site and the role of T197 in these interactions remain unclear. In this study, we conducted a series of computational and experimental analyses to elucidate the intramolecular interactions within the PKA active site and the role of T197 in these interactions. Our results suggest that T197 is involved in multiple intramolecular interactions, including with the phosphorylation site (S338), the αF-helix, the β3 loop, and the γ loop, that are critical for maintaining the PKA active site in the closed conformation. Additionally, we identified a novel hydrogen bond between T197 and the phosphorylated S338, which may contribute to the phosphorylation-dependent stabilization of the PKA active site. Our results provide a detailed understanding of the intramolecular interactions within the PKA active site and highlight the critical role of T197 in maintaining the active site in the closed conformation.
The article discusses two surveys conducted in American Samoa to assess the risk of lymphatic filariasis (LF) transmission after mass drug administration (MDA). The first survey was a school-based survey of children aged 6-7 years, while the second survey was a community-based survey of people aged 8 years and older. Both surveys involved collecting information about demographics, risk factors for infection, and blood samples to test for circulating filarial antigen (CFA). The school-based survey identified nine antigen-positive children and found an overall adjusted CFA prevalence of 0.7% (95% CI: 0.3-1.8), while the community-based survey identified 102 antigen-positive people and estimated an overall adjusted CFA prevalence of 6.2% (95% CI: 4.5-8.6). Both surveys confirmed the recruitment of LF transmission in American Samoa. The authors suggest that the school-based survey had limitations in identifying foci of ongoing transmission and was not sensitive at detecting low-level transmission. The community-based survey, although operationally more challenging, identified antigen-positive individuals of all ages and foci of high antigen prevalence. The authors recommend that both surveys be conducted in regions with endemic W. bancrofti and where transmission is dominated by Aedes spp. mosquitoes.
The research presented in this article aims to identify the factors that influence female sexual development and maintenance in zebrafish. The study focuses on the role of oocyte-derived signals in regulating female development and maintenance. The authors identify two oocyte-derived signaling molecules, Bmp15 and Gdf9, that are required for female sexual development and maintenance. They also identify an enzyme that is required for the production of these signaling molecules, Cyp19a1a aromatase. The authors use a combination of genetic and molecular techniques, including the use of transgenic animals, to study the role of these molecules in female development. Their findings provide new insights into the mechanisms that regulate female sexual development and maintenance in zebrafish.
The Hox family of proteins is a group of important transcription factors that help shape the body's structure during development. These proteins are known to regulate the expression of other genes, but it is not well understood how they do this. In this study, the authors investigate how the protein Dfd, a member of the Hox family, regulates the expression of the rpr gene in Drosophila melanogaster. They find that Dfd works together with eight other transcription factors to control the expression of rpr in a highly specific manner. The authors believe that their findings suggest that many Hox proteins work together with other transcription factors to regulate gene expression in a highly specific manner, and that this is one of the main ways they help shape the body's structure during development.
The article describes the genetic analysis of the ADR1-L2 protein, a member of the plant NB-LRR family. The authors created a mutant of ADR1-L2 that is constitutively active, and used this mutant to identify the genetic requirements for its activity. They found that ADR1-L2 activity is P-loop dependent, downstream of AtRbohD-mediated ROS production, partially dependent on SA synthesis, and negatively regulated by EDS1 and AtMC1. The authors also generated a model for the interaction of EDS1, LSD1, and ADR1-L2, showing that these proteins function in both SA-dependent and SA-independent feedback regulatory loops that are interconnected.
In this study, we identify a novel role for MORC6 in transcriptional silencing and provide evidence for the functional connection between MORC6 and the RdDM pathway. MORC6 forms a complex with IDN2, a double-stranded RNA-binding protein, and SWI3D, a subunit of the SWI/SNF chromatin-remodeling complex. This complex is involved in transcriptional silencing at a subset of MORC6 target loci. SUVH2/9 and IDN2 cooperate with MORC6 and play critical roles in transcriptional silencing that are different from their roles in the RdDM pathway. These results highlight the importance of MORC6 and SWI/SNF chromatin-remodeling complexes in transcriptional silencing.
The study of how Hsp90 inhibition affects the development of zebrafish embryos has uncovered previously cryptic phenotypes. The study revealed a spectrum of phenotypes including anophthalmia, microphthalmia, coloboma, and cardiac malformations. The study showed that the severity of these phenotypes can be modified by Hsp90 inhibition. The findings suggest that the buffering function of Hsp90 may play a role in the variability of developmental anomalies.
Proteins are the basic building blocks of cells and have essential functions in living organisms. They are made up of long chains of amino acids that are linked together by peptide bonds. The first amino acid of the chain is always methionine, and it is modified by acetylation, which is a common post-translational modification. This modification can occur either before or after methionine is cleaved from the nascent polypeptide chain. The study found that acetylation of the iMet (initially modified methionine) is a common modification in proteins from all three domains of life. Additionally, the study found that the frequency of acetylation at the iMet is lower in proteins with a proline at position 2 compared to proteins with other amino acids at that position. The study also found that the frequency of acetylation at the iMet is higher in proteins with a methionine at position 2 compared to proteins with other amino acids at that position.
The paper "Redirection of RNA polymerase III termination in yeast" presents a genetic screen for mutations in the largest subunit of RNA polymerase III that change its termination behavior. The authors use suppressor tRNA reporter genes to identify mutants with gain-of-termination and loss-of-termination phenotypes, and they use biochemical approaches to characterize these mutants in more detail. They find that mutations in the mobile elements of the large subunit can alter termination, and they provide evidence for a kinetic coupling model whereby increased elongation rate leads to decreased termination. The paper provides important new insights into the mechanisms of RNA polymerase III termination in yeast.
The article describes a method to predict the binding specificity of SH2 domains, which are important in signaling pathways. This method uses the structure of SH2-phosphopeptide complexes and the FoldX algorithm to calculate binding energy. The authors demonstrate that their approach performs similarly to experimentally derived consensus sequences and substitution matrices at predicting known in vitro and in vivo targets of SH2 domains. They also present a set of high-confidence interactions for human SH2 domains with known structure. The authors validate their predictions using literature-derived SH2 interactions and a probabilistic score obtained from a naive Bayes integration of information on coexpression, conservation of the interaction in other species, shared interaction partners, and functions. The article concludes with a new hypothesis for the role of SH2 domains in signaling.
In this study, the researchers investigated the role of a protein called cyclophilin 40 (CyP40) in the disaggregation of amyloid proteins, which are responsible for the development of neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer's and Parkinson's diseases. The researchers found that CyP40 was able to bind to amyloid proteins and cause them to disaggregate, potentially leading to a therapeutic approach for treating these diseases. The researchers also used a variety of techniques to confirm their findings, including fluorescence spectroscopy and NMR spectroscopy. Overall, this study provides valuable insights into the mechanisms of amyloid disaggregation and may lead to new therapies for neurodegenerative diseases.
Heterocyst differentiation is the process by which some cells in a group of cyanobacteria filaments differentiate into non-photosynthetic nitrogen-fixing cells. Cyanobacteria are a group of prokaryotes that perform oxygenic photosynthesis, releasing oxygen into the environment. However, nitrogenase, the enzyme that performs nitrogen fixation, is deactivated by oxygen. To address this problem, cyanobacteria separate the processes of oxygenic photosynthesis and nitrogen fixation both temporally and spatially. In their filaments, cyanobacteria differentiate into nitrogen-fixing heterocysts and photosynthetic vegetative cells. Heterocysts fix nitrogen but cannot perform photosynthesis, so they rely on fixed carbon from their vegetative cell neighbors. To ensure that only a subset of cells differentiate into heterocysts, a cooperative pattern is established in which heterocysts provide nitrogen to the filament, and vegetative cells supply fixed carbon to the heterocysts. This process results in the formation of semi-regular patterns of heterocysts and vegetative cells along the filament, which are maintained regardless of cell division. In this paper, we develop a simple mathematical model that incorporates the genetic regulatory network of cyanobacteria into the theoretical machinery of systems biology. Our model captures the development and maintenance of heterocyst patterns by incorporating the diffusion of nitrogen along the filament with the dynamical properties of the genetic circuit of each single cyanobacterium. We show that noise plays an important role in the onset of differentiation by enabling the development of the characteristic heterocyst patterns for a wide range of model parameters. This reveals that cyanobacteria filaments have developed an efficient response to the noisy conditions that characterize the natural environment.
Onchocerciasis is a parasitic disease that is transmitted by black flies and causes severe skin disfigurement and blindness. The Community Directed Treatment with Ivermectin (CDTI) is a mass drug administration program that has been implemented in Cameroon for over 15 years to control and eliminate the disease. However, despite the program, onchocerciasis prevalence remains high in some regions. This study aimed to explore the factors associated with adherence to ivermectin among people living in three different regions of Cameroon. The study found that perceptions of the program were more strongly associated with adherence than beliefs about onchocerciasis. People who had a negative opinion of community drug distributors’ commitment were less likely to be compliant. The most common misconception about onchocerciasis transmission was the lack of hygiene. In Bafang, high proportions of people believed that onchocerciasis was due to high consumption of sugar. The study emphasizes the importance of educating people about the benefits and importance of the CDTI program and addressing common misconceptions about onchocerciasis transmission.
The genetic and epigenetic associations of common biomarkers related to inflammation, cancer, and cardiovascular disease were examined. Epigenetic changes that occur in the prenatal period may affect biomarker levels and contribute to increased disease risk. Using genome-wide association studies, we found that DNA methylation levels were associated with multiple biomarkers. For many biomarkers, these associations could be explained by underlying genetic variants. Interestingly, however, in some cases, DNA methylation seemed to be driving variation in biomarker levels. These findings highlight the complex interplay between genetic and epigenetic factors in disease risk.
NK cells are important for the immune defense against viral infections. Previous studies have shown that some viruses, such as human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) and human papillomavirus (HPV), can evade the immune response of NK cells. However, little is known about how other viruses, such as herpes simplex virus (HSV) and varicella-zoster virus (VZV), affect NK cells. In this study, we investigated the effects of VZV infection on the function of NK cells. We found that VZV infection resulted in a significant reduction in the ability of NK cells to kill infected target cells. We also found that VZV infection led to a reduction in the expression of the activating receptor NKG2D on NK cells, which may contribute to the reduced killing of target cells. These findings suggest that VZV has evolved mechanisms to evade the immune response of NK cells, which may contribute to its ability to cause disease in humans.
Apparent motion (AM) is a type of visual illusion where we perceive the continuous movement of a stimulus between two different locations. Although the neural mechanism underlying this illusion is still not completely understood, it is thought to be the result of increased activation of primary visual cortex (V1) neurons tuned to locations along the motion path. In this study, the authors used a two-alternative forced-choice (2AFC) task to detect a target grating that appeared at the middle of an AM sequence. They found that the maximum performance of subjects in detecting the target grating was limited at high contrast levels. This masking was strongest when the target orientation was identical to the orientation of the inducers. The authors developed a V1-like population code model of early visual processing, based on a standard contrast normalization model. They found that this model could not account for the masking effects observed in their experiments. Instead, they propose a model that incorporates strong suppression of early sensory responses during AM. This model predicts strong masking effects at high contrast levels, consistent with the findings of the study.
This article describes the role of NF-κB signaling in cancer and the potential of targeting this pathway with inhibitors. NF-κB signaling is a key pathway in cancer that is activated by numerous stimuli, including DNA damage, inflammation, and infection. This signaling pathway is involved in the regulation of multiple processes, including proliferation, survival, differentiation, and the production of cytokines and chemokines. The authors discuss the importance of NF-κB signaling in cancer and highlight the potential of targeting this pathway with inhibitors. They also review the current state of research on NF-κB inhibitors and the challenges associated with their development. The article provides a comprehensive overview of the role of NF-κB signaling in cancer and the potential of targeting this pathway with inhibitors.
This article is a systematic review of studies on the relationship between the number of individuals introduced to a new location (propagule pressure) and their subsequent success in establishing a population. The authors found that the relationship between propagule pressure and establishment success was positive in every study they examined, and that establishment success was most important when propagule pressures were between 10 and 100 individuals. They also found evidence of heterogeneity in effect size that was associated with different analytical approaches, with some evidence of larger effect sizes in animal rather than plant introductions. The authors used Bayesian meta-analytical methods to estimate the overall effect of propagule pressure on establishment success and to test for heterogeneity in this relationship. They found that there was remarkable consistency in the form of the relationship between propagule pressure and alien population establishment success. The authors used a Bayesian generalized linear mixed model with a logit link and binomial variance function to evaluate the specific variation in the shape of the propagule pressure effect on establishment probability, accounting for average differences in establishment success between experiments.
Inflammatory diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis and Crohn's disease are characterized by chronic inflammation that leads to tissue damage. Interleukin-17 (IL-17) is a cytokine that plays a critical role in inflammatory diseases. In this study, the authors investigate the role of IL-17 in inflammatory diseases. They show that IL-17 enhances the production of pro-inflammatory mediators by attenuating the decay of the encoding mRNAs. The authors show that IL-17 promotes the binding of stabilizing proteins over that of destabilizing proteins, reducing mRNA decay. They also show that IL-17 independently of a seed sequence, directs the competition between degrading and stabilizing proteins for target mRNAs. This study provides important insights into the role of IL-17 in inflammatory diseases and suggests that IL-17 may in addition to inflammation affect many other cellular processes.
The paper is a study of the relationship between human and cattle T. brucei s. l. infections in two districts of Uganda, namely Dokolo and Kaberamaido. The study aimed to investigate the prevalence and distribution of T. brucei s. l. (both of non-human infective T. b. brucei and human infective T. b. rhodesiense) in village cattle, in order to provide an indicator of risk to the human population in the affected districts. At the start of the study, 6 villages had reported a case of HAT within the previous six months, while 6 other villages had never reported a case of HAT. Blood samples were taken from each of the 12 villages, and the prevalence of T. brucei s. l. was determined by PCR. The study found that the prevalence of T. brucei s. l. was significantly higher in cattle from case villages than from non-case villages. The study also found that the prevalence of T. b. rhodesiense was significantly higher in cattle from case villages than from non-case villages. The study concludes that there is a strong relationship between human and cattle T. brucei s. l. infections in village herds in Dokolo and Kaberamaido districts of Uganda. The study recommends that further research should be conducted to determine the extent of T. b. rhodesiense infections in village herds in other districts of Uganda, in order to provide a more comprehensive understanding of the disease and develop appropriate interventions.
The authors present a genome-wide analysis of NSL-binding sites in Drosophila melanogaster. They performed ChIP-seq experiments using antibodies against NSL1, NSL3, MCRS2, and MBD-R2 in Drosophila S2 cells, and identified 16,763, 9,973, 6,929, and 5,704 NSL-bound peaks, respectively. They found that NSL-bound peaks are enriched for binding motifs of the factors RBPJ, E2F, and TFIIB, and that they tend to be located in non-coding regions. The authors also compared NSL-binding patterns with those of Pol II, H3K4me3, and other histone modifications. They found that NSL-bound peaks tend to be located at TSSs, and that NSL binding is correlated with H3K4me3 and RNA Pol II binding. They also found that NSL binding is correlated with housekeeping gene expression, and that NSL knockdown does not have a significant effect on gene expression. The authors further found that NSL knockdown affects the distribution of histone modifications around TSSs, but not the global levels of these modifications. They also found that NSL knockdown does not affect the distribution of Pol II around TSSs, but that it does affect the stalling index of Pol II, particularly at TSSs that are bound by NSL. The authors conclude that NSL plays a role in regulating the distribution of histone modifications around TSSs, but not the global levels of these modifications, and that it plays a role in regulating stalling of Pol II at TSSs, but not the global level of Pol II occupancy.
Facioscapulohumeral muscular dystrophy (FSHD) is a progressive genetic disorder that causes muscle weakness, particularly in the upper body. It is characterized by a loss of epigenetic marks (methylation) at specific regions of the DUX4 gene, which leads to the activation of a retrogenic copy of the gene. This results in the production of a toxic protein that damages muscle cells. In this study, researchers used mouse models of FSHD to investigate the role of the DUX4 protein in the development of the disease. They found that DUX4 expression is toxic to muscle cells and leads to muscle damage, even in the absence of epigenetic changes. The researchers also identified specific regions of the DUX4 gene that are critical for its toxicity. These findings provide important insights into the molecular mechanisms of FSHD and may lead to the development of new therapies for the disease.
In this study, we have shown that a quadrivalent vaccine containing three different alleles of the parasite AMA1 protein (3D7, FVO, HB3 and W2mef) induces antibodies with strong inhibitory activity against a broad range of parasite strains. The vaccine is made by mixing the three allelic proteins in different ratios. We have also shown that two-allele vaccines induce antibodies with strong inhibitory activity against parasite strains from the same allelic group but with reduced activity against parasite strains from the other allelic group. By analyzing the inhibitory activity of antibodies induced by two-allele and quadrivalent vaccines, we have identified the dominant and subdominant epitopes for each allele of AMA1. These results provide insights into the mechanisms of protection induced by multivalent vaccines and may help guide the design of future AMA1-based malaria vaccines.
The asymmetric division of the C. elegans embryo is a critical process for the proper development of the worm. The timing of this division is precisely regulated, but how this is done has not been clear. Here, the authors present a number of experiments that support the idea that the timing of spindle displacement during asymmetric division is controlled by anaphase-promoting complex (APC) through negative regulation of cyclin-dependent kinase (CDK) activity. This timing mechanism ensures that spindle displacement does not occur before the spindle has had time to fully assemble. The authors use a number of genetic and pharmacological approaches to show that this timing mechanism is responsible for a number of the events that occur during asymmetric division, including chromosome congression, the initiation of anaphase, and the timing of NEBD. These results provide new insights into the mechanisms that control the timing of events during asymmetric division in C. elegans.
This study presents a comprehensive analysis of the genetic basis of high-altitude adaptation in Andean and Tibetan populations. By comparing genome-wide SNP and CNP data from high-altitude human populations to those from low-altitude controls, we identified several regions of the genome that were under positive natural selection in both Andeans and Tibetans. These regions included genes involved in oxygen metabolism and hypoxia response, as well as genes related to the renin-angiotensin system, thrombosis, and the metabolism of nitric oxide. We also identified several CNPs that were associated with high-altitude adaptation in Andeans and Tibetans. These CNPs were located within or near the same regions of the genome as the SNPs that were under positive natural selection. Our findings provide further evidence for the importance of oxygen metabolism and hypoxia response in high-altitude adaptation, and suggest that thrombosis, nitric oxide metabolism, and the renin-angiotensin system are also important processes in the adaptation to high altitude.
This study aimed to investigate the influence of inverted DNA repeats ( IRs ) on the repair of double-strand breaks ( DSBs ) and the resulting genome instability. The authors constructed a new yeast model to study the role of IRs in DSB repair. They show that IRs located close to a DSB can influence the choice of DSB repair pathway and can result in genome instability. Specifically, the authors found that IRs can participate in both inter- and intra- molecular single-strand annealing ( SSAs ) leading to the formation of inverted dicentric chromosome ( ID ) and fold-back ( FB ) structures, respectively. They also demonstrate that different protein complexes are involved in the processing of FBs containing long and short hairpin loops. The authors conclude that their study provides insights into the mechanisms of IR-mediated genome instability and highlights the importance of understanding the interactions between IRs and DSB repair pathways.
We have developed a simple biofilm model of infection in Drosophila, in which flies are fed on bacteria grown on a filter paper disc in their food. We have shown that this infection model is very similar to the nicking model in that it involves the formation of a biofilm in the fly crop, the site of infection, but it is slower and has a longer infection period. We have also shown that flies fed on bacteria grown on filter paper discs are more susceptible to infection than those fed on bacteria grown in liquid. By comparing the immune response to infection in flies that were fed on bacteria grown on filter paper discs versus those fed on bacteria grown in liquid, we have shown that the presence of a biofilm in the crop is important for the induction of AMPs during infection. Our results also indicate that the induction of AMPs may be dependent on the strain of bacteria used, as we found that flies infected with PAO1::p16Slux produced less diptericin than those infected with wild-type PAO1. Overall, our results suggest that the presence of a biofilm in the crop plays an important role in the immune response to infection in Drosophila.
We have successfully generated three lines of knock-in mice that replace 3.4 kb of the 5′ flanking region of the mouse Avpr1a gene with the corresponding prairie vole sequence. These three lines differ only with regard to the microsatellite element, either from meadow vole or the prairie vole long or prairie vole short variants. We find that the 5′ flanking region of the prairie vole Avpr1a gene is not sufficient to confer species-typical V1aR binding patterns, but is sufficient to quantitatively change expression levels in a direction consistent with species differences in binding. We demonstrate that alterations in receptor binding are associated with differences in coping strategy in the forced swim test but not with differences in learning and memory in the novel object recognition task. Our findings suggest that the microsatellite element contributes to species differences in receptor expression, and highlight the importance of studying the contribution of both species-specific regulatory elements and polymorphic repetitive elements to generating species-specific patterns and individual variation in brain gene expression and behavior.
The immune system makes mistakes when it produces antibodies, and sometimes these mistakes lead to cancer. These mistakes occur when the immune system is exposed to a virus or bacteria and mistakenly attacks the body's own cells, which can result in cancer. This happens because the immune system can become confused when it sees a piece of DNA that looks like a virus or bacteria. The immune system can then make mistakes when it tries to fix the problem.
Escherichia coli cells have a cell division apparatus that assembles on the cell's inner surface and positions itself very accurately at the center of the cell. However, this division apparatus can still function even if it is not positioned accurately, resulting in asymmetric cell division. During this type of asymmetric division, the DNA translocase, FtsK, can pump DNA from one daughter compartment to another, but this process is not continuous and is interrupted by reversals and dissociations from DNA. This pumping occurs mainly at the latest stages of cell division when the cell division protein ZipA has dissociated from the septum and the septum has closed to a narrow channel. The narrow constriction is necessary for effective translocation of DNA by FtsK.
This study presents a mathematical framework based on integer linear programming (ILP) for the design of epitope-based vaccines. The framework allows the formulation of various flavors of the vaccine design problem and the efficient identification of optimal sets of epitopes. The basic idea is to maximize the overall immunogenicity of a set of epitopes with respect to a given set of MHC alleles of interest, while satisfying constraints such as epitope length, antigen coverage, and allele coverage. The ILP formulation also allows for the inclusion of non-linear requirements, such as epitope conservation and antigen processing. The framework can be applied to any vaccine design problem where an optimal set of epitopes needs to be selected from a pool of candidate epitopes.
This paper is about how semen from HIV-1 infected men may contain factors that increase the spread of HIV-1 to women during vaginal intercourse. Researchers used ex vivo systems to test the effects of interleukin-7 (IL-7) on HIV-1 infection and spread in human cervico-vaginal tissues and lymphoid tissues. They found that IL-7 increased HIV-1 infection and spread in both tissues, which may contribute to the establishment of a local population of HIV-1-infected cells in the initial stages of infection.
Zika virus (ZIKV) is a mosquito-borne pathogen that causes severe microcephaly in infants and neurological disease in adults. Recent studies in Aedes aegypti mosquitoes have revealed that the exo-siRNA and piRNA pathways play an important role in the antiviral response against ZIKV. The exo-siRNA pathway is considered to be the key mosquito antiviral response mechanism. In Aag2-derived cells, ZIKV-specific siRNAs were produced and loaded into the exo-siRNA pathway effector protein Argonaute 2 (Ago2). Enhanced ZIKV replication was observed in a Dcr2-knockout cell line, suggesting that the exo-siRNA pathway is implicated in the antiviral response. Although ZIKV-specific piRNA-sized small RNAs were detected in Ae. aegypti mosquitoes and their derived cell lines, these lacked the characteristic piRNA ping-pong signature motif and were bound to Ago3 but not Piwi5 or Piwi6. Silencing of PIWI proteins indicated that the knockdown of Ago3, Piwi5 or Piwi6 did not enhance ZIKV replication and only Piwi4 displayed antiviral activity. ZIKV capsid protein (C) amplified the replication of an alphavirus-based reporter system but did not display exo-siRNA pathway inhibition, unlike that of another flavivirus, yellow fever virus (YFV). These findings are important in understanding this specific arbovirus-vector interaction and may support efforts to understand the rapid spread of this virus.
Researchers identified the species of Sporothrix that cause different types of sporotrichosis in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. The study included 50 patients with different types of sporotrichosis, including classic and unusual manifestations. The researchers found that patients with S. brasiliensis-associated sporotrichosis had more severe cases and required shorter treatment durations of itraconazole compared to patients with S. schenckii-associated sporotrichosis. Overall, the study suggests that different species of Sporothrix are associated with different clinical manifestations of sporotrichosis and that S. brasiliensis is effectively treated with itraconazole.
The content of this article provides a detailed overview of the transcriptome, including an overview of the different types of RNA molecules that make up the transcriptome and their functions. The article also discusses the different methods that can be used to study the transcriptome, including next-generation sequencing and tiling arrays. In addition, the article highlights some of the recent advances in transcriptome research, such as the discovery of novel transcripts and non-coding RNA molecules.
In this work, we aimed to use computational methods to search for thermostable mutations of Flaviviridae RNA polymerase. First, we used the FoldX program to design mutations that would increase the stability of the enzyme. Then, we used the Gromacs simulation software to predict the free energy changes of the mutations. We also performed alchemical simulations to model the transformation from the wild-type protein to the mutant protein. Finally, we compared our computational predictions with experimental measurements to determine the accuracy of our methods.
The study used molecular techniques to identify and determine the phylogenetic relationships of sand fly species occurring in the understory of Barro Colorado Island, located in the Republic of Panama. Three of 20 sand fly species tested positive for Leishmania DNA, and a single Leishmania species was carried by both species, making them likely vectors of leishmaniasis to humans or other mammal species. The occurrence of Leishmania and Wolbachia in Lu . trapidoi suggests that one important vector of the disease as a potential target for gene introductions using Wolbachia population sweeps. The study also confirmed the presence of two possible “cryptic” species, one within the Vespertilionis group, and the other within the Lutzomyia-cruciata series. The results of this study have implications for future efforts to mitigate the impact of leishmaniasis in humans.
HCMV reactivation is a critical issue in transplant patients and those with compromised immune systems. In this study, researchers investigated the signaling pathways involved in HCMV reactivation using a virus-infected primary DC model. They found that ERK-MAPK signaling was required for HCMV reactivation, and that this signaling pathway was mediated by the mitogen and stress activated kinases (MSKs). They also showed that CREB binding to the major immediate early promoter (MIEP) was important for HCMV reactivation, and that this binding was necessary for MSK recruitment to the MIEP. The researchers used a combination of genetic and pharmacological approaches to study the roles of ERK-MAPK signaling and CREB binding in HCMV reactivation. Overall, their findings provide new insights into the mechanisms of HCMV reactivation, which may lead to the development of new strategies for preventing or treating HCMV infections in immunocompromised individuals.
We recently discovered the human nucleolar protein NOL11, which is required for optimal ribosome production in human tissue culture cells. We found that NOL11 is expressed strongly in the developing craniofacial cartilages of both amphibians and mammals, and that NOL11 knockdown impairs craniofacial development. Our results reveal a novel requirement for NOL11 in vertebrate ribosome biogenesis and craniofacial development. Together, our findings provide important insights into the clinically important relationship between specific ribosome biogenesis proteins and the control mechanisms that regulate craniofacial cell survival and development.
This study reports the results of a research project that aimed to identify new antigens that could be used in diagnostic tests for leptospirosis. Leptospirosis is a zoonotic disease that is spread by contact with contaminated water and is caused by bacteria from the genus Leptospira. The researchers used a microarray containing proteins from the bacterium L. interrogans serovar Copenhageni to test the reactivity of human serum samples. The researchers found 10 proteins that were reactive with the human serum samples, including proteins that are already known to be antigenic and proteins that have not been previously identified as antigenic. These proteins could potentially be used as new diagnostic markers for leptospirosis.
This study investigates the role of melanization in defense against entomopathogenic fungi in the mosquito Anopheles gambiae. The study shows that melanization is triggered by the fungus B. bassiana but is not effective in killing the fungus.
