Overall, their results point to an inherent difference between cancerous and non-cancerous proliferation determinants and suggest that understanding these differences could contribute to the future development of novel cancer-specific anti-proliferative drugs.
Cystic echinococcosis (CE) is a disease caused by a parasite that can infect the heart and the vena cava, but not many cases have been reported. This study is a review of 11 patients who had CE in the heart or the vena cava and were followed up for 15 years. Most of the patients had symptoms such as thoracic pain or dyspnea, and their cysts were located mostly in the right atrium and inferior vena cava. Some patients had been previously diagnosed with CE, and echocardiography was the main diagnostic method. Nine patients underwent cardiac surgery, nine received long-term antiparasitic treatment, and one patient was lost to follow-up. One patient died intra-operatively, two patients died 10 and 14 years after diagnosis due to pulmonary embolism and cardiac failure, respectively. Patients who had cardiac involvement exclusively did not have complications after surgery, while patients with vena cava involvement developed serious complications. The study recommends that CE should be included in the differential diagnosis of cardiovascular diseases in patients from endemic areas.
This study confirms the presence of a TirS-like protein in S . aureus that interferes with the TLR2-induced signaling pathway and enhances bacterial survival within the host. Interestingly, the tirS gene is invariably located within the mobile genetic element SCC476 of MSSA strains. Moreover, our work shows that sub-inhibitory concentrations of fusidic acid induce overexpression of tirS . This suggests that tirS may confer resistance to antibiotics in a subset of MRSA and MSSA strains . Our findings also confirm previous reports of negative regulation of the TLR signaling pathway by TirS expression . Furthermore, we demonstrate that TirS modulates bacterial virulence through attenuation of host inflammatory responses during infection .
We used gene expression datasets for the fruit fly Drosophila melanogaster and the mosquito Anopheles gambiae to search for changes in gene expression that might explain differences in the two species' embryonic morphologies. We found that many orthologous gene pairs could be clustered based on the presence of coincident discordances in their temporal expression profiles. One such cluster contained genes specifically expressed in the mosquito serosa. We also found a striking difference in the temporal expression of a subset of maternal genes. We propose that gene clustering by local temporal discordance can be used to identify the gene batteries underlying morphological diversity.
The study found that DNA from H. ducreyi and T. pallidum subsp. pertenue, two major causes of leg ulcers in children in Africa and the Pacific Region, were present on the skin of asymptomatic children. The study also found that T. pallidum subsp. pertenue and H. ducreyi DNA were present in flies and on household linens. This is the first time that H. ducreyi DNA and colonization has been demonstrated on the skin of asymptomatic children and that H. ducreyi DNA and T. pallidum subsp. pertenue DNA has been identified in flies and on fomites. These findings suggest that the environment plays a role in the spread of the organisms, which could contribute to their persistence in the community and their transmission. This study provides evidence for the need to address environmental factors to control the spread of these organisms.
Bioinformatics is a rapidly growing field that involves the use of computing and mathematics to analyze and interpret biological data. However, there is currently no consensus on what knowledge and skills are necessary for individuals to be successful in this field. The Curriculum Task Force of the International Society of Computational Biology (ISCB) has created a set of core competencies that can be used as a framework for training in bioinformatics. These competencies have been developed through surveys and community engagement, and are designed to be applicable across a wide range of user personas and training programs. The report provides a series of use cases that demonstrate how the competencies can be applied in diverse training contexts, including complete degree programs, supplements to existing degree programs, and training resources outside the context of specific degree programs. These use cases illustrate how the competencies can be used to define, refine, or assess a bioinformatics training mechanism.
A Strongyloides stercoralis transcriptome was generated using RNA sequencing of seven different developmental stages. Transcriptome analysis revealed that S. stercoralis dauer-like development is regulated by conserved signaling pathways and that S. stercoralis may possess an expanded repertoire of TGFβ ligands.
The study evaluated the effects of bacterial genotoxins on nuclear remodeling, including the formation of nucleoplasmic reticulum ( NR ) in vitro and in vivo. The study used mouse models, coculture experiments with CDT- and colibactin-secreting bacteria, and hepatic, intestinal, and gastric cells. The results showed that CDT and colibactin induced NR formation and the concentration of ribosomes, proteins involved in mRNA translation, polyadenylated RNA, and the main components of the complex mCRD involved in mRNA turnover in the NR. The study suggests that the NR would be a privileged gateway for selected mRNA to be preferentially transported therein for local translation. These findings offer new insights into the context of NR formation, a common feature of many cancers.
This study aimed to evaluate facial deformities in people who had leprosy using three-dimensional computed tomography (3D-CT). The authors compared CT images of the maxilla in people who had leprosy (former patients with leprosy) and those who did not have leprosy (control subjects). They found that some people who had leprosy had deformities in the maxilla, which supports the results of paleopathological studies of excavated skeletal remains. The authors also were able to quantify the thickness of the maxillary bone defects using CT images, which could be helpful for reconstructive surgery.
The present study is a review of the impact of background noise on auditory coding in the brain. The review is structured into five main sections: (1) Background noise in the auditory environment, (2) Background noise and adaptation in the auditory periphery, (3) Background noise and adaptation in the midbrain, (4) Background noise and adaptation in the thalamus, and (5) Background noise and adaptation in the cortex. The review provides a comprehensive overview of the current research in this area and highlights important gaps in our understanding of how the brain adapts to background noise. Overall, the review highlights the need for more research to understand how background noise affects the encoding of complex sounds in the brain.
In this study, the authors use protein-protein interaction (PPI) networks to analyze changes in yeast cellular organization under heat shock stress. They find that heat shock results in a significant decrease in both the overlaps and connections of yeast interactome modules, leading to a more fragmented interactome structure. The authors suggest that this change may be a general adaptation response to environmental changes and provide a model of network-level organization under stress.
Chagas disease is a serious health problem in Latin America, and now there is growing concern about its spread to other parts of the world. Amiodarone is a drug that has been used to treat the abnormal heart rhythms that can be caused by Chagas disease. The purpose of this study was to see if amiodarone works in people with Chagas disease. The researchers searched for studies in which amiodarone was given to people with Chagas disease, and they found 9 studies that met their criteria. In 5 of these studies, the researchers could use information from each patient to analyze the results individually, while in the other 4 studies, they had to use group data. The researchers looked at how many people in each group had ventricular tachycardia, ventricular premature beats, or ventricular couplets before and after taking amiodarone. They also looked at how many people in each group had side effects from the drug. The researchers then combined the results from the studies to see if there was a clear effect of amiodarone on these outcomes. They found that amiodarone reduced the number of ventricular tachycardia episodes, ventricular premature beats, and the incidence of ventricular couplets. However, there was no evidence that amiodarone reduced hard endpoints like sudden death or hospitalization. The researchers also found that amiodarone was associated with side effects like corneal microdeposits, gastrointestinal events, sinus bradycardia, dermatological events, and drug discontinuation. Overall, the researchers concluded that amiodarone appears to be effective in reducing ventricular arrhythmias in people with Chagas disease, but more research is needed to determine its long-term safety and efficacy.
The paper is a medical record review study that aimed to determine the seasonality of dengue fever in rural Ecuador. The study found that dengue fever diagnoses followed a single annual peak in case counts during mid-March, and were more likely to be diagnosed on Tuesdays and Thursdays than on Saturdays or Sundays. Public holidays, such as the day after Christmas, were associated with an increase in dengue diagnoses. The study also found that school schedules did not impact dengue diagnoses in school-aged children. Finally, the study found that the effect of climate on the seasonality of dengue fever diagnoses is complex and multifactorial.
The paper "Amplification of a Constitutively Active Innate Immune State by Expression of a Stable Form of Picornavirus RdRP" describes the authors' findings that expression of a form of the picornavirus RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (RdRP) that is constitutively active can induce a powerful, sustained antiviral immune response. This response is characterized by upregulation of hundreds of interferon-stimulated genes (ISGs) and is independent of the presence of viral RNA. The authors also show that this response is mediated by the retinoic acid-inducible gene I (RIG-I) pathway, and that it is not associated with autoimmune disease or chronic inflammation. These findings suggest that manipulation of the RdRP-RIG-I pathway may be a promising approach for the development of novel antiviral therapies.
In this study, the infection dynamics of two closely related plant viruses, Tomato yellow leaf curl virus (TYLCV) and Tomato yellow leaf curl RNA virus (TYLCV-RNA), were analyzed. The study found that both viruses followed the independent action hypothesis (IAH), which suggests that each virus infects host plants independently, without interfering with the other. The study also found that the genetic diversity of TYLCV-RNA was reduced during horizontal transmission, and that the genetic diversity of viruses in systemically infected plants was lower than in primary infection foci. These findings suggest that the host plant's immune system may be involved in reducing genetic diversity during horizontal transmission. The study also found that the ratio of mixed-genotype infections in plants infected with both viruses was not significantly different from what would be expected under the IAH. This suggests that the two viruses are not antagonistic towards each other, and that they may even be synergistic in some cases. Overall, the study provides important insights into the infection dynamics of plant viruses and the role of the host plant's immune system in shaping these dynamics.
In this study, we propose a new statistical method for identifying genes that are regulated by multiple genetic factors. We applied this method to rat gene expression data in four tissues and identified genes that are regulated in cis or in trans. We also compared our method to two other methods and found that our method had higher power to detect shared genetic regulation of gene expression across tissues. These findings highlight the importance of jointly analyzing gene expression across tissues in order to identify genes that are regulated by multiple genetic factors.
A mathematical model of caspase-dependent apoptosis has been developed based on experimental data. The model includes a range of upstream and downstream reactions and accurately reproduces the behavior of cells perturbed by protein depletion and overexpression. The model identifies the duration of the delay prior to effector caspase activation as a variable-delay, snap-action switch that controls the timing of cell death. The duration of this delay is determined by the activity of initiator caspase-8 and the rates of other reactions lying immediately downstream of the TRAIL receptor. The snap-action switch is regulated by the interplay between Bcl-2 family members, the partitioning of Smac from its binding partner XIAP, and the mechanisms of pore assembly. The model has been used to identify a role for C8 and its substrates in pre-MOMP delay and to explore how competition among pro- and anti-apoptotic Bcl-2 family members determines when MOMP occurs. Multiple alternative topologies for reactions involving Bcl-2-like proteins were examined and a subtle interplay between protein compartmentalization, translocation, and multimerization was uncovered in the regulation of snap-action switching.
In this study, we used yeast two-hybrid screening to identify a novel host protein that interacts with the bacterial invasin Listeria monocytogenes internalin (Inl) protein. We found that the host protein, a previously unknown protein called afadin, binds to Inl through its LRR5 domain. This interaction occurs in the cytoplasm of the host cell and may contribute to the ability of L. monocytogenes to invade host cells. We also found that afadin is expressed in the human placenta, and that it may be involved in the ability of L. monocytogenes to invade the placenta and cause infection.
The proteome of the T . pallidum spirochete is the most abundant and diverse group of proteins in the human body. In this study, we present the first mass spectrometry-based proteomics characterization of T . pallidum. We present a comprehensive description of the proteome of T . pallidum, including information about protein abundance, subcellular localization, and functional annotation. Our results provide insights into the fundamental biology of this organism and may help guide the development of new therapeutic approaches.
Protein Kinase A ( PKA ) is a protein that plays a key role in cell signaling. It is regulated by the binding of cyclic adenosine monophosphate ( cAMP ) and the subunits of PKA. A recent study has investigated the effects of the two-domain construct RIα on the activity of PKA. The study used nuclear magnetic resonance ( NMR ) to investigate the changes in the structure of RIα in its apo, cAMP2, and C-bound forms. The findings of the study suggest that CBD-B in RIα plays a critical role in the inhibition and activation of PKA. The study also showed that CBD-A is important for the activation of PKA and that inter-domain dynamics affect the binding of cAMP to CBD-A.
In this article, the authors describe a proteomic analysis of mouse bone marrow-derived macrophages (BMDM) infected with vaccinia virus. They compared the proteomes of ISG15-deficient and ISG15-sufficient BMDM infected with vaccinia virus and identified a number of differentially expressed proteins. They also investigated the role of ISG15 in regulating the mitochondrial metabolism and found that ISG15 deficiency decreased the activity of complex I and II of the electron transport chain and the activity of citrate synthase. Additionally, they found that ISG15 deficiency increased the levels of reactive oxygen species and the activity of arginase, which is an enzyme involved in the urea cycle. These findings suggest that ISG15 plays an important role in regulating the mitochondrial metabolism and the production of reactive oxygen species in BMDM infected with vaccinia virus.
The proteasome is a powerful machine that breaks down unwanted or damaged proteins to their component parts. Proteins are marked for degradation by being "ubiquitinated" with small molecules called ubiquitin. The proteasome reads the "ubiquitin code" and breaks down the marked proteins. Viruses have found ways to manipulate the proteasome for their own needs. The human immunodeficiency virus 1 (HIV-1) protein called Vpu helps the virus infect new cells by hijacking the proteasome. Vpu is a small, membrane-bound protein that is important for HIV-1 to infect human cells. It helps the virus to escape from the immune system of the host, allowing it to replicate and spread throughout the body. It also helps the virus to release its infectious particles more efficiently. Vpu can do this because it binds to a protein called βTrCP, which is part of the proteasome. By binding to βTrCP, Vpu is able to direct it to degrade other proteins that are important for the immune system. This helps the virus to survive and continue to replicate in the host. The ability of Vpu to degrade these proteins makes it an important part of the HIV-1 virus. It helps the virus to infect new cells and spread throughout the body. Without Vpu, the HIV-1 virus would have a harder time infecting new cells and spreading throughout the body.
Developmental processes must be coordinated so that they generate correct tissues. Tissues develop from cells that, through a process called patterning, acquire specific identities. These identities result from the coordinated expression of patterning genes. We have proposed two hypotheses on how tissue patterning is coordinated with whole-body development, either by tight coordination or by alignment at developmental milestones. To distinguish between these hypotheses, we have developed a staging scheme for wing imaginal discs of third instar Drosophila larvae based on the expression of canonical patterning genes. We have used this scheme to explore how the progression of pattern changes when developmental time is altered either by changing temperature or by altering the timing of hormone synthesis that drives developmental progression. We found that the progression of pattern is tightly coordinated with moulting and pupariation, representing developmental milestones, but shows greater variability between these milestones. Our data showed that discs from wandering larvae showed greater variability in patterning stage. Thus for wing disc patterning, wandering does not appear to be a developmental milestone. Our findings reveal that tissue patterning remains robust against environmental and physiological perturbations by aligning at developmental milestones. Furthermore, our work provides an important glimpse into how the development of individual tissues is coordinated with the body as a whole.
The ESCRT complex is a key regulator of endosome-mediated transport in fungal hyphae. Loss of the ESCRT regulator Did2 results in defective vacuolar targeting, less processive long-distance transport and abnormal shuttling of early endosomes. These defects suggest that Did2 coordinates endosomal maturation and thus provides the correct membrane identity for efficient endosomal long-distance transport. Moreover, the ESCRT regulator Vps60 is required for the efficient attachment of molecular motors to early endosomes. These findings provide important insights into the function of ESCRT complexes in the coordination of endosomal transport.
The B . subtilis add gene encodes a riboswitch that binds adenine and positively regulates the expression of the downstream gene. Two variants of the add riboswitch were generated by site-directed mutagenesis: one variant is unable to bind adenine and the other binds adenine with a lower affinity. The results show that the ability of the riboswitch to bind adenine determines whether it can be transcribed by a T7 RNA polymerase in vitro. The in vivo regulation of the add gene by the add riboswitch was examined by generating single-copy chromosomal insertions of the add'-lacZ and addOFF'-lacZ fusions in E . coli. The results show that the add gene is upregulated in the presence of adenine. The regulation of the add gene by the add riboswitch is a kinetic process that depends on the rate of transcription and on the NusA elongation factor.
We demonstrate that the physiological role of transcription initiation from primers is more widespread than previously thought and is utilized by many species of bacteria. We also show that PDI in E. coli and V. cholerae is growth phase-dependent, and the primers involved in PDI in these species are derived from species-specific dinucleotides.
Here, we report that increased dosage of the maternal genome in Arabidopsis thaliana seeds causes a decrease in expression levels of the maternal imprinted gene MEA and a corresponding increase in expression of the paternal imprinted gene PHE1. This change is accompanied by a loss of imprinting of MEA and PHE1. We suggest that this imprinting deregulation results from changes in the expression of the paternal FIS2 gene, a key component of the Polycomb group complex. These results are unexpected, as we had previously shown that increased paternal dosage causes an increase in expression of MEA and a decrease in expression of PHE1. We propose that parental dosage imbalance in seeds causes a complex series of non-symmetrical responses that disrupt the imprinted gene network, which in turn may contribute to species isolation mechanisms.
This article presents a new method for reconstructing virtual brains using EEG and MEG recordings, and comparing them to real brains. The authors first hypothesize that the dynamics of these brain recordings are caused by underlying functional connectivity between the brain's nodes, rather than by the anatomy or synaptic connections between them. They then use mathematical techniques to reverse-engineer network configurations that generate the same dynamics as the EEG and MEG recordings. They find that the virtual brains they construct share common features with real brains, and are able to replicate various aspects of epileptic and schizophrenic diseases. The authors conclude that the method they present has the potential to provide new insights into the neural basis of diseases, and to serve as a tool for developing new therapies.
The current study is a population genetics analysis of 6,441 unrelated individuals from the Multi-Ethnic Study of Atherosclerosis (MESA) who self-identified as Hispanic and were of Central or South American, Dominican, Mexican, or Puerto Rican ancestry. The purpose of the study was to determine whether different Hispanic ethnic groups have distinct genetic ancestry profiles, and whether they can be distinguished using genome-wide ancestry markers. The study found four distinct subgroups of Hispanics, each with a unique pattern of genetic ancestry, and that these subgroups can be distinguished using a set of 33 single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in the lipoprotein gene region. The study also found that the four subgroups have distinct patterns of genetic ancestry that are associated with different levels of triglyceride, a risk factor for cardiovascular disease. The findings suggest that different Hispanic ethnic groups may have different genetic susceptibilities to cardiovascular disease, and that genetic ancestry information may be useful for identifying individuals at high risk for the disease.
The study found that Elp3, a subunit of the Elongator histone acetyltransferase complex, is required for transcriptional silencing and maintenance of genome stability. Elp3 interacts with proteins involved in DNA replication-coupled nucleosome assembly and with PCNA, a component of the DNA replication machinery. The Elongator complex is required for replication-independent nucleosome assembly and for histone H4K8 acetylation in vivo. Additionally, the study showed that Elp3 interacts with the Hat1 histone acetyltransferase and that the SAM domain of Elp3 is required for its interactions with Elp2 and PCNA. The findings provide insight into the functions of the Elongator complex in maintaining genome stability and support its role in the regulation of chromatin structure.
We propose a machine learning-based method for triage of publications relevant for variant curation in two external knowledge bases: UniProtKB/Swiss-Prot and the GWAS Catalog. We use convolutional neural networks (CNN) as our classification models and trained them using a dataset of publications that have been manually curated as either relevant or not relevant for variant curation. We evaluated our method on a test set of publications and compared its performance to that of the current query-based triage method. Our method outperforms the current query-based method by 1.81 and 2.99 times in precision and recall, respectively, without compromising recall. It also improves the efficiency of the triage process by reducing the number of false positives.
Atrial fibrillation (AF) is a common clinical arrhythmia. Genetic mutations in ion channels can lead to a variety of arrhythmias, including AF. Kir2.1 channels play an important role in stabilizing the resting membrane potential of cardiac myocytes. In this study, we used a computational model of the human atrial action potential to investigate the effects of Kir2.1 mutations on the repolarization of the action potential and the susceptibility of the atria to re-entrant excitation. We found that Kir2.1 mutations could shorten the action potential duration and increase the excitation threshold. We also investigated the effects of Kir2.1 mutations on the wave length of re-entrant excitation, which was decreased in both homozygous and heterozygous Kir2.1 mutations. We found that combined block of IKr and IKur could be an effective strategy for treating AF in Kir2.1 mutations. These findings provide insights into the mechanisms underlying atrial arrhythmias caused by Kir2.1 mutations and may help guide the development of new treatments for these arrhythmias.
Chagas disease is a serious illness caused by a parasite transmitted mainly by insects. It affects around 7 million people worldwide, particularly in Latin America, and is often fatal. In this study, researchers used adipose-derived mesenchymal stem cells (ASC) to treat a mouse model of chagas disease and showed that these cells can significantly reduce heart inflammation and parasite burden. The researchers also analyzed the effects of ASC on the immune system and found that they help to modulate the inflammatory response. Overall, this study highlights the potential of ASC to treat chagas disease.
Leishmaniasis is a parasitic disease that affects millions of people worldwide. It is caused by parasites from the genus Leishmania that live inside mammalian cells in a specialized organelle called the parasitophorous vacuole (LPV). Retro-2cycl is a small molecule that disrupts the retrograde transport machinery in mammalian cells, leading to reduced LPV development and parasite numbers in infected macrophages. DHQZ 36 and DHQZ 36 . 1 are optimized analogs of Retro-2cycl that are even more potent at limiting parasite growth in infected macrophages. These compounds also caused a reversal of Leishmania-induced suppression of IL-6 release by infected cells after LPS activation. Importantly, these analogs are Leishmania-cidal, meaning they kill the parasites directly. These findings suggest that Retro-2cycl and its analogs could be useful drugs for the treatment of leishmaniasis.
We developed a new method of predicting nucleosome sensitivity for a given transcription factor binding site within the mouse Ly49 gene family, and confirmed this prediction using chromatin immunoprecipitation sequencing (ChIP-Seq) in a mouse NK cell line. We found that the AML-1a transcription factor is particularly sensitive to nucleosome positioning, and this sensitivity is predictive of its binding to specific promoter sequences. Our work suggests that nucleosome positioning may play a role in regulating the expression of Ly49 genes in vivo.
In a recent study, we investigated the role of cyclin H-CDK7 complex in CDK4 and CDK6 activation in human colon carcinoma HCT116 cells . Previous studies had demonstrated that CDK4 and CDK6 are activated by CAK/CDK7, but our study revealed that CDK4 and CDK6 can also be activated by other CAKs . We used a K7AS mutant of CDK7 that is specifically inhibited by bulky adenine analogs to demonstrate that CDK4 and CDK6 are activated in a CDK7-independent manner . This finding is supported by the observation that T172 phosphorylation of CDK4 is differentially regulated in cyclin D1 or cyclin D3 complexes, which is not compatible with the requirement of CAK/CDK7 for CDK4 phosphorylation. We also demonstrated that CDK4 and CDK6 are activated by one or several proline-directed kinases ( s ) that are different from CAK/CDK7. This is supported by the observation that CDK4 phosphorylation can be differentially regulated in cyclin D1 or cyclin D3 complexes. Finally, we demonstrated that CDK4 phosphorylation can be abrogated by mutation of the P173 site in CDK4, whereas the T172 site remains unchanged, indicating that CDK4 can be phosphorylated in a CAK-independent manner. In summary, our study has uncovered a complex network of interactions and pathways that regulate CDK4 and CDK6 activation in human colon carcinoma cells. This new knowledge could provide important insights into the mechanisms underlying the defective regulation of cell cycle checkpoints in many tumors.
In this study, the authors report the identification and characterization of DUET, a plant-specific transcription factor that is essential for meiosis in Arabidopsis. They found that DUET interacts with chromatin via its PHD finger, and that its PHD finger binds H3K4me2 in vitro. They also found that duet plants exhibit defects in chromosome condensation and segregation, and abnormal microtubule organization during meiosis II. The authors identified TDM1 and JAS as targets of DUET, and found that both genes are meiosis-specifically expressed and are required for cell cycle transitions during meiosis I and II, respectively. They also found that duet expresses only during diplotene stage of prophase I, suggesting a possible role for DUET in regulating male meiotic gene expression.
The Fragile X syndrome is a genetic disorder that affects the nervous system and causes intellectual disability, autism, and seizures. The disease is caused by the expansion of a repeat sequence of the fragile X mental retardation protein (FMRP) gene, which leads to the decrease of FMRP protein in the brain. Researchers have found that the fragile X protein repeat (rCGG) sequence can cause toxicity in fruit flies by interacting with other proteins in the cell. In this study, the authors used fly models and mass spectrometry to identify proteins that interact with the fragile X protein repeat. They found that the repeat sequence can bind to several proteins, including the helicase protein Rm62. The authors also showed that the fragile X protein repeat can affect the expression of other genes in the cell, leading to the accumulation of mRNA in the nucleus. These findings suggest that the fragile X protein repeat can cause toxicity in the brain by affecting the expression of other genes and interacting with other proteins.
In this study, the authors examined the biofilm matrix of the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa using a combination of confocal laser scanning microscopy and fluorescence-labeled lectins. They found that the matrix is composed of multiple exopolysaccharides, including polysaccharide A (Psl), which is the focus of the study. The authors observed that Psl is anchored to the bacterial cell surface through a helical structure and that it encases the bacteria in the biofilm in a fibrous matrix. They also showed that the matrix undergoes changes during the maturation of the biofilm, such as the degradation of Psl in the center of the microcolony. These findings provide insight into the structure and function of the biofilm matrix in P. aeruginosa and may have implications for the development of new antimicrobial therapies.
This study examined the concordance of somatic mutations and structural variations between primary pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) and its matched patient-derived xenograft (PDX) and organoid (PDO) disease models. While PDXs and PDACs shared most of their single nucleotide variants, only a subset of structural variations and copy number changes were concordant between PDAC and PDX. In contrast, PDOs displayed a similar mutational profile as PDAC but had a higher rate of somatic mutations, which could be explained by the in vitro selection of PDAC organoids. This study highlights the challenges associated with recapitulating the mutational profile of PDAC in patient-derived disease models and suggests that a combination of PDX and PDO models may be necessary to better understand PDAC.
The study provides strong evidence for a novel breast cancer susceptibility locus represented by rs9485372, near the TAB2 gene. Two other possible breast cancer susceptibility loci were also identified on chromosomes 11q24.3 and 12q14.1. The findings are based on a large-scale genome-wide association study that included over 19,000 breast cancer cases and 20,606 controls from East Asian countries. The study has important implications for understanding the genetic basis of breast cancer, identifying high-risk individuals, and developing targeted prevention and treatment strategies.
This study provides an overview of cryptococcal meningitis, a serious and often fatal disease caused by the fungus Cryptococcus neoformans. The authors discuss the importance of understanding genetic diversity and virulence factors associated with the disease in order to develop new treatments and improve patient outcomes. They describe a cohort of 230 HIV-infected patients with cryptococcal meningitis from South Africa, and analyze their clinical presentation and outcomes, as well as their genetic diversity and virulence phenotypes. The authors find that the genetic diversity of the fungus is high in South Africa, and that certain lineages are associated with different virulence traits. They also find that certain lineages are associated with different clinical outcomes, including survival rates. The authors conclude that a better understanding of the genetic diversity and virulence factors of cryptococcal meningitis is important for developing new treatments and improving patient outcomes.
A novel signal transduction pathway that regulates filamentous growth in the yeast Candida albicans was discovered using a novel experimental strategy that compares gene expression patterns in different genetic backgrounds. The pathway is composed of three different genetic modules, each of which may have evolved from a different ancestral pathway. The discovery of this novel pathway may provide insights into the evolution of yeast signal transduction pathways.
The genomic GC-content of bacteria varies dramatically, from less than 20% to more than 70%. Researchers have tried to explain this variation by suggesting that it is due to differences in the pattern of mutation between bacteria. Here, the authors used datasets from 149 bacterial species to examine patterns of synonymous polymorphism and found that there is a large excess of synonymous GC→AT mutations over AT→GC mutations. They showed that this excess is inconsistent with mutation bias, since it would imply that most GC-rich bacteria are declining in GC-content, which is unsustainable. They also showed that the patterns are probably not due to translational selection or biased gene conversion because optimal codons tend to be AT-rich, and the excess of GC→AT SNPs is observed in datasets with no evidence of recombination. The authors therefore conclude that there is selection to increase synonymous GC-content in many species. Since synonymous GC-content is highly correlated with genomic GC-content, they further conclude that there is selection on genomic base composition in many bacteria.
The study aimed to develop a Bayesian geostatistical model to predict the observed prevalence of soil-transmitted helminths (STH) infection across Kenya, using data from over 1000 cross-sectional surveys conducted between 1974 and 2009. The model was used to estimate the spatial distribution of the combined observed prevalence of STH infection and the probability that this prevalence exceeded the World Health Organization (WHO) intervention threshold of 20%. The study found that endemicity was high around the shores of Lake Victoria and on the coast, with most districts requiring treatment. The model was also used to estimate the school-aged population at risk of infection and requiring MDA, which was projected to be 2.8 million children. The study highlights the importance of accurate geographical information in STH control programmes and the need for regular monitoring to ensure that interventions are targeted at the areas of highest need.
The immune response to Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) involves innate and adaptive immune cells, which work together to control the infection. This study investigates the role of innate lymphocytes in immunity to Mtb. The authors establish an in vitro system using splenocytes and infected macrophages to study the effects of innate lymphocytes on the growth of Mtb. They find that splenocytes inhibit the growth of Mtb, and that this effect is dependent on CD1d-restricted invariant NKT (iNKT) cells. The authors also adoptively transfer iNKT cells into mice infected with Mtb and find that these cells protect the mice against the infection. The study provides important insights into the role of innate lymphocytes in immunity to Mtb.
In the spore of the bacterium Bacillus subtilis, a transglutaminase named Tgl is responsible for cross-linking coat proteins to fortify the coat. Tgl is produced in an active form, and efficiently catalyzes amine incorporation and protein cross-linking in vitro. The absence of regulatory factors raises questions about how the activity of Tgl is controlled during spore coat assembly. Here, we show that the localization of Tgl is regulated by the prior assembly of its substrates. The Q side of Tgl makes a more important contribution to assembly of the enzyme than the K side. The enzyme becomes part of the cross-linked products. We suggest that Tgl exerts a “spotwelding” activity to covalently fortify pre-assembled complexes at the surface of the developing spore.
Opisthorchis viverrini is a type of parasite that can cause liver disease in people who eat raw or undercooked fish. A survey was done in Champasack province, Laos, to see how many people are infected and what factors might be related to this. Surveys and questionnaires were done in 51 villages, and people's stool samples were checked for the presence of parasites. Environmental factors, such as the type of vegetation, temperature, rainfall, and proximity to water bodies, were also considered. The results showed that 61.1% of people in the survey were infected with O. viverrini, and that several factors were associated with infection, including age, ethnicity, education level, occupation, access to clean water, and history of praziquantel treatment. Environmental factors, such as temperature, rainfall, and proximity to water bodies, were also found to be related to infection. The study found that the highest rates of infection were in the Mekong Valley, where there are many fish farms and people often eat raw or undercooked fish. The study also identified several risk factors for infection, including age, ethnicity, education level, occupation, access to clean water, and history of praziquantel treatment. Environmental factors, such as temperature, rainfall, and proximity to water bodies, were also related to infection. Overall, the study provides valuable information that can be used to develop targeted interventions to control the spread of O. viverrini in Laos.
This article describes a study conducted in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania, to understand the types of aquatic habitats in the city that are important breeding sites for disease vectors. The study found that drains were the most common type of habitat that contained Anopheles and Culex larvae, and that the presence of larvae was associated with several factors, including the presence of human-made connections that blocked water flow, the presence of waste materials, the presence of vegetation, and the location of the drain in a residential area. These findings highlight the importance of drains as breeding sites for disease vectors and suggest that efforts to control disease transmission in Dar es Salaam should focus on managing drains.
The cellular host of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been extensively studied, especially its ability to replicate in human cells, such as neural stem cells and microglia. ZIKV has also been found to replicate in various mouse models, including embryos, newborns, and adult mice. One of the most widely used mouse models for ZIKV research is the A129 mouse strain, which lacks type I interferon receptors. These mice are highly susceptible to ZIKV infection, and can be used to study the pathogenesis of ZIKV in the brain and other tissues. Several mouse models have been developed to mimic the human response to ZIKV infection, including knockout mice for various cytokines and chemokines. These models have helped researchers to understand the immune response to ZIKV infection in mice and humans.
We used an all-atom molecular dynamics simulation of the 70S ribosome to create a quantitative bridge between kinetic measurements and the energy landscape of ribosomal translocation. We identified sets of residues that undergo rotary rearrangements implicated in ribosome function, and estimated the diffusion coefficients along these coordinates. These measures were used to interconvert between experimental rates and measures of the energy landscape, providing an upper-bound estimate of the free-energy barriers associated with translocation. Our analysis is general and may be applied to energetic and kinetic descriptions that include any number of intermediates and transition states.
In this study, the authors sequenced the genomes of 84 sporadic medullary thyroid cancer (MTC) patients and identified 101 hotspot mutations in 18 genes. They also discovered anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) rearrangements in two patients by immunohistochemistry and break-apart fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH). To identify the genomic breakpoint and 5’ fusion partner of ALK, customized targeted cancer panel sequencing was performed using DNA from tumor samples of the two patients. The authors found that two patients had the glutamine:fructose-6-phosphate transaminase 1 (GFPT1)-ALK fusion and the echinoderm microtubule-associated protein-like 4 (EML4)-ALK fusion. The GFPT1-ALK fusion was a result of an intra-chromosomal translocation or deletion, whereas the EML4-ALK fusion was a result of a translocation between chromosomes 5 and 22. The authors also noted that a metastatic MTC case harboring the EML4-ALK fusion showed a dramatic response to an ALK inhibitor, crizotinib. They suggested that the EML4-ALK fusion in MTC may be a potential driver mutation and a valid target of ALK inhibitors. The authors also noted that the GFPT1-ALK fusion may be a potential candidate for molecular target therapy.
The paper describes a study that was conducted to determine the role of asymptomatic carriers in the transmission of visceral leishmaniasis (VL) in the district of Malda, West Bengal. The study used rapid diagnostic tests to identify asymptomatic carriers, who were then followed for three years to observe the pattern of sero-conversion and disease transformation. Out of 2603 people screened, 79 were classified as asymptomatic leishmaniasis cases and 10 as active VL cases. Seven (9.09%) of the asymptomatic cases remained sero-positive even after three years, and progression to clinical disease among asymptomatic individuals was taking place at any time up to three years after the baseline survey. The study suggests that asymptomatic leishmaniasis cases need to be given more attention in order to successfully eliminate VL.
We used the MLPA (Multiplex Ligation-dependent Probe Amplification) technique to analyze Ty1-mediated GCRs in Saccharomyces cerevisiae. MLPA is a PCR-based method that allows for the rapid and simultaneous analysis of multiple genomic regions. We found that Ty1-mediated translocations were predominantly mediated by a small number of translocation targets. We also observed a number of nonreciprocal translocations that were mediated by RAD52-independent recombination. Finally, we found that defects in acetylation of histone H3 lysine residue 56 resulted in increased accumulation of both GCRs and whole-chromosome duplications. Overall, we found that MLPA is a versatile technique that can facilitate the genetic analysis of the pathways that prevent and promote GCRs and aneuploidy.
Protein-protein docking is the process of predicting the structure of a complex between two proteins. The problem is formulated as finding the lowest energy conformation of a rigid body structure where the two proteins are in contact. The free energy of a structure is estimated by a sum of various terms, including a desolvation term, an electrostatic term, and a van der Waals term. The search for the lowest energy conformation is carried out using a combination of rigid body docking and flexible local minimization. The rigid body docking is carried out using the FFT correlation approach, which samples billions of docked conformations. The conformations are clustered using pairwise RMSD as the distance metric. The best clusters are selected based on their size and are retained for flexible local minimization. The flexible local minimization is carried out using the Charmm potential, which allows for side-chain flexibility. The search for the lowest energy conformation is carried out using an iterative process where the current conformation is used as the starting point for the next iteration. The search process is terminated when a hit with a ligand binding site RMSD of less than 5 Å is found.
